And, if guests have vouchers for a free meal or drink, they're getting coffee included in their room fee.</p> \n<p>If Freehand Hotel guests love the drinks from Cafe Integral, they can visit the standalone in Lower Manhattan, New York, earning the location more loyal customers.</p> \n<h3>2. Snarls + The Sonder Bombs Split</h3> \n<p>A split is a common music industry term to describe two acts coming together on the same release. Audiences can enjoy original and cover versions of each artist's music. They're a great way to discover new music and give musicians new ways to promote their work.</p> \n<p>This split is from label-mates <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/thesonderbombs/\">The Sonder Bombs</a> and <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/snarlsband/\">Snarls</a>, and it offers two original songs from each band and two covers of the other's most popular tunes:</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/reach%20and%20delight%20(the%20right)%20customers%20with%20cooperative%20marketing-2.png\" alt=\"The product page for the Snarls and Sonder Bombs split.\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><span style=\"font-family: 'times new roman', times;\"><a href=\"http://www.takethistoheartrecords.com/products/671516-snarls-the-sonder-bombs-a-really-cool-split\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<p>For one price, audiences get two bands and a chance to hear them play new, exclusive versions of old favorites. They can also hear professional covers from another band that might become their new favorite.</p> \n<h3>3. Vegancuts Snack Box</h3> \n<p>Subscription boxes are another example of cooperative marketing in action. Instead of buying individual products at once, consumers are able to pay one price for a bundle. This allows for the marketing messaging to focus on the value of product discovery.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/reach%20and%20delight%20(the%20right)%20customers%20with%20cooperative%20marketing-1.png\" alt=\"Example of a snackbox from Vegancuts.\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><span style=\"font-family: 'times new roman', times;\"><a href=\"http://vegancuts.com/snackbox\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<p>The <a href=\"https://vegancuts.com/snackbox/\">Vegancuts Snack Box</a>, for example, lets you try snacks from multiple different brands. Usually, there's a variety, like cookies, chips, and candy. While not necessarily a marketing campaign, subscription box companies like this one can capitalize using their <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/business-plan-template?_ga=2.267055182.1179602377.1596518655-940436819.1565181751\">business model </a>as a cooperative marketing tactic.</p> \n<h3>4. Streaming Service Bundle</h3> \n<p>Disney+, a popular streaming service, offers a bundle for customers. For a few dollars more than the standalone subscription price, customers can have access to <a href=\"https://www.hulu.com/\">Hulu</a> and <a href=\"https://www.espn.com/\">ESPN</a>. That way, customers can have movies, sports, and shows for one price.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/reach%20and%20delight%20(the%20right)%20customers%20with%20cooperative%20marketing.png\" alt=\"Disney+ bundled services offer.\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><span style=\"font-family: 'times new roman', times;\"><a href=\"https://vegancuts.com/offer/build-up-your-pantry-box/?gclid=EAIaIQobChMIger446Hw6gIV64taBR3A5wuIEAYYASABEgJxcvD_BwE\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<p>Disney's marketers bundling the services invites fans from diverse ages and interests to sign up for the service. Disney is family-friendly, Hulu has original shows and movies, and ESPN is all about sports. Each company can enjoy new subscribers and cross-promotional content from Disney as a result.</p> \n<h3>5. Sony + Naughty Dog Games</h3> \n<p>It's not uncommon for new video game consoles to come with a copy of a popular game so players can learn the controls. For <a href=\"https://www.sony.com/\">Sony's</a> PlayStation 4 release, the pack-in game was Naughty Dog's <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncharted_4:_A_Thief%27s_End\">Uncharted 4</a>. This was a great cooperative marketing opportunity between a video game console and a game development company.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/reach%20and%20delight%20(the%20right)%20customers%20with%20cooperative%20marketing-4.png\" alt=\"The PS4 bundle with Uncharted 4.\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><span style=\"font-family: 'times new roman', times;\"><a href=\"https://www.walmart.com/ip/Sony-PlayStation-4-Slim-500GB-Uncharted-4-Bundle-Black-3001504/52901918?wmlspartner=wlpa&amp;selectedSellerId=3651&amp;&amp;adid=22222222227048046159&amp;wl0=&amp;wl1=g&amp;wl2=c&amp;wl3=146648785093&amp;wl4=pla-258790301890&amp;wl5=9002005&amp;wl6=&amp;wl7=&amp;wl8=&amp;wl9=pla&amp;wl10=114431238&amp;wl11=online&amp;wl12=52901918&amp;veh=sem&amp;gclid=EAIaIQobChMIzNnNuqPz6gIVga_ICh3XuQDgEAQYAiABEgKXpvD_BwE\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<p>Uncharted 4 coming with every new PS4 being sold meant that Naughty Dog's game was being exposed to <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/erikkain/2019/01/11/putting-the-playstation-4s-91-6-million-sales-into-context/#7e66b92a6c50\">millions of players</a>. That's an incredible reach, one that the game company would probably struggle to do on their own.</p> \n<p>Fans got to experience a new game to play with their new console, Sony got to sweeten the console offering, and Naughty Dog earned more leads, making this partnership a home run.</p> \n<h3>6. HubSpot Webinar</h3> \n<p>As part of <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/adapt2020\"><u>Adapt 2020</u></a>, an educational webinar series, \"<a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/advertising-in-a-time-of-crisis?hubs_signup-url=offers.hubspot.com%2Fadapt2020&amp;hubs_signup-cta=null\"><u>Advertising in a Time of Crisis</u></a>\" is a conversation between one of HubSpot's general project managers, <a href=\"http://google.ca\"><u>Google Canada</u></a>'s head of marketing, a <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/insights\"><u>Facebook IQ</u></a> lead marketer, and the Director of Paid Media at <a href=\"https://www.wundermanthompson.com/\"><u>Wunderman Thompson</u></a>.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-08-04%20at%2012.15.30%20AM.png?width=566&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-08-04%20at%2012.15.30%20AM.png\" alt=\"The stream for Adapt 2020's advertising discussion.\" width=\"566\" style=\"width: 566px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">These minds came together to discuss how companies should be advertising, how to shift the messaging of targeted ad campaigns, and how to measure the success of those campaigns. This webinar is completely free, and gives B2B audiences excellent insights about timely subjects from industry thought leaders.</p> \n<p>This offering gives all companies involved a more broad reach. A collaboration, like this webinar, is a great idea when thinking about ways to cooperatively market on a budget.</p> \n<p>Are you thinking of adding cooperative marketing products or strategies to your next rollout? When thinking of the right route to take, don't forget to factor in your<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/smart-goal-examples?_ga=2.98082655.1179602377.1596518655-940436819.1565181751\"> business goals</a> and audience.</p> \n<p>From there, you can make a decision based on the benefit of all parties — partnerships included. If you're part of a small business that doesn't have many resources to spare, a cooperative strategy could be an incredible way to expand your network and share resources to generate more business.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcooperative-marketing&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 04 Aug 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":924,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/reach%20and%20delight%20(the%20right)%20customers%20with%20cooperative%20marketing-3.png","linkMd5":"2070b1e878ba0d50a19a829bfb6b5729","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx17/cdn92@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-27-609_e3074d11037f4437.webp","author":"Kayla Carmicheal","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/reach%20and%20delight%20(the%20right)%20customers%20with%20cooperative%20marketing-3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn56@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-33-861_e3074d11037f4437.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/reach%20and%20delight%20(the%20right)%20customers%20with%20cooperative%20marketing-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn3@2020_2/2020/08/16/13-48-35-288_456f687a526428fa.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/reach%20and%20delight%20(the%20right)%20customers%20with%20cooperative%20marketing-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx17/cdn100@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-38-583_3c6564b1e1e07737.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/reach%20and%20delight%20(the%20right)%20customers%20with%20cooperative%20marketing.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn91@2020_3/2020/08/16/13-48-37-065_f404d2d097a880ea.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/reach%20and%20delight%20(the%20right)%20customers%20with%20cooperative%20marketing-4.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn64@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-36-631_5d064cd1ceeddec5.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-08-04%20at%2012.15.30%20AM.png?width=566&name=Screen%20Shot%202020-08-04%20at%2012.15.30%20AM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn84@2020_3/2020/08/16/13-48-28-830_8d93947df1c4c589.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcooperative-marketing&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn64@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-33-222_55b8b38544262eb5.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:25","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:25","title":"Why A Digital PR Specialist Should Always Be Involved in Content Creation","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/digital-pr-specialist-content-creation","description":"<p>If you've been on the creative side of content marketing, you know not every idea is a winner. Sometimes projects gather a few links and then vanish under a pile of other content.</p> \n<p>To compete, you have to ensure the content you're creating, from the idea to the actual execution, is <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/customers/how-to-generate-effective-content-ideas\">compelling</a> enough to earn the coverage and attention you hope it'll achieve.</p> \n<p>And there's one really excellent way to do this: involve a digital PR specialist from the get-go.</p> \n<p>I work in digital PR and have consulted on hundreds of content projects.</p> \n<p>Below, let's review what I've learned about how content creators and digital PR professionals can successfully work together to create engaging, newsworthy content.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3>1. Recognize viral ideas.</h3> \n<p>Digital PR specialists are responsible for interacting and building relationships with the media, so they likely spend around 70% of their workday online.</p> \n<p>Typically, they're reading new studies, picking apart articles, and getting to know writers. It's only natural that after experiencing the nuances of the news cycle, PR specialists are able to recognize which ideas make it big.</p> \n<p>If that kind of market research already exists in the brains of the outreach specialists on your team, why not utilize it?</p> \n<p>Getting feedback from the birth of a project means the trajectory of the content will be aimed for top-tier coverage. From the idea stage, it may make sense to create a ranking system with your team.</p> \n<p>Outreach specialists can categorize each idea by newsworthiness, relevance, and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-promotion-ideas\">promotional viability</a> to get a better understanding of where your projects stand.</p> \n<p>From there, you can go back to the drawing board or work with your best concepts.</p> \n<p>Using your PR pros will help expand creative ideas from using only what the creative team thinks is interesting to using what publishers think is interesting. Who knows? A single tip from an outreach specialist could turn a mediocre campaign into a huge win for a client.</p> \n<p>For example, at <a href=\"https://www.frac.tl/\">Fractl</a>, one of our biggest recent wins in the career vertical involved pivoting an idea about millennial work/life balance to a survey packed with \"would you rather\" questions.</p> \n<p>This new formatting allowed the creative strategist to ask more hard-hitting questions and challenged millennials to give concrete information about how much they'd be willing to sacrifice in their personal lives in order to get ahead in business. Some of the notable takeaways included:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>More than two in five millennials are willing to end a relationship if it meant getting a promotion at work.</li> \n <li>One in three would dump their S.O. for a raise.</li> \n <li>Millennials put their career before marriage: most are willing to postpone marriage for another seven years if it means they'd land a promotion.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>2. Keep data human.</h3> \n<p>In a recent study from <a href=\"https://www.buzzstream.com/blog/creating-the-most-authoritative-content.html\">BuzzStream and Fractl</a>, consumers ranked data analysis and index as the most authoritative form of online content.</p> \n<p>Those who work in content production are exceptional at analyzing these numbers to reveal their hidden insights. However, it can be easy to get lost in the data while exploring every perspective and lose sight of the most compelling pieces.</p> \n<p>Outreach specialists can help bridge the gap between data and human interest. If there isn't a cohesive narrative weaved throughout your data, a digital PR specialist can pull from their experience in studying what kind of stories emotionally resonate, and can help identify the true story in the data.</p> \n<p>While analyzing data, touch base with your outreach team to develop a storyline. Be sure they identify the simplest ways to digest the information you're trying to get across. If it takes longer than 60 seconds to understand the information in a graph, you're going to lose your audience.</p> \n<p>Oftentimes, content creators become attached to their data and believe every aspect is essential to the piece. While this may be true in some cases, oftentimes slimming down excess information can be beneficial to the narrative as a whole.</p> \n<p>Don't be afraid of feedback, and remember that outreach specialists spend <em>a lot</em> of time dissecting stories online. They're likely a trustworthy editor for your work.</p> \n<p>For example, when presenting repetitive information, it's important to provide interesting visuals to accompany data. When creating infographics about dangerous tools for a home improvement client, our team at Fractl decided to spice up statistics that would otherwise be mundane by placing the information within a tool shed.</p> \n<p>This project ended up being a winner within the home and garden vertical and I owe the promotional viability to the engaging way the information was presented.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/%5BGuest%20Post%20for%20Hubspot%5D%20Why%20A%20Digital%20PR%20Specialist%20Should%20Always%20Be%20Involved%20in%20Content%20Creation.png?width=600&amp;name=%5BGuest%20Post%20for%20Hubspot%5D%20Why%20A%20Digital%20PR%20Specialist%20Should%20Always%20Be%20Involved%20in%20Content%20Creation.png\" alt=\"Infographic helps humanize data.\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>If your data tells a story your audience wants to hear, graphs and images become as essential as the words on the page. Using industry knowledge from your outreach specialist's tool belt, you can elevate data-driven content to make it worthy of top-tier press.</p> \n<h3>3. Extract the juiciest takeaways.</h3> \n<p>You have a great idea, you research it, pull all the data, and it falls flat. Sometimes the stories you thought would be told through data don't come to fruition. But this doesn't mean your project is DOA, your outreach specialist may be able to revive it.</p> \n<p>Having an eye on the media means that outreach specialists may be able to extract something from a project that would have otherwise been overlooked. Digital PR pros can draw up some ideal headlines or takeaways to increase the project's chances of appealing to particular publishers and audiences.</p> \n<p>Whether it means tying the data to a trending story or pitching a vertical not initially intended to be a match for your content, there's usually always a way to distill data into a highly promotable headline.</p> \n<p>Chris Lewis, account manager and creative strategist at Fractl, said he incorporates feedback from media specialists into his projects.</p> \n<p>\"Outreach specialists are my secret weapon in creating compelling data-driven story content,\" he said. \"More than anything, they help me get out of my own way by always finding the promotable and most interesting parts of content and finding ways to highlight them.\"</p> \n<h3>4. Create better content.</h3> \n<p>Incorporating feedback from several team members throughout the life of a project can mean improved results from your content marketing efforts.</p> \n<p>Consider hosting collaborative meetings every once in a while or implementing edits from your outreach specialists if an idea falls dry.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, using a digital PR specialist in your content creation will help you create promotable content because of the work with the media and interaction online.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fdigital-pr-specialist-content-creation&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 11 Aug 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":924,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/digital-pr-specialist.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"7254e177cdc584fa16ca62f114c4c6b5","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn11@2020_3/2020/08/16/13-48-27-485_f795c443636f3a02.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/digital-pr-specialist.jpg#keepProtocol","destWidth":598,"destHeight":398,"author":"Delaney Kline","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/%5BGuest%20Post%20for%20Hubspot%5D%20Why%20A%20Digital%20PR%20Specialist%20Should%20Always%20Be%20Involved%20in%20Content%20Creation.png?width=600&name=%5BGuest%20Post%20for%20Hubspot%5D%20Why%20A%20Digital%20PR%20Specialist%20Should%20Always%20Be%20Involved%20in%20Content%20Creation.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn12@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-39-665_ba3466db66c4767b.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fdigital-pr-specialist-content-creation&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn60@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-32-267_cc7c73145b6ec61a.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:25","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:25","title":"7 Helpful Resources for Creating Beautiful Infographics","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/resources-for-creating-infographics","description":"<p>Visuals have a huge impact in marketing. Not only do they make content more sharable -- <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/infographics-for-seo-strategy#sm.0000e1w1nuwvbeo5sq61j1tim2kyj\">40 times as much</a> -- but they help us retain information. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/infographics-for-seo-strategy?&amp;_ga=1.166843966.1053898511.1470656920#sm.0000e1w1nuwvbeo5sq61j1tim2kyj\">When details are paired with an image, we remember 55% more of it</a>.</p> \n<p>That can be pulled off with infographics -- the nifty images that visually break down complex statistics. They're customizable, sharable, and they're easier to create than you might think.</p> \n<p>Sure, you could hire a professional to create the infographics for you. But if you're restricted by budgets or time, there are some great DIY resources out there for making compelling visuals.</p> \n<p>To help visual marketers, we scouted the web for some of best sites and tools for building infographics. Check them out below.&nbsp;</p> \n<h2>Helpful Resources for Creating Infographics</h2> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://www.canva.com\">Canva</a></h3> \n<p><strong>Cost: </strong>Free with limited features, $9.95/month for Pro, or $30/month for Enterprise.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Canva-16.png?width=600&amp;name=Canva-16.png\" width=\"600\" title=\"Canva-16.png\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"creating infographics in Canva\"></p> \n<p>Oh, how we love the ease and intuitiveness of Canva.</p> \n<p>From the very beginning, it asks you a series of simple, colorfully-illustrated questions about what’s brought you to their site. (Today, it’s infographics, but there’s a ton of other stuff you can create there, too.)</p> \n<p>Once you’ve let Canva know what you want to do, the site generates several templates you can use as a foundation for your infographic. Plus, it’s got a library of roughly 1,000,000 images that you can add to your project.</p> \n<p>From there, you can edit the text, background image, shapes and other aspects of the infographic to make it your own. And it’s so easy -- here’s a goofy one that I put together on how my dog spends his day:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Tullamores_Day_Infographic_2.png?width=669&amp;name=Tullamores_Day_Infographic_2.png\" alt=\"Tullamores_Day_Infographic_2.png\" width=\"669\" title=\"Tullamores_Day_Infographic_2.png\" style=\"width: 669px;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em><a href=\"https://www.canva.com/design/DACA4CZE14s/cbwuFIIiTFB1Zdcq_doPPw/view?utm_content=DACA4CZE14s&amp;utm_campaign=designshare&amp;utm_medium=link&amp;utm_source=sharebutton\">Image Source</a></em> </span></p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://piktochart.com/\">Piktochart</a></h3> \n<p><strong>Cost: </strong>Free, with paid packages available starting at $24/month</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Piktochart2.png?width=669&amp;name=Piktochart2.png\" alt=\"Piktochart2.png\" width=\"669\" title=\"Piktochart2.png\" style=\"width: 669px;\"></p> \n<p>Similar to Canva, Piktochart can be used to design more than just infographics -- it can also build reports, presentations, and posters.</p> \n<p>But the templates available for infographics are numerous, and there’s an upgrade available. “Pro” memberships -- which run between $24 to $80, depending on the features you want -- allow access to even more templates, as well as removed watermarks and hi-res downloads.</p> \n<p>When it comes to creating the infographic itself, the features are fairly similar to Canva’s -- the background, text, and images can all be changed, or users can upload their own files for greater personalization.</p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://venngage.com/\">Venngage</a></h3> \n<p><strong>Cost: </strong>Free, with paid packages available starting at $19/month</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Vanngage.png?noresize&amp;width=600&amp;name=Vanngage.png\" alt=\"Venngage infographic software steps\" width=\"600\" title=\"Venngage.png\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Like its predecessors above, Venngage has quite a few design features, including&nbsp;<span>an </span><a href=\"https://venngage.com\"><span>infographic maker</span></a><span> and&nbsp;</span>its great social media templates, which users can download to create their own personalized Instagram posts, blog headers, and more.</p> \n<p>For infographics, there's a decent range of templates, each categorized by type -- statistical, process, and timeline, to name a few.</p> \n<p>Some of the templates are limited to premium members, reflecting Venngage's four-tiered approach to pricing -- free, premium, education, and non-profit. Plus, there are templates available for those latter two categories. Here's one that helps non-profits visually communicate highlights from an annual report:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/thumbnails.venngage.com/template/bbc41da5-9284-44d3-a915-bec91ff75f26.png?noresize\" alt=\"Venngage Infographic\" width=\"669\" title=\"Venngage Infographic\" style=\"width: 669px;\"></p> \n<h3>4. <a href=\"https://www.easel.ly\">Easel.ly</a></h3> \n<p><strong>Cost: </strong>Starts at $4/month with special discounts for students and educators.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/easelly.png?noresize&amp;width=600&amp;name=easelly.png\" alt=\"easelly infographic templates\" width=\"600\" title=\"easelly.png\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Upon visiting Easel.ly's website, you're immediately presented with a plethora of infographic templates, most of which can be immediately clicked and customized without having to create an account. If you want to save and share your work, though, you will have to join -- for free.</p> \n<p>Unlike its predecessors listed here, Easel.ly seems to be a no-frills platform that's comprised of infographics. You can choose which category you'd like, but it's not quite as organized as some other sites -- the drop-down menu is a bit hidden to the left of the templates. Still, most of templates appear to be available for free (more become available with a Pro membership), and they're fairly easy to edit.</p> \n<h3>5. <a href=\"http://www.freepik.com\">Freepik</a></h3> \n<p><strong>Cost: </strong>Free, with paid packages available starting at $7.50/month</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/freepik.png?noresize&amp;width=669&amp;name=freepik.png\" alt=\"freepik.png\" width=\"669\" title=\"freepik.png\" style=\"width: 669px;\"></p> \n<p>As its name suggests, Freepik is a resource for, well, free pictures. Infographics are just one type, but after performing a search for them, there are plenty of options -- most of which are complimentary.</p> \n<p>The only drawback? Freepik doesn't quite allow the same level&nbsp;of customization that some others in this list do. You can download the images for free, but you’ll need a vector graphics editor in order to customize them -- Brittany Leaning and Megan Conley of HubSpot's content marketing team both suggest using <a href=\"http://www.adobe.com/products/illustrator.html\">Adobe Illustrator</a>.</p> \n<h3>6. <a href=\"https://infogr.am\">Infogram</a></h3> \n<p><strong>Cost:</strong> A limited number of options available for free, with paid packages available starting at $19/month</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/infogram%20examples-1.png?width=600&amp;name=infogram%20examples-1.png\" alt=\"infogram examples\" width=\"600\" title=\"infogram examples-1.png\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Like many of its visual peers, Infogram is a resource that helps users create both picturesque charts and infographics. It's definitely one of the more \"grown-up\" sites available for building these images, which might explain why very few of their tools a re free -- including restricting your work from public consumption.</p> \n<p>However, Infogram also has the option of enlisting professional help with infographic design. So if you're short on time and have a bit of room in your budget, this route might be the best one for you.</p> \n<h3>7. <a href=\"https://developers.google.com/chart/\">Google Charts</a></h3> \n<p><strong>Cost: Free</strong></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google_charts.gif?noresize&amp;width=600&amp;name=Google_charts.gif\" alt=\"Google_charts gif example\" width=\"600\" title=\"Google_charts.gif\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Okay, maybe a chart isn’t exactly the same as an infographic. But, given the interesting selection templates made available by Google, we would be remiss to exclude it.</p> \n<p>There are a few items of value in Google charts. First, we love the selection of charts available. From animated bubble graphs -- like the one above -- to clever word trees, the features allow users to bring information to life. (I mean, admit it -- adding animation to data always makes it a little less boring.)</p> \n<p>Plus, these charts can be created to be interactive. One of our favorites, GeoCharts, allows data to be assigned to different regions of a map that appear when hovered over. Check it out:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google_Geo_Charts.gif?noresize&amp;width=600&amp;name=Google_Geo_Charts.gif\" alt=\"Google_Geo_Charts.gif\" width=\"600\" title=\"Google_Geo_Charts.gif\" style=\"width: 600px;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em><a href=\"https://developers.google.com/chart/interactive/docs/gallery/geochart\">Image Source</a></em> </span></p> \n<p>We'll admit that some features of Google Charts might be a bit more advanced than the other resources we’ve listed. But, if you’re ready to step up your visuals game, give it a try.</p> \n<h2>Start Creating Infographics</h2> \n<p>There's no shortage of resources when it comes to creating your own visuals -- charts, reports, and infographics. And, depending on your budget and needs, there's a veritable plethora of options available, all of which have their pros, with very few cons.</p> \n<p>Want to learn more about designing brilliant infographics? <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/create-infographics-with-free-powerpoint-templates\">Check out these helpful tips</a>.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fresources-for-creating-infographics&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 11 Aug 2020 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":924,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/resources-for-designing-infographics.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"fba938449a6562b793d104947f750ea1","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx20/cdn47@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-27-431_d048dc2dbaa8bb3d.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/resources-for-designing-infographics.jpg#keepProtocol","destWidth":598,"destHeight":398,"author":"Amanda Zantal-Wiener","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Canva-16.png?width=600&name=Canva-16.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn48@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-33-759_cfaa08a627856143.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Tullamores_Day_Infographic_2.png?width=669&name=Tullamores_Day_Infographic_2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn83@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-36-828_8516b0a93c76b0c1.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Piktochart2.png?width=669&name=Piktochart2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn71@2020_3/2020/08/16/13-48-29-645_99f03e97d8ab3710.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Vanngage.png?noresize&width=600&name=Vanngage.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn75@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-32-508_773ab0960b65f583.webp","https://s3.amazonaws.com/thumbnails.venngage.com/template/bbc41da5-9284-44d3-a915-bec91ff75f26.png?noresize":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn32@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-29-304_eb42a7670a367740.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/easelly.png?noresize&width=600&name=easelly.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn35@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-29-651_1b94ce1f79060b1d.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/freepik.png?noresize&width=669&name=freepik.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn47@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-34-867_7dfd1560c61ec582.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/infogram%20examples-1.png?width=600&name=infogram%20examples-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx20/cdn71@2020_3/2020/08/16/13-48-35-007_809907476669fb88.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google_charts.gif?noresize&width=600&name=Google_charts.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn52@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-38-455_01640727dad5e3fa.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google_Geo_Charts.gif?noresize&width=600&name=Google_Geo_Charts.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn23@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-31-300_1a165a7d66171e7f.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fresources-for-creating-infographics&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx20/cdn63@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-32-271_4f9c272a6eea9c51.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:25","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:25","title":"The 30-60-90 Day Plan: Your Guide for Mastering a New Job [Template + Example]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/30-60-90-day-plan","description":"<p>With all the joy and excitement of landing a new job, you can feel just as much fear and anxiety. The same can go for the hiring manager.</p>  \n<p>Overcoming a new role's learning curve and the desire to make a lasting impression on your employer can put a lot of pressure on you. What if you can't adapt in time?</p>  \n<p>Fortunately, there's a way to organize and prioritize your time and tasks, helping you seamlessly adapt to your new environment. It's called a 30-60-90 day plan. And following it enables you to soak in as much information as possible, master your core job responsibilities, and sets you up to make a lasting impact on your new team.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Think of a 30-60-90 day plan as a new employee's North Star, keeping your sights set in the right direction and guiding you toward success. But before we show you how to write this plan, let's go over what exactly it is and how it'll enhance your performance during your (or your employee's) first three months on the job.</p> \n<p>In this post, we'll cover everything you need to know about 30-60-90 day plans whether you're writing one for yourself or a new hire on the team.</p> \n<p>There are two situations where you'd write a 30-60-90 day plan: during the final stages of an interview process and during the first week of the job itself. Here's how each type can be executed:</p> \n<h3>30-60-90 Day Plan for Interview</h3> \n<p>Some hiring managers ask candidates to think about and explain their potential 30-60-90 day plan as a new hire. They want to see if they can organize their time, prioritize the tasks they'd likely take on, and strategize an approach to the job description.</p> \n<p>For a new hire, a well thought-out 30-60-90 day plan is a great way to help the hiring manager visualize you in the role and differentiate yourself from all other candidates.</p> \n<p>Of course, it can be difficult to outline your goals for yourself before you accept a new job. So, how are you supposed to know what those goals are? Start with the job description. Normally, open job listings have separate sections for a job's responsibilities and a job's qualifications. Work to find commonalities in these two sections, and how you might turn them into goals for yourself staggered over the course of three months.</p> \n<p>For example, if a job requires three years of experience in Google Analytics, and the responsibilities include tracking the company's website performance every month, use these points to develop an action plan explaining how you'll learn the company's key performance metrics (first 30 days), strengthen the company's performance in these metrics (next 30 days), and then lead the team toward a better Google Analytics strategy (last 30 days).</p> \n<h3>30-60-90 Day Plan for New Job</h3> \n<p>The second situation where you'd write a 30-60-90 day plan is during the first week of a new job. If you're the hiring manager, this plan will allow you to learn how the new employee operates, address any of their concerns or preconceived notions about the role, and ultimately help them succeed.</p> \n<p>If you're starting a new job, and are not asked to craft a 30-60-90 day plan during the first week of that job, it's still a good idea to write one for yourself. A new job can feel like a completely foreign environment during the first few months, and having a plan in place can make it feel more like home.</p> \n<p>Even though 90 days is the standard grace period for new employees to learn the ropes, it's also the best time to make a great first impression.</p> \n<p>The purpose of your plan is to help you transition into your new role, but it should also be a catalyst for your career development. Instead of just guiding you over your job's learning curve, the goals outlined in your plan should push you to perform up to your potential and raise your bar for success at its every stage.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2>30-60-90 Day Plan for Managers [Template]</h2> \n<p>Almost all 30-60-90 day plans consist of a learning phase, a contributing phase, and a leading phase — which we'll go over in the example plan below. This includes plans that are designed to guide people in new <em>management</em> roles. What sets apart a <em>manager's</em> plan from any other is their obligation to their direct reports and the decisions they're trusted to make for the business.</p> \n<p>If you're accepting (or hiring for) a new manager role, consider any of the following goals and how to roll them out at a pace that sets you up for success.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/30,%2060,%2090%20Day%20Plan%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=30,%2060,%2090%20Day%20Plan%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg\" alt=\"free editable 30 60 90 day plan template\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h3>Get to your know your team's strengths and weaknesses.</h3> \n<h4>Recommended phase: First 30 days</h4> \n<p>Everyone is learning the ropes in their first month at a company. For managers, much of that learning happens by talking to the team.</p> \n<p>If you're a new manager, grab some time with your direct reports and get to know their roles. What do they like about them? What are their biggest pain points?</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.projectmanager.com/blog/5-goals-of-effective-managers\">Making your team happy</a> is a hard goal to measure, but it's an important responsibility to take on as a manager. Your first step is to figure out how you'll manage and coach your employees through their day-to-day work.</p> \n<h3>Improve the cost-effectiveness of your team's budget.</h3> \n<h4>Recommended phase: Final 30 days</h4> \n<p>Managers often have access to (and control over) the budget for their department's investments — things like software, office supplies, and new hires. After you spend the first couple of months learning what the team spends its money on, consider using the final 30 days of your plan to make suggestions for new investments or how to reallocate money where you think it needs to be.</p> \n<p>Is there a tool that can automate a task that's taking your team forever to do manually? Draft a financial strategy that includes this tool in the following quarter's budget.</p> \n<h3>Help a direct report acquire a new skill.</h3> \n<h4>Recommended phase: Second 30 days</h4> \n<p>Even though you're new to the company, you were hired for a reason: You've got skills. And you can bring these skills to the people you work with, particularly those people who report to you.</p> \n<p>After meeting with and learning about your new colleagues, you might use the second month of your on-boarding plan to find skill gaps on your team that you can help fill.</p> \n<p>Do you have expert-level experience with HubSpot, and your new company just started using <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing?_ga=2.73575319.440552189.1554432490-1093622293.1516842654\">HubSpot Marketing Hub</a>? Teach them how to do something in the platform they didn't know before.</p> \n<h3>Draft a training strategy that can help guide your direct reports into new roles.</h3> \n<h4>Recommended phase: Final 30 days</h4> \n<p>You won't be expected to promote people in the first three months of your new job, but that doesn't mean you shouldn't have learned enough about your team to decide who's good at what and how to coach them to where they want to be.</p> \n<p>In the final 30 days of your 30-60-90 day plan, you might agree to a goal to develop a training strategy that outlines how to manage your direct reports, and ultimately how to guide them into new roles in the future.</p> \n<h2>30-60-90 Day Plan for Executives</h2> \n<p>Executives are a little different from managers in that there's higher performance expectations coming in. As an executive, you'll need to be highly engaged with the organization from the first day and implement high-impact changes in your role as soon as you can. At the same time, context is important, and you'll need to understand the culture, team, current operating processes, and challenges before you solve for them.</p> \n<p>Here are some critical steps to include in your 30-60-90 day plan in an executive role.</p> \n<h3>Soak up as much information as possible.</h3> \n<h4>Recommended phase: First 30 days</h4> \n<p>There's no point in taking action without context, so start your ramp-up period by gathering information and charting the lay of the land. That means reviewing existing documentation, attending as many meetings as you can, meeting with direct reports and skip levels, and ask a lot of questions.</p> \n<h3>Create alignment between you and the team.</h3> \n<h4>Recommended phase: First 30 days</h4> \n<p>In the first 30 days, you'll be meeting new people and understanding their roles in the organization. Ultimately, your job as an executive is to set the vision for the organization while removing roadblocks for your team as they strategize and execute on it.</p> \n<p>One of the best questions you can ask as you familiarize yourself and align with your team is, \"In your opinion, what are some existing threats to our business (external or internal)?\"</p> \n<p>This shows that you care about their opinion and trust their expertise while getting unique perspectives from multiple vantage points in the organization. Plus, if you start hearing some of the same points from multiple team members, you'll be able to identify the biggest pains, equipping you to make the highest impact changes.</p> \n<h3>Create goals based on what you've learned.</h3> \n<h4>Recommended phase: Second 30 days</h4> \n<p>When you are interviewing or shortly after you're hired, you'll get a feel for the types of pains that the executive team has and the objectives in mind for bringing you on.</p> \n<p>Once you have more context about how the organization works, you can take this vision and translate it into concrete, measurable goals that will take your department to the next level.</p> \n<h3>Identify the A players on the team.</h3> \n<h4>Recommended phase: First 30 days</h4> \n<p>An A player is a member of your team that goes above and beyond what's expected in their role. While not every employee will be an A player, you'll want to ensure that critical roles and teams have at least one A player to lead, inspire, and strengthen camaraderie.</p> \n<p>From there, you can figure out the existing gaps in staffing and training, whether it's team members who need a lot of guidance and must be coached up to performance or empty roles that need to be filled altogether.</p> \n<h3>Diagnose process issues.</h3> \n<h4>Recommended phase: Second 30 days</h4> \n<p>Companies of all sizes run into operational issues as they implement processes that are efficient and work at scale. Sometimes, when an executive team isn't aligned with middle management, processes can become unwieldy.</p> \n<p>Learn why things are done the way they are and then figure out if there are workarounds you can implement to streamline operations. Perhaps it's as simple as eliminating bottlenecks or adding automation to certain functions.</p> \n<h3>Put together and implement hiring plan.</h3> \n<h4>Recommended phase: Final 30 days</h4> \n<p>You know your A and B players, and you hopefully have a plan to retain, invest in, and mentor them. However, you'll likely come across gaps that you need to fill and positions that need to be created to eliminate bottlenecks. From there, you'll want to create a hiring plan to execute, both for short-term, middle-term, and long-term needs.</p> \n<h3>Effect changes in operations.</h3> \n<h4>Recommended phase: Final 30 days</h4> \n<p>Speaking of bottlenecks, your final 30 days of your plan should be focusing on the areas of the business that can achieve the results the fastest. Once you've identified these, you can focus on removing these roadblocks to start hitting goals and achieving higher performance.</p> \n<h3>Contribute to broader company goals.</h3> \n<h4>Recommended phase: Final 30 days</h4> \n<p>As a member of the executive team, you'll also be looped in one high-level company initiatives, and the other executives of the company will be relying on you to contribute your deep discipline expertise and experience.</p> \n<p>Be ready to lean in on executive meetings and contribute to the vision and strategy of the organization as it moves forward.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>How to Write a 30-60-90 Day Plan</h2> \n<p>No matter what the level of the job for which a company is hiring, improving an employee's skills requires concrete performance goals, so watch out for vagueness in the objectives you set for yourself.</p> \n<p>“Write a better blog post,” or “get better at brainstorming” are terrific ambitions, but they don't give you a way to measure your progress in them. Set goals that are realistic, quantifiable, and focused. You'll know exactly how to achieve them and gauge your success.</p> \n<p>To write challenging yet feasible performance goals, ask yourself the following questions:</p> \n<h3>What are my team's goals?</h3> \n<p>Try to understand the purpose behind your team's goals. It'll give you more insight into why you and your team should achieve them, motivating you to work as hard as possible to meet those goals.</p> \n<h3>What will be my main priorities?</h3> \n<p>By connecting your personal responsibilities to your team's goals, you'll know exactly how to align your tasks with the needs of the team, which keeps you accountable and compels you to help your team achieve their goals.</p> \n<h3>How will I measure my progress?</h3> \n<p>Tracking your progress helps you gauge your performance and rate of improvement. To see how you're doing, set up weekly meetings with your manager to ask her what she thinks of your work and track the improvement of your own performance metrics, like the growth of your blog posts' average views or the amount of qualified leads your eBooks generate.</p> \n<p>Reaching your performance goals isn't the only path toward future success in your new role, though. You also need to study the ins and outs of your team and company, take initiative, and develop relationships with coworkers — all things that a lot of new hires underestimate the importance of.</p> \n<p>Consider setting the following types of goals during each stage of your 30-60-90 day plan:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Learning Goals</strong> - How will you absorb as much information as possible about your company, team, and role?</li> \n <li><strong>Initiative Goals</strong> - What will you do to stand out?</li> \n <li><strong>Personal Goals</strong> - How will you integrate with your company and team?</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Aiming to achieve these types of goals will help you hit the ground running in all the right areas of your job. And if you stick to your plan, you'll notice you'll be able to spend less time learning and more time executing.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>30-60-90 Day Plan Template With Examples</h2> \n<p>Behold, your 30-60-90 day plan template. Click the image below to download your own copy.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/30,%2060,%2090%20Day%20Plan%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=30,%2060,%2090%20Day%20Plan%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg\" alt=\"free editable 30 60 90 Day Plan Template, Blog Image\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>So, how might you fill in the lines shown in the template above? Here's an example:</p> \n<h3>30 Days</h3> \n<h4>Primer</h4> \n<p>Many new hires are eager to impress, so they dive head-first into their work or try to make suggestions about their team's process with limited experience in how their new team operates. But have patience.</p> \n<p>Understanding your company's vision and your team's existing strategy is crucial for producing high-quality work and actually making an impact. If you don't know the purpose behind your role or the optimal way to perform, you'll risk missing the mark and your early efforts won't pay off the way you expect them to.</p> \n<p>It's always better to over-prepare than under-prepare. And it's okay to take time to learn the ropes — it pays huge dividends in the long run. In the first 30 days of your employment, your priority is to be a sponge and soak in as much information as possible. Once you do that, you can then try to improve more specific parts of your team's work style.</p> \n<h4>Theme: Be a Sponge</h4> \n<h5>Learning Goals</h5> \n<ul> \n <li>Study my company's mission, vision, and overarching strategy.</li> \n <li>Read my company's culture code to learn more about our company culture and why we implement it.</li> \n <li>Read the customer persona and target audience overview to truly understand who our customers are, their pain points, and how our product and content can help them.</li> \n <li>Meet with my team's director to learn about how meeting our goals will help our business grow.</li> \n <li>Read up on our team's new SEO strategy, editorial process, and traffic goals.</li> \n <li>Learn how to use the SEO Insights Report to plan and structure blog posts.</li> \n <li>Review my team's pillar-cluster model overview and understand how to match posts to clusters.</li> \n <li>Meet with my manager to learn more about her expectations.</li> \n</ul> \n<h5>Performance Goals</h5> \n<ul> \n <li>Complete new hire training and pass the test with a 90% or higher.</li> \n <li>Be able to write 3 blog posts per week.</li> \n</ul> \n<h5>Initiative Goals</h5> \n<ul> \n <li>Run the Facebook Instant Article experiment that my manager recommended me to do.</li> \n</ul> \n<h5>Personal Goals</h5> \n<ul> \n <li>Grab coffee with everyone on my team, so I can get to know them on a professional and personal level.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>60 Days</h3> \n<h4>Primer</h4> \n<p>By the end of your first 60 days, you should ramp up your workload, start overachieving, and make a name for yourself on your team.</p> \n<p>To do this, start speaking up more at meetings. Don't be afraid to share your ideas about improving your team's processes. This shows you're quickly conquering the learning curve and recognizing some flaws that your colleagues might've overlooked. You still have a fresh perspective on the company, so your insight is invaluable.</p> \n<h4>Theme: Be a Contributor</h4> \n<h5>Learning Goals:</h5> \n<ul> \n <li>Learn how to optimize a new post from scratch based on both the SEO Insights Report and my own competitive research.</li> \n <li>Read every other marketing team's wiki page to learn about other marketing initiatives and how our entire department works together to grow our business.</li> \n <li>Deep dive into my company's product roadmap and strategy to fully grasp our mission and vision.</li> \n</ul> \n<h5>Performance Goals</h5> \n<ul> \n <li>Be able to write 5 blog posts per week.</li> \n <li>Be down to one cycle of edits per post.</li> \n <li>Understand how to edit a guest post -- clean up at least one rough draft.</li> \n</ul> \n<h5>Initiative Goals</h5> \n<ul> \n <li>Share content strategy idea at my team's monthly meeting and ask if I can spearhead the project to boost blog traffic.</li> \n <li>Ask my manager if I can oversee Facebook messenger and Slack distribution strategy.</li> \n</ul> \n<h5>Personal Goals</h5> \n<ul> \n <li>Meet with my colleagues on other teams to learn about their marketing initiatives and develop relationships outside of my team.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>90 Days</h3> \n<h4>Primer</h4> \n<p>By the end of your first three months, you should have a firm grasp of your role, feel confident about your abilities, and be on the cusp of making a breakthrough contribution to your team. Instead of reacting to problems that pop up at random, be proactive and spearhead a new initiative for your team.</p> \n<p>You should also be cognizant of how you can collaborate with other teams to improve your own team's processes. By taking on some new projects outside of your main role, you'll start turning some heads and catch the attention of the department at large.</p> \n<h4>Theme: Be a Leader</h4> \n<h5>Learning Goals</h5> \n<ul> \n <li>Do an analysis of my highest and lowest performing blog post up to date. How can I use this information to optimize new content so it performs better out of the gate?</li> \n</ul> \n<h5>Performance Goals</h5> \n<ul> \n <li>Be comfortable with writing five blog posts per week</li> \n <li>Edit one guest post per week</li> \n <li>Try to have 75% of my blog posts not require revisions.</li> \n <li>Write at least one new post that generates over 10,000 views in one month.</li> \n</ul> \n<h5>Initiative Goals</h5> \n<ul> \n <li>Ask SEO team if they want to partner with product marketing team to brainstorm content topics related to our product road map.</li> \n <li>Ask social media team if they're willing to develop a relationship where we can share each other's content.</li> \n <li>Ask sales team what our customers' pain points are, so we can write content that our target audience craves and help them close more qualified leads.</li> \n</ul> \n<h5>Personal Goals</h5> \n<ul> \n <li>Join the yoga club.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Learning the nuances of your new role in less than three months won't be easy. But crafting a strong 30-60-90 day plan is your best bet for accelerating your development and adapting to your new work environment as quickly as possible.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in April 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<div></div>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2F30-60-90-day-plan&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 07 Aug 2020 14:53:00 +0000","feedId":924,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/30-60-90-day-plan-2.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"8a6f144720f7dbd1b6377623ebd539b7","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx17/cdn12@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-27-322_9ff7c934c59669cd.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/30-60-90-day-plan-2.jpg#keepProtocol","destWidth":598,"destHeight":399,"author":"cchi@hubspot.com (Clifford Chi)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/30,%2060,%2090%20Day%20Plan%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg?width=1500&name=30,%2060,%2090%20Day%20Plan%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn95@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-30-822_aee4f44e77411392.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2F30-60-90-day-plan&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn4@2020_3/2020/08/16/13-48-30-893_937e7560f9c90806.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","title":"How to Build A Business Plan That Stands Out [Free Template]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/business-plan-template","description":"<p>Nowadays, it seems like a new company is starting every hour.</p>  \n<p>But, while starting a company may seem easier now than ever before, entrepreneurs have an uphill battle from the moment they start a business. On average, a new business will need to compete with <a href=\"https://www.dmnews.com/data/article/21048500/business-is-becoming-more-competitive\">25 competitors</a> in order to stand out and thrive in its industry.</p> \n<p>Aspiring business owners that go in blind without a clear, actionable plan for marketing, hiring, finances, and operations are destined to face significantly more difficulties on their journey to building a successful company — which is why crafting a <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/business-plan-template?hubs_post-cta=body\">business plan</a> is an essential step in the entrepreneurial process.</p> \n<p>In this post, we’ll walk you through the process of filling out your <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/business-templates/one-page-business-plan?hubs_post-cta=imagesir\">business plan template, like this free, editable version</a>:&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/One-Page%20Business%20Plan%20Template.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=One-Page%20Business%20Plan%20Template.jpg\" alt=\"free editable One-Page Business Plan pdf  Template\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/business-plan-template?hubs_post-cta=imagesir\"><em>Download a free, editable one-page business plan template.&nbsp;</em></a></p> \n<p>This way, you’ll be able to show them how organized and well-thought-out your business idea is, and provide them with answers to whatever questions they may have.</p> \n<p>When looking at a blank page on a laptop screen, the idea of writing your business plan can seem impossible. However, it’s a mandatory step to take if you want to turn your business dreams into a reality.</p> \n<p>That’s why we’ve crafted a business plan template for you to download and use to build your new company. <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/business-plan-template?hubs_post-cta=body\">You can download it here for free</a>. It contains prompts for all of the essential parts of a business plan, all of which are elaborated on, below.</p> \n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\">Featured Resource: <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/business-plan-template?hubs_post-cta=body\">Free Business Plan Template</a></h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/business-plan-template?hubs_post-cta=image\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/bpt-cover-gif.gif?width=409&amp;name=bpt-cover-gif.gif\" alt=\"bpt-cover-gif\" width=\"409\" style=\"width: 409px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></a></p> \n<span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/business-plan-template?hubs_post-cta=imagebottom\">Download this Template</a></span> \n<h3>1. Cover Page</h3> \n<p>Your business plan should be prefaced with an eye-catching cover page. This means including a high-resolution image of your company logo, followed by your company’s name, address, and phone number.</p> \n<p>Since this business plan will likely change hands and be seen by multiple investors, you should also provide your own name, role in the business, and email address on the cover page, as well.</p> \n<h3>2. Executive Summary</h3> \n<p>The <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/executive-summary-examples\">executive summary</a> of your business plan should provide a one or two page overview of the business and highlight the most crucial pieces of information for readers. Intended to grab the reader’s attention, this section should summarize critical information regarding your company overview and upcoming short-term and long-term goals.</p> \n<p>The executive summary is essentially a boiled-down version of your entire business plan, so remember to keep this section to-the-point and filled only with essential information.</p> \n<p>Typically, this brief section includes:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>A mission statement.</li> \n <li>The company's history and leadership model.</li> \n <li>An overview of competitive advantage(s).</li> \n <li>Financial projections.</li> \n <li>Company goals.</li> \n <li>An ask from potential investors.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>3. Company &amp; Business Description</h3> \n<p>In this section, you’ll provide a more thorough description of what your company is and why it exists.</p> \n<p>The bulk of the writing in this section should be about your company’s purpose – covering what the business will be selling, identifying the target market, and laying out a path to success.</p> \n<p>In the Company &amp; Business Description portion of your business plan, you can also elaborate on your company’s:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Mission and/or vision statement.</li> \n <li>Core values.</li> \n <li>Team &amp; organizational structure.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>3. Product &amp; Services Line</h3> \n<p>Here’s where you’ll provide a more in-depth overview of the makeup of your business’s product and/or services line. You should provide each product or service’s name, its purpose, and a description of how it works (if appropriate).</p> \n<p>Next, add some color to the sales strategy by outlining your pricing model and mark-up amounts.</p> \n<p>If you’re selling tangible products, you should also provide an explanation of production and costs, and how you expect these factors to change as you scale.</p> \n<h3>4. Market Analysis</h3> \n<p>The market analysis section is where you’ll provide details about the audience to which you’re marketing your business. This should encompass the size of your total addressable market, your market’s demographics and psychographics, and a location analysis for your business’s operating space.</p> \n<p>It helps to reference your market research documentation here, like a Porter’s Five Forces Analysis or a SWOT Analysis (<a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/market-research-kit\">templates for those are available here</a>). You can also include them in your appendix.</p> \n<p>If your company already has buyer personas, you should include them here as well. If not, you can make them right now using the <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/make-my-persona\">Make My Persona Tool</a>.</p> \n<h3>5. Marketing Plan</h3> \n<p>Unlike the market analysis section, your marketing plan section should be an explanation of the tactical approach to reaching your aforementioned target audience. List the channels you’ll be advertising on, what organic marketing methods you’ll employ, etc.</p> \n<p>If your company has a fully fleshed out marketing plan, you can attach it in the appendix of your business plan. If not, <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/marketing-plan-template\">download this free marketing plan template</a> to outline your strategy.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3>6. Sales Plan</h3> \n<p>It doesn’t matter if your sales department is an office full of BDRs or a dozen stores with your products on their shelves. The point is – like all companies – all sales strategies are different, so you should clearly outline yours here. Common talking points include:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Sales team structure, and why this structure was chosen.</li> \n <li>Sales channels.</li> \n <li>Sales tools, software, and resources.</li> \n <li>Prospecting strategy.</li> \n <li>Sales goals and budget.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Like with your marketing plan, it might make sense to attach your completed sales plan to the appendix of your business plan. You can <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/sales-plan-template\">download a template for building your sales plan here</a>.</p> \n<h3>7. Legal Notes</h3> \n<p>Your investors may want to know the legal structure of your business, since that could directly impact the risk of their investments. For example, if you’re looking for business partners to engage in a non-corporation or LLC partnership, this means they could be on the line for more than their actual investment. Because this clarification is often needed, explain if you are and/or plan to become a sole proprietor, partnership, corporation, LLC, etc.</p> \n<p>You should also outline the steps you have taken or will need to take in order to operate legally. This includes necessary licenses, permits, registrations, insurance requirements, etc. that are needed to follow the law. The last thing your investor wants to hear after they’ve sent you a big chunk of change is that you’re operating without proper approval from local, state, or federal government.</p> \n<h3>8. Financial Considerations</h3> \n<p>Ultimately, investors want to know two things:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>When they will earn their money back.</li> \n <li>When they will start seeing <em>returns</em> on their initial investment.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>That said, you’ll need to be clear, calculated, and convincing in this section. It should cover:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Startup costs.</li> \n <li>Sales forecasts for the next several months/quarters.</li> \n <li>Break-even analysis for time <em>and</em> dollars.</li> \n <li>Projected P&amp;L statement.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Most importantly, you’ll want to explain the <em>why</em> behind each of these sections. Facts and figures are key here, so be as specific as possible with each line item and projection, in addition to <em>why</em> you’ve included it.</p> \n<p>If you have pages upon pages of charts and spreadsheets for this section (which – arguably – you should), you may want to distill them into a page or two and include the rest of the sheets in the appendix.</p> \n<h3>9. Appendix</h3> \n<p>The best business plans are filled with imperative information, spanning dozens or even hundreds of pages long. To avoid disrupting the flow of the business plan with visuals, charts, and spreadsheets, consider including all of these resources in the appendix. Aside from what we’ve already mentioned – marketing plan, sales plan, department budgets, financial documents, etc. – you may also want to attach the following in the appendix:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Floor plans for your location.</li> \n <li>Images of social media pages.</li> \n <li>Your logo and any graphic design assets.</li> \n <li>Mock-ups of your product.</li> \n <li>Renderings of your office space or location design.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Adding these pieces to the appendix enriches the reader’s understanding of your business and proves you’ve put the work into your business plan without distracting from the points throughout the plan.</p> \n<h2><strong>Use a Business Plan Template to Get Started</strong></h2> \n<p>Writing a business plan shouldn’t be an insurmountable roadblock to starting a business. Unfortunately, for all too many, it is.</p> \n<p>That’s why we recommend using our <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/business-plan-template?hubs_post-cta=body\">free business plan template</a><strong>. </strong>Pre-filled with detailed section prompts for all of the topics in this blog post, we’re confident this template will get your business plan started in the right direction.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in June, 2017 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fbusiness-plan-template&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 07 Aug 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":924,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/business-plan-2.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"9a3dca76c24ad4ee342cb3326466ecd1","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn28@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-27-572_fce165d05ba01362.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/business-plan-2.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"AJ Beltis","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/One-Page%20Business%20Plan%20Template.jpg?width=1500&name=One-Page%20Business%20Plan%20Template.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn99@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-31-942_316daa92eb250477.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/bpt-cover-gif.gif?width=409&name=bpt-cover-gif.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn28@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-36-675_a84d5b3d5c9e6b05.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fbusiness-plan-template&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn92@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-35-181_3b0fda08f214b8e0.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:25","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:25","title":"11 of the Best Professional Bio Examples We've Ever Seen [+ Bio Templates]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/professional-bio-examples","description":"<p>Is your professional bio as good as it can be?</p>   \n<p>In this article, we have nine real bio examples you should definitely compare yours to — and a series of free bio templates you can use to perfect it.</p> \n<p>Most people don't think about their professional bio until they're suddenly asked to \"shoot one over via email,\" and have approximately one afternoon to come up with it. That's when we scramble, and our bio ends up reading like this:</p> \n<em>Rodney Erickson is a content marketing professional at HubSpot, an inbound marketing and sales platform that helps companies attract visitors, convert leads, and close customers. Previously, Rodney worked as a marketing manager for a tech software startup. He graduated with honors from Columbia University with a dual degree in Business Administration and Creative Writing.\"</em>\n<br> \n<p>Woof, that was dull. Are you still with me? I swear, not even adding a tidbit about his cats would liven that bio up.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>To be fair, in certain contexts, your professional bio does need to be more formal, like Mr. Erickson's up there. But in many cases, writing a bio that's readable — even conversational — is actually a really good thing. That means dropping that traditional format of listing your accomplishments like a robot and cramming as much professional-sounding jargon in there as you can.</p> \n<p></p> \n<div style=\"text-align: center;\"> \n <div> \n  <h2 style=\"text-align: left;\"><strong>How to Write a Bio</strong></h2> \n  <p><strong><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Professional%20Bio%20Template%201.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=Professional%20Bio%20Template%201.jpg\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"editable short professional bio pdf template\"></strong></p> \n </div> \n <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/personal-brand-professional-bio-examples?%3Fhubs_post-cta=imagesir\"><em>Download a free, editable short professional bio template.</em></a>\n <br> \n <p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Professional%20Bio%20Template%202.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=Professional%20Bio%20Template%202.jpg\" alt=\"free editable long professional bio pdf template\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/personal-brand-professional-bio-examples?%3Fhubs_post-cta=imagesir\"><em>Download a free, editable long professional bio template.</em></a></p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">Writing a professional bio that captures your brand and what you offer to your audience can help you grow better. But doing it right is just as important. Here's how to write a bio, step-by-step.</p> \n <div> \n  <div> \n   <h3 style=\"text-align: left;\">1. Create an 'About' page for your website or profile.</h3> \n  </div> \n  <div style=\"text-align: left;\"> \n   <div> \n    <p>Before you can publish your professional bio, you need a living space for it. Here are a few to consider (some of these you might already have in place):</p> \n    <ul> \n     <li>Facebook Business page</li> \n     <li>LinkedIn profile</li> \n     <li>Instagram account</li> \n     <li>Personal website</li> \n     <li>Personal blog</li> \n     <li>Industry website</li> \n     <li>Industry blog byline</li> \n    </ul> \n    <p>As you'll see in the professional bio examples below, the length and tone of your bio will differ depending on which of the above platforms you choose to be on. Instagram, for example, allows only <a href=\"https://sproutsocial.com/insights/social-media-character-counter/\">150 characters</a> of bio space, whereas you can write virtually as much as you want on your personal website — or even your Facebook Business page. But once created, this bio should represent who you are in the eyes of your audience.</p> \n   </div> \n  </div> \n </div> \n <div style=\"text-align: left;\"> \n  <div> \n   <h3>2. Begin writing your bio with your first and last name.</h3> \n  </div> \n  <div> \n   <div> \n    <p>If your readers don't remember anything else about your bio, make sure they remember your name. For that reason, it's a good idea for your first and last name to be the first two words of your professional bio. Even if your name is printed above this bio (hint: it should), this is a rare moment where it's okay to be redundant.</p> \n    <p>For example, if I were writing my own bio, I might start it like this:</p> \n    <h4><em>Lindsay Kolowich</em></h4> \n    <p><em>Lindsay Kolowich is a Senior Marketing Manager at HubSpot.</em></p> \n   </div> \n  </div> \n </div> \n <div style=\"text-align: left;\"> \n  <div> \n   <h3>3. Mention any associated brand name you might use.</h3> \n  </div> \n  <div> \n   <div> \n    <p>Will your professional bio represent yourself, or a business you work for? Make sure the brand you want to be associated with is mentioned in your bio. If you're a freelancer, perhaps you have a personal business name or pseudonym you advertise to your clients. Here are a few examples:</p> \n    <ul> \n     <li>Lindsay Kolowich Marketing</li> \n     <li>SEO Lindsay</li> \n     <li>Kolowich Consulting</li> \n     <li>Content by Kolowich (what do you think ... too cheesy?)</li> \n    </ul> \n    <p>Maybe you founded your own company, and you want its name to be separate from your real name. Don't be afraid to keep it simple: <em>\"Lindsay Kolowich is the founder and CEO of Kolowich Consulting.\"</em></p> \n   </div> \n  </div> \n </div> \n <div style=\"text-align: left;\"> \n  <div> \n   <h3>4. State your current position and what you do.</h3> \n  </div> \n  <div> \n   <div> \n    <p>Whether you're the founder of your company or a mid-level specialist, use the next few lines of your bio to describe what you do in that position. Don't assume your audience will naturally know what your job title entails. Make your primary responsibilities known for the reader, helping them paint a picture of who you are during the day and what you have to offer the industry.</p> \n   </div> \n  </div> \n </div> \n <div style=\"text-align: left;\"> \n  <div> \n   <h3>5. Include at least one professional accomplishment.</h3> \n  </div> \n  <div> \n   <div> \n    <p>Just as a business touts its client successes in the form of case studies, your professional bio should let your own audience know what you've already achieved. What have you done for yourself — as well as for others — that makes you a valuable player in your industry?</p> \n   </div> \n  </div> \n </div> \n <div style=\"text-align: left;\"> \n  <div> \n   <h3>6. Describe your values and how they inform your career.</h3> \n  </div> \n  <div> \n   <div> \n    <p><em>Why</em> do you do what you do? What might make your contribution to the market different than your colleagues? Better yet, what values do you and your colleagues share that would make your business a worthwhile investment to others? Start to wrap up your professional bio by simply explaining what gets you up in the morning.</p> \n   </div> \n  </div> \n </div> \n <div style=\"text-align: left;\"> \n  <div> \n   <h3>7. Briefly tell your readers who you are outside of work.</h3> \n  </div> \n  <div> \n   <div> \n    <p>Transition from describing your values in work to describing who you are <em>outside</em> of work.
