This may include:</p> \n    <ul> \n     <li>Your family</li> \n     <li>Your hometown</li> \n     <li>Sports you play</li> \n     <li>Hobbies and interests</li> \n     <li>Favorite music and travel destinations</li> \n     <li>Side hustles you're working on</li> \n    </ul> \n    <p>People like connecting with other people. The more transparent you are about who you are personally, the more likable you'll be to the people reading about who you are professionally.</p> \n   </div> \n  </div> \n </div> \n <div style=\"text-align: left;\"> \n  <div> \n   <h3>8. Consider adding humor or a personal story to add flavor to your professional bio.</h3> \n  </div> \n  <div> \n   <div> \n    <p>End your professional bio on a good note — or, more specifically, a funny note. Leaving your audience with something quirky or uniquely you can ensure they'll leave your website with a pleasant impression of you.</p> \n    <p>It's important to follow the steps above when writing your bio, but don't obsess over any one section. Remember, the people reading your bio are suffering from information fatigue. If you don't hook 'em in the first line, you'll lose them quickly.</p> \n   </div> \n  </div> \n </div> \n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\"><em>(P.S. Want to give your professional brand a boost? <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/certification?hubs_post=blog.hubspot.com/marketing/professional-bio-examples\">Take one of HubSpot Academy's free certification courses</a>. In just one weekend, you can add a line to your resume and bio that's coveted by over 60,000 marketers.)</em></p> \n<h2 style=\"text-align: left;\"><strong>Why Good Bios Are Important for a Professional</strong></h2> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">Alright, I know what you may be thinking ... <em>So what? It's just a bio.</em> I mean, how many people actually read professional bios, anyway?</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">The answer: A lot of people. More importantly, though, there's no way to tell exactly <em>who</em> is reading it — and you always want it to be ready for when the <em>right</em> people come across it. And when they do, you want it to catch their eye. In a good way.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">You see, while <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-write-a-standout-resume\">your resume</a> is only useful for when you're actively applying for specific positions, your professional bio is much more visible. It can live on <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/linkedin-profile-perfection-cheat-sheet\">your LinkedIn profile</a>, your company's website, your guest blog posts, your speaker profiles, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/insiders/how-to-write-a-twitter-bio\">your Twitter bio</a>, and many other places.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>And, most importantly, it's the tool that you can leverage most when you're networking.</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">Bottom line? People <em>will</em> read your professional bio. Whether they remember it, and whether it makes them actually care about you, is a matter of how well you present yourself to your intended audience.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">So, what does a top-notch professional bio look like?</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">Below, we've curated some of the best real professional bio examples we've ever seen on Twitter, Instagram, Facebook, LinkedIn, and the various websites where you might describe yourself.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">Check 'em out, and use them as inspiration when crafting your own.</p> \n<h2 style=\"text-align: left;\"><strong>11 of the Best Professional Bio Examples We've Ever Seen</strong></h2> \n<h3 style=\"text-align: left;\">1. <a href=\"http://www.annhandley.com/\" style=\"font-size: 1.5rem;\">Ann Handley</a></h3> \n<h4 style=\"text-align: left;\">Bio Platform: Personal Website</h4> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">If you're a marketer, you've likely heard of Ann Handley. Her list of credentials is lengthy, and if she really wanted to, she could go on and on and on about her accomplishments.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">But when people list out all their accomplishments in their bios, they risk sounding a little egotistical. Sure, you might impress a handful of people with all those laurels, but many people who read your bio will end up feeling either intimidated or annoyed. Think about it: Is that how you want the majority of your readers to feel when they read your bio?</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">To minimize the egoism that comes with talking about yourself, think about how you can list out your accomplishments without sounding like you're bragging. Ann does this really well, choosing a tone in her bio that's more approachable.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">It starts with the excerpt in the footer of her personal website. Give it a quick read, paying close attention to the opening and closing lines:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/ann-handley-website-bio.png?width=640&amp;name=ann-handley-website-bio.png\" alt=\"Ann Handley's professional bio on her personal website\" width=\"640\" style=\"width: 640px;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">\"This is Ann Handley's website, and this is a bit of copy about her ... That's not giving you a lot of detail, is it? So read more here.\" This is the kind of simple, friendly language that invites the reader in rather than shutting them out.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">Follow the link and you'll be led to a page dedicated to a fuller bio, which she's divided into two parts: a \"short version\" (literally a bulleted list of key facts) and a \"long version,\" which includes traditional paragraphs. There's something in there for everyone.</p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/miss604/\">Rebecca Bollwitt</a></h3> \n<h4>Bio platform: Instagram</h4> \n<p>Instagram is a notoriously difficult platform on which to write a good bio. Similar to Twitter, you simply don't have room for a professional bio that includes <em>everything</em> about you. And because Instagram is primarily a mobile app, many viewers are reading about you passively on their mobile device.</p> \n<p>Instagram's limited bio space requires you to highlight just your most important qualities, and blogging icon Rebecca Bollwitt does so in her own Instagram bio in an excellent way.</p> \n<p>Rebecca's brand name is Miss604, and cleverly uses emojis in her Instagram bio to tell visitors exactly what makes her a valuable content creator. Take a look in the screenshot below.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/miss604.png?width=1518&amp;name=miss604.png\" alt=\"miss604 professional bio on Instagram\" width=\"1518\" style=\"width: 1518px;\"></p> \n<p>Starting with a trophy emoji, Miss604 says she's BC's most award-winning blogger. I haven't even looked at her pictures yet and the introduction of her bio has already sucked me in.</p> \n<p>The rest of her bio follows suit, breaking up the text with an appropriate emoji and a perfect collection of nouns to tell me who she is as a person. She even links out to her husband's Instagram account after the heart emoji (an adorable addition), and assures her followers that all of her pictures are authentically hers.</p> \n<p>Take a lesson from Miss604, and show your personal side. Just because you're branding yourself as a professional doesn't mean you have to take your <em>human being</em> hat off. Often your most personal attributes make for the best professional bio content.</p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://twitter.com/m_gallion\">Mark Gallion</a></h3> \n<h4>Bio Platform: Twitter</h4> \n<p>As a venture capitalist and an executive at several start-ups, Mark Gallion has different versions of his bio all over the internet. You can imagine some are more formal than others. But when it comes to his Twitter bio, he carefully phrased his information in a way that helps him connect with his audience — specifically, through the use of humor.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/mark-gallion.png?width=1082&amp;name=mark-gallion.png\" alt=\"mark gallion professional bio on twitter\" width=\"1082\" style=\"width: 1082px;\"></p> \n<p>Why would he choose humor when he runs four start-ups and constantly seeks funding for them? Well, Mark's tactic is totally intentional: it's a lever he pulls to refresh his brand while maintaining his already impressive and established identity as an entrepreneur.</p> \n<p>Mark leverages his Twitter bio because it’s place where he can be human. And it helps him relate to his followers and potential investors.</p> \n<p>When crafting your own Twitter bio, consider your audience and the personal brand you're trying to create for yourself. Use it as an opportunity to be relatable. (And check out this <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/twitter-bio\">list of amusing Twitter bios for inspiration</a>.)</p> \n<h3>4. <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/pg/DJNexus4/about/\">DJ Nexus</a></h3> \n<h4>Bio Platform: Facebook</h4> \n<p>This New England-based DJ has single-handedly captured the Likes of more than 2,000 people in and beyond Boston, MA. And even if you don't listen to the type of music he produces, it's hard not to listen to his compelling Facebook bio.</p> \n<p>Stage-named DJ Nexus, Jamerson's professional bio makes use of nearly every Page field inside the About tab. Right away, his audience knows which genres he plays in, where he's from, and who else he's worked with. The latter — under \"Affiliation,\" as shown in the screenshot below — is unique and seldom mentioned in professional bios today.</p> \n<p>Our favorite part about DJ Nexus's bio? His tagline, under \"About\" — \"<strong>Quiet during the day. QUITE LOUD at night!</strong>\" DJ Nexus tells you <em>when</em> he works in an awesome way. I got goosebumps just imagining a dance club he might play his music in.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/dj-nexus-professional-bio.png?width=575&amp;height=439&amp;name=dj-nexus-professional-bio.png\" alt=\"DJ Nexus's professional bio on Facebook\" width=\"575\" height=\"439\" style=\"width: 575px;\"></p> \n<p>DJ Nexus's bio brilliance doesn't stop there.</p> \n<p>The great thing about Facebook Business Pages is that you can write as much as you want without <i>overwhelming your Page visitors</i>. For those who just want Jamerson's basic info, they have the four categories shown above. For those who want to learn more about him, he tells an excellent story of his career. Here's just a preview of his story, below:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/dj%20nexus%20professional%20bio%20story.png?width=385&amp;height=376&amp;name=dj%20nexus%20professional%20bio%20story.png\" alt=\"A story on DJ Nexus's Facebook Business Page\" width=\"385\" height=\"376\" style=\"width: 385px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p>In this story, DJ Nexus describes both when he \"became known as DJ Nexus\" and a company he founded shortly afterward — all before going to college. This is a terrific lesson for Facebook Businesses today: customers want to learn about you, and as Facebook increasingly becomes a place for meaningful interactions, there's no better place to tell your story than on your Facebook Business Page.</p> \n<h3>5. <a href=\"https://therapists.psychologytoday.com/rms/name/Lena_Axelsson_PsyD,LMFT_Santa+Cruz_California_89644\">Lena Axelsson</a></h3> \n<h4>Bio Platform: Industry Website</h4> \n<p>When it all comes down to it, your professional bio is no different than any other piece of persuasive copy — no matter where it lives. One of the most common mistakes people make is thinking of it as its own beast, separate from other pieces of writing. If you think about it that way, you're far more likely to write something painfully uninteresting.</p> \n<p>When you sit down to write your professional bio and you're watching that cursor blinking on the screen, think about how you would introduce a blog post. You don't just dive right into the meat of the thing, now, do you? No. You start with an introduction.</p> \n<p>The best bios are often concise (around 200–300 words), so you don't have a lot of room to play around. But a single sentence that tees your reader up and provides context for the accomplishments that follow could make the rest of your bio that much more persuasive.</p> \n<p>Take Lena Axelsson's bio, for instance. She's a marriage and family therapist — a job where empathy and compassion are a big part of the job description. That's why she chooses to open her bio with a great introductory sentence: \"When human beings experience trauma or severe life stressors, it is not uncommon for their lives to unravel.\"</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/therapist-bio-example.png?width=640&amp;name=therapist-bio-example.png\" alt=\"Lena Axelsson's professional bio on an industry website for therapists\" width=\"640\" style=\"width: 640px;\"></p> \n<p>Then, she goes into why she's passionate about her job, how she helps her clients, and how she caters her approach to each individual patient. The necessary educational information is left for the end, after the reader has been hooked.</p> \n<p>Your bio doesn't have to be super serious, nor does it have to start with a joke. This bio shows how you can capture your reader's attention by being empathetic and showing how that empathy shapes a valuable professional.</p> \n<h3>6. <a href=\"http://www.levyinnovation.com/about/\">Mark Levy</a></h3> \n<h4>Bio Platform: Personal Website</h4> \n<p>Mark Levy is a small business owner who's taken a more traditional approach to the professional bio on his website — but in a way that takes care to speak to his intended audience.</p> \n<p>What we love about his bio is the way he's set it up: On his business' \"About\" page, he's listed two biographies, which he's labeled \"Mark Levy's Biography #1\" and \"Mark Levy's Biography #2.\"</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/mark-levy-professional-bio.png?width=640&amp;name=mark-levy-professional-bio.png\" alt=\"Mark Levy's professional bio in his personal website\" width=\"640\" style=\"width: 640px;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"http://www.levyinnovation.com/about/\">Click here to see the full version</a>.</p> \n<p>Like Ann, Mark's given his readers two different options. The first biography is a \"short version,\" which includes a combination of bullet points listing his credentials and a few short paragraphs.</p> \n<p>The second is the \"long version,\" which is actually even more interesting than the first one. Why? Because it reads like a story — a compelling one, at that. In fact, it gets really funny at parts.</p> \n<p>The second sentence of the bio reads: \"He was frightened of public school, loved playing baseball and football, ran home to watch ape films on the 4:30 Movie, listened to The Jam and The Buzzcocks, and read magic trick books.\"</p> \n<p>Here's another excerpt from the middle:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/mark-levy-long-bio-snippet.png?width=640&amp;name=mark-levy-long-bio-snippet.png\" alt=\"A snippet from Mark Levy's full professional bio on his personal website\" width=\"640\" style=\"width: 640px;\"></p> \n<p>Of course, the fantastic copywriting isn't a surprise, given that this guy wrote several books. But the conversational tone and entertaining copy let his quirky personality (and great writing skills) shine.</p> \n<h3>7. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/author/corey-wainwright\">Corey Wainwright</a></h3> \n<h4>Bio Platform: Blog Byline</h4> \n<p>Corey Wainwright is the director of content here at HubSpot. She's written content for HubSpot's Marketing Blog for years, and her blog author bio has caught my eye since before I ever started working for HubSpot. (Back then, it started with, \"Corey just took a cool vacation.\")</p> \n<p>What I love most about Corey's bio is that it's a great example of how to deliver information about yourself without taking things too seriously. And in this context, that's totally appropriate.</p> \n<p>Despite having a number of impressive accomplishments under her belt, she simply doesn't like displaying them publicly. So, she prefers making her author bio a little more \"light.\"</p> \n<p>Her bio (pictured below) reads, \"Corey is a Bruce Springsteen fan who does content marketing, in that order.\"</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/corey-wainwright-bio.png?width=640&amp;name=corey-wainwright-bio.png\" alt=\"Corey Wrainwright's professional bio as a blog byline for HubSpot\" width=\"640\" style=\"width: 640px;\"></p> \n<p>It works in this particular context because, at HubSpot, our blog authors often prefer to make themselves as friendly and approachable as possible — while letting the content speak for itself.</p> \n<p>It helps that authors' social media accounts are located right below our names and above our pictures. For folks who really do want a list of Corey's credentials, they can click the LinkedIn button to go to her LinkedIn page. (You can <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/29544/The-Ultimate-Cheat-Sheet-for-Creating-Social-Media-Buttons.aspx\">read this blog post to learn how to create social media buttons</a> and add them to your website.)</p> \n<h3>8. <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/marie-mikhail-12283b39/\">Marie Mikhail</a></h3> \n<h4>Bio Platform: LinkedIn</h4> \n<p>Marie Mikhail checks off nearly every box for what makes an excellent bio. A professional recruiter, she expresses her \"passion for recruiting\" upfront, in the first sentence, while using that sentence to hook her profile visitors into a brief story of her background.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/marie-mikhail-bio.png?width=1186&amp;name=marie-mikhail-bio.png\" alt=\"Marie Mikhail's professional bio on LinkedIn\" width=\"1186\" style=\"width: 1186px;\"></p> \n<p>But there are a lot of recruiters out there, and Marie knows that. So, to differentiate herself, she closes the first paragraph of her bio explaining that she likes \"getting people excited about the things [she's] excited about.\" It's a well-put value proposition that sets her apart from the rest of the HR industry.</p> \n<p>Marie Mikhail finishes off her bio by including a smooth mixture of professional skills, such as her Spanish fluency; and personal interests, such as podcasting and Star Wars (she mentions the latter with just the right amount of humor).</p> \n<h3>9. <a href=\"http://www.wonbowoo.com/about.html\">Wonbo Woo</a></h3> \n<h4>Bio Platform: Personal Website</h4> \n<p>Wonbo Woo is the executive producer of WIRED's video content, and he has a number of impressive credits to his name. What does this mean for his professional bio? He has to prioritize. With this in mind, Wonbo opens his bio with the most eye-catching details first (if the image below is hard to read, click it to see the full copy).</p> \n<p><a href=\"http://www.wonbowoo.com/about.html\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/wonbo-woo-professional-bio-example.jpg?width=690&amp;name=wonbo-woo-professional-bio-example.jpg\" alt=\"Wonbo Woo's professional bio on his personal website\" width=\"690\"></a></p> \n<p>Not only does Wonbo's bio start strong, but he also takes readers on a suspenseful journey through some of his most harrowing assignments — where he was when news broke and how he responded. You can see this quality below.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/wonbo-woo-professional-bio-2.jpg?width=690&amp;name=wonbo-woo-professional-bio-2.jpg\" alt=\"snippet from Wonbo Woo's bio on his personal website\" width=\"690\" style=\"width: 690px;\">The accomplished journalist concludes his gripping bio as strong as it began, measuring his experience by the number of states, countries, and continents to which he's traveled in his career. See how this looks above. All in all, it's a fantastically concise bio for as much detail as it holds.</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">10. <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/chrisburkard\">Chris Burkard </a></h3> \n<h4>Bio Platform: LinkedIn</h4> \n<p>If you're writing your bio but having trouble figuring out how to showcase your accomplishments without boasting, photographer Burkard's LinkedIn bio is a great example for inspiration.</p> \n<p>Written in third-person, his bio tells a fluid story, starting with his ultimate mission — \"capture stories that inspire humans to consider their relationship with nature\" — before diving into more tangible accolades (giving a TED talk, publishing books, etc.).</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/chris-burkard-bio.png?width=1260&amp;name=chris-burkard-bio.png\" alt=\"Chris Burkard's professional bio on LinkedIn\" width=\"1260\" style=\"width: 1260px;\"></p> \n<p>Best of all, rather than using his bio as an opportunity to brag, he instead ties his talents into how he hopes to help <i>others</i>, writing, \"Through social media Chris strives to share his vision … and inspire [his followers] to explore for themselves.\" I wouldn't necessarily be inclined to follow Chris if his bio had simply read \"I post beautiful images\" … but inspire me to travel? Now that's something I can get behind.</p> \n<p>Lastly, he ends on a humble, sweet note, writing \"He is happiest wth his wife Breanne raising their two sons\". Don't be afraid to inject some personal information into your bio — it could help you seem more approachable as a result.</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">11. <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/detoxinista/\">Megan Gilmore</a></h3> \n<h4><strong>Bio Platform: Instagram</strong></h4> \n<p>Megan Gilmore is a best-selling cookbook author, and she often posts healthy recipes on her Instagram page to inspire followers' to realize that you don't have to sacrifice taste for the sake of health.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/megan-gilmore-bio.png?width=1524&amp;name=megan-gilmore-bio.png\" alt=\"Megan Gilmore's professional bio on Instagram\" width=\"1524\" style=\"width: 1524px;\"></p> \n<p>Fortunately, you glean most of this information immediately from her Instagram bio, which is short and to-the-point: \"Best-selling cookbook author + former fast-food junkie + mom of 2. I like to make healthy food as easy as possible.\" Her \"former fast-food junkie\" call-out shows followers she's relatable (and that her recipes are likely delicious yet healthy alternatives), and by mentioning she's a mother, you get the sense that her recipes really <i>will </i>actually be quick and easy.</p> \n<p>Plus, Gilmore includes a CTA link within her Instagram bio that leads followers to free, ready-to-use recipes. You might be thinking — <i>Why would she do that, since it discourages people from buying her book? </i>But that couldn't be further from the truth.</p> \n<p>By giving her followers the chance to try out her recipes, she's slowly turning leads into customers. After I tried a few of her Instagram recipes and loved them, I decided to go ahead and buy her book, knowing I'd like more of what she had to offer.</p> \n<p>Want more? Read <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-write-cover-letter-template\">How to Write a Cover Letter That Gets You the Job [Bookmarkable Template + Examples]</a>.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's Note: This post was originally published in November 2019 and has been updated for accuracy and comprehensiveness.</em></p>  \n<p></p>   \n<img om/hs-fs/hubfs/mark-levy-long-bio-snippet.png?width=640&name=mark-levy-long-bio-snippet.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn95@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-36-253_e5606bd488e98f59.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/corey-wainwright-bio.png?width=640&name=corey-wainwright-bio.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn91@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-39-702_fc71db16a891b830.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/marie-mikhail-bio.png?width=1186&name=marie-mikhail-bio.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn67@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-37-485_5f522aac8e97afc2.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/wonbo-woo-professional-bio-example.jpg?width=690&name=wonbo-woo-professional-bio-example.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn88@2020_3/2020/08/16/13-48-36-173_e40d6b61749e63d4.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/wonbo-woo-professional-bio-2.jpg?width=690&name=wonbo-woo-professional-bio-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn95@2020_2/2020/08/16/13-48-28-871_1b07dff40ba054d9.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/chris-burkard-bio.png?width=1260&name=chris-burkard-bio.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn35@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-36-367_9b58dd9621caa93d.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/megan-gilmore-bio.png?width=1524&name=megan-gilmore-bio.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn12@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-31-897_127116474b479df4.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fprofessional-bio-examples&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn16@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-37-951_2b9d72552d74653e.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:25","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:25","title":"15 Free Professionally-Designed Landing Page Templates","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/free-landing-page-templates","description":"<p style=\"text-align: left;\">When it comes to turning web visitors into leads, <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/marketing-statistics?_ga=2.39122723.1096999129.1559048254-1894039831.1558108101\">68% of B2B CEO’s use strategic landing pages</a> as part of their strategy.</p>  \n<p>A strong <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/7177/what-is-a-landing-page-and-why-should-you-care.aspx?_ga=2.211244565.1096999129.1559048254-1894039831.1558108101\">landing page</a> usually offers your website’s visitors a resource, such as a piece of content, in exchange for contact information. Sharing or hyperlinking to the URL of a landing page, rather than a homepage, also <a href=\"https://www.google.com/url?q=https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/7177/what-is-a-landing-page-and-why-should-you-care.aspx&amp;sa=D&amp;ust=1558711791967000&amp;usg=AFQjCNGgiGh6Xv6RAe0-QJMjG9_49crS1w\">increases the likelihood of turning traffic into conversions</a>.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Landing%20Page%20Template%201.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=Landing%20Page%20Template%201.jpg\" alt=\"free website Landing Page Template\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>While landing pages can play a vital role in lead generation, they don’t have to be complicated. In fact, you should aim for a page that’s concise and inviting, rather than complex and overwhelming.</p> \n<p>Rather than just placing a rigorous contact form on a page, it can be more productive to tease an interesting offer or a free resource in exchange for only a small amount of information.</p> \n<p>Even when you know what you’re going to offer and what information you’d like to receive from a visitor, the idea of building a landing page can still feel daunting.</p> \n<p>If you don’t have the bandwidth to build a page yourself, have little experience in design software, or have limited resources to hire a designer, using a pre-designed template could be the most efficient way to launch a professional looking page in a short amount of time.</p> \n<p>We’ve put together a list of 15 free, easy-to-use templates that can guide you through the process of building your next landing page.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2>15 Free Professionally-Designed Landing Page Templates</h2> \n<h3>1. Royce</h3> \n<p><em>Available on Squarespace</em></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://royce-demo.squarespace.com/\">Royce</a> is specialized for event reservations. There is no navigation bar, but the layout features a customizable background image, a headline, and a call-to-action button that says “RSVP.”</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Royce%20Event%20Landing%20Page.png?width=598&amp;name=Royce%20Event%20Landing%20Page.png\" alt=\"Royce Event Landing Page\" width=\"598\" style=\"width: 598px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p>To fill out the form and reserve a spot, visitors can click the RSVP button to see a form appear, or scroll down below the fold to see a static reservation form. This is an interesting template because it amplifies visuals and keeps the layout simple while still offering visitors two ways to convert.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Royce%20RSVP%20Form.jpg?width=598&amp;name=Royce%20RSVP%20Form.jpg\" alt=\"Royce RSVP Submission Form on Royce Landing Page\" width=\"598\" style=\"width: 598px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<h3>2. Invest</h3> \n<p><em>Available on HubSpot</em></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://marketplace.hubspot.com/products/inboundpixels/invest?_ga=2.158278450.966289747.1558623644-1894039831.1558108101\">This</a><a href=\"https://marketplace.hubspot.com/products/inboundpixels/invest?_ga=2.12917559.1096999129.1559048254-1894039831.1558108101\"> design</a> includes a photo, customizable text, no navigation (to keep visitors focused on your offer), and a short form. Users can also customize and add other elements such as the icons seen at the bottom of the image. Below the fold, users can also add more information about the offer or company.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-1.png\" alt=\"Invest Landing Page Template from Hubspot\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<h3>3. Hubstrap</h3> \n<p><em>Available on HubSpot</em></p> \n<p>The <a href=\"https://marketplace.hubspot.com/products/hubstrap-pro/hubstrap-lite-landing?_ga=2.235884929.1096999129.1559048254-1894039831.1558108101\">Hubstrap</a> template has a simplistic look and feel but devotes a bit more room to text. This might be a good option if your content offer has less imagery to go with it. For example, you might use this page to describe an offer or a long whitepaper on a topic related to your industry. Users can similarly personalize the design and add drag-and-drop sections to the page.</p> \n<p>Unlike the above landing pages, this example does include navigation. However, it’s simple enough that it doesn't detract from the offer.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Hubstrap%20Landing%20Page.jpg?width=485&amp;name=Hubstrap%20Landing%20Page.jpg\" alt=\"Hubstrap Landing Page\" width=\"485\" style=\"width: 485px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<h3>4. Landing Form</h3> \n<p><em>Available on HubSpot</em></p> \n<p>This <a href=\"https://marketplace.hubspot.com/products/inboundpixels/landing-form?_ga=2.235884929.1096999129.1559048254-1894039831.1558108101\">template</a> includes a background image with a dark overlay, a headline, text, bright call-to-action buttons, and a form. It eliminates the navigation bar but includes a button at the top of the page. The image also has a dark overlay to keep it visible, but less distracting. As you scroll below the fold, this template also includes spots for more imagery and details that could relate to the product or offer.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates.png\" alt=\"Landing Form Landing Page Template from Hubspot\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>5. Gradient</h3> \n<p><em>Available on HubSpot</em></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://marketplace.hubspot.com/products/inboundpixels/gradient-landing-left?_ga=2.235884929.1096999129.1559048254-1894039831.1558108101\">Gradient</a> is sleekly designed for a content-based offer. It has a simple layout with a form, headline, description text, photo, and logo, but continues the theme of no navigation. Like the other HubSpot templates, users can add a photo or product shot, a background image that appears behind a gradient color, and descriptive text. They can also adjust or change the gradient background’s color.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-5.png\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"Gradient Landing Page Template from Hubspot\">\n</div> \n<h3>6. University</h3> \n<p><em>Available on Wix</em></p> \n<p>This <a href=\"https://www.wix.com/website-template/view/html/1296?siteId=0dcd76ec-0243-44a6-8e2e-e78bc991b6ff&amp;metaSiteId=d7925b50-8841-41de-8462-0bb2c08217c3&amp;originUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.wix.com%2Fwebsite%2Ftemplates%3Fcriteria%3Duniversity%26page%3D1\">layout</a> may be useful for those seeking leads for an educational event, course, or a similar service. The form is more detailed, but the layout itself also allows room for more text and imagery. Above the fold, you can see a headline, supporting images, and a form. If you keep scrolling, there are additional sections where more text and imagery can be placed.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-10.png?width=598&amp;name=15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-10.png\" alt=\"University Landing Page Template from Wix\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 598px;\" width=\"598\">\n</div> \n<h3>7. Skyline</h3> \n<p><em>Available on Wix</em></p> \n<p>This <a href=\"https://www.wix.com/website-template/view/html/1896?siteId=c54249f0-9878-4464-9dc0-5cc938a097e4&amp;metaSiteId=2f5a38ee-e1bf-4a2d-a169-8e9670dd4cb0&amp;originUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.wix.com%2Fwebsite%2Ftemplates%2Fhtml%2Flanding-pages\">template</a> may be helpful to a company or individual that hasn’t yet launched a website or product but still wants to gain early leads in the meantime. Above the fold, there’s a giant headline area, where the template has “Coming Soon” printed.</p> \n<p>When you scroll down, you can see a quick description of the company and a box where visitors can add their email. Users can also add a photo or video to the background.</p> \n<div style=\"text-align: center;\">\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-7.png?width=598&amp;name=15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-7.png\" alt=\"Skyline Landing Page Template from Wix\" width=\"598\" style=\"width: 598px; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-6.png?width=598&amp;name=15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-6.png\" alt=\"Under the fold of Skyline Landing Page from Wix\" width=\"598\" style=\"width: 598px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<h3>8. Online Store Coming Soon</h3> \n<p><em>Available on Wix</em></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.wix.com/website-template/view/html/1939?siteId=2eef1a7e-1c6a-4b0f-8966-9fe337214403&amp;metaSiteId=6eaab85a-12cd-445e-89b7-4529b6417db7&amp;originUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.wix.com%2Fwebsite%2Ftemplates%2Fhtml%2Flanding-pages\">This template</a> is very simple. Like the above “Coming Soon” template, the text could be edited to use this layout for a different purpose. There is no navigation and any information about the company is off to the corners. This layout allows space for a clear product shot, as seen with the shoes. Headline text, a small amount of descriptive text, an email box, and a button are pre-designed in the layout. Users can also link their social media accounts to the icons under the “Notify Me” button.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-3.png?width=600&amp;name=15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-3.png\" alt=\"Wix's &quot;Online Store Coming Soon&quot; Template.\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<h3>9. Lead-Gen Landing Page</h3> \n<p><em>Available on Wix</em></p> \n<p>This template <a href=\"https://www.wix.com/website-template/view/html/2369?siteId=4188a619-cd81-4bc6-b8fb-ace88e20b9d0&amp;metaSiteId=8de98e44-cda6-4a02-a847-87629a440173&amp;originUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.wix.com%2Fwebsite%2Ftemplates%2Fhtml%2Flanding-pages\">seems specialized for B2B products</a>. It allows users to edit and customize the text and images through Wix. Users can also place background videos into the layout. The page is designed to be long, with the form and call-to-action above the fold followed by sections that detail different aspects of a company or firm, such as staff information.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-8.png?width=598&amp;name=15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-8.png\" alt=\"Lead-Gen Landing Page from Wix\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 598px;\" width=\"598\">\n</div> \n<h3>10. Fagri</h3> \n<p><em>Available on WordPress.org</em></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://wordpress.org/themes/fagri/\">Fagri</a> was designed broadly for multiple purposes and industries. According to its description, the theme’s widgets, such as the contact form are customizable. Users can also change the text and images. Although there is a navigation bar, the layout’s design still draws attention to the text, call-to-action buttons, and the contact form.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Fagri%20landing%20page%20from%20Wordpress.jpg?width=598&amp;name=Fagri%20landing%20page%20from%20Wordpress.jpg\" alt=\"Fagri landing page from Wordpress\" width=\"598\" style=\"width: 598px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<h3>11. Real Estate Landing Page</h3> \n<p><em>Available on Wix</em></p> \n<p>Although <a href=\"https://www.wix.com/website-template/view/html/1884?siteId=95b005c4-79e5-4c37-89f6-7011ea2fa6d9&amp;metaSiteId=20ff8dd7-a2cd-4318-8ce7-800826bb5282&amp;originUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.wix.com%2Fwebsite%2Ftemplates%2Fhtml%2Flanding-pages\">this template</a> doesn’t offer a resource for information, it can be edited and customized to include an offer. As you scroll down the page, the background image can remain static. With the current page’s design, there is room to add company information below the fold. There is also a second form at the very bottom so visitors will have another chance to convert.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Real%20Estate%20Landing%20Page.jpg?width=598&amp;name=Real%20Estate%20Landing%20Page.jpg\" alt=\"Real Estate Landing Page\" width=\"598\" style=\"width: 598px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<h3>12. Construction and Lawyer Landing Pages</h3> \n<p><em>Both Available on WordPress.org</em></p> \n<p>Wordpress also offers two similar <a href=\"https://wordpress.org/themes/lawyer-landing-page/\"><strong>Lawyer Landing Page</strong></a> and <a href=\"https://wordpress.org/themes/construction-landing-page/\"><strong>Construction Landing</strong> <strong>Page</strong></a> templates. Although the original designs are targeted at the two job fields, they can be customized to fit other brands and industries. Both have a header image, overlaid text, and an arrow pointing to a decently sized form above the fold. They also both offer the visitor a free quote.</p> \n<h3>13. Gardenhouse</h3> \n<p><em>Available on MailChimp</em></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-2.png?width=600&amp;name=15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-2.png\" alt=\"Gardenhouse Landing Page from MailChimp\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>This template does not include a navigation bar, which forces a visitor to focus on the given offer. Towards the bottom of the page, it can be customized to include logos or other company information. Like all MailChimp landing page themes, this layout is optimized for mobile and will automatically adjust to different screen sizes.</p> \n<h3>14. Bandmates</h3> \n<p><em>Available on MailChimp</em></p> \n<p>This template is also pretty simple with room for customization. It similarly removes navigation and keeps the company logo, text description, and a subscribe form above the fold.</p> \n<p>Users can also drag in more elements, like text or form boxes, into the design. Just below the form, users can include a product shot or another image. The blue background allows the form and call-to-action button to pop, but these colors can also be customized to fit your brand.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-9.png?width=598&amp;name=15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-9.png\" alt=\"Bandmates Landing Page from Mailchimp\" width=\"598\" style=\"width: 598px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<h3>15. O-Book</h3> \n<p><em>Available on Unbounce</em></p> \n<p>Unbounce layouts come with its subscription, but <a href=\"https://unbounce.com/landing-page-template/o-book/\">here's one of the landing pages </a>that you can test out with a free 14-day trial. This template is focused on book-specific lead generation. There is a clear spot for a product image, headlines, detailed description text, and a form box.</p> \n<p>The top navigation is minimal, but it does include social media buttons. Since this layout is only free for a trial period, this might be a better option for a company that has already gained revenue from landing pages and is looking to test out a more detailed, but affordable design.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-4.png?width=598&amp;name=15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-4.png\" alt=\"O-Book Landing Page from Unbounce\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 598px;\" width=\"598\">\n</div> \n<h3>Landing Page Best Practices</h3> \n<p>The above templates already follow a number of landing page best practices. For example, many of them exclude a navigation bar, which may detract attention or clicks away from the offer on the page. Most of them also leave room for a photo or video. While photos offer a great product tease, videos have also been seen to <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/marketing-statistics\">increase conversions by 86%</a>.</p> \n<p>To learn about other landing-page best practices, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/landing-page-templates?_ga=2.37649824.1096999129.1559048254-1894039831.1558108101\">check out this guide</a>.</p> ps://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn15@2020_3/2020/08/16/13-48-32-856_5e748a6d2cc8c2ff.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-6.png?width=598&name=15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-6.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn19@2020_3/2020/08/16/13-48-30-237_eb7f46f849133bec.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-3.png?width=600&name=15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn47@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-30-625_5c1180e09e9f9b5f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-8.png?width=598&name=15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-8.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn76@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-35-296_302a9673b74c0b10.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Fagri%20landing%20page%20from%20Wordpress.jpg?width=598&name=Fagri%20landing%20page%20from%20Wordpress.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx20/cdn55@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-29-595_eec78a4d99fd4403.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Real%20Estate%20Landing%20Page.jpg?width=598&name=Real%20Estate%20Landing%20Page.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn43@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-32-345_05f8000d89a3eda5.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-2.png?width=600&name=15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn11@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-29-434_c5e884eac6086411.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-9.png?width=598&name=15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-9.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn100@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-37-863_2c4ede52e0fc2aa3.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-4.png?width=598&name=15%20Free%20Professionally-Designed%20Landing%20Page%20Templates-4.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn63@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-35-152_42f5cc18568e1add.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ffree-landing-page-templates&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn23@2020_3/2020/08/16/13-48-30-181_b343c98b957eb000.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","title":"How to Make Digital Credentials Your Most Impactful Marketing Tool","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/digital-credentials","description":"<p>Marketing can have an enormous, positive impact on both revenue and brand recognition. Which is why organizations spend so much time, energy, and resources trying to reach their target audience.</p> \n<p>And yet, from billboard ads and radio slots to the roughly <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/456500/daily-number-of-e-mails-worldwide/\">300 billion</a> emails sent each day, it's hard to boost your brand amidst all the noise.</p> \n<p>Fortunately, there are innovative ways to cut through the crowded market and build brand awareness: and one of those opportunities is through <a href=\"https://resources.credly.com/what-is-a-dc-infographic\">digital credentials</a>.</p> \n<p>Digital credentials have emerged as an impactful marketing tool across a variety of industries including corporate training, associations, professional development and certifications, and higher education. If your organization issues digital credentials, there are several things you can do to make the most of their marketing power.</p> \n<p>Here, we'll cover four areas where incorporating digital badges can help your brand stand out.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3>1. Social</h3> \n<p>With over <a href=\"https://thenextweb.com/contributors/2019/01/30/digital-trends-2019-every-single-stat-you-need-to-know-about-the-internet/\">3.4 billion</a> active users, there's no denying social media is a modern marketing powerhouse. If your brand doesn't already have a social strategy in place, you're potentially losing out on the opportunity to engage with <em>millions</em> of customers.</p> \n<p>Incorporating digital credentials into your social media strategy can drive brand awareness, increase engagement with the individuals who earn your badges, and strengthen the reputation of your company online.</p> \n<p>To incorporate digital credentials, try using keywords and hashtags to search for individuals sharing your digital credentials online and interact with them — give them a \"Like\", a re-tweet, or congratulate them on their achievement. You'll build stronger connections and create new engagement opportunities with your badge earners.</p> \n<p>For instance, anyone who's earned a HubSpot certification could post it on their LinkedIn, like the example below:</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Make%20Digital%20Credentials%20Your%20Most%20Impactful%20Marketing%20Tool.png?width=427&amp;name=How%20to%20Make%20Digital%20Credentials%20Your%20Most%20Impactful%20Marketing%20Tool.png\" alt=\"\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 427px;\" width=\"427\">\n</div> \n<p>Connecting with these users over social media in a meaningful way provides an opportunity for every single one of them to become an evangelist for your brand.</p> \n<p>Another way to leverage digital credentials in this way is for employees to share their certifications socially. Think of this as employees promoting company news or recent awards. By sharing achievements on their social channels, your employees are promoting your brand among users you may not have had the chance to get in front of otherwise.</p> \n<h3>2. Email</h3> \n<p>We've already established there is an inordinate number of emails exchanged each day, which means the average person receives multiple emails every hour. Even so, email marketing is still one of the most important and effective ways for your business to connect with customers and build meaningful relationships.</p> \n<p>Since your team is sending emails to people outside your organization, putting digital credentials in employee email signatures drives brand awareness and validation from the moment an email is opened. When your employees' certifications are on display, they work alongside your company logo to reinforce your brand every time an email is sent, forwarded, or replied to.</p> \n<p>Likewise, encourage your external badge earners to add digital credentials to their professional email signatures, too. Credentials help them establish credibility from the moment they hit \"Send\", allows email recipients to instantly verify the digital badge, and helps them learn more about your products and organization in the process.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Hubspot%20Article_Email%20Example.png?width=381&amp;name=Hubspot%20Article_Email%20Example.png\" alt=\"Hubspot Article_Email Example\" width=\"381\" style=\"width: 381px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<h3>3. Online</h3> \n<p>As a marketer, driving quality traffic to your company's site is a core focus. It's the reason there's such importance placed on including backlinks to a website in emails, social media posts, and content.</p> \n<p>The beauty of digital credentials is they're meant to be seen and shared. Developing a dedicated landing page for your digital credentials where potential earners can see the badge associated with the skill is a great way to get visibility for your credentials and is a great place for new earners to start the trial or purchase process. The more people visiting the page, the more recognition you'll have for your initiative.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Hubspot%20Example_Online%20Landing%20Page.png?width=1172&amp;name=Hubspot%20Example_Online%20Landing%20Page.png\" alt=\"Hubspot Example_Online Landing Page\" width=\"1172\" style=\"width: 1172px;\"></p> \n<h3>4. Events</h3> \n<p>Events are a critical marketing initiative because they offer the opportunity to build relationships with key customers and prospects. In an increasingly digital world, many marketers believe face-to-face interactions at events are crucial to generating pipeline. In fact, <a href=\"https://www.marketingcharts.com/customer-centric/lead-generation-and-management-82291\">68% of B2B marketers</a> agree that live events help generate the most leads.</p> \n<p>Since events place a significant focus on generating brand awareness in a sea of industry solutions, you have to ensure your brand stays top-of-mind for attendees.</p> \n<p>Whether it's a job fair or conference, including digital badges at your booth is a great way to encourage conversation and spark questions about your organization's products and programs, as well as your commitment to employee development.</p> \n<p>The visual representation of competencies allows key audiences to see your expertise before they even engage with your team.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Hubspot%20Example_Event%20Flyer.png?width=541&amp;name=Hubspot%20Example_Event%20Flyer.png\" alt=\"Hubspot Example_Event Flyer\" width=\"541\" style=\"width: 541px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p>Today, having a great product or service is only half the battle. Making sure people know about your organization and how to engage with it is a huge challenge, but also a huge part of brand success. Creating brand awareness won't happen overnight. Using these ideas can help carve out your place in the market and help your brand stand out in no time.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fdigital-credentials&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" 21:48:25","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:25","title":"How to Design Content Remarketing Campaigns That Actually Work","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/design-content-remarketing-campaigns","description":"<p>You know content marketing works, so you've been plugging away at blog posts, ebooks, and other valuable, educational content for your potential customers.</p> \n<p>And people come -- they find your content in search results and in their social media feeds. But they may not fill out a form and become a lead right then and there. It's not always because they're not interested in your message -- so how do you recapture those viewers who left your site?</p> \n<p>Recapturing audience attention to turn lookers into leads is an effective marketing tactic, and if you're not doing it, you're leaving money on the table.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Let me outline for you the sections I'm going to cover in this post:</p> \n<ol> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/design-content-remarketing-campaigns#what-is-remarketing\">What the Heck is Remarketing?</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/design-content-remarketing-campaigns#what-is-gdn\">What Is the Google Display Network?</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/design-content-remarketing-campaigns#campaign-examples\">Remarketing Campaign Examples</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/design-content-remarketing-campaigns#set-up-remarketing-campaign\">How to Set Up a Remarketing Campaign</a></li> \n</ol> \n<a></a> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>What the Heck Is Remarketing?</h2> \n <p>At its core, remarketing is the process of tagging your site visitors and targeting them with content after they leave your site in an effort to reengage them and bring them back to your site.</p> \n</div> \n<p>Remarketing gives you the opportunity to appear in front of people who have already expressed an interest in your website. They could be checking their email, reading the news, watching a YouTube video… and there you are, with something new and awesome to show them. It could be a reminder to complete an action they had started, or a new piece of content to further a buying decision, and so on.</p> \n<p>Remarketing provides the opportunity to:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Turn bounced website visitors into leads.</li> \n <li>Increase brand recall (and thus increase branded searches).</li> \n <li>Increase repeat visitor rates and engagement.</li> \n <li>Increase the effectiveness of search engine optimization (SEO) and content marketing.</li> \n</ul> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" style=\"width: 650px;\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1811089655-png/Remarketing1.png?width=650&amp;name=Remarketing1.png\" width=\"650\" alt=\"a graphic illustrating all the users who visited your website vs. bringing them back to your website\" /></p> \n<p>A common stat in the industry is that <strong>96% of people who visit a website leave without completing the action the marketer would have liked them to take.</strong> Remarketing gives you a second chance to make that first impression (and even a third, and a fourth). We can't afford to be forgettable -- we have to make our content more <em>sticky</em>.</p> \n<p>Alright, so we understand both the problem and the opportunity. Now, let's dive into the solution.&nbsp;You're going to learn how to use remarketing strategies with the Google Display Network to dramatically increase the effectiveness of your inbound marketing efforts.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2><strong>What Is the Google Display Network?</strong></h2> \n<p>The Google Display Network is a group of websites where your Google display (banner) ads can appear. <br><br>More than 2 million sites are in the network, including heavily trafficked ones such as YouTube. Google estimates that the <a href=\"https://support.google.com/google-ads/answer/117120?hl=en\">GDN can reach 90% of people on the internet</a>. <br><br>Who you reach and how often will depend on your ad targeting (more on that later).</br></br></br></br></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1809803507-png/Remarketing2.png?width=600&amp;name=Remarketing2.png\" alt=\"graphic that shows google display network's reach in the US across millions of sites, videos, and devices including LinkedIn, CNN, lastfm, eHow, xe, howstuffworks, The New York Times, YouTube, Blogger, Gmail, Google Finance, and Google maps\" width=\"600\" /></p> \n<a></a> \n<h2><strong>Remarking Campaign Examples</strong></h2> \n<p>To further underscore the opportunity that remarketing has to offer, there are some really cool campaign types that you can dig into.</p> \n<h3>Online Activity</h3> \n<p>By far the most common remarketing tactic is creating an audience based on their behavior on your website. Your options here are virtually endless — with parameters such as by number of page views (indicating a high level of interest) or by which pages viewed (indicating intent).</p> \n<p>Here are some ideas for using this type of campaign:</p> \n<h4>Targeting by Buyer's Journey Stage</h4> \n<p>Your blog posts are earlier in the buyer's journey than other pages on your site. That means you'd match their intent with an ad that moves them further down their journey rather than one that sells. Targeting by topic or category-say you run a bakery. Why run general ads to audiences that landed on your wedding-related content? Instead, you'd target them with more personalized ads around wedding cakes and desserts.</p> \n<h4>Targeting by Intent</h4> \n<p>Aside from just topic, there's a lot you can learn from your audience's site behavior. For example, visiting a product page indicates interest, but not making it to checkout could mean a price objection or other friction. This means you need to sweeten the deal in some way (like a promo or discount).</p> \n<h4>Past Purchases</h4> \n<p>You can also target those that did make it through your purchasing process and target them with ads to earn an upsell.</p> \n<h3><strong>YouTube TrueView</strong></h3> \n<p>The human race spends billions of hours every month watching YouTube ads. You may have your own YouTube content, but perhaps your viewing metrics aren’t quite as high as you’d like them to be, or perhaps your users have no idea you have interesting video content to share.</p> \n<p>Using <a href=\"http://www.wordstream.com/blog/ws/2014/01/15/youtube-remarketing\">YouTube TrueView ads</a>, you can target your audiences as they are watching other videos on YouTube.</p> \n<p>Take the screenshot below, for example.&nbsp;I’m trying to watch a Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle video and it’s showing me an ad for a tourism company in Italy. Why? Because I was planning a trip to Florence at the time I took this screenshot, and they’re remarketing to me.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1811335425-png/Remarketing995.png?width=551&amp;name=Remarketing995.png\" width=\"551\" style=\"width: 551px; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"image ad in youtube video\" /></p> \n<p>The cool thing about TrueView videos is that you only pay if people view your video content. There’s no cost if the person clicks on the “skip ad” button. If you’re creating video content, why wouldn’t you pay a few bucks to promote it?</p> \n<h3>Video Views</h3> \n<p>Speaking of YouTube, your visitors don't even need to make it to your website in order for you to retarget them. If you have a solid YouTube presence, you can create an audience based on video views. If someone watched one of your videos, you can create a display campaign that shows them your ads even beyond the YouTube platform.</p> \n<h3><strong>Remarketing Lists for Search Ads (RLSA)</strong></h3> \n<p>Here’s another interesting but advanced thing you can do. It’s a little complicated, but I promise it's awesome. It’s called Remarking Lists for Search Ads.</p> \n<p>RLSA lets you target people in your audiences with customized ads when they perform searches for specific keywords on Google.&nbsp;</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1809994192-png/Remarketing998.png?width=522&amp;name=Remarketing998.png\" width=\"522\" style=\"width: 522px; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"graphic illustrating RLSA process: users visit your site, get added to your remarketing list, then you show them customized ads when they search on Google\" /></p> \n<p>Say, for example, someone visits your site. You tag them, and now they’re in one of your audiences.</p> \n<p>That person then searches for a competitor of yours. This probably means they’re doing some comparison shopping.</p> \n<p>Using RLSA, you can target that comparison shopper with a specific ad, like a 10% discount code or something similar. Knowing that the person visited specific pages on your site and is now performing specific searches, it’s possible to come up with very specific and compelling ad copy.</p> \n<h3>Bonus: Remarketing With Facebook</h3> \n<p>Noticeably absent from the GDN is Facebook, the other big player on the web, and that's because they have their own remarketing system through Facebook Custom Audiences.</p> \n<p>It works in much the same way — the difference being that ads are shown to users within the Facebook platform.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2><strong>How to Set Up a Remarketing Campaign With Google Ads</strong></h2> \n<p>Like I said earlier, using the GDN for remarketing gives you a great deal of reach. Generally, you can find your tagged site visitors on the network many times per day, several days per week, and across many different sites.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3><strong>1. Define your audience.</strong></h3> \n<p>One of your first steps in remarketing is to define the specific audience(s) you want to remarket to. For example, you could create an audience for people who visited your blog or for people who visited specific pages on your website, like your pricing page. This will enable you to reach out to<em> just</em> those people with offers and messaging to suit their interests.</p> \n<p>To define an audience, <a href=\"https://support.google.com/adwords/answer/2454064?hl=en\">create a new remarketing list</a> in Google Ad. Google will take care of setting all of the cookies; all<em> you</em> need to do is specify which website visitors to include or exclude from your audience.&nbsp;</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1809833607-png/Remarketing4.png?width=600&amp;name=Remarketing4.png\" alt=\"new remarketing list interface within google ads\" width=\"600\" /></p> \n<p>Segmenting different lists of users enables you to show different ads, depending on which section of your site they visited.</p> \n<p>A secondary benefit is that you can bid more aggressively to get more impressions and higher ad positions, and to get visitors to the higher value sections of your website. For example, your data might show that visitors to your pricing or product page are more valuable than your blog visitors.</p> \n<p>Another creative remarketing strategy for content marketers is to <a href=\"http://www.wordstream.com/blog/ws/2012/02/09/how-to-create-adwords-audiences\">define audience categories</a> in Google Ads based on the different post categories in your blog. If you already have a ton of blog content that is classified by topic, leverage those existing classifications in your remarketing audience definition strategy.</p> \n<h3><strong>3. Set audience membership duration.</strong></h3> \n<p>In remarketing, the audience membership duration is the number of days that you follow a user around with your ads. For example, if I set my audience membership duration to 60 days, then users who visit my site will see my ads for 60 days. You can test and tweak this number to see what's right for your audience.</p> \n<p>Ad fatigue is a real thing in every industry and across every medium: TV, radio, print … and, yes, display ads.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Now, I'd like to address a concern I've heard from some fellow marketers: that overly aggressive remarketing will make your prospective customer feel uncomfortable.&nbsp;Let's look at a few facts and see just how \"creepy\" remarketing really is.</p> According to \n<a href=\"https://kenshoo.com/blog/retargeting-stats/\">Kenshoo</a>, retargeting can lift ad engagement rates up to 400%, 60% of consumers are neutral about the topic of retargeting ads, and 25% say they actually like them. \n<a href=\"https://blog.wishpond.com/post/97225536354/infographic-7-incredible-retargeting-ad-stats\">Wishpond</a> reports that the average click-through rate for retargeted ads is 10 times that of a regular display ad, and retargeting can lead to a 726% lift in site visitation after four weeks of exposure. \n<p>So, be bold!&nbsp;People visited your site for a reason, and past browsing history is among the strongest predictors of future purchasing intent.&nbsp;It’s worth testing out remarketing with relatively higher impression caps and membership durations and seeing what happens. <strong>A</strong><strong>s long as your offers and messaging are on target and you're providing value, it's not creepy.&nbsp;</strong>I would suggest:</p> \n<ul> \n <li class=\"normalCxSpMiddle\">Try setting your audience membership duration to an amount equal to 3x your average sale cycle length.</li> \n <li class=\"normalCxSpMiddle\">If it typically takes an average of one week to go from first touch to sale, set the<strong> audience membership duration to three weeks.</strong></li> \n <li class=\"normalCxSpMiddle\">Don’t worry too much about impression caps. (Remember, more impressions means higher conversion rates. Consider <strong style=\"font-size: inherit;\"><em>rotating though multiple ads per campaign</em></strong> to combat ad fatigue.)</li> \n</ul> \n<h3><strong>3. Create a killer ad.</strong></h3> \n<p>Now that we’ve talked about defining an audience to remarket to, let's focus on how to create killer remarketing ads.</p> \n<h4><strong>Understand Ad Formats on the GDN</strong></h4> \n<p>There are several different display ad formats on the Google Display Network, some of which are shown below.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/google-display-ads-responsive-formats.jpg?width=600&amp;name=google-display-ads-responsive-formats.jpg\" alt=\"examples of google display ads responsive formats\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\"><a href=\"https://www.wordstream.com/blog/ws/2019/05/23/google-display-ads\">Image Source</a><br><br /></br></img></p> \n<table style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: table;\"> \n <tbody> \n  <tr style=\"height: 21px;\"> \n   <td style=\"height: 21px;\">Type</td> \n   <td style=\"height: 21px;\">Dimensions</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr style=\"height: 21px;\"> \n   <td style=\"height: 21px;\">Mobile</td> \n   <td style=\"height: 21px;\">300x250, 320x50, 320x100, 250x250, 200x200</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr style=\"height: 21px;\"> \n   <td style=\"height: 21px;\">Desktop</td> \n   <td style=\"height: 21px;\">300x250, 336x280, 728x90, 300x600, 160x600, 970x90, 468x60</td> \n  </tr> \n </tbody> \n</table> \n<p><br>Ad formats matter to marketers because of how the ad auction works. Different ad formats do not compete against each other for positioning, as shown in this screenshot:</br></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1811230125-png/Remarketing9.png?width=600&amp;name=Remarketing9.png\" alt=\"example webpage with multiple display ads: shows that different ad formats do not compete against each other but same format ads still do\" width=\"600\" /></p> \n<h4><strong>Write Copy That Resonates Emotionally</strong></h4> \n<p>According to <a href=\"https://www.neurosciencemarketing.com/blog/articles/emotional-ads-work-best.htm\">neurosciencemarketing.com</a>, an emotional approach in advertising is nearly twice as effective as a rational approach. The same emotions that draw people to your content will drive people to click on your ads.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>The key here is to create ads that resonate with users on an emotional level. Stay away from boring, plain, informational ads that look the same as every other ad out there. Instead, create ads that <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/emotion-marketing\">appeal to your audience on an emotional level</a>.</p> \n<p>Content marketers are uniquely qualified to become fabulous PPC marketers. Why?&nbsp;Because so much of the success and failure of PPC marketing relies on the creativity of your ads.</p> \n<p>For example,&nbsp;look at these ads for a search of “Big Data Solutions” -- the ads are essentially all the same:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" style=\"width: 650px;\" title=\"Remarketing992\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1811305370-png/Remarketing992.png?width=650&amp;name=Remarketing992.png\" width=\"650\" alt=\"ads for &quot;big data solutions&quot; where none of the competing advertisers have unique ad headlines\" /></p> \n<p>Content marketers, on the other hand, tend to have a few creative bones in their bodies. I call this a&nbsp;<a href=\"http://www.wordstream.com/blog/ws/2014/01/29/hacking-adwords\">Google Ads Jackpot</a>&nbsp;because it reminds me of hitting a row of lucky 7s in Vegas -- I just hit a Big Data Solutions jackpot! If you can come up with an emotionally charged, totally different and stand-out ad,&nbsp;you can blow away the competition.</p> \n<h3><strong>4. Perform ongoing CTR optimization.</strong></h3> \n<p>Google doesn’t make money by showing ads no one clicks on, so it makes sense for them to show ads that are more likely to get clicks. They use&nbsp;an algorithm called&nbsp;<a href=\"http://www.wordstream.com/quality-score\">Quality Score</a>&nbsp;to determine which ads to show, what position each will display in, and how much to charge the advertiser for each ad click.</p> \n<p>To provide an incentive for advertisers to create great ads, they give out huge discounts for ads with high clickthrough rates… and dish out huge penalties for ads with low clickthrough rates.</p> \n<p>This all sounds good in theory, but how do you create an ad with high clickthrough rate?</p> \n<h4><strong>1. Send people to your high-value offers.&nbsp;</strong></h4> \n<p>What should you be featuring in your image ads? The most common tactic is to simply promote your highest value offers, like a free trial of your product, a request for a demo, etc. This is my top-performing ad:&nbsp;</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1809918942-png/Remarketing97.png?width=463&amp;name=Remarketing97.png\" alt=\"remarketing ad from wordstream with a puppy on it that says &quot;my dog ate my ppc! no more excuses for poor results&quot;\" width=\"463\" style=\"width: 463px; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<p>Of course it has a cute puppy. How could it not? Make people&nbsp;love your ads, not dread them.</p> \n<h4><strong>2.</strong>&nbsp;<strong>Do a conversion path analysis.</strong></h4> \n<p>The goal here is to figure out which pages on your site, if visited during a user’s session, result in a much higher probability of the user converting to a lead or a sale. For example, the highest converting page on your site could be your product overview page.&nbsp;Come up with a list like this one and target those pages in your remarketing audience.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1809918967-png/Remarketing98.png?width=444&amp;name=Remarketing98.png\" alt=\"excel spreadsheet showing different pages and their conversion rates, indicating the top converting pages are ideal for remarketing\" width=\"444\" style=\"width: 444px; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<h4>3. Send people to your best content.</h4> \n<p>Check out this ad from my colleague <a href=\"http://www.linkedin.com/in/aimclear\">Marty Weintraub</a> at AimClear, which sends anyone who clicks to his PPC analyses.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\" title=\"Remarketing99\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-1808175089-png/Remarketing99.png?width=600&amp;name=Remarketing99.png\" alt=\"remarketing ad at the top of a page that says &quot;10 kevlar ppc analyses and process for a bulletproof account&quot;\" width=\"600\" /></p> \n<p>But how do you know what content to feature in your ads?</p> \n<h4><strong>4. Analyze social shares on your blog content. </strong></h4> \n<p>If you analyze your blog content, what you’ll usually find is that around 5% of your pages generate half of the shares on social media.</p> \n<p>For example, I analyzed all of the articles on one business blog over the last year and found that on average, a typical article gets several hundred shares on social media. However, the top 5% of articles gets tens of thousands of social shares.&nbsp;Not surprisingly, we found that the same stories that work well on social media also tend to do very well as featured content within ads.</p> \n<h3><strong>5. Get strategic with bid management.</strong></h3> \n<p>Now that you have remarketing audiences and ads down to a science, let's turn our attention to bid management strategies.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Remember, in PPC marketing, you have to pay for each click. The advertiser specifies a maximum cost per click that they’re willing to pay, but the key here is not to buy every possible click.&nbsp;Rather, you want to be super picky and just cherry-pick the clicks that are the most relevant to your business. The way to do this is through bid management.</p> \n<p>It doesn’t make any sense to remarket ads to everyone in your audience. Why? Because not everyone who visits your website is a qualified buyer.</p> \n<p>With Google Ads, you can overlay user demographic information on top of your remarketing audiences to find the needles in the haystack. For example, someone from Zimbabwe could visit your site -- but they can't convert if you can't ship there.</p> \n<p>Here’s when it comes in handy to know a thing or two about your <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/make-my-persona\">target customer persona</a>.</p> \n<ul> \n <li>What are the ages?</li> \n <li>Parental status?</li> \n <li>Where do they live?</li> \n <li>Gender?</li> \n <li>What time do they search for your products?</li> \n <li>What is their income?</li> \n</ul> \n<p>You can be very picky, and <em>just</em> bid for the people in your audience who also meet your demographic filters.</p> \n<p>You've done your research, you know your topic, you have something interesting and entertaining to say -- but sometimes you need that extra push. As individuals and brands have become publishers, the game has been upped big time. Competition is fierce.</p> \n<p>With remarketing, we at WordStream increased our repeat visitors by 50%, tripled our average time on site, and saw a huge increase in direct visits to our site.</p> \n<p>In short, content remarketing enabled us to maximize the value of every piece of content we put out. We were able to get each piece in front of the audience with the most intent, at the right time, and via the right channels.</p> \n<p>You can achieve this kind of success too with a killer remarketing campaign and the right advertising plan.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in October 2014 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<img
