21:48:26","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","title":"The 17 Best Resume Templates for Every Type of Professional","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-resume-templates","description":"<p>While an eye-catching resume alone probably won't land you your dream gig, it doesn't hurt to put a little extra effort into how you present yourself on paper.</p>  \n<p>The right resume design speaks to your individual skills and personality, and can propel your application to the top of the stack. But finding a cool design that also fits your professional identity can be a major hassle — and applying for jobs is already hard enough.</p> \n<p>We've scoured the web for some of the best resume templates to help you stand out in a sea of Times New Roman and crowded copy.</p> \n<p>You'll want to steal each and every one of these creative resume templates — and the good news is: You can! These generous designers have made their work available for free download. Read on to check them out and find a great fit for your next job application.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Resume%20Template%201-1.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=Resume%20Template%201-1.jpg\" alt=\"free editable resume word pdf template\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/marketing-resume-templates?hubs_post-cta=imagesir&amp;hubs_signup-url=blog.hubspot.com/marketing/resume-templates-word&amp;hubs_signup-cta=null\" style=\"text-align: center; text-decoration: none; font-weight: 600; margin: 0px; border: 0px;\"><em style=\"font-style: italic; font-weight: inherit; margin: 0px; border: 0px;\">Download a free, editable resume template.</em></a></p> \n<p>We've organized them by the type of candidate they're best for.</p> \n<h2>The 17 Best Resume Templates for Every Type of Professional</h2> \n<h3>Best for Creatives</h3> \n<p><em>These templates emphasize the design, color, and typography skills that creatives need to show from the get-go.</em></p> \n<h4>1. Resume Template with a Photo Background</h4> \n<p>This template from Polish designer <a href=\"http://tydziennik.pl/\">Patryk Korycki</a> is perfect for photographers, graphic designers, and other creatives looking to showcase a sample of their best work. The template can be downloaded <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/28413891/Free-Minimalistic-ResumeCV-Illustrator\">here</a> for free.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_04.png\"> \n<h4>2. Monochromatic and Retro Resume Template</h4> \n<p>This design from freelancer <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/Fay-Zodiac\">Fay Zodiac</a> is a whimsical take on traditional resumes. The retro typography adds a playful element, while the boxy layout keeps everything from looking too busy or crowded. You can download this resume design <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/22623583/FREE-Resume-Template\">here</a> for free.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_13.png?width=500&amp;name=resume_template_13.png\" alt=\"Typography resume template for illustrators and graphic designers\" title=\"Typography resume template for illustrators and graphic designers\" width=\"500\" style=\"width: 500px;\"> \n<h4>3. Vibrant and Visual Resume Template</h4> \n<p><a href=\"http://alessiacurcio.dk/\">Alessia Curcio</a>, a Copenhagen-based designer, gives us a perfect example of how to incorporate kaleidoscopic color without going over the top. Infographic-inspired elements help clearly display work experience and skills with minimal text. Download Curcio's free template <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/23923945/Infographic-resume-vol2\">here</a>.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_15.jpg?width=600&amp;name=resume_template_15.jpg\" alt=\"Resume template with colorful header and footer\" title=\"Resume template with colorful header and footer\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px;\"> \n<h4>4. Infographic Style Resume Template</h4> \n<p>Created by digital art director and freelance designer <a href=\"http://www.justcreativeideas.com/\">Fernando Báez</a>, this unique, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/infographic-resume\">infographic-inspired resume</a> template helps you organize your work experience and skills into a minimal visual layout. Báez has made the template available for free download <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/8477535/Freebie-Vertical-Resume-Template\">here</a>.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_01.png?width=600&amp;name=resume_template_01.png\" alt=\"Resume template formatted like an infographic\" title=\"Resume template formatted like an infographic\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px;\"> \n<h3>Best for Freelancers</h3> \n<p><em>These templates emphasize the headshot photo for freelancers who might not meet their employers in person, and need substantial text space and a visual to offer something memorable.</em></p> \n<h4>5. Resume Template with a Simple Color Accent</h4> \n<p>Adding color to a resume might seem intimidating at first — especially if you're applying to a more traditional workplace — but a few sophisticated pops of color can add some interest without compromising on professionalism.</p> \n<p>This template from designer <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/eogawac\">Eduardo Ogawa</a> uses bright accents to spice up the traditional layout. You can download it for free <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/42485071/Free-Resume-Template\">here</a>.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_03.png?width=500&amp;name=resume_template_03.png\" alt=\"Resume template with photo space on the top right\" title=\"Resume template with photo space on the top right\" width=\"500\" style=\"width: 500px;\"> \n<h4>6. Bold Classic Resume Template</h4> \n<p>If you're looking for a more traditional resume template that still makes a bold impression, check out this creation from Finish designer <a href=\"http://creativebooster.net/\">Mats-Peter Forss</a>. The template includes space for a headshot, and is available for free download <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/30805663/Free-Resume-Template-for-Word-Photoshop-Illustrator\">here</a>.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_02.png?width=600&amp;name=resume_template_02.png\" alt=\"Creative resume template with vertical header and space for a headshot photo\" title=\"Creative resume template with vertical header and space for a headshot photo\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px;\"> \n<h4>7. Resume Template with Pops of Primary Colors</h4> \n<p>Proof that color can be professional, this template boasts a compact, sophisticated layout and bright, colorful accents. It also has room for a substantial summary. Designer <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/davisai\">David Gómez</a> actually uses this resume template himself, and he's been generous enough to share it for free download <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/28465321/Free-resume-template\">here</a>.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_07.png?width=600&amp;name=resume_template_07.png\" alt=\"Colorful resume template with blue primary font color\" title=\"Colorful resume template with blue primary font color\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px;\"> \n<h3>Best for Recent Graduates</h3> \n<p><em>These templates make great use of empty space — perfect for students who are still building experience — through eye-catching designs that help these candidates make a splash in their industry.</em></p> \n<h4>8. Graphic and Adventurous Resume Template</h4> \n<p>This is not a resume template for wallflowers. The folks at <a href=\"https://beta2.createer.com/\">Createer</a> whipped up this daring design as part of a free resume template pack, which you can check out <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/28945909/Free-Resume-Template-Pack\">here</a>.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_05.png\"> \n<h4>9. Resume Template with an Unexpected Format</h4> \n<p>If you want to <i>really</i> stand out in a crowded applicant pool, then this resume is definitely for you. Graphic designer and freelance photographer <a href=\"http://www.paolopettigiani.com/\">Paolo Pettigiani</a> created this bold template for his own professional use, but has made it available for free download <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/24416019/Self-Promotion-Free-CV\">here</a>.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_12.png\"> \n<h4>10. Center-Aligned Resume Template</h4> \n<p>If you want to mix up your resume format without going too crazy, try a center-aligned layout, like this clean, modern design by <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/Zohanhabib\">Zohan Habib</a>. The custom icons and colored border add a nice creative touch. This template is available for free download <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/28111401/Laconique-Resume-Template\">here</a>.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_14.png\"> \n<h3>Best for Executive/Upper-Level Professionals</h3> \n<p><em>These templates offer ample real estate for candidates to express their deep experience in the plain but formal manner that many employers expect.</em></p> \n<h4>11. Black and White Resume Template</h4> \n<p>Running low on colored ink? Check out this minimal black and white template from editorial designer <a href=\"http://broluthfi.co/\">Bro Luthfi</a>. The simple design is anything but boring, and includes a set of custom icons to add some visual interest. You can download the free template <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/16124595/FREE-Simple-Resume\">here</a>.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_08.jpg?width=600&amp;name=resume_template_08.jpg\" alt=\"Black and white resume template\" title=\"Black and white resume template\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px;\"> \n<h4>12. Clean and Modern Resume Template</h4> \n<p>Your resume is really your first impression with a potential employer, and this template design from the team at <a href=\"https://creativemarket.com/GoaShape?u=GoaShape\">GoaShape</a> is modern without being too edgy.</p> \n<p>The template pack includes a two-page resume layout and cover letter design, and can be downloaded for free <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/41819029/Unique-Resume-CV-Template-Pages-Word\">here</a>.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_11.png?width=600&amp;name=resume_template_11.png\" alt=\"Resume and cover letter template\" title=\"Resume and cover letter template\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px;\"> \n<h4>13. Resume Template with Subtle Color Scheme</h4> \n<p>Beirut-based designer <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/'https://www.behance.net/blugraphic&quot;\">Wassim Awadallah</a> serves up a simple, two-page resume template for more advanced professionals.</p> \n<p>Displaying the headshot and contact information on the cover leaves plenty of room on the second page to document all your career highlights and accomplishments. Download the template for free <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/38750701/Minimal-Advanced-Resume-Template\">here</a>.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_06.png?width=600&amp;name=resume_template_06.png\" alt=\"Best two-page resume template with cover page\" title=\"Best two-page resume template with cover page\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px;\"> \n<h3>Best for People Changing Careers</h3> \n<p><em>These templates help those who are changing industries organize their experience by skill, rather than employer. Sections can be customized to the candidate who needs to show how his/her background can transfer.</em></p> \n<h4>14. Resume Template with an Organized Use of Space</h4> \n<p>When you're trying to crunch years of work experience and a laundry list of skills onto a single sheet of paper, things tend to get crowded quickly. This template from designer <a href=\"http://www.helsinkibranding.com/\">Tina Von Helsinki </a> invites you to simplify.</p> \n<p>The distinct sections highlight different aspects of your qualifications — eliminating anything extraneous and putting the focus on what matters to your potential employers the most. Download the template <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/30716433/Free-Resume-CV-vol2\">here</a>.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_09.png?width=500&amp;name=resume_template_09.png\" alt=\"Minimalist resume template\" title=\"Minimalist resume template\" width=\"500\" style=\"width: 500px;\"> \n<h4>15. Playful and Professional Resume Template</h4> \n<p>Italian designer <a href=\"http://martinacavalieri.name/\">Martina Cavalieri</a> created this resume template with a set of 16 custom icons to highlight your interests and skills. The modern layout is anchored by a bold two-toned border: just enough color to help your resume stand out in the pile. Cavalieri offers this template for free download <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/33273657/Free-CV-and-icons-Its-time-to-change\">here</a>.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_10.png\"> \n<h3>Best for Hardcore Marketers</h3> \n<p><em>We couldn't help ourselves. Although every template in this blog post can work for marketers, the templates below are perfect for those who love to brand themselves.</em></p> \n<h4>16. Heavy Header Resume Template</h4> \n<p>\"Hey, you!\" That's what I think of when I see this flashy yet classy template. Made by designer <a href=\"http://www.cursiveq.com/about/\">Mike Bradshaw</a>, the resume features a variety of sections without seeming too cluttered.</p> \n<p>Long first or last names might look overwhelming with this header, but it certainly does a good job conveying a breadth of information. Download it for free <a href=\"http://www.cursiveq.com/designs/modern-swiss-style-resume-cv-psd-template/\">here</a>.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/swiss-resume-template.jpg?width=600&amp;name=swiss-resume-template.jpg\" alt=\"Creative resume template with large, red header\" title=\"Creative resume template with large, red header\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px;\"></p> \n<h4>17. Profile Style Resume Template</h4> \n<p>This last resume was actually designed by the company, <a href=\"https://www.hloom.com/\">Hloom</a>, and is rather plain. But there's something so familiar about it: The resume header looks like a Facebook profile!</p> \n<p>While Hloom suggests the lengthy skills section could make this template appealing to the IT industry, we think it is equally perfect for digital marketers — especially those who work in social media. Download it for free <a href=\"https://www.hloom.com/get/glimmer/\">here</a>.</p> \n<p><img gh/myreaderx12/cdn16@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-34-367_f91f094b537923d1.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_14.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn20@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-36-284_1c508a4feb5945e7.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_08.jpg?width=600&name=resume_template_08.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn96@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-30-023_2c3bed4db56663a3.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_11.png?width=600&name=resume_template_11.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn31@2020_3/2020/08/16/13-48-33-059_1ca2e0001c00aa89.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_06.png?width=600&name=resume_template_06.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx20/cdn79@2020_2/2020/08/16/13-48-28-793_befbcfc92db89e5e.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_09.png?width=500&name=resume_template_09.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn39@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-29-697_d9ff14fb687e2957.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/resume_template_10.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn100@2020_2/2020/08/16/13-48-35-610_96e1b43819786ab5.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/swiss-resume-template.jpg?width=600&name=swiss-resume-template.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn84@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-32-568_9fc8b47be35100ce.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/profile-resume-template.png?width=480&name=profile-resume-template.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn63@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-35-848_f1f4ce7414afdebc.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fbest-resume-templates&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn7@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-33-415_947f9e84854215f2.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:24","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:24","title":"Writing for SEO: How to Write Blogs That Rank on Page 1 of Google","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/blogging-for-seo","description":"<p>If you've ever written a blog post before, you know how much time they can take.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>From topic selection, to gathering research, to writing the post and pressing \"Publish,\" the process often demands hours.</p> \n<p>That's why, if your post <em>doesn't</em> earn the traffic you expected, it can be a major letdown. All that work that goes into a post for less-than-stellar engagement is, no doubt, one of the most frustrating experiences.</p> \n<p>Fortunately, there's a way to combat low traffic and bring eyes to your writing: search engine optimization. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/seo\"><span>SEO</span></a> is a language that speaks specifically to search engines like Google to tell it your post deserves to be at the top of search engine results pages (SERPs).</p> \n<p>As marketers, we're always aiming to write content that'll rank highly on Google, and SEO is the bridge that'll help you get there.</p> \n<p>Of course, that begs the question: How do you write in SEO's language?</p> \n<p>For that, don't worry — we've got you covered. In this post, we're going to dive into 13 ways you can master writing for that high ranking your content deserves.</p> \n<p>Ready to get started?</p> \n<h3>1. Use headings to your benefit.</h3> \n<p>Headers tell Google what different sections of your blog article will be about. In this post, for example, the header, \"How To Write Blog Posts for SEO,\" tells the search engine what this section is about.</p> \n<p>Users who type search queries like, \"writing for SEO\" into Google will likely come across this post because of what the header tells Google. Ultimately, search engines are going to look at <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/blog-search-engine-optimization?_ga=2.256326411.1692937882.1597029621-940436819.1565181751\"><span>headers and snippets before they look at body text</span></a>.</p> \n<p>Think of Google as a reader who is skimming your blog. They're going to focus on the main ideas — and that's what headers, like H2s and H3s, display. Use headers to accurately convey the main idea of your section, but make sure each header uses accurate, high-intent keywords. When you use the right keywords (using <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/22842/4-helpful-tools-for-identifying-the-right-keywords.aspx?_ga=2.256326411.1692937882.1597029621-940436819.1565181751\"><span>keyword research tools</span></a>) you have a much higher chance of helping your post rank on the first page.</p> \n<h3>2. Take advantage of featured snippets.</h3> \n<p>According to <a href=\"https://support.google.com/websearch/answer/9351707?p=featured_snippets&amp;hl=en&amp;visit_id=637322668994927457-279137339&amp;rd=1\"><span>Google</span></a>, \"Featured snippets come from web search listings. Google's automated systems determine whether a page would make a good featured snippet to highlight for a specific search request.\"</p> \n<p>Featured snippets on Google are the most direct answers to search queries. For instance, if I were to search, \"How do you write a blog post?\", Google might use a featured snippet to show the most sufficient answer:</p> \n<p><span style=\"border: none;\"><img src=\"https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/jkrLX_FCneOwRvR527KfiHOfFW4ZYp15QeyUkS8X363Wr52Q5NKHlUw2JCvyFVAGwgi7k5CTIka7eKnNWO7XNaIHBbzMknV1lBsQCiE5ogQZdW0Yw0y1EGJbrB58OcHM8C1tY8IE\" width=\"624\" height=\"436\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"Example of a featured snippet on Google.\" /></span></p> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-featured-snippet-box?_ga=2.256326411.1692937882.1597029621-940436819.1565181751\"><span>To earn a featured snippet</span></a> on Google, you'll want to answer the questions readers might have when they come to your blog post. For instance, if the search term is \"how should I write a blog post?\", answer that question with a list, starting with \"How to Write A Blog Post\" as the header, accompanied by a list of items that are relevant and actionable.</p> \n<p>If you're wondering how to make list items actionable, a good rule of thumb is to write complete sentences and start each sentence with a verb, like \"Write\", \"Research\", \"Create\". Additionally, make sure each sentence answers the question or challenge. For definitions, or <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/winning-googles-featured-snippet?_ga=2.210163477.1692937882.1597029621-940436819.1565181751\"><span>paragraph snippets</span></a>, make sure they're succinct, but give enough background to explain the word or phrase.</p> \n<h3>3. Write to answer questions for customers.</h3> \n<p>One of the reasons we write blog posts is to diversify the content on our website. Another reason is to boost the credibility of our business. But if \"to solve for your audience\" isn't in your list of reasons, you may be losing out on key SEO opportunities.</p> \n<p>Google answers countless questions a day. For instance, I must've Googled about five questions in the last hour alone. When you frame posts to answer the queries of your audience, Google will see that and push your post to a higher page.</p> \n<p>Earlier, we talked about the bells and whistles you can add to posts to boost rankings. But, additionally, you'll want to ensure the content you're beefing up is also working towards that goal.</p> \n<p>If you're stuck on trying to figure out what your audience is asking, you'll want to perform keyword research. Sites like <a href=\"http://ahrefs.com/\"><span>Ahrefs</span></a> and <a href=\"http://woorank.com/\"><span>Woorank</span></a> crawl search engines for popular search queries. To organize the process, create different topic clusters to write about, such as \"Instagram Marketing,\" \"LinkedIn Advertising\" — subjects you can dive into that provide value to your audience.</p> \n<p>Still stuck on keywords? Don't worry — this <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-do-keyword-research-ht?_ga=2.210163477.1692937882.1597029621-940436819.1565181751\"><span>keyword research guide is perfect for beginners.</span></a></p> \n<h3>4. Use meta descriptions to your advantage.</h3> \n<p>Are you adding meta descriptions to your post? If your answer is \"No,\" then you're probably not giving your post the most exposure possible. Let's get into why they're important.</p> \n<p>By now, we've talked about a couple of the ways a blog post can communicate with Google: with headers, keywords, and snippets. However, that's not an exhaustive list.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/meta-descriptions?_ga=2.210163477.1692937882.1597029621-940436819.1565181751\"><span>Meta descriptions</span></a> is another method Google leverages when ranking search results. Meta descriptions are the 1-3 sentence descriptions you'll find underneath the title of a result.</p> \n<p><span style=\"border: none;\"><img src=\"https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/SthW36UwXSSgw6xA9MsSlcduXxbbMVKP3QpXTdUdc1KGMa4pqGAvSipqTkuL-TZICne4Dr-WXlVVEDagqYlDYavLLIPJEzesocOU6Gy9_qEHPbWEGmvwB6vIZJmd5zRmxy0YbxCg\" width=\"624\" height=\"227\" alt=\"Example of a meta description on Google.\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" /></span></p> \n<p>Use meta descriptions to sum up what your post is about. Remember to keep it short, use keywords, and make sure it's engaging. After all, there are going to be loads of posts similar to yours, aiming to rank at #1. You're going to want yours to stand out above the rest.</p> \n<p>Most blogging software have meta description boxes built into the toolbar or post formatting options, so you won't have to look far to use the function. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/?_ga=2.216912790.1692937882.1597029621-940436819.1565181751\"><span>HubSpot</span></a> and <a href=\"https://wordpress.com/\"><span>WordPress</span></a>, for example, point out where to add meta descriptions in the post editor.</p> \n<h3>5. Add alt text to images.</h3> \n<p>With any image you add to your post — whether it be the featured image or a body text one — you'll want to add alt text. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/32567/a-marketer-s-guide-to-optimizing-images-for-google-search.aspx?_ga=2.216912790.1692937882.1597029621-940436819.1565181751\"><span>Alt text describes what's happening</span></a> in the photo. Think of it as a closed caption for images.</p> \n<p>Alt text helps Google, as well as those who are visually impaired, understand why the photo is in your post. This improves your article's rank and accessibility, making it more shareable.</p> \n<p>For instance, if you include an infographic about audience segmentation, the alt text should read something like, \"A helpful infographic that explains audience segmentation.\" Notice how this sentence uses keywords to appeal to Google even further.</p> \n<p>Now let's say you're using a stock image as a featured photo, but it doesn't necessarily depict anything that relates to your post's content. For instance, let's say your topic is click-through rate, and this is your featured image:</p> \n<p><span style=\"border: none;\"><img src=\"https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/2jNZPSwpDQmCpp93qSsfmJzrztmQR8rQSjoBxLZDUz6vQLjPKBNCkbd2_njQNqt5lVzCZPFEV70MJmreYxiRHjUSU8yFvmJI6ZIhHHe1Kt5gKjwFk6ZbBvVM1-rC_pfTdREJUSih\" width=\"624\" height=\"416\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"A marketing team discusses audience segmentation strategy.\" /></span></p> \n<p>This doesn't really have anything to do with audience segments, right? But what you can do to remedy the situation is to make a scenario. For instance, \"A marketing team discusses audience segmentation strategy.\"</p> \n<p>This alt text uses keywords to describe a situation that fits into the theme of the post. That way, your image doesn't bring down the ranking of your post, but works towards improving where it ranks. If Google sees alt text, it's another box checked for a high position on SERPs.</p> \n<h3>6. Don't limit keywords to the body of your post.</h3> \n<p>Ultimately, keywords should be used in nearly every part of your blog. We've talked a little about where keywords can be included in your post: snippets, photos, and headers, for example.</p> \n<p>Keywords are so powerful because they're the jumping off point for SERPs. Google will always take what browsers type into the search bar and search for web pages with those exact words. So it's important to make sure every element, from the post title, to the calls-to-action, relate to your keywords.</p> \n<p>That said, it's also important not to keyword stuff your post. The goal is to make your page fully optimized, not overbearing. Find natural fits for keyword additions, but don't force them so your content is illegible.</p> \n<p>For example, if your keywords are \"account based marketing,\" \"startups,\" and \"sales,\" your meta description <em>shouldn't</em> be something like:</p> \n<p>\"Sales for account based marketing startups.\"</p> \n<p>Instead, try focusing on one or two phrases to make the description more natural:</p> \n<p>\"Are you looking for killer strategies to boost your account-based marketing game? Find out our surefire secrets in this post.\"</p> \n<p>That way, you're still using keywords, but you're not oversaturating the post to the point where it's illegible. Remember, even though Google is a search engine, it still has to comprehend your post in order to recommend it to website browsers. Additionally, a reader's experience will determine how well your posts rank. If readers bounce from your webpage because it's confusing to them, that will signal to Google that your post isn't good enough to rank.</p> \n<h3>7. Identify highly-effective keywords when looking for post ideas.</h3> \n<p>Google handles <a href=\"http://www.internetlivestats.com/google-search-statistics/\">over 40,000 search queries</a> a second. Staggering, right? If you want to cut through search result clutter and outrank your competitors, you need to target the specific keywords and phrases your potential customers are searching. How else will they find your content and website?</p> \n<p>To identify those hot keywords, head on over to the social platforms your target audience frequents and see what’s trending. Pay close attention to the exact phrases they use and monitor popular industry terms and topics.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.google.com/trends/\">Google Trends</a> can also give you a feel for what keywords are popular at any given time. If you see searches are steadily declining over time for a specific keyword, you know that’s probably not the right keyword to target for your marketing and vice versa for increasing trends.</p> \n<p>If you’re ever running low on keyword ideas, get inspiration from your competition. Use tools to see what keywords they’re currently ranking for — if these keywords are relevant to your business, consider using them too! <a href=\"https://www.semrush.com/\">SEMRush</a> lets you enter a competitor and see the keywords they’re ranking for, their position in search results, traffic received for that keyword and other key metrics.</p> \n<p>Keep in mind that the most obvious keywords aren’t always the best keywords. Searchers tend to use very specific “long-tail” keywords, keyword phrases and questions when they’re looking for something.</p> \n<p>Long-tail keywords comprise up to <a href=\"https://www.hittail.com/blog/the-hidden-value-of-long-tail-seo\">70% of all search traffic</a> and can unlock the door to successful SEO. When <a href=\"http://www.wpbeginner.com/\">WPBeginner</a>, the largest WordPress resource site for WordPress beginners, adopted a long-tail SEO strategy, they increased their organic search traffic by <a href=\"http://www.wpbeginner.com/wp-tutorials/how-we-increased-our-organic-search-traffic-by-using-hittail/\">20% in just two months</a>!</p> \n<p>Because you face fierce competition for shorter, more general keywords, you often have a better chance of ranking in the top results for long-tail keywords. And, long-tail keywords allow you to zero in on higher quality website traffic that often knows what they’re looking for and may be farther along in the buyer’s journey.</p> \n<p>Once you’ve done your research and built a list of what you think are the most valuable, relevant keywords, plug them into a keyword research tool like Google’s <a href=\"https://adwords.google.com/KeywordPlanner\">Keyword Planner</a>, <a href=\"https://moz.com/products/pro/keyword-explorer\">Moz’s Keyword Explorer</a>, <a href=\"https://keywordseverywhere.com/ubersuggest.html\">Ubersuggest</a>, <a href=\"http://keywordtool.io/\">Keyword Tool</a> and so on. Many keyword research tools give you the monthly volume for any given keyword. Test out different keyword tools — marketers are drawn to different ones for different reasons.</p> \n<p>Depending on your business or industry (or budget or bandwidth for SEO efforts), it may be important to rank for high competition, short tail keywords. Still, try to also optimize for a healthy dose of long-tail keywords that are high in search volume but low in competition. You may find it’s much easier to rank for these words.</p> \n<p>Remember that your focus keywords will evolve over time as trends shift, terminology changes or your product/service line changes. Be sure to conduct keyword research periodically to ensure you’re still focusing on the right keywords for your target audience and not missing out on vital ranking opportunities.</p> \n<h3>8. Naturally integrate those keywords throughout your posts.</h3> \n<p>Once you’ve decided on a list of target keywords, it’s time to write a blog post focused on one of these keywords. Brainstorm blog topics with your team and decide on a topic that will entice and engage your target audience.</p> \n<p>Keep your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33491/Everything-Marketers-Need-to-Research-Create-Detailed-Buyer-Personas-Template.aspx\">buyer personas</a>, their motivations, challenges, interests, etc. in mind throughout the brainstorming process. Choose a topic that will <a href=\"http://experience.stratusinteractive.com/blog/how-to-create-an-emotional-connection-with-prospects-to-turn-them-into-customers\">emotionally resonate</a> with your potential customers and their needs, desires or pains.</p> \n<p>As you write your blog, your keyword and natural variations should be regularly interspersed throughout the post. Your primary keyword should appear in these key places:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/blogging-for-seo#BlogPostTitle\">Title</a></li> \n <li>Headings and subheadings</li> \n <li>URL if possible</li> \n <li>Image alt text (search engines can’t read images)</li> \n <li>Meta description</li> \n <li>Throughout the content</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Remember that you’re writing for humans, not search engines. Focus on engaging readers with a natural writing style that takes their needs and interests into account.</p> \n<h3>9. Link to influential websites.</h3> \n<p>As you build out your blog post, don’t be afraid to link to other articles or blogs.</p> \n<p>Linking to applicable and reputable websites not only offers blog readers additional reading material to expand their knowledge, but it also shows Google and other search engines that you’ve done your research. And the blogger or writer may even return the favor and link to your site.</p> \n<p>Nothing strengthens a blog post like hard-to-argue-with, research-backed statistics from influential websites. Compelling stats help you build a more convincing and concrete argument that will get your readers thinking (especially when they’re from trustworthy sites they know and love).</p> \n<h3>10. Aim for scannable, longer posts.</h3> \n<p>In an age of short attention spans (<a href=\"http://time.com/3858309/attention-spans-goldfish/\">average of 8 seconds for humans</a>), you would think shorter blog posts are the way to go. But search engines actually prefer longer, in-depth blog posts.</p> \n<p>The longer your blog post, the greater its chance of appearing in the top search engine results. <a href=\"http://blog.serpiq.com/how-important-is-content-length-why-data-driven-seo-trumps-guru-opinions/\">SerpIQ found</a> that the 10th position pages have 400 fewer words than 1st position pages. Longer posts will rank more easily for your target keyword.</p> \n<p>Think about it: the more content on the page, the more clues search engines have to figure out what your blog is about. We recommend writing a minimum of <a href=\"https://yoast.com/blog-post-length/\">300 words per blog post</a>. This length gives search engines plenty of keywords and text to crawl and helps them understand what your blog is about.</p> \n<p>The downside to longer blogs is that they may scare off your readers. We live in a world of skimmers and scanners. In a heat map analysis, CoSchedule learned that <a href=\"http://coschedule.com/blog/read-your-content/\">only 10-20% of their readers</a> were making it to the bottom of their posts. So, the million dollar question is, how can longer blog posts appeal to today’s online readers?</p> \n<p>You can write <a href=\"http://experience.stratusinteractive.com/blog/scannable-content-your-key-to-writing-successful-blogs\">scannable</a>, readable blog posts that hook online readers by tightening up your sentences and paragraphs. Turn a long-winded sentence into two. Keep your paragraphs to 2-3 sentences max.</p> \n<p>Also, take full advantage of bulleted lists and subheadings that grab reader’s attention. By following these tactics, you’ll create blogs that are easier to read (especially on a mobile device!) and less intimidating to the scanner’s eye.</p> \n<h3>11. Internally link words or phrases to other posts on your site.</h3> \n<p>Linking to other pages or blog posts on your website helps search engines crawl your website and create a more accurate sitemap. It also helps your audience discover more of your content and get to know you as a trustworthy, credible source of information.</p> \n<p>Internal links to other valuable content keep users on your site longer, reducing bounce rate and increasing your potential for a conversion (and isn’t that what it’s all about?).</p> \n<p>When linking to any pages on your website, or even outside sources, use natural language for your anchor text. Avoid using spammy or generic text such as “top-rated cheap laptops” or “click here.”</p> \n<p>Instead, use descriptive keywords that give readers a sense of what they will find when they click on the hyperlink, such as a <a href=\"http://hubs.ly/H05xGXn0\">search engine optimization guide</a>.</p> \n<p>Never force feed links to your top webpages, featured products or discounted items. These types of links will only turn off readers and could lead to search engines penalizing your website.</p> \n<p>A word of caution: don’t overdo your internal linking or any linking. We know it’s tempting to link to all of your blogs and webpages, but only choose the ones that best enhance the point or insight you’re writing about in any particular blog. Always think about whether or not these links naturally tie in with the subject matter and if they will offer significant value to your readers.</p> \n<h3>12. Optimize pictures for the fastest possible page speed.</h3> \n<p>Google <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-page-speed\">rewards pages with faster page speed </a>and places those that lag lower on its rankings. So, it's important to make sure your page-load times are as quick as possible.</p> \n<p>One of the leading culprits of page lag is <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-page-speed\">large photos</a>. If the photo you uploaded is too big, it will make the page take a longer time to load -- even if the image <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-page-speed\">doesn't seem huge on screen</a>. Luckily, you can keep your posts visually interesting without sacrificing crucial speed.</p> \n<p>Once you pick a photo, use a free compression software, like Squoosh.app to make it as small as it can go before it loses any quality. Any removal of excess photo data will speed up loading times so readers won't have to wait.</p> \n<p>If you suspect that your SEO issues are related to low page speeds, Google offers a free tool that can score your page and give you suggestions for speed improvement. Here's <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-page-speed\">a guide on how to use it and boost your score</a>.</p> \n<h3>7. Preform link building strategies.</h3> \n<p>Traffic from places other than Google is <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/link-building-software\">crucial to your search rankings</a>. Why? Think of search results like a competition where the winners get the most votes. Each webpage that links back to you is considered a \"vote\" for your website, which makes your content more trustworthy in the eyes of Google. In turn, this will make you rise farther up on search results.</p> \n<p>So, it's good to write posts that other websites or publications will want to hyperlink within their own posts. You can also write posts on other business' websites that link back to your website in some way.</p> \n<p>To make your website's blogpost more linkable, include valuable assets or information, such as your own data, original thoughts, infographics, definitions, or other facts that people might not find anywhere else.</p> \n<p>Here's an example of how this mindset could help you. If you write a post titled \"How to Make a Video Tutorial,\" or \"13 Stats about Video Tutorials,\" bigger sites that are writing about something similar might hyperlink words like \"video tutorials\" or \"research from [Your Company Name]\" to your post so they can give their reader more context without repeating your work.</p> \n<p>Once you've written the post, you might want to start sending it to other publications or websites that might want to discuss it or link it to their other posts. This outreach lets other publications know of the post and might also help you grow link building alliances with them in the future.</p> \n<p>You can also consider doing promotion, such as interviews or guest posts that link to your website's blog post to further encourage link building.</p> \n<p>These strategies can be key to your SEO success, but they can be time consuming. To help you, consider trying out <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/link-building-software?utm_campaign=Marketing%20Blog%20-%20Daily%20Emails&amp;utm_source=hs_email&amp;utm_medium=email\">one of these softwares</a>.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>How to Title Blog Posts for SEO</h2> \n<p>Even with a great, SEO-friendly post body, a bad title could hurt you in search engines. To title your post with SEO in mind, draft a clear understandable title that both shows the reader what they're about to read and integrates the keywords you identified in the first step. As mentioned above, write something that pleases Google's ranking algorithms, but is also understandable and enticing to humans.</p> \n<p>Here are a few examples:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>If you're a beauty blogger and you see that people are searching \"how to wear matte lipstick,\" your post could be titled, \"How to Wear Matte Lipstick: A 5-Step Guide.\"</li> \n <li>On the other hand, if your blog covers artificial intelligence and you see that people are searching a new AI app, you could write a blog post called \"How to Use [Insert AI App Name],\" or \"We Tried the New [Insert App Name] App: Here's What Happened\"</li> \n <li>If you blog about farming or sustainability and find out that \"what to buy at farm stands\" is a regular search, you might write a listicle titled \"What to Buy at Farm Stands This Summer.\"</li> \n</ul> \n<p>You know how to write content audiences will love. Now, it's time to write for what Google loves. SEO only heightens the chance of your post getting seen by the right audiences, expanding your reach.</p> \n<p>It can sound tricky at first, writing for two audiences, but just remember these takeaways: keywords, snippets, and descriptions. Learning a new language takes time, but luckily, your blogging software can likely remind you of these SEO tips. I can't wait to see your next blog post at the top of my search results.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p> \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fblogging-for-seo&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \" />","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 11 Aug 2020 19:34:00 +0000","feedId":924,"bgimg":"https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/jkrLX_FCneOwRvR527KfiHOfFW4ZYp15QeyUkS8X363Wr52Q5NKHlUw2JCvyFVAGwgi7k5CTIka7eKnNWO7XNaIHBbzMknV1lBsQCiE5ogQZdW0Yw0y1EGJbrB58OcHM8C1tY8IE","linkMd5":"09d376dc66fa9d912ba8e5b0b85f7658","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn3@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-27-431_2bdd57ccaa5e30ca.webp","destWidth":890,"destHeight":622,"author":"Courtney Feairheller","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/jkrLX_FCneOwRvR527KfiHOfFW4ZYp15QeyUkS8X363Wr52Q5NKHlUw2JCvyFVAGwgi7k5CTIka7eKnNWO7XNaIHBbzMknV1lBsQCiE5ogQZdW0Yw0y1EGJbrB58OcHM8C1tY8IE":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn63@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-34-085_2bdd57ccaa5e30ca.webp","https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/SthW36UwXSSgw6xA9MsSlcduXxbbMVKP3QpXTdUdc1KGMa4pqGAvSipqTkuL-TZICne4Dr-WXlVVEDagqYlDYavLLIPJEzesocOU6Gy9_qEHPbWEGmvwB6vIZJmd5zRmxy0YbxCg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn63@2020_2/2020/08/16/13-48-29-814_8da8bdf5b15faf8b.webp","https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/2jNZPSwpDQmCpp93qSsfmJzrztmQR8rQSjoBxLZDUz6vQLjPKBNCkbd2_njQNqt5lVzCZPFEV70MJmreYxiRHjUSU8yFvmJI6ZIhHHe1Kt5gKjwFk6ZbBvVM1-rC_pfTdREJUSih":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn68@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-32-347_745136777536ec8a.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fblogging-for-seo&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx17/cdn4@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-32-669_8f71651f20b60f93.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","title":"The Ultimate Guide to Communication","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/communication","description":"<p>The key to any relationship is communication.</p> \n<p>This includes romantic relationships, of course, but it also applies to friendships, coworker relationships, manager-team relationships, and even brand-customer relationships.</p> \n<p>Any scenario that requires you to convince, inform, entertain, or engage with another involves communication.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>The topic of communication is quite broad, right? I mean, it encompasses an entire college major at most universities. But we won’t be covering <i>everything</i> about communication in this guide.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Communication%20Plan%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=Communication%20Plan%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg\" alt=\"free editable Communication Plan Template\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<p>Below, you’ll be reading about communication as it applies <strong>to the workplace</strong> and <strong>to your customers</strong> — two pretty important topics, right?</p> \n<p>We’ll also be sharing ways to improve your communication and learn how your colleagues and customers communicate, too.</p> \n<p>Keep reading to get started, or use the chapter links below to jump around.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>In simpler terms, communication is said to be the “creation and exchange of meaning.” Communication is also a process … a series of actions. It’s not a single phenomenon, and it varies based on method, channel, and person.</p> \n<p>As a partner, friend, coworker, boss, and brand, you have a responsibility to learn how to <i>best</i> communicate. Let’s talk about how to communicate effectively.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>How to Communicate Effectively</h2> \n<p>Not all communication is good communication. In fact, not communicating at all is better (in some circumstances) than communicating poorly.</p> \n<p>Not adhering to effective communication practices can exacerbate or worsen a communicative environment, break trust, and make messages harder to receive.</p> \n<h3>Effective Communication Skills</h3> \n<p>Effective communication isn’t just speaking clearly and honestly. It also involves creating a safe, comfortable space for communication — even if you’re not the one talking. Employ these effective communication skills to give and receive information successfully.</p> \n<h4>1. Listening Actively</h4> \n<p>Effective communication is less about talking and more about listening. Active listening isn’t just hearing what the other person has to say; it also involves understanding their emotions and point-of-view.</p> \n<p>The goal of effective communication is to empathize and understand the person or party with whom you’re communicating. Here’s how:</p> \n<ul> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Focus on the other person</strong>. Don’t look at your phone, look around the room, or begin speaking to someone else. You can’t pick up on voice inflection or nonverbal cues if you’re not paying attention.</li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Show interest</strong> in what the other person is saying by nodding your head or saying “yes.”</li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Try not to judge</strong> or assume as the other person speaks. We talk more about these barriers <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/communication#barriers\">in the next section</a>.</li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Ask questions</strong> and provide reinforcing feedback, such as “What I’m hearing is…” or “Is this what you mean?”</li> \n</ul> \n<p>When you practice active, engaged listening, you becoming fully in-sync with what the other person is saying and feeling. That’s the point of effective communication.</p> \n<h4>2. Asserting Yourself</h4> \n<p>Being assertive means considering your thoughts, opinions, and feelings and communicating them in a clear, respectful way. It doesn’t mean being demeaning or aggressive. (We talk more about the different communication styles in <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/communication#styles\">the next section</a>.)</p> \n<p>Asserting yourself can help you stay clear on your own goals while empathizing with others. Here’s how:</p> \n<ul> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Get clear on your own values</strong> and opinions before you engage with someone else so that you don’t get confused or change your mind to make a conversation easier.</li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Positively express negative thoughts</strong> or opinions. Try to avoid outright anger or demeaning language or attitudes.</li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Be comfortable</strong> enough to say “no” or “I don’t agree.”</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Although effective communication is about understanding the other person, it doesn’t mean we should forget about our own perspectives.</p> \n<h4>3. Minimizing Stress and Communication Barriers</h4> \n<p>Whether you’re speaking or listening, minimizing stress in communication helps create a healthy, effective environment. Here’s how:</p> \n<ul> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Stall or pause</strong> to collect your thoughts. This can help you avoid outbursts or speaking before you think … and saying something you might regret.</li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Make one point</strong> at a time so that you or the other person don’t get confused or overwhelmed.</li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Don’t interrupt</strong> or make unnecessary comments or noises while the other person is speaking.</li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Try to stay objective and upbeat</strong> as you speak and listen. Keep the mood and tempo of the conversation elevated.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>It’s also important to recognize and remove any communication barriers like the ones we describe below. Anyone with a perceived “upper hand” in a relationship — like managers, executives, or parents — should especially keep these in mind.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Common Barriers to Communication</h3> \n<p>Here are a handful of common communication barriers that may be hindering communication in your relationships. I’ve also included an example of how these might apply in the workplace.</p> \n<h4>Language/Cultural Communication Barriers</h4> \n<p>Language or cultural barriers occur when two parties don’t speak the same language or perhaps have different understandings of the same language.</p> \n<p><strong>Example</strong>: An international intern is shirking his duties to coworkers. The team lead gives feedback by saying “You’re passing the buck.” The intern doesn’t understand the jargon. He isn’t sure how to improve in his role and continues making his mistake, further frustrating the team and team lead.</p> \n<p>Today’s workplace environments are more diverse than ever, meaning collaboration happens among all kinds of cultures. The best way to remove cultural or language barriers is by choosing common, clear phrases that are universally understood. If you’re speaking with someone who speaks a different language, try to use a translator or a verified translation tool.</p> \n<h4>Psychological / Attitudinal Communication Barriers</h4> \n<p>Psychological barriers happen when one or both parties carry cultural assumptions or are restricted by emotional hurdles or taboos. They also happen when there’s a lack of trust, attention, or empathy.</p> \n<p><strong>Example</strong>: A female employee is returning from maternity leave and needs a place to pump breast milk. In her previous job, her male manager wasn’t accommodating to her needs as a new mother, so when she approaches her current male superior with her request, she’s defensive and nervous … thus creating a tense, tough conversation.</p> \n<p>In this specific case, if the male superior was aware of her previous experience, he’d be able to inject more empathy and patience to make the employee more comfortable. Otherwise he might be uncomfortable with her defensiveness. While the female employee can’t help her previous experience, she could try to approach the new manager without any assumptions.</p> \n<p>Everyone’s mind is different, as is their upbringing. When it comes to psychological and attitudinal barriers, the responsibility falls on both parties to set aside expectations and prejudices and prioritize empathy, patience, and understanding.</p> \n<h4>Physical Communication Barriers</h4> \n<p>Physical barriers refer to anything that physically stands in the way of clear communication. These barriers typically exist through email, social media, text, or phone communication (anything that isn’t face-to-face) or when hearing or speaking handicaps are present.</p> \n<p><strong>Example</strong>: A remote employee is awaiting important feedback on a new project. His superior replies, via email, in a way that could be construed as cold or harsh — even though she was quite happy with the results. The remote employee assumes she’s unhappy with the project and loses confidence in his ideas and progress.</p> \n<p>In today’s world, digital and text-based communication is very common, especially with remote work.</p> \n<p>Receivers can avoid these barriers by not assuming the meaning behind a message or by simply asking for clarification. Also, senders can make their messages easier to receive by adding clarifying punctuation or words when communicating nonverbally.</p> \n<p>Lastly, always be aware of personal handicaps with which others might be dealing.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>The Four Communication Styles</h2> \n<p>Personality tests, like DiSC and Myers-Briggs, help others better understand your needs, strengths, and weaknesses.</p> \n<p>The same goes for communication styles. Understanding the different styles below gives you a better understanding of how and why others communicate the way they do.</p> \n<h3>Passive Communication Style</h3> \n<p>Passive communicators act indifferent and often yield to others. On the outside, they may seem meek, quiet, or flexible. They likely aren’t good at <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-say-no\">saying \"no”</a> or dealing with conflict, but they’re easy to get along with as they typically “go with the flow.”</p> \n<p>Phrases you might hear from passive communicators are:</p> \n<ul> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><i>“It doesn’t matter to me.”</i></li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><i>“This isn’t worth fighting over. Let’s just keep the peace.”</i></li> \n</ul> \n<h3>Aggressive Communication Style</h3> \n<p>Where passive communicators are meek and quiet, aggressive communicators are loud, brash, criticizing, and physically aggressive. Their communication style reverberates through their behavior, volume, and wording. Aggressive communicators issue commands, interrupt, and often talk down to people.</p> \n<p>Phrases you might hear from aggressive communicators are:</p> \n<ul> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><i>“You’re wrong.”</i></li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><i>“This is your fault. Fix it.”</i></li> \n</ul> \n<h3>Passive-Aggressive Communication Style</h3> \n<p>The passive-aggressive style displays a mixture of both. On the surface, this type of communicator might seem passive, but they probably harbor an aggressive side underneath. Behaviorally, they might seem agitated and display facial expressions or nonverbal cues that don’t match what they’re saying.</p> \n<p>Phrases you might hear from passive-aggressive communicators are:</p> \n<ul> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><i>“Whatever, but don’t blame me if the team doesn’t agree.”</i></li> \n</ul> \n<ul> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><i>“That’s fine.”</i> (and then proceeds to do the opposite)</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>Assertive Communication Style</h3> \n<p>Assertive communicators are said to follow the most effective and healthiest communication style. These communicators can express their own needs, opinions, and commands while also considering the needs and opinions of others.</p> \n<p>They typically communicate to reach a compromise or win-win situation, and will often employ “I” statements to take ownership of feelings while still expressing a need or desire.</p> \n<p>Phrases you might hear from assertive communicators are:</p> \n<ul> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><i>“I respect your opinion, but I disagree and here’s why …”</i></li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><i>“I feel frustrated when you miss deadlines.</i></li> \n</ul> \n<p>Understanding your own communication style, as well as your team’s and colleagues’, can be helpful when conversations get tough. It can also alert you to ways in which you can improve your own communication skills and challenge others to do the same.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>The Four Types of Communication</h2> \n<p>Communication isn’t limited to face-to-face speaking conversation; it applies to any exchange of information. Below, we walk through the four main types of communication and how you might see them in the workplace.</p> \n<h3>Verbal Communication</h3> \n<p>This type of communication is exactly what it sounds like: verbal conversation that includes sounds, words, and language. Verbal communication is said to be the most effective way to express emotions, feelings, opinions, and needs. If used correctly, words can help you be very straightforward and concise while leaving little room for question or assumption.</p> \n<p>There are four types of verbal communication.</p> \n<ul> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Intrapersonal</strong>, which is when we communicate to ourselves through our thoughts or out loud.</li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Interpersonal</strong>, which is when we communicate one-on-one with someone else.</li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Small group</strong>, which is when two or more people are involved. Team meetings, small presentations, and press conferences are examples of small group communication.</li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Public</strong>, which is when one person communicates to a large group. Public speeches, company-wide meetings, and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/tv-ad-business\">TV commercials</a> are examples of public communication.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>Nonverbal Communication</h3> \n<p>Nonverbal communication happens when messages are sent and received without words. It typically applies to body language, tone of voice, inflection, facial responses, and other gestures.</p> \n<p>It also includes creative or aesthetic means of communication such as dance, painting, and pottery. (Note: Nonverbal isn’t the same as visual, which is explained below.)</p> \n<p>Some examples of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/nonverbal-communication-tips\">nonverbal communication</a> include:</p> \n<ul> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Making eye contact (or lack thereof)</li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Shaking hands</li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Crossing or uncrossing legs</li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Folding or unfolding arms</li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Fidgeting</li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Hugging</li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Moving eyebrows</li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Smiling or frowning</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>Written Communication</h3> \n<p>Written communication is any message sent through written words or text. This form unique because, unlike verbal or nonverbal communication, written communication can be edited and changed before messages are sent.</p> \n<p>Written communication also encompasses components of visual communication when sent through electronic means, such as phones or computers.</p> \n<p>Examples of written communication include memos, emails, letters, reports, articles or blog posts (like this one!), social media posts, and print advertising.</p> \n<h3>Visual Communication</h3> \n<p>Visual communications involves sending and receiving a message with the help of visual aids. While visual communication encompasses some written communication, it mostly refers to symbols, images, and video.</p> \n<p>Movies, TV shows, video, and plays are all visual communication as receivers need to <i>watch</i> them to receive their messages. Icons and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/emojis\">emojis</a> are also considered visual communication. The most common form of visual communication, though, is the internet, which sends us messages using a combination of text, colors, images, symbols, and design.</p> \n<h2>Communication in Business</h2> \n<p>Whether you know it or not, you’re communicating right now by reading this guide. You’re the recipient of this message that I’ve written and transmitted via blog post.</p> \n<p>Communication happens all around us, and it’s especially important in business. Not only are we communicating non-stop with colleagues and teammates, but through <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/marketing-campaigns\">marketing</a>, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/advertising\">advertising</a>, sales, and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/customer-support\">support</a> efforts, we’re also sending and receiving messages with our customers and consumers.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Communication in the Workplace</h3> \n<p>This section is about <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/28151/3-tips-for-better-internal-marketing-communication.aspx\">internal communication</a>, meaning communication that happens within the workplace. This communication can refer to conversations with your boss, project collaborations with teammates, or perhaps reading your company’s internal wiki to learn about another team’s updates.</p> \n<p>Regardless, here are some tips on communication in the workplace.</p> \n<h4>Communication as a Manager</h4> \n<p>As a manager or team lead, you’re dealing with a lot, right? Not only do you have your own responsibilities, but you also have to oversee and organize those of your team.</p> \n<p>One of the hardest parts of managing can be figuring out how to systematize and catalog important communications happening within and around your team.</p> \n<p>Building an internal communications strategy can help you manage this. Here’s how.</p> \n<h5><strong>1. Assign a communication medium for specific types of communication.</strong></h5> \n<p>It’s hard to speak up at work. People aren’t always sure who to trust. They also aren’t sure which information will stay private, and which information will come with consequences if shared.</p> \n<p>This is where it’s up to you, as a manager, to create a safe, healthy environment for effective communication. One way to do that is to “assign” specific media or channels for specific types of communication.</p> \n<p>For example, constructive criticism or feedback should take place in-person and privately. Instead of sending random emails or criticizing employees during team-wide meetings, consider scheduling one-on-one feedback sessions every quarter. This reassures your employees that hard conversations will remain private, and it also builds trust by showing your employees that you respect them enough to speak in-person.</p> \n<p>Here are some other types of communication that might need their own medium or channel.</p> \n<ul> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Praise</li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Collaboration or Project Updates</li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Strategies or Processes for Cross-Team Collaboration</li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Concerns or Questions</li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Important Business Updates</li> \n</ul> \n<h5>2. Encourage your team (and other teams) to adhere to these processes.</h5> \n<p>Once you define these communication processes, write them down and share them with your team. Encourage your team — and other teams — to adhere to the processes in respect of themselves and their colleagues.</p> \n<p>Where appropriate, record your communication. This creates a record for others to reference and makes it easier to review and improve your processes … which is the next step.</p> \n<h5>3. Review every six months to see how you can improve.</h5> \n<p>Twice a year or so, survey your team and colleagues to make sure your internal communications strategy is working for everyone. Carve out time to receive feedback from your own employees. Remember, communication is a two-way street.</p> \n<h4>Communication Across Generations and Cultures</h4> \n<p>Whether you’re a brand new employee or a CEO, it’s crucial to understand that <i>we all communicate differently</i>. In the beginning of this guide, we reviewed some common communication barriers, namely cultural barriers.</p> \n<p>The vast diversity of today’s workplaces (something to be celebrated!) means that people of all backgrounds, upbringings, and ages are collaborating. It also means that workplaces will have a myriad of communication styles and preferences.</p> \n<p>Here’s how to prepare and stay aware of those differences.</p> \n<ul> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Educate yourself</strong> on how others communicate. Based on our upbringings and education, we all prefer to receive praise, feedback, and instruction in different ways. Take the time to ask your employees and colleagues how you can best communicate with them.</li> \n</ul> \n<ul> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Define communication</strong> as it applies to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/global-communication-tips\">each culture</a>. What does silence mean to each employee? How do they prefer to collaborate? What does disagreement look like? How do they like to receive praise? Start the discussion and foster an open environment within your team and company. Stay diligent and work to meet everyone’s preferences.</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Communication to the Consumer</h3> \n<p>This section is about external communication, which refers to communication that your business has with consumers and customers. This communication includes marketing and advertising efforts, sales pitches, support conversations, and any public relations and crisis communications.</p> \n<p>When it comes to any communication you have with the consumer, it’s wise to have a strategy to keep your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/6577/6-sales-and-marketing-communication-tips-to-build-smarketing.aspx\">business functions aligned</a> and keep <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/brand-communication-strategy\">brand communication</a> strong.</p> \n<p>Whether your posting on social media, publishing a press release, or building a new marketing campaign, all communication to the consumer — whether words, images, or video — should be consistent in tone, personality, and overall <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/brand-awareness\">branding</a>.</p> \n<h2>Over to You</h2> \n<p>Communication really<i> is</i> the key to any relationship. It may be a broad, vague topic, but it’s still able to be mastered in the workplace. Prioritizing communication among your team and company can help resolve conflict, strengthen collaboration, clarify strengths, and prepare you to do the same with your customers and clients.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in August, 2017 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcommunication&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \" />","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 07 Aug 2020 12:00:00 +0000","feedId":924,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/communication.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"5c69306ae6e472ee13e6e7eb056383c3","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn68@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-27-421_df2774fe18ae5c9c.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/communication.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"adecker@hubspot.com (Allie Decker)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Communication%20Plan%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg?width=1500&name=Communication%20Plan%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn75@2020_2/2020/08/16/13-48-33-415_e5bfbe3c2662b1e9.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcommunication&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn79@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-39-463_80b03309c91cb1ef.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","title":"The Ultimate Guide to RFPs","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/rfps","description":"<p>Have you been tasked with the job of creating a request for proposal, or an RFP?</p>  \n<p>Whether you have no idea what that is or haven’t written one in awhile, today’s guide can help.</p> \n<p>We’re diving into the specifics of what an RFP actually is, why you might need one, and how to <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/rfp-templates?hubs_post-cta=body\">create your very first one today</a>.</p> \n<p>To start, you should understand what all these letters even mean.</p> \n<p></p> \n<a></a> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<a></a> \n<p>When your company has a new (often large) project, or one that’s more complex and requires a bit of outsourcing, an RFP can help you get the job done right the first time.</p> \n<p>The RFP doc becomes a way for you to quickly uncover the strengths and weaknesses of potential vendors in relation to your project without having to spend too much of your time hunting for them yourself.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>RFPs can also give you a sneak peek into different strategies you may not have considered since each vendor will include their own unique action plan along with their bid.</p> \n<p>And you’ll have this information before you ever have to commit to the vendor.</p> \n<p>Keep in mind, this should not be confused with an RFQ.</p> \n<h3>RFP vs. RFQ</h3> \n<p>An RFQ, or request for quotation, is slightly different than an RFP since it’s just the quote itself. Here, companies solicit multiple price quotes from various vendors to compare services based on price alone. While an RFP includes a price quote (along with several other specifics), an RFQ does not detail anything other than price.</p> \n<p>As opposed to an RFP, an RFQ is a request for quote or quotation.</p> \n<p>Here’s how to understand the difference:</p> \n<p>While you’re technically receiving a quote in an RFP, you’re also getting information&nbsp;like&nbsp;the action plan,&nbsp;timeline&nbsp;of completion, deliverable schedule, and the list of services provided as well.</p> \n<p>But with an RFQ, you’re only receiving the quote itself for the service or products you’re interested in purchasing.</p> \n<p>In most cases, simply comparing quotes is not enough to see if a potential vendor is&nbsp;the right&nbsp;fit for your company, which is why an RFP is more appropriate in these situations.</p> \n<a></a>\n<a></a> \n<h2>The RFP Process Explained</h2> \n<a></a> \n<p>Before potential bidders can submit their proposals, an RFP must be drafted by the company requesting the work.&nbsp;<i>(P.S. We’ll show you how to do this later in this guide)</i></p> \n<p>This gives potential contractors a better idea of what your company is looking for.</p> \n<p>Once your RFP is sent out, contractors or vendors can review it and submit their best bids to compete for the job.</p> \n<p>In these proposals, vendors generally include the following items:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>An action plan of how they’re going to solve the issue</li> \n <li>A timeline of what you can expect</li> \n <li>Any necessary background information</li> \n <li>How much they expect the entire project to cost</li> \n</ul> \n<p>In certain cases, bidders may come back and say specific components of the RFP need to be adjusted based on their experience in the industry.</p> \n<p>At this point, you can either review their feedback and create a new RFP to adjust for the changes, or you can leave the original as is and keep it in mind while considering the other submitted bids.</p> \n<p>Once you receive all the proposals, it will be almost effortless to compare each one and determine which vendor is the best fit for your company.</p> \n<p>Out of the stack of bidders, you’ll want to narrow this down to a handful of your top three, five, or 10 favorites to consider, depending on how many you receive or are interested in.</p> \n<p>From here, you’ll want to spend time vetting potential vendors further to determine who’s really the ideal fit for the job.</p> \n<p>Some companies may request one more best and final offer from their top vendors after they’ve started this negotiation process to ensure they’re not only getting the right person or company for the job, but at the right price, too.</p> \n<p>While this may sound like an extra step, it’s one that may save you money, time, and headaches down the road.</p> \n<p>But this also leads us to a big question: Is all of this really necessary?</p> \n<p>Can’t you just spend time reviewing two or three vendors on your own?</p> \n<p>As you’ll see next, that route is definitely not in your best interest.</p> \n<a></a>\n<a></a> \n<h2>Why Issue a Request for Proposal?</h2> \n<a></a> \n<p>Let’s briefly compare these two scenarios:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Option #1: Spend time finding the perfect vendor on your own.</li> \n <li>Option #2: Use an RFP to get potential vendors to come to you.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Choose the first route, and you’ll probably use your coworkers, friends, and networking groups to help solicit possible referrals for the job.</p> \n<p>Or you might perform a Google search to check out the top vendors in your area.</p> \n<p>After you review the website of a possible candidate for the job, you’ll craft the perfect message to reach out and learn if they can even help.</p> \n<p>Then, you’ll have to explain the specifics of your project and you may or may not ask them to submit a proposal before deciding to choose them for your project.</p> \n<p>It’s not a complicated process, but did we mention you have to repeat it for every promising referral or vendor you come across?</p> \n<p>Imagine how long that’s going to take!</p> \n<p>Now, what if these potential contractors already knew your project details and they came back with their best plan of action and a formal bid for you to review?</p> \n<p>So instead of having to explain your needs each time, you would simply outline it once, and send it out to the masses.</p> \n<p>And to save you even more time, it would be up to potential contractors — not you — to reach out.</p> \n<p>The RFP route also gives you a sneak peek into each vendor’s real plan of action, not the one they talk you into over the phone or in person.</p> \n<p>Since potential candidates have to submit a formal bid, they’ll need to spend time outlining the solution and really working through the problem at hand.</p> \n<p>And if they don’t, you have an easy way to weed out vendors and cut through the stack of options fairly quickly.</p> \n<p>But, to get to this point, you can’t make this next mistake.</p> \n<h2>Here’s What <em>Not</em> To Do With an RFP</h2> \n<p>If you want to find the right vendor, you need your RFP to be specific.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p>Only asking “yes” or “no” questions&nbsp;<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/34097/the-right-way-to-think-about-your-marketing-software-rfp-sample.aspx\">won’t get you anywhere</a>.</p> \n<p>That’s why you must create specific questions that require thoughtful answers.</p> \n<p>Try to use sentences similar to these:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><i>Can you share an example of how you’ve solved this problem or a similar one for another company? Did you encounter any unforeseen roadblocks? What would you do the same or differently this time?</i></li> \n</ul> \n<ul> \n <li><i>With your proposed redesign, how long would it take a non-tech savvy person to complete the new registration form? How much time do you estimate this could save?</i></li> \n</ul> \n<p>With these tips in mind, you’re ready to draft your first RFP.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>How to Write an RFP</h2> \n<a></a> \n<p>Here’s the basic structure of an RFP and what to include in yours:</p> \n<h3>1. Project Overview</h3> \n<p>Before you go into the specifics of your company, you should give a brief introduction to the project itself so vendors know right away if it’s something worth bidding on.</p> \n<h3>2. Your Company Background</h3> \n<p>This shouldn’t be a long&nbsp;history of your company. Rather, it should give contractors a better idea of what your company does and who you serve as a target market.</p> \n<h3>3.
