The Goals of Your Project</h3> \n<p>Clearly identify what you hope to accomplish with this project and what you see as a “win” so everyone is on the same page.</p> \n<h3>4. Project Scope</h3> \n<p>The details of the project are essential in an RFP. In the same&nbsp;way&nbsp;you don’t want to use vague questions, a vague project scope won’t help you find the right vendor either.</p> \n<p>Spend time really detailing your project scope so&nbsp;there’s&nbsp;no surprises later on.</p> \n<h3>5. Target Deliverable Schedule</h3> \n<p>Even if your deadlines aren’t super tight, you should still have a target deliverable schedule in mind. This needs to be included in your RFP so potential vendors can properly gauge if they have the resources and bandwidth to complete the job on time.</p> \n<h3>6. Possible Roadblocks</h3> \n<p>Don’t hide your existing or potential issues under the proverbial rug if you want them to disappear. A successful RFP is explicitly clear about any technical issues or possible roadblocks, such as: Are you dealing with custom coding or an outdated platform? Does your team have limited resources?</p> \n<p>By explaining these up front, potential vendors will know exactly what they’re getting into.</p> \n<p>You’ll also naturally weed out contractors who can’t handle the task due to those constraints.</p> \n<p>But you’ll also connect with companies that know how to work around these common issues with skill and finesse.</p> \n<p>Remember, it’s far better to find this out now than after you’ve accepted the bid and started work.</p> \n<h3>7. Budget Constraints</h3> \n<p>It’s also important to be upfront with your budget too. The more you can eliminate surprises, the better for all parties involved.</p> \n<h3>8. What You’re Looking For in Potential Vendors</h3> \n<p>Another way to reduce or eliminate surprises is to explain exactly what you’re looking for in potential contractors.</p> \n<p>All you have to do is outline what matters most to your project (i.e., time, solution, budget, etc.) and show how you’ll be evaluating their proposals based on that.</p> \n<p>We’ll show you how this is done soon, but before we do, there’s one more thing to add here: an RFP cover letter.</p> \n<p>Just like a cover letter for a resume, an RFP cover letter creates a professional image for your brand and sets the tone for prospective vendors. It signals that they should take the proposal and the project seriously.</p> \n<p>The good news is there are a number of tools to make creating RFPs easier and less stressful than you’re imagining.</p> \n<a></a>\n<a></a> \n<h2>Proposal Software Tools to Help You Manage RFPs</h2> \n<a></a> \n<a></a> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/agency/proposal-tools\">In this article</a>, we outlined 10 tools to help you manage and create professional looking proposals in less time.</p> \n<p>For today’s purposes, the following five tools are great places to get started:</p> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://www.rfpio.com/\">RFPIO</a></h3> \n<p><span style=\"color: #444444;\">RFPIO Solves the problem of responding to RFPs, from project management to collaboration, to integrating with other software.&nbsp; Their solution includes reporting dashboards, auto-response features, and automated generation of proactive proposals from within your CRM. RFPIO also includes an intelligent answer library that turns previous RFP responses into on-demand intelligence that empowers revenue teams with enterprise content at their fingertips wherever the work.&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p>And what's <span style=\"color: #444444;\">better?</span> RFPIO has an <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/integrations/rfpio?_ga=2.147111541.331930299.1565019670-195194016.1541095843\">integration with HubSpot</a> that will automatically sync your RFP with your portal, making it easy to share information with your team.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://www.pandadoc.com/proposal-software/\">PandaDoc</a></h3> \n<p>To create customized RFPs with your own branding, consider using the proposal software PandaDoc.</p> \n<p>Here you can set up your first RFP within minutes and even collaborate with team members using real-time updates within the document itself.</p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://nusii.com/\">Nusii</a></h3> \n<p>Similar to other proposal software on the market, Nusii uses a drag and drop editor that makes building RFPs a breeze — especially for beginners.</p> \n<p>Thanks to its clean, modern, simple design, it’s also really easy to figure out too.</p> \n<p>One of the most helpful features of Nusii is using it for re-working existing RFPs to save you time. Just copy the content from an RFP you like and edit information to fit your new request.</p> \n<h3>4. <a href=\"https://www.loopio.com/\">Loopio</a></h3> \n<p>How do you plan on organizing all the responses to your RFPs?</p> \n<p>One standout feature with&nbsp;Loopio&nbsp;is its RFP response library, which gives you instant access to all your answers from previous RFPs. This saves you the hassle of digging around to find what you need in a crowded inbox.</p> \n<p>Their magic feature will even help you auto-populate a response if it appears similar to&nbsp;one&nbsp;you’ve already done.</p> \n<p>Plus, you can manage your entire RFP process — including sending automated responses — and collaborate with your team all in one place with their intuitive dashboard.</p> \n<p>And if proposal tools are out of the budget right now, or if you’d like to try your hand at creating your own first, use this template as a starting point.</p> \n<h3>5. <a href=\"https://rfp360.com/\">RFP360</a></h3> \n<p><span>RFP360 streamlines your approach to RFP response management. Their intuitive knowledge management, workflow and collaboration features make it easy to create, review, update and approve compelling responses in a single library. Proposal automation and answer intelligence (AI) capabilities accelerate your ability to answer questions, suggesting the best possible responses and automatically completing them in bulk. </span></p> \n<p><span>You can also import RFPs in various formats and generate polished final proposals, and integrated </span><a href=\"https://t.sidekickopen80.com/s1t/c/5/f18dQhb0S7lM8dDMPbW2n0x6l2B9nMJN7t5XWPdSD1CW1qMLtn2BFJWsV1wVXx1t7XWH103?te=W3R5hFj4cm2zwW45TRgW3K2B1QW4hLTz93T0WvLW3zh2D83Fbt5SW4cgtCT1GLttpW1-Y3wb4cRW_3W21rh1R43JQ5WW2k4cZV3zbVlJW49KXGf1-Xz2739CQ2&amp;si=8000000000479823&amp;pi=8ee7e395-d4d4-4a6e-e1c2-000f97b2c1df\"><span>extensions</span></a><span> allow anyone across your organization to use content from your knowledge library in Microsoft Office files, online questionnaires and forms — without leaving those applications.</span></p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Free and Editable RFP Template</h2> \n<a></a> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Request%20for%20Project%20Proposal%20(RPT)%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=Request%20for%20Project%20Proposal%20(RPT)%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg\" alt=\"free editable RFP request for proposal PDF template\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/rfp-templates?hubs_post-cta=imagesir&amp;hubs_signup-url=blog.hubspot.com/marketing/rfp-template&amp;hubs_signup-cta=null\" style=\"text-decoration: none; font-weight: 600; margin: 0px; border: 0px;\"><em style=\"font-style: italic; font-weight: inherit; margin: 0px; border: 0px;\">Download a free, editable RFP template.</em></a></p> \n<p>To use this template, simply <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/rfp-templates?hubs_post-cta=body\">download it here</a> or fill out the form below. You can remove sections or pieces of information that don’t pertain to your project and add whatever else you need for your RFPs.</p> \n<div style=\"text-align: left;\"> \n <h2>Over To You</h2> \n <p>Now that you have a better idea of what an RFP is and how to create your first one, you’re ready to get started.</p> \n <p>Sit down with your team to narrow down your project’s specifics, goals, and scope of work. Then determine when the project needs to be completed and your budget before moving on to the drafting phase.</p> \n <p>With this intel gathered, you’ll be ready to plug everything into our template.</p> \n <a></a> \n <p>You can also use this tried-and-tested&nbsp;<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/agency/proposal-formula\">proposal formula</a>&nbsp;to ensure your RFP is professional and polished too.</p> \n <p>Follow these steps and you’ll have an RFP template you can quickly update. Your&nbsp;next project will be a success that much faster.&nbsp;</p> \n <p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in August, 2018 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n</div> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Frfps&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 07 Aug 2020 10:00:00 +0000","feedId":924,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/rfp-3.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"d4b88e2af2ab8a44ea747319c90baefa","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn23@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-27-498_bdf51fa4ae885f75.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/rfp-3.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"joetting@hubspot.com (Jami Oetting)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Request%20for%20Project%20Proposal%20(RPT)%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg?width=1500&name=Request%20for%20Project%20Proposal%20(RPT)%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn39@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-30-326_59851a7ee2fb2497.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Frfps&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn27@2020_2/2020/08/16/13-48-32-860_6c639603f437c97e.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:25","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:25","title":"The Social Media Content Calendar Template Every Marketer Needs [Free Template]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33415/the-social-media-publishing-schedule-every-marketer-needs-template.aspx","description":"<p>\"We have a 9 a.m. meeting? Hold on -- let me just click around the internet like a maniac to find something for the morning tweet.\"&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Sound familiar? Scrambling for social content is nothing new. We have meetings. We run late. Things come up. And it's really hard to get any meaningful amount of work done when you have the next social media update looming over your head every 30, 60, or 90 minutes.&nbsp;It all&nbsp;moves so fast that you might periodically feel a case of the vapors coming on, which is why pre-scheduled social media content should be your new best friend.<strong><br /></strong></p> \n<p>To make social media content easier for companies to plan and schedule across the accounts they manage, we created a <strong><a title=\"templated schedule\" href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/social-media-content-calendar\">social&nbsp;media&nbsp;content calendar template</a></strong><a title=\"templated schedule\" href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/social-media-content-calendar\"></a>. And recently,&nbsp;we updated&nbsp;to be better, faster, stronger, and just generally prettier.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>But first...</p> \n<h2>What is a content calendar?</h2> \n<p>A content calendar organizes your publishing schedule by date so that you can keep track of deadlines, better manage your content creation team, and create transparency with all parties.</p> \n<h3>What's in this content calendar template?</h3> \n<p>Every content calendar is different and should be adjusted for your unique process. However, in this one, you'll find a general schedule tab, your monthly planning calendar, a repository for website content, and updates for each of the top social media platforms:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33415/the-social-media-publishing-schedule-every-marketer-needs-template.aspx#twitter\">Twitter</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33415/the-social-media-publishing-schedule-every-marketer-needs-template.aspx#facebook\">Facebook</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33415/the-social-media-publishing-schedule-every-marketer-needs-template.aspx#linkedin\">LinkedIn</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33415/the-social-media-publishing-schedule-every-marketer-needs-template.aspx#instagram\">Instagram</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33415/the-social-media-publishing-schedule-every-marketer-needs-template.aspx#pinterest\">Pinterest</a></li> \n</ul> \n<p>This blog post will walk you through exactly how to use the template to stay on top of your social media content planning for each one.</p> \n<p><em><strong>Note:</strong> HubSpot customers can also schedule content through <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/social-inbox\">Social Inbox</a>, or use this spreadsheet to organize their content and subsequently upload it to Social Inbox. Detailed instructions for doing this exist in <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/social-media-content-calendar\">the cover sheet of the template</a>.</em></p> \n<p class=\"p1\"></p> \n<h2>How to Use the Social Media&nbsp;Calendar Template to Plan Your&nbsp;Content Schedule</h2> \n<p>When&nbsp;you <a title=\"open up the social media publishing template\" href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/social-media-content-calendar\">open up the social media content calendar&nbsp;template</a>, you'll notice the bottom of the Excel spreadsheet has several different tabs, most of which are dedicated to a specific social network.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/content-calendar-excel-tabs.jpg?width=1362&amp;name=content-calendar-excel-tabs.jpg\" alt=\"content calendar excel tabs: schedule, monthly planning calendar, content repository, twitter updates, facebook updates, linkedin updates, instagram updates, pinterest updates\" width=\"1362\" style=\"width: 1362px;\" /></p> \n<p>The reason you'll want a different worksheet for every social network is simply that every social network is a little bit different.&nbsp;<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/create-perfect-social-media-posts-slideshare\">You can't just craft one, single social media update</a> and use it across LinkedIn, Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and Pinterest.</p> \n<p>You can certainly promote the same piece of content across those networks, but that doesn't mean you'll craft your update in the same way for every single one of them. (In fact, you may even want to add additional tabs if you're active on other networks, like Quora or YouTube.)</p> \n<p>This following sub-sections will walk you through how to fill out each of the tabs you see in this template -- the updates for Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn, Instagram, and Pinterest. But before we get to that, let's just walk through the \"Monthly Planning Calendar\" so you know what that's for.</p> \n<h3>Monthly Social Media&nbsp;Schedule&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>The tab \"Monthly Planning Calendar\" provides an overall snapshot of your monthly social media campaigns. It'll help you coordinate better with other stakeholders, not to mention keep all the moving parts straight in your own mind. Here's what it looks like:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/social-media-calendar-month-view.png?width=669&amp;height=388&amp;name=social-media-calendar-month-view.png\" title=\"social-media-calendar-month-view.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"388\" alt=\"social media content calendar month view with colored cells for each content type\" /></p> \n<p>There are three sections to take note of when you edit this template for your own purposes. First, the color-coding key: These are the types of content or campaigns around which you might coordinate, like ebooks, webinars, blog posts, product launches, and so on. Though only some of these might be relevant to you, they're there to indicate what you may want to put in there -- so be sure to edit these categories to align with your own campaigns.</p> \n<p>The other two sections you'll need to edit are the Month and Year at the top of the calendar (duh), as well as the cells below each day of the week. In those cells, you should&nbsp;enter&nbsp;the type of content you'll be promoting that day and color-code it to align with the campaign it's supporting.</p> \n<p>Instead of deleting all the content in this spreadsheet each month, I recommend copying this worksheet twelve times over, and creating a separate sheet for each month. (If that gets to be too overwhelming, you can always save those tabs as a separate file.)</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Planning Your Twitter Content Calendar</h3> \n<p>Alright, now let's get to the social media content. This section will be the lengthiest, because all subsequent sections will draw on the instructions we go through here. So if you read one section in this whole post, make it&nbsp;this one.</p> \n<p>Let's say you want to add some tweets&nbsp;to your scheduling template.&nbsp;Skip over to the \"Twitter Updates\" tab, where you'll see this:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/social-media-calendar-twitter-updates.png?width=669&amp;height=296&amp;name=social-media-calendar-twitter-updates.png\" alt=\"Social media calendar template for Twitter content\" title=\"social-media-calendar-twitter-updates.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"296\" /></p> \n<p>The first four columns, \"Day,\" \"Date,\" \"Time,\" and \"Date &amp; Time\" are there for your convenience, and if you choose to use a third-party app for pre-scheduling your tweets (like <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/social-inbox\">HubSpot's Social Inbox</a>), then these columns will be useful.&nbsp;For now, just fill in the date on which you'd like your updates to publish to Twitter, and the time at which you'd like them to go out. The \"Date &amp; Time\" column will automatically change based on what you input in the previous two columns.</p> \n<p>Now, let's move over to the \"Message\" column. Here,&nbsp;input the copy you'd like to appear in your tweet, bearing in mind you should<strong>&nbsp;cap it at 116 characters to allow enough room for a link, and at 115 characters to allow room for an image.</strong>&nbsp;(<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/character-limit-social-media-blog-posts\">Read this blog post for a full character count guide</a>.) This spreadsheet will auto-calculate the number of characters you've entered to keep you on-point, turning yellow when you've reached 95 characters, and red when you've reached 116 characters.</p> \n<p>After you've composed your tweet, paste the URL you'd like to include in your tweet in the \"Link\" column. Be sure to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-are-utm-tracking-codes-ht\">include UTM parameters</a>&nbsp;so&nbsp;you'll know whether all of these tweets are actually driving traffic, leads, and customers. This is an important step to remember if you'd like to be able to demonstrate ROI from social. You can also use the \"Campaign\" column to add an associated campaign, which helps which more robust tracking and reporting.</p> \n<p>Finally, in the \"Image\" column, attach the tweet's image (if you have one). For Twitter, we recommend images that are 1024&nbsp;x 512 pixels. (<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ultimate-guide-social-media-image-dimensions-infographic\">Click here for a full cheat sheet of social media image sizes</a>.) If you're having trouble attaching your image to the spreadsheet, follow these steps:</p> \n<p style=\"padding-left: 30px;\"><strong>Step 1:</strong> Right-click the cell in which you'd like your image.</p> \n<p style=\"padding-left: 30px;\"><strong>Step 2:</strong> Click \"Hyperlink,\" then click the \"Document\" button, and finally, click \"Select\" to choose your image.</p> \n<p style=\"padding-left: 30px;\"><strong>Step 3:</strong> In the \"Choose a File\" window, select the image from your computer and click \"Open.\"</p> \n<p style=\"padding-left: 30px;\"><strong>Step 4:</strong> You'll now see the image attached to the \"Insert Hyperlink\" screen. Feel free to edit the \"Display\" text to change the file name, then click \"OK.\"</p> \n<p><strong>Note:</strong> This process is simply for organizational purposes. If you decide to upload the spreadsheet to your social media publishing&nbsp;software, it will not attach -- you'll have to do that with your marketing software. If you're a HubSpot customer, details for <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/social-media-user-guide-v2/how-to-upload-social-media-messages-in-bulk-for-schedule-publishing\">how to bulk upload your Twitter content to Social Inbox</a> can be found within the downloaded template.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Planning Your Facebook Content Calendar</h3> \n<p>Now, let's talk about how to plan your <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/facebook-marketing\">Facebook marketing</a>&nbsp;in advance with the template. Navigate on over to the tab&nbsp;in your template labeled \"Facebook Updates.\"</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/social-media-calendar-facebook-updates.png?width=669&amp;height=304&amp;name=social-media-calendar-facebook-updates.png\" alt=\"Social media calendar template for Facebook content\" title=\"social-media-calendar-facebook-updates.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"304\" /></p> \n<p>Facebook updates work similarly to Twitter updates, with the exception being bulk uploading your content is not possible in Social Inbox.</p> \n<p>The first three columns, \"Day,\" \"Date,\" and \"Time\" are there for your convenience. Head on over to the column labeled \"Message\" and input&nbsp;the copy you'd like to appear in your status update, corresponding to the days and times you'd like those updates to run.&nbsp;Then, move to the \"Link\" column and input the link you'll be, you know, linking to in the update. (Don't forget <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-are-utm-tracking-codes-ht\">that tracking token</a>.) If you'd like the update to be tagged to a certain campaign, include this in the \"Campaigns\" column. Finally, attach an image just like you did with your Twitter updates -- if you're using one, we suggest you edit it to be 1200 x 900 pixels.&nbsp;(<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ultimate-guide-social-media-image-dimensions-infographic\">Click here for a full cheat sheet of social media image sizes</a>.)</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Planning Your LinkedIn Content Calendar</h3> \n<p>LinkedIn updates are the most unique, because you have both Company Pages and Groups to consider. To demonstrate the difference between Company Page updates and Group updates, let's navigate over to the column labeled \"Title (For Group Discussions Only).\"</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/social-media-calendar-linkedin-updates.png?width=669&amp;height=227&amp;name=social-media-calendar-linkedin-updates.png\" alt=\"Social media calendar template for LinkedIn content\" title=\"social-media-calendar-linkedin-updates.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"227\" /></p> \n<p>LinkedIn Groups let you post a few kinds of updates, one of which is called a \"Discussion.\" You will only fill out the \"Title (For Group Discussions Only)\" column if you're looking to post a Discussion to your LinkedIn Group -- because Discussions are the only update you'll be posting that requires a title. If you're not posting a Discussion to a LinkedIn Group, you don't need to fill out this field, because your update will not have a title.</p> \n<p>You'll fill out the next column, \"Message,\" for every type of update you post, whether it's for a Company Page or a Group. Simply input your copy into this column, and then navigate to the next two columns, \"Link\" and \"Campaign\" to input the URL to which you're directing readers with <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-are-utm-tracking-codes-ht\">the tracking token</a> you'll use to track&nbsp;activity, and the associated campaign if one exists. If you'd like to use an image for an update, attach it per the instructions laid out in the \"Twitter\" section. We recommend editing the image to 700 x 520 pixels.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Planning Your Instagram Posting Calendar</h3> \n<p>Now, let's move on to&nbsp;how to set up your Instagram&nbsp;photos and videos&nbsp;in advance with the template. Navigate on over to the tab&nbsp;in your template labeled \"Instagram&nbsp;Updates.\"</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/social-media-calendar-instagram-updates.png?width=669&amp;height=187&amp;name=social-media-calendar-instagram-updates.png\" alt=\"Social media calendar template for Instagram content\" title=\"social-media-calendar-instagram-updates.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"187\" /></p> \n<p>Instagram&nbsp;updates work similarly to Facebook&nbsp;updates, in that content can't be uploaded in bulk to&nbsp;Social Inbox&nbsp;like it can with Twitter.</p> \n<p>The first three columns, \"Day,\" \"Date,\" and \"Time\" are there for your convenience. Head on over to the column labeled \"Message,\" and input&nbsp;the copy you'd like to appear in your post's caption, corresponding to the days and times you'd like those updates to run. Keep in mind that although Instagram captions can be up to&nbsp;2,200 characters long, they&nbsp;cut off in users' feeds after three lines of text. The exact length of these three lines depends on the length of your Instagram handle.&nbsp;(<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/character-limit-social-media-blog-posts\">Read this blog post for a full character count guide</a>.)</p> \n<p>Next, move to the \"Link for Bio\" column and input whichever link you plan to put in the bio when you publish the accompanying Instagram post. (The reason you'd put a link in your bio and not the photo caption itself is because clickable URLs aren't allowed anywhere except the single \"website\" box in your bio.) Oh, and&nbsp;don't forget <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-are-utm-tracking-codes-ht\">that tracking token</a>.</p> \n<p>If you'd like the update to be tagged to a certain campaign, include this in the \"Campaigns\" column. Finally, attach an image just like you did with your other social media&nbsp;updates -- we suggest you edit it to be 1080 pixels x 1080 pixels.&nbsp;(<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ultimate-guide-social-media-image-dimensions-infographic\">Click here for a full cheat sheet of social media image sizes</a>.)</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Planning Your Pinterest Content Calendar</h3> \n<p>Alright, now let's go over&nbsp;how to set up your Pinterest pins&nbsp;in advance with the template. Navigate on over to the tab&nbsp;in your template labeled \"Pinterest Updates.\"</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/social-media-calendar-pinterest-updates.png?width=669&amp;height=246&amp;name=social-media-calendar-pinterest-updates.png\" alt=\"Social media calendar template for Pinterest content\" title=\"social-media-calendar-pinterest-updates.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"246\" /></p> \n<p>Pinterest&nbsp;updates work similarly to Facebook and Instagram updates, in that content can't be uploaded in bulk to&nbsp;Social Inbox&nbsp;like it can with Twitter.</p> \n<p>The first three columns, \"Day,\" \"Date,\" and \"Time\" are there for your convenience. Go to&nbsp;the column labeled \"Message,\" and input&nbsp;the copy you'd like to appear in your pin's description, corresponding to the days and times you'd like those updates to run. Then, move to the \"Link\" column and input the link you'll be, you know, linking to in the update. (Don't forget <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-are-utm-tracking-codes-ht\">that tracking token</a>.)</p> \n<p>If you'd like the update to be tagged to a certain campaign, include this in the \"Campaigns\" column. Finally, attach an image like you did with your other social media&nbsp;updates -- we suggest you edit it to be&nbsp;735 pixels x 1102 pixels.</p> \n<h3>Content Repository (Or, Where to Source Social Media Content)<strong><br /></strong></h3> \n<p>This template also provides you with a tab&nbsp;called \"Content Repository,\" which should help you keep track of all your content and maintain a healthy backlog of fodder&nbsp;to make sourcing social media content easier.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/social-media-calendar-content-repository.png?width=669&amp;height=146&amp;name=social-media-calendar-content-repository.png\" alt=\"social media content calendar's content repository\" title=\"social-media-calendar-content-repository.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"146\" /></p> \n<p>As you create more assets, you'll likely want to resurface and re-promote those pieces down the line, too.&nbsp;To ensure you don't lose track of all of that content, record it on this tab so you're never at a loss for what to publish on social. If the content you're promoting isn't evergreen, be sure to include an expiration date in the column marked \"Expiration\" so you don't promote it when it's&nbsp;jumped the shark.</p> \n<p>This tab will also help&nbsp;you maintain&nbsp;a healthy balance of content: A mix of your own content and others', a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-social-media-popularity\">mix of content formats and types</a>, and mix of lead generation content vs. MQL-generating content vs. traffic-friendly content.</p> \n<h2>Don't Forget to Interact With Your Followers</h2> \n<p>Whether you use this spreadsheet to plan your content out in advance or upload to a third-party app, you'll still need to supplement these updates with one the fly content. Breaking news hits? Whip up a quick update to share it with your network. Someone in your network tweets something interesting? Give it <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/27675/How-to-Retweet-the-Right-Way-in-4-Easy-Steps.aspx\">a retweet with some commentary</a>. Got a fascinating comment on one of your updates? Respond with a \"thank you\" for their interaction or an additional follow-up comment.</p> \n<p>Coming up with and scheduling your social media content in advance is a huge time-saver, but it should go without saying that you still need to monitor and add to your social presence throughout the day.</p> \n<p>Finally, we encourage you to experiment with your social media publishing. This template provides publishing dates and times for each social network, but you may find those are way too many updates for you to fill, or perhaps too infrequent for your booming social presence. You should adjust your social media publishing frequency as needed.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in January 2020 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<img Kolowich)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/content-calendar-excel-tabs.jpg?width=1362&name=content-calendar-excel-tabs.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn92@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-31-571_f90ca5b0d2e1dd8f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/social-media-calendar-month-view.png?width=669&height=388&name=social-media-calendar-month-view.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn92@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-34-285_7d00700896f17a6c.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/social-media-calendar-twitter-updates.png?width=669&height=296&name=social-media-calendar-twitter-updates.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn87@2020_3/2020/08/16/13-48-34-245_ce0511f1fed07ad1.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/social-media-calendar-facebook-updates.png?width=669&height=304&name=social-media-calendar-facebook-updates.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn4@2020_2/2020/08/16/13-48-38-826_07245d8e730a20df.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/social-media-calendar-linkedin-updates.png?width=669&height=227&name=social-media-calendar-linkedin-updates.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn71@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-37-665_631c08300d61d1fe.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/social-media-calendar-instagram-updates.png?width=669&height=187&name=social-media-calendar-instagram-updates.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn28@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-28-726_04f3c97e99e56140.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/social-media-calendar-pinterest-updates.png?width=669&height=246&name=social-media-calendar-pinterest-updates.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx17/cdn12@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-38-282_936d284f402305c8.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/social-media-calendar-content-repository.png?width=669&height=146&name=social-media-calendar-content-repository.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn52@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-29-681_89718392f4e99aed.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fblog%2Ftabid%2F6307%2Fbid%2F33415%2Fthe-social-media-publishing-schedule-every-marketer-needs-template.aspx&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn39@2020_3/2020/08/16/13-48-40-114_0003b1a836e6591f.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","title":"The Ultimate Guide to Social Media Analytics","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-media-analytics","description":"<p>There are over <a href=\"https://wearesocial.com/blog/2020/01/digital-2020-3-8-billion-people-use-social-media\">3.8 billion social media users</a> across the globe.</p> \n<p>As you can probably imagine, that’s a major reason why businesses want to be active on social, too. Businesses use social media to market, sell, and provide support to their target audience and customers as well as learn about and bond with them.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>The key is to understand what types of posts on which platforms are most effective in resonating with these audience members and customers.</p> \n<p>This will allow your business to consistently produce engaging content that positively impacts your bottom line.</p> \n<p>How do you do this? Well, it requires social media analytics and reporting.</p> \n<div class=\"CmABtb RNfche\"> \n <div class=\"CmABtb-bN97Pc-sM5MNb\"> \n  <div class=\"CmABtb-YPqjbf-sM5MNb\"> \n   <div class=\"notranslate IZ65Hb-YPqjbf fmcmS-x3Eknd CmABtb-YPqjbf\"></div> \n  </div> \n </div> \n</div> \n<a></a> \n<h2>What is social media analytics?</h2> \n<p><a href=\"https://sproutsocial.com/features/social-media-analytics/\">Social media analytics</a> is the process of gathering and analyzing data and reports based on metrics from one or multiple social media accounts.</p> \n<p>Social media analytics provides insight into a number of important factors that are directly tied to the success of your marketing efforts and your business as a whole.</p> \n<p>Here’s a list that explains the <strong>importance of social media analytics:</strong></p> \n<ul> \n <li>Develop a deeper understanding of who your target audience is and where they spend their time</li> \n <li>Identify which social platforms receive the greatest amount of traffic</li> \n <li>Determine what type of social content leads to the most conversions, engagements, etc.</li> \n <li>Discover what type of social media post has the greatest reach and resonates best with your audience on certain platforms</li> \n <li>Learn about what is and isn’t working in terms of social media campaigns and ads among your audience while they’re live and after they wrap up</li> \n <li>Develop a stronger social media strategy for your business’s specific goals related to things like your marketing, sales, and service efforts</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Social Media Analytics Reports</h2> \n<p>Social media analytics reports provide an overview of specific metrics and data points — such as engagements and impressions — related to the content you share on various social media platforms. Simply put, reports are how you’ll review your social media analytics.</p> \n<p>Social media analytics tools (<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-media-analytics#social-media-analytics-tools\">which we’ll review next</a>) make the creation of reports simple — some of these resources provide reports from one social platform at a time while others provide reports from multiple social platforms.</p> \n<p>Either way, social media analytics reporting tools are typically customizable — meaning, you can view and pull the data and reports that matter most to you and your business.</p> \n<p>With the tools we’re going to review below, reports can be automatically made and shared for you. But, here are some of the unique <strong>aspects of social media analytics reports</strong> that you can typically customize:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Statistics and data points that matter to you and will be displayed in the report</li> \n <li>Time frame (weekly, monthly, quarterly, yearly, campaign start to end)</li> \n <li>Progress growth (i.e. how you’ll share your progress growth over time through a report — typically, either in the form of a snapshot or a comparison of stats in a given time period).</li> \n</ul> \n<p><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/social-media-roi-monthly-report?hubs_post-cta=pillar_allphrase&amp;_ga=2.202530578.2097981921.1583513905-1675356138.1572978608\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Learn how to create impactful monthly reports to show ROI on your social media efforts.</a></p> \n<p>As stated, your reports will be unique based on the analytics software or tool you use. However, let’s look at some of the most common social media analytics reports that you may come across or create at some point.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Types of Social Media Analytics Reports</h3> \n<p>To give you an idea of some of the different types of social media analytics reports available in commonly-used tools, let’s look at <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/social/analyze-social-reports?_ga=2.202530578.2097981921.1583513905-1675356138.1572978608\">HubSpot’s social media analytics reporting options</a>.</p> \n<h4>1. Audience Analytics Report</h4> \n<div> \n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-3.png?width=1500&amp;name=Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-3.png\" alt=\"audience social media analytics report\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"> </img>\n</div> \n<p>The Audience report displays your current number of followers for each of your social accounts compared to the number of followers you had in a previous time period.</p> \n<h4>2. Published Posts Analytics Report</h4> \n<div> \n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020.png?width=1500&amp;name=Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020.png\" alt=\"published posts social media analytics report\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"> </img>\n</div> \n<p>The Published Posts report shows the number of social posts published across your social accounts during a specific time period.</p> \n<h4>3. Interactions Analytics Report</h4> \n<div> \n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-6.png?width=1500&amp;name=Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-6.png\" alt=\"interactions social media analytics report\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"> </img>\n</div> \n<p>The Interactions report displays the number of likes, reactions, and comments on all of your posts across multiple platforms.</p> \n<h4>4. Clicks Analytics Report</h4> \n<div> \n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-1.png?width=1500&amp;name=Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-1.png\" alt=\"clicks social media analytics report\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"> </img>\n</div> \n<p>The Clicks report displays how many clicks you get on your social posts published through HubSpot.</p> \n<h4>5. Shares Analytics Report</h4> \n<div> \n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-7.png?width=1500&amp;name=Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-7.png\" alt=\"shares social media analytics report\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"> </img>\n</div> \n<p>The Shares report displays the amount of your posts that were shared by your audience members.</p> \n<h4>6. Impressions Analytics Report</h4> \n<div> \n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-4.png?width=1500&amp;name=Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-4.png\" alt=\"impressions social media analytics report\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"> </img>\n</div> \n<p>The Impressions report shows the number of views that posts on your LinkedIn, Facebook, and Instagram pages received.</p> \n<h4>7. Sessions Analytics Report</h4> \n<div> \n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-2.png?width=1500&amp;name=Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-2.png\" alt=\"sessions social media analytics report\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"> </img>\n</div> \n<p>The Sessions report displays how many web sessions took place within a given time period on your site that were driven from social media.</p> \n<h4>8. New Contacts Analytics Report</h4> \n<div> \n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-5.png?width=1500&amp;name=Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-5.png\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"new contacts social media analytics report\"> </img>\n</div> \n<p>The New Contacts report displays how many new contacts have been created in HubSpot as a result of web sessions driven from social media within the selected time period.</p> \n<p>Now you may be wondering what tools are available to help you pull these reports and data — next, we’ll cover some of your options.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Social Media Analytics Tools</h2> \n<p>There are a plethora of social media analytics tools available today which is why identifying the right one for your business can seem like a daunting task. We’ve compiled the following list of seven of our favorites to help get you started.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/social-media-templates?hubs_post-cta=pillar_allphrase&amp;_ga=2.248025092.2097981921.1583513905-1675356138.1572978608\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Download 10 free social media templates to help you manage and optimize your content to achieve the best results.</a></p> \n<h3>1. HubSpot Social Media Software</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/social-inbox?_ga=2.248025092.2097981921.1583513905-1675356138.1572978608\">HubSpot Social Media Software</a> gives you insight into the customer journey through integrated analytics tools. These help you understand which of your marketing tactics are working best among your audience, determine how your marketing efforts are impacting your bottom line, and learn about your search engine optimization (SEO)-related ROI.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/free-trial-social-media-tools?hubs_post-cta=pillar_allphrase&amp;_ga=2.248025092.2097981921.1583513905-1675356138.1572978608\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Try HubSpot's social media tools free for 30 days</a><span style=\"font-style: italic;\">.</span></p> \n<p>In addition to this HubSpot’s Social Media Software, there are <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/resources/social-media?_ga=2.248025092.2097981921.1583513905-1675356138.1572978608\">a number of resources</a> including social media analytics report templates, free social media analytics tools, and <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/resources/courses/social-media?_ga=2.248025092.2097981921.1583513905-1675356138.1572978608\">social media courses</a> available for you to implement in your strategy.</p> \n<p><strong>Note</strong>: HubSpot also integrates with other analytics software, like <a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/social-media/oktopost?_ga=2.248025092.2097981921.1583513905-1675356138.1572978608\">Oktopost</a>, as well as major social platforms and their respective analytics tools such as <a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/social-media/linkedin?_ga=2.84646170.2097981921.1583513905-1675356138.1572978608\">LinkedIn</a>, <a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/social-media/facebook?_ga=2.84646170.2097981921.1583513905-1675356138.1572978608\">Facebook</a>, <a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/social-media/instagram?_ga=2.84646170.2097981921.1583513905-1675356138.1572978608\">Instagram</a>, and <a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/social-media/youtube?_ga=2.84646170.2097981921.1583513905-1675356138.1572978608\">Youtube</a> (among many others, which you can learn about in the HubSpot integrations <a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/analytics-data?_ga=2.84646170.2097981921.1583513905-1675356138.1572978608\">marketplace</a>).</p> \n<h3>2. TweetDeck</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://tweetdeck.twitter.com/\">TweetDeck</a> is an analytics tool used for Twitter. It works in real-time to help you view and analyze your Tweet engagement, organization, management, and tracking on the platform.</p> \n<h3>3. Tweet Reach</h3> \n<p>Despite what you may think based on its name, <a href=\"https://tweetreach.com/\">Tweet Reach</a>&nbsp;isn’t just used for Twitter. The analytics tool creates snapshot reports to help you efficiently monitor and pull key takeaways from your Twitter, Instagram, and Facebook profiles based on factors you identify as most important to your business.</p> \n<h3>4. Buffer</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://buffer.com/analyze\">Buffer</a> provides an in-depth look at how you can strategize to grow your brand on social media. The software does this by measuring your performance on various social platforms, creating detailed reports about the data points that matter to you, and recommending ways to improve your reach, engagement, and more.</p> \n<h3>5. Hootsuite</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://hootsuite.com/platform/analytics\">Hootsuite</a> allows you to create customized social media reports using over 200 metrics over any of your social channels and campaigns. These reports are easily shareable with members of your team as well as your clients to keep everyone on the same page and prove ROI.</p> \n<h3>6. Sprout Social</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://sproutsocial.com/analytics-and-social-listening/\">Sprout Social</a> provides a look into the needs of your customers through the conversations your customers and followers are having on social. The software also measures your specific content and campaign work across various platforms and channels to determine what’s working best among audience members and what should be improved upon.</p> \n<p>(Note: Sprout Social is another social media software that <a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/social-media/sprout-social?_ga=2.84646170.2097981921.1583513905-1675356138.1572978608\">integrates with HubSpot</a>.)</p> \n<h3>7. Mention</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://mention.com/en/\">Mention</a> is a tool that allows your company to monitor, listen, and analyze your posts as well as your interactions with and among audience members via different social channels and platforms. The software also makes it easy to create automated reports to share this data with fellow employees or clients.</p> \n<p>Next, let’s look at how to apply these tools and resources in your day-to-day work by reviewing the steps involved in tracking social media analytics (also known as your <strong>social media analytics strategy</strong>).</p> \n<a></a> \n<p>Work through the following steps to begin tracking your social media analytics and gaining a better understanding of which parts of your processes are working and which need to be modified. Again, you can think of this as your social media analytics strategy.</p> \n<h3>1. Set SMART social media analytics goals.</h3> \n<p>Create and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-write-a-smart-goal-template?_ga=2.81024276.2097981921.1583513905-1675356138.1572978608\">set SMART goals</a> to help you achieve your social media analytics goals. By ensuring your goals are SMART, they’ll be Specific, Measureable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time-bound — meaning, you’ll be able to focus your strategy to reach or even exceed your expectations efficiently.</p> \n<p>To begin, ask yourself, “What do I want to learn from my social media analytics?” Then, dive into each part of the SMART goal. Here’s an example of a SMART goal related to your social media analytics strategy for reference.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/how-to-determine-your-smart-marketing-goals?hubs_post-cta=pillar_allphrase&amp;_ga=2.81024276.2097981921.1583513905-1675356138.1572978608\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Use a free template to help you create SMART goals and achieve them</a><span style=\"font-style: italic;\">.</span></p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Specific:</strong> I want to use social media analytics to identify specific data points related to my marketing tactics to determine which posts and campaigns are working best in reaching and engaging our audience members.</li> \n <li><strong>Measurable:</strong> I want to be able to identify some specific data points to accomplish this goal.</li> \n <li><strong>Attainable: </strong>I will work to identify <em>three</em> specific data points to help accomplish this goal.</li> \n <li><strong>Relevant:</strong> These data points will help my team and I measure our success in reaching and engaging our audience members across social media channels as well as identify any gaps or areas for improvement in our social media strategy.</li> \n <li><strong>Time-bound:</strong> I want to identify these specific data points over the course of the next month — this way, in four week’s time, we can begin using them to measure our success in reaching and engaging audience members across social channels and identify gaps and areas for improvement in our social media strategy.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>2. Decide which metrics you’ll and focus on and track.</h3> \n<p>Now it’s time to decide which <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-media-metrics-ceos-cares-about?_ga=2.81024276.2097981921.1583513905-1675356138.1572978608\">social media metrics</a> you’re going to track. There are a number of commonly-tracked social media metrics for your consideration. Metrics may vary by social platform as well as which analytics tool you chose. But, here are some all-encompassing metrics applicable to virtually every social channel and analytics tool to get started.</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Reach</strong> is the total number of people who have seen your content.</li> \n <li><strong>Engagements</strong> are all interactions including shares, likes, and comments.</li> \n <li><strong>Impressions</strong> are the number of times or content is displayed on someone’s feed.</li> \n <li><strong>Mentions</strong> are the times your business and brand are referenced on social media by audience members or other businesses.</li> \n <li><strong>Social ROI</strong> provides insight into whether the investment you've put into your social media marketing is resulting in an increase or decrease in customers, sales, brand awareness, and customer loyalty.</li> \n <li><strong>Social listening</strong> is when you monitor conversations about your business and brand on social to see what customers and audience members are saying about you.</li> \n <li><strong>Likes</strong> are when an audience member taps (or double taps) on your social content to show they’re a fan of your post.</li> \n <li><strong>Retweets/shares/reposts</strong> are when audience members post the content your business published on their profiles.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>3. Determine which social media analytics tools you’ll use.</h3> \n<p>Next, determine which social media analytics tools you’ll use — <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-media-analytics#social-media-analytics-tools\">we covered some popular choices above</a> but you can always review other options through a simple Google search.</p> \n<p>Before making a decision regarding which tool or tools you’ll use, think about the following questions:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Do you want a tool or software to help you manage your social media analytics across multiple channels and platforms (e.g. Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn) or just one (e.g. Twitter)?</li> \n <li>Which metrics did you decide you’re going to track (as we touched on in the above step)?</li> \n <li>What is your budget? Do you need a tool with flexible pricing options and features that you can add to or remove from over time? (To find this information, review the pricing pages like <a href=\"https://sproutsocial.com/pricing/\">this page on Sprout Social’s website</a>.)</li> \n <li>Which tools and software options are suited to help you achieve the SMART goals you set? (Check out feature pages for this type of information, like <a href=\"https://www.oktopost.com/platform/social-media-analytics\">this page on Oktopost’s website</a>.)</li> \n <li>Do you want your tool to integrate with the greater software your team uses to run your business (such as <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/crm?_ga=2.81024276.2097981921.1583513905-1675356138.1572978608\">HubSpot’s CRM</a>, for example)?</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>4. Measure the success of your social media analytics efforts.</h3> \n<p>Once you implement your social media analytics software, you’ll be able to measure the success of your efforts. To do this, you may use the analytics tool you implemented — depending on your software, you might have the ability to create customized reports and dashboards or pull the specific details about data points you care most about.</p> \n<p>In addition to applying your tools to help measure your success, you may also consider your answers to the following questions:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Did you achieve your SMART goals?</li> \n <li>Did the metrics you chose to focus on tell a story that’s helpful for your business?</li> \n <li>Did the software or tool you implemented support your business needs?</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>5. Make necessary social media analytics adjustments.</h3> \n<p>Once you measure the success of your social media analytics efforts, you’ll be able to determine whether or not any part of your strategy needs to be changed or updated.</p> \n<p>Maybe you realize one of your data points isn’t providing the level of insight into your marketing efforts across social platforms, so you need to identify a new one to measure. Maybe your software doesn’t allow you to customize cross-channel reports the way you want to, so you need to implement a new tool. Or, if you’re happy with the way your social media analytics reporting and strategy is working, be sure to revisit your strategy in the future to ensure it continues meeting your expectations.</p> \n<h2>Begin Tracking and Applying Social Media Analytics</h2> \n<p>By tracking and applying the process of social media analytics to your strategy, you’ll be able to more effectively reach your audience. And when you do this, you’ll see improvements in factors that are directly tied to your ROI like engagement, conversions, loyalty, and more.</p> \n<p>Consider which tools and software are best for you and determine how you’ll track your social media analytics to create deeper relationships with your customers and followers.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in March 2020 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p> \n<img Baker)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-3.png?width=1500&name=Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx20/cdn31@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-30-782_1d782f113eca95aa.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020.png?width=1500&name=Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn4@2020_2/2020/08/16/13-48-37-120_fc3252e85145593e.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-6.png?width=1500&name=Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-6.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx17/cdn52@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-31-342_70ebf99985e0356e.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-1.png?width=1500&name=Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn60@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-38-616_fd9455e5805de46a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-7.png?width=1500&name=Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-7.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx17/cdn36@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-35-130_81b47f533599e210.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-4.png?width=1500&name=Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-4.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn68@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-35-178_08ba614e6441388f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-2.png?width=1500&name=Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn39@2020_3/2020/08/16/13-48-36-573_f5ec5772b9991c12.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-5.png?width=1500&name=Social%20Media%20Analytics%20%E2%80%94%20NNP%20Pillar,%20Marketing%20Blog,%20SIR%20Q1%2020-5.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn19@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-32-883_6b181701877c58e4.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fsocial-media-analytics&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn20@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-28-596_2bc87f19a7f351dd.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","title":"How to Write an Effective Communications Plan [+ Template]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/communications-plan","description":"<p>Remember the \"<a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/to-your-health/wp/2018/01/13/teens-are-daring-each-other-to-eat-tide-pods-we-dont-need-to-tell-you-thats-a-bad-idea/?noredirect=on\">Tide Pod Challenge</a>?\" That horrendous time at the beginning of 2018 when adolescents filmed themselves ingesting laundry detergent?</p>  \n<p>While it was a funny (albeit dangerous) start to the new year, this small boost of infamy was a PR mess for the detergent brand in question,<a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbesagencycouncil/2018/03/26/four-pr-lessons-to-learn-from-the-tide-pod-challenge/#6d2039347b0f\"> </a><a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbesagencycouncil/2018/03/26/four-pr-lessons-to-learn-from-the-tide-pod-challenge/#6d2039347b0f\">Tide</a>, whose crisis communication team had to figure out how to respond to America's teens swallowing their toxic product. Tide's parent company, Procter &amp; Gamble, was swift in their response, thanks in large part to their<a href=\"https://knowledge.wharton.upenn.edu/article/fallout-tide-pod-challenge/\"> </a><a href=\"https://knowledge.wharton.upenn.edu/article/fallout-tide-pod-challenge/\">communication plan</a>.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Communication plans can help you clarify the purpose of a product launch or new initiative and officially determine the messages you want to deliver to your intended audience(s).</p> \n<p>Additionally, a communication plan can help your business during a time of crises if a previous marketing message or business decision damaged your reputation with internal stakeholders or customers.</p> \n<p>If companies don't have a communication plan, they'll be unprepared when disaster strikes. It may be unlikely that your company will find teenagers eating your product for internet fame, but not so unlikely that you'll never find yourself needing a procedure to effectively handle difficult situations.</p> \n<p>Now that we've gone over how a communication plan can be helpful, let's learn how to write one that will be effective.</p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 20px; text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Communication%20Plan%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=Communication%20Plan%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg\" alt=\"free editable Communication Plan Template\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Need a free, easy-to-use communication plan template? HubSpot has 12. Check out<a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/crisis-management-communication-kit\"> </a><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/crisis-management-communication-kit?_ga=2.115977615.880690380.1568750897-940436819.1565181751\">this</a> toolkit for everything you need to build your own.</p> \n<p>This is part of a template offered in the toolkit. For this particular template, the organization is separated into phases, a description of that phase, and who needs to complete that action.</p> \n<p>Communication plans can get tricky, but writing an effective one will prove itself with its longevity.</p> \n<p>This communication checklist below, by<a href=\"https://www.prezly.com/academy/relationships/crisis-communication/the-only-crisis-communication-plan-you-will-ever-need\"> </a>Prezly, gives a great overview of the details of a crisis plan from beginning to end. It can be used as an effective guide when drafting a crisis management strategy.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/how%20to%20write%20an%20effective%20comm%20plan%20+%20template.png\" alt=\"\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><strong>Image source:</strong> </span><a href=\"https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/19IpxcyBo06roFik-b9jolagtABIzUa8L0q7R0JT7pXc/edit?usp=sharing\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\">Prezly</span></a></p> \n<h3>1. Conduct an audit of your current communications materials.</h3> \n<p>Before sitting down to get rollin' on your plan, you need to first decide where it'll fit into your business. So it's important you complete a \"state of the union\", or an audit of the current climate of communications within your company. This can help you identify any problem areas.</p> \n<p>For instance, let's say you need to create a communications plan for a new product launch. To create your plan, you'll first need to perform an audit to identify gaps in your current marketing approach.</p> \n<p>After performing the audit, you might find there is a major gap in your marketing materials in which you rarely discuss a topic that aligns well with your new product. You'll want to ensure this topic makes it into your communications plan.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>To conduct an audit, you'll need to carefully gather and interpret data on your current marketing plan performance and build a path forward based on those results. Additionally, you might consider <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-run-a-focus-group\">hosting focus groups</a> or sending surveys to your audience to find gaps in your current communications materials.</p> \n<p>Of course, you'll want to have the <i>goal </i>of your communications plan in-mind when conducting an audit. In the example above, noticing you're lacking material on a certain subject only matters if your goal is to drive leads and conversions to a product that aligns with that subject.</p> \n<p>For instance, if you're launching a new email marketing tool and you notice you're lacking content on Google Ads, this might not be relevant information for your communications plan. However, if you're missing content on email marketing best practices, that's important information you can use to tailor your communications plan appropriately.</p> \n<h3>2. Set SMART goals for your communications plan based on the results from your audit.</h3> \n<p>After your audit, you'll want to lay out a few goals based on the data from the results. What do you want to achieve with this plan?</p> \n<p>When in doubt, remember that your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-write-a-smart-goal-template\">goals should be SMART</a>: Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time-based.</p> \n<p>For instance, if a small agency is writing a communications plan for its client, they might write a goal along these lines: \"We plan to increase employment applications for our client by 25% over the course of one quarter.\"</p> \n<p>Alternatively, perhaps your HR team needs to write a communications plan to pitch designing a new growth matrix for individual contributors who don't want to become managers.</p> \n<p>If that's the case, your HR team will need to identify specific goals they hope to achieve as a result of their plan, even if the results are less quantifiable — for instance, their goal might be to \"increase employee retention rates by 10% over the next year\" or even \"increase employee satisfaction, as indicated by their next NPS scores.\" They'll need to pitch these goals to stakeholders to get leadership on-board.</p> \n<h3>3. Identify the audience to whom you plan to deliver your communications plan.</h3> \n<p>Good communication starts with knowing and understanding your listener. In this case, if a crisis communication plan is for stakeholders, which one(s) are you writing for? Stakeholder examples include employees, investors, customers, local government officials, or media outlets.</p> \n<p>If you're writing for media outlets, a press release detailing your goals is a good idea for that audience. There should be a process for who will speak to the media outlets, an outline of what they will say, and an action plan put in place moving forward.</p> \n<p>Alternatively, if your audience is your employees, you might want to create an up-to-date internal document for employees to refer to, as well as the contact information for the internal DRI if they have follow-up questions.</p> \n<h3>4. Outline and write your plan, keeping your audiences in-mind.</h3> \n<p>When you're ready to outline and write your plan, it's likely easiest if you start with a table or chart to identify the messages you need to promote, to whom you're targeting those messages, and on which channel(s).</p> \n<p>Once you've created a general outline, here's how you'll want to structure your communications plan (feel free to copy these sections into a Table of Contents for your own plan):</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Purpose (what is this communications plan for)</li> \n <li>Escalation Framework (including 'first line of defense' and 'greater response team')</li> \n <li>Roles and responsibilities of each employee</li> \n <li>Do's and Don'ts</li> \n <li>How to maintain an effective response plan</li> \n</ul> \n<p>(If you need help writing a communications plan, download our <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/crisis-management-communication-kit\">free, ready-to-use communications plan templates</a>.)</p> \n<p>When writing your communication plan, work with groups or representatives from your stakeholders to improve accuracy. Strategies should solve for goals or potential risks.</p> \n<p>For instance, if you work for an agency aiming to promote a client's product, a risk might be spending money on paid ads without a guaranteed ROI. To solve for that risk, the agency should detail different steps to ensure the ads are effective before going public.</p> \n<h3>5. Determine the channel(s) on which you need to deliver your messages.</h3> \n<p>The channels you choose to communicate with your audience depends on your message, and to whom you want to deliver that message. For instance, if you're creating a communications plan for internal employees, you might send out your communications plan in a company-wide email, or use in-person team meetings to deliver your message.</p> \n<p>Alternatively, if you're communicating with customers, you might determine it's best to communicate via an email newsletter, or via a press release.</p> \n<p>Of course, the channel(s) you choose will depend on your goals, but it's important as you're writing your communication plan that you keep your distribution methods in-mind.</p> \n<h3>6. Decide which team members are responsible for delivering the message.</h3> \n<p>Once you determine your audience and channel(s) on which you'll deliver your communications plan, figure out the DRI for delivering the message.</p> \n<p>For instance, if your HR team is pitching a new growth matrix to leadership, you might ask your Director of HR to deliver the initial pitch in the first meeting. Once leadership is on-board, you might ask each HR representative to deliver one training session for each internal team to ensure every employee understands what's changing internally, and why.</p> \n<h3>7. Estimate a timeline for how long each step should take.</h3> \n<p>You should have a ballpark estimate of how much time each step in executing your strategy will take. For instance, if your plan needs to go from the higher-ups down to the employees, it's good to take into account how long going through the chain of command will take. It's also smart to infer how long a media cycle will last.</p> \n<p>For instance, for a minor slip-up on an ad campaign, the advertising agency might estimate the cycle for controlling the issue will take a month — including meeting with the client, stakeholders, and employees to discuss steps moving forward.</p> \n<h3>8. Measure the results of your plan after presenting to stakeholders, and determine successes and areas for improvement.</h3> \n<p>There's always room for improvement. Measure the results of the plan after presenting it to stakeholders, and determine aspects that went well, and areas for improvement next time.</p> \n<p>For instance, the ad agency might not have met its goal of increasing prospective applications by 25% within a quarter. They might rework their goals to give themselves more time or pivot their quarterly focus to fit those goals.</p> \n<p>Alternatively, if you notice certain language in your communications plan evoked a level of stress or fear with internal stakeholders, consider how you can re-word next time to ensure your communications plan feels helpful, beneficial, and positive.</p> \n<p>Some aspects of building a communication plan can be a \"choose your own adventure\" journey. The key is choosing aspects that best reflect what your business needs in times when effective communication is key. What do your stakeholders need to know, and how are you going to best communicate that?</p> \n<h2><strong>Communication Plan Examples</strong></h2> \n<p>A basic communication plan should include an analysis for the stakeholders you'd respond to and the procedures for what to include in those conversations. You might also include an overview of your business, potential communication challenges, and risk management strategy.</p> \n<p>Bright Hub Project management has an<a href=\"https://www.brighthubpm.com/templates-forms/16931-an-example-communication-plan-for-the-project-manager/\"> </a><a href=\"https://www.brighthubpm.com/templates-forms/16931-an-example-communication-plan-for-the-project-manager/\">example</a> that includes how to put this information — and more — into your communication plan as a project manager.</p> \n<p>This example is great because it details how communication managers write crisis plans and acknowledges that sometimes the busy marketer or project manager does as well.</p> \n<p><strong><img src=\"https://img.bhs4.com/4e/6/4e667fb74fa9198f840f825439aed552286b947c_large.jpg\" alt=\"Communications Plan\" class=\"ezlazyloaded\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></strong></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\">Source: <a href=\"https://www.brighthubpm.com/templates-forms/16931-an-example-communication-plan-for-the-project-manager/\">Bright Hub</a></span></strong></p> \n<p>The National School Public Relations Association has a free<a href=\"https://www.nspra.org/files/docs/Sample%20Communication%20Plan.pdf\"> </a><a href=\"https://www.nspra.org/files/docs/Sample%20Communication%20Plan.pdf\">version</a> of a sample communication plan in PDF format. It’s a great example of how to format a crisis strategy and how to fit your budget into the plan:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/communications-plan-example.gif\" alt=\"communications-plan-example\"></p> \n<p>Finally, here's an example of a Billing Upgrade Project from Simplicable. As you can see, the communications plan includes necessary sections including audience, goals, format, and DRI:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/example%20of%20crisis%20communication%20plan.png?width=1758&amp;name=example%20of%20crisis%20communication%20plan.png\" alt=\"example of crisis communication plan\" width=\"1758\" style=\"width: 1758px;\"><strong><span style=\"font-size: 11px;\">Source: <a href=\"https://simplicable.com/document/5245/communication-plan\">Simplicable</a></span></strong></p> \n<p>Finally, here are some extra tips to keep in mind to help your plan shine: when describing procedures for handling crises, include who the situation involves. This lets stakeholders envision decision-making processes.</p> \n<p>Additionally, if you're part of a larger company with a broad stakeholder list, it's okay to split up target audiences for your plan.</p> \n<p>For instance, maybe your audience is more than just \"consumers.\" Split stakeholder groups for easier comprehension and more distinct solutions.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, your communications plan needs to clearly and succinctly provide necessary information to everyone involved in the business decision, product launch, or PR crises. Use the strategy mentioned above, as well as our <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/crisis-management-communication-kit\">communication plan templates</a>, to ensure yours is as effective as possible.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in September, 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p><em></em></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcommunications-plan&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\"
