\">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 07 Aug 2020 12:15:00 +0000","feedId":924,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/communicaton-plan.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"5e2dec39d02aee63da799f82df38ab97","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn35@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-27-417_7ae824a87a88a6fa.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/communicaton-plan.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"Kayla Carmicheal","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Communication%20Plan%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg?width=1500&name=Communication%20Plan%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn75@2020_2/2020/08/16/13-48-33-415_e5bfbe3c2662b1e9.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/how%20to%20write%20an%20effective%20comm%20plan%20+%20template.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn23@2020_2/2020/08/16/13-48-32-723_386fb9240fecfc1f.webp","https://img.bhs4.com/4e/6/4e667fb74fa9198f840f825439aed552286b947c_large.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn39@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-38-162_c8a55f70c8d90d5a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/communications-plan-example.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn99@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-39-599_2a757e58b4fb7d7f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/example%20of%20crisis%20communication%20plan.png?width=1758&name=example%20of%20crisis%20communication%20plan.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn71@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-31-319_e910d2c733b3dad9.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcommunications-plan&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn52@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-37-321_26a75325a77017fc.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","title":"Upstream vs. Downstream Marketing, Explained","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/upstream-vs-downstream-marketing","description":"<p>How many times have you seen a term for something you already knew about? This probably happens a lot, right?</p>  \n<p>&nbsp;For example, before I took marketing classes in college, I had no idea that there was a term for making sure your content has a better chance of ranking highly on search engines. (Hint: This is <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/blog-search-engine-optimization?_ga=2.261676877.1179602377.1596518655-940436819.1565181751\">search engine optimization</a>, or SEO).</p> \n<p>You may already know about upstream and downstream marketing. When I learned what these two terms meant, I found myself saying, \"<em>Oh, so that's what it's called!</em>\"</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>You’re probably here for the same reason. So, let’s talk about the difference between these two terms and how they work together. Are you ready for a quick introduction to upstream and downstream marketing?</p> \n<h2>Upstream Marketing</h2> \n<p>Upstream marketing is a long-term plan. It allows for marketers to conceptualize a timeline for future releases based on <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/customer-segmentation?_ga=2.261676877.1179602377.1596518655-940436819.1565181751\">customer segments</a>. To create an upstream marketing plan, start with a section of your audience that you want to focus on in the next year or so.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/upstream%20vs.%20downstream%20marketing,%20explained.png\" alt=\"The definition of upstream marketing.\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>Your completed upstream plan should include the following:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Identification of a portion of your audience's problems</li> \n <li>A product or service that will solve those challenges</li> \n <li>A price and competitive edge for campaign assets</li> \n</ul> \n<p>First, identify the challenges your customers are facing. Do this by referring to your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/buyer-persona-research?_ga=2.261676877.1179602377.1596518655-940436819.1565181751\">buyer persona</a> and researching the current market as well as gathering feedback from current customers.</p> \n<p>For instance, let's say your company offers a CRM and your team decides to use an upstream plan for improving the enterprise-level tier of offerings. The first step is to identify consumers' pain points. After analyzing market and feedback data, you find that enterprise customers want software that will simplify testing campaign assets.</p> \n<p>Enterprise-level customers need sophisticated, scalable software that enables them to analyze campaigns and engagement metrics. You and your team decide that's where your new product is going to come in — it will focus on helping customers analyze campaigns that are impactful.</p> \n<p>You decide on adding an adaptive testing feature to your CRM. It first will allow customers to automatically test web page performance for metrics like <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/choosing-kpis?_ga=2.261676877.1179602377.1596518655-940436819.1565181751\">click-through rate, conversions, and session time</a>. They can use that data to improve the effectiveness of those pages.</p> \n<p>With the challenge and solution figured out, think about how much the tool will cost and how it can be set apart from the market. If you included competitor data in your research process, you can refer to it at this step to strategize your product's market edge.</p> \n<p>This strategy looks similar to deciding on a price. Factor in your customer segment, competitor pricing, and your own pricing model. With this information, you ultimately decide that the tool will be an add-on to your existing enterprise tier, and the marketing edge will be that the service is a complementary update.</p> \n<p>Conceptualizing a product, its price, and its competitive edge sounds like it would happen pretty early on in the marketing process, right? It is, and, in fact, it should be done before considering downstream marketing. Upstream marketing helps companies plan roll-outs by providing a bird's eye view of what can be expected in the long-term.</p> \n<p>Now, you've come up with the who, what, when, where, why, and how. An adaptive testing feature will be added for enterprise-level customers within your company's CRM within the next year. The marketing strategy will focus on its increased value for the enterprise tier.</p> \n<p>With this plan in place, you can solidify a downstream process.</p> \n<h2>Downstream Marketing</h2> \n<p>If upstream marketing is the \"big picture\" planning session, downstream is the game plan. So, for the CRM company, the next step is to come up with a campaign strategy. That process involves downstream marketing.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/upstream%20vs.%20downstream%20marketing,%20explained-1.png\" alt=\"The definition of downstream marketing.\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>Downstream marketing is more short-term than upstream marketing. It strategizes marketing campaigns and asks the question, \"<em>What resources can we leverage to make the customer want our product?</em>\"</p> \n<p>Sometimes, downstream is used interchangeably with general marketing practices: Coming up with processes and activities that will effectively communicate the value of a product or service. This isn't wrong.</p> \n<p>Because the upstream process identified the product, its price, and its competitive edge, the downstream method can use this information to produce an informative, engaging campaign.</p> \n<p>Your CRM company, at this point, will now have to decide the framework for your adaptive testing campaign. Think about what social media channels you will leverage, the angle of the promotional video, and offers you may want to draft. Decide how you will communicate the release of your updates to customers and leads.</p> \n<p>For instance, in this step, you may decide to use <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/linkedin-advertising-campaigns?_ga=2.60355693.1179602377.1596518655-940436819.1565181751\">LinkedIn Ads</a>, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/email-marketing-guide?_ga=2.60355693.1179602377.1596518655-940436819.1565181751\">email marketing</a>, and an <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/ab-testing-kit?q=testing&amp;hubs_signup-url=www.hubspot.com%2Fresources&amp;hubs_signup-cta=directories__link&amp;_ga=2.31447807.1792232450.1595858977-940436819.1565181751https://offers.hubspot.com/ab-testing-kit?q=testing&amp;hubs_signup-url=www.hubspot.com%2Fresources&amp;hubs_signup-cta=directories__link&amp;_ga=2.60355693.1179602377.1596518655-940436819.1565181751\">ebook offer</a>. These channels will be used to acquire leads, excite existing customers, and explain how the update adds value to the existing product.</p> \n<h2>Upstream Marketing vs. Downstream Marketing</h2> \n<p>When upstream and downstream work together, the result is a smooth product development cycle that keeps marketing in mind. The two help you build the bones of a campaign at an early stage.</p> \n<p>Let's go back to the CRM company example. You used upstream marketing to come up with a product of value for your existing customers. It helped you to identify its market edge and campaign cycle.</p> \n<p>Then, using downstream marketing, you developed a framework for the overall marketing strategy. You decided which channels would reach enterprise-level customers effectively. You decided how branding will play a part in solidifying the growth of your product, and how to shape messaging that will connect to your audience.</p> \n<p>The two can create focused campaigns because they identify a customer segment, challenge, and benefit to be used for effective messaging. It keeps teams on the same track, even if the upstream ideas have to change.</p> \n<p>For the long-term, what are some of the ways you plan to use both in future planning?</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fupstream-vs-downstream-marketing&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 05 Aug 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":924,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/upstream%20vs.%20downstream%20marketing,%20explained.png","linkMd5":"daf0cc231fde6bd0ef1a6139eb95d95b","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn5@2020_3/2020/08/16/13-48-28-450_dab181428d63d212.webp","author":"Kayla Carmicheal","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/upstream%20vs.%20downstream%20marketing,%20explained.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn95@2020_3/2020/08/16/13-48-36-865_dab181428d63d212.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/upstream%20vs.%20downstream%20marketing,%20explained-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn7@2020_3/2020/08/16/13-48-29-853_358f340d021cf283.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fupstream-vs-downstream-marketing&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn4@2020_2/2020/08/16/13-48-37-911_f9900ab2026aa8f8.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:25","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:25","title":"What is a Business Plan? Definition, Tips, and Templates","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-business-plan","description":"<p>The business plan is an undeniably critical component to getting any company off the ground. It's key to securing financing, documenting your business model, outlining your financial projections, and turning that nugget of a business idea into a reality.</p>  \n<p>In an era where more than <a href=\"https://www.oberlo.com/blog/small-business-statistics#:~:text=There%20are%2030.7%20million%20small%20businesses%20in%20the%20USA.,small%20and%20medium%2Dsized%20businesses.\">50% of small enterprises fail</a> in their first year, having a clear, defined, and well thought-out business plan is a crucial first step for setting up a business for long-term success.</p> \n<p>Business plans are a required tool for all entrepreneurs, business owners, business acquirers, and even business school students. But … what exactly <em>is</em> a business plan?</p> \n<p>In this post, we'll explain what a business plan is, list the reasons why you'd need one, and identify different types of business plans.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2><strong>What is a Business Plan?</strong></h2> \n<p>A business plan is a documented strategy for a business that highlights its goals and its plans for achieving them.</p> \n<p>Business plans outline a company's go-to-market strategy, financial projections, market research, business purpose, and mission. The business plan is also a prominent tool used to secure investors and financing for a business.</p> \n<h2><strong>Business Plan Template</strong></h2> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/bpt-cover-gif-1.gif?width=443&amp;name=bpt-cover-gif-1.gif\" alt=\"bpt-cover-gif-1\" width=\"443\" style=\"width: 443px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">Working on your business plan? Try using <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/business-plan-template\">our Business Plan Template</a>. Pre-filled with the sections a great business plan needs, the template will give aspiring entrepreneurs a feel for what a business plan is, what should be in it, and how it can be used to establish and grow a business from the ground up.</p> \n<h2><strong>Purposes of a Business Plan</strong></h2> \n<p>Chances are, someone drafting a business plan will be doing so for one or more of the following reasons:</p> \n<h3>1. Securing financing from investors.</h3> \n<p>Since its contents revolve around how businesses succeed, break even, and turn a profit, a business plan is primarily used as a tool for sourcing capital. This document is an entrepreneur's way of showing potential investors and/or loaners how their capital will be put to work and how it will help a business thrive.</p> \n<p>All banks, investors, and venture capital firms will want to see a business plan before handing over their money, and investors typically want <a href=\"https://smallbusiness.chron.com/small-business-investors-percentage-forever-73824.html#:~:text=Angel%20investors%20typically%20want%20from,high%20risk%20it%20is%20taking.\">a 20-25% ROI</a> from the capital they invest in a business.</p> \n<p>Therefore, these investors need to know if – and when – they'll be making their money back (and then some). Additionally, they'll want to read about the process and strategy for <em>how</em> the business will reach those financial goals, which is where the context provided by sales, marketing, and operations plans come into play.</p> \n<h3>2. Documenting a company's strategy and goals.</h3> \n<p>A business plan should leave no stone unturned.</p> \n<p>Business plans can span dozens or even hundreds of pages, affording their drafters the opportunity to explain what a business's goals are and how the business will achieve them.</p> \n<blockquote>\n To show potential investors that they've addressed every question and thought through every possible scenario, entrepreneurs should thoroughly explain their marketing, sales, and operations strategies – from acquiring a physical location for the business to explaining a tactical approach for marketing penetration.\n</blockquote> \n<p>These explanations should ultimately lead to a business's break even point supported by a sales forecast and financial projections, with the business plan writer being able to speak to the why behind anything outlined in the plan.</p> \n<h3>3. Legitimizing a business idea.</h3> \n<p>Everyone's got a great idea for a company – until they put pen to paper and realize that it's not exactly feasible.</p> \n<p>The business plan is an aspiring entrepreneur's way to prove that a business idea is actually worth pursuing.</p> \n<p>As entrepreneurs document their go-to-market process, capital needs, and expected return on investment, entrepreneurs likely come across a few hiccups that will make them second guess their strategies and metrics – and that's exactly what the business plan is for.</p> \n<p>It ensures an entrepreneur's ducks are in a row before bring their business idea to the world and reassures the plan's readers that whoever wrote the plan is serious about the idea, having put hours into thinking of the business idea, fleshing out growth tactics, and calculating financial projections.</p> \n<h3>4. Getting an A in your Business class.</h3> \n<p>Speaking from personal experience, there's a chance you're here to get business plan ideas for your Business 101 class project.</p> \n<p>If that's the case, might we suggest checking out this post on <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/business-plan-template\">How to Write a Business Plan</a> – providing a section-by-section guide on creating your plan?</p> \n<h2><strong>Types of Business Plans</strong></h2> \n<h3>1. Startup Business Plan</h3> \n<p>Arguably the most common type of business plan, a startup business plan is used for brand new business ideas. This plan is used to take a business concept and lay the foundation for its eventual success.</p> \n<p>The biggest challenge with the startup business plan is that it requires its writer to completely start from scratch. Startup business plans start with a blank word document, and before they are finished, need to reference existing industry data and explain unique business strategies and go-to-market plans.</p> \n<h3>2. Business Acquisition Plan</h3> \n<p>Investors will still want to see a business plan to acquire funding to purchase an existing business in order to see how its new owner will run the business.</p> \n<p>What will change and what will stay the same under new ownership, and why? Additionally, the business plan should speak to what the current state of the to-be-acquired business is, and why it's up for sale.</p> \n<p>For example, if someone is purchasing a failing business, the business plan should explain why the business is being purchased and what the new owner will do to turn the business around, referencing previous business metrics, sales projections after the acquisition, and a justification for those projections.</p> \n<h3>3. Business Repositioning Plan</h3> \n<p>When a business wants to save itself, reposition its brand, or try something new, some CEOs or owners will want to develop a business repositioning plan.</p> \n<p>This plan should:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Acknowledge the current state of the company.</li> \n <li>State a vision for the future of the company.</li> \n <li>Explain why the business should (or must) be repositioned.</li> \n <li>Outline a process for how the company will adjust.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Companies planning for a business reposition do so – proactively or retroactively – due to a shift in market trends and customer needs. For example, <a href=\"https://www.restaurantbusinessonline.com/financing/pizza-hut-plans-close-hundreds-us-units\">Pizza Hut announced a plan</a> to drastically overhaul its brand last year, as it sees the need to shift from dine-in to delivery – a decision resulting from observing years of industry and company trends and acknowledging the need to reposition itself for the future of its sector.</p> \n<h3>4. Expansion Business Plan</h3> \n<p>Building onto a successful business venture with another location typically requires its own business plan, as the project may require a new location, focus on a new target market, and demand more capital.</p> \n<p>Fortunately, an expansion business plan allows its writers to reference sales, revenue, and successes from any previous location(s). However, as great as a reference as these points can be, it's important to not be <em>too</em> reliant on them, since it's still a new business that could succeed or fail for a myriad of reasons.</p> \n<h2><strong>Getting Started With Your Business Plan</strong></h2> \n<p>At the end of the day, a business plan is simply an explanation of a business idea and why it will be successful. The more detail and thought you put into it, the more successful your plan – and the business it outlines – will be.</p> \n<p>If you need help starting your business plan, download <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/business-plan-template\">Download HubSpot's Free Business Plan Template</a> and fill out the sections to meet your business idea's concept.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fwhat-is-business-plan&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 14 Aug 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":924,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/business-plan-Aug-04-2020-04-21-30-57-PM.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"e7740a89a97811b84df5f3e27b6f4e3a","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn35@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-27-296_aeb1a6f98cb70d63.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/business-plan-Aug-04-2020-04-21-30-57-PM.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"AJ Beltis","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/bpt-cover-gif-1.gif?width=443&name=bpt-cover-gif-1.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn4@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-28-936_0f9f0df1ada75d87.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fwhat-is-business-plan&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx20/cdn79@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-37-643_b4db0abc82431299.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","title":"How to Run a SWOT Analysis for Your Business [Template Included]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/swot-analysis","description":"<p>A SWOT analysis is a useful technique to evaluate a new project or objective your business faces, or your business as a whole.</p>  \n<p>Essentially, a SWOT analysis is a roadmap for how you should move forward with your business, which opportunities you’re missing out on, and which challenges you should tackle.</p> \n<p>It’s an effective method to maximize opportunities while minimizing negative factors associated with a given project or objective. Plus, it lets you unbiasedly evaluate your business’s strengths and weaknesses, which is key to avoiding unnecessary errors down the road from lack of insight.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Here, we’ll provide a SWOT analysis template, and conduct SWOT analyses on major brands Apple and Starbucks. When you’re done reading, you’ll have all the inspiration and tactical advice you need to tackle a SWOT analysis for yourself.</p> \n<p>You know a SWOT analysis is important, but, how do you conduct one?</p> \n<p>There are four steps you’ll want to take when evaluating your business as a whole, or your product in particular. Before you start, you’ll need to figure out what you’re evaluating with your SWOT analysis. Creating a social media program, launching a new product, or considering a brand re-design are all good reasons to conduct a SWOT analysis.</p> \n<h2><strong>Use this SWOT Analysis Template.</strong></h2> \n<p>To visualize your SWOT analysis, it's helpful to make a table. Here, I’ve created a sample using a simple Google Doc table -- feel free to use the model yourself, or create your own as it suits your needs.</p> \n<h3>Make a SWOT Analysis Table</h3> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/SWOT%20Analysis%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=SWOT%20Analysis%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg\" alt=\"free editable SWOT Analysis pdf template\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/market-research-kit?hubs_post-cta=imagesir\">Download a free, editable SWOT Analysis template.</a></p> \n<p>Use the four steps below as a references when filling in your table.</p> \n<p><strong>1. Identify your strengths.</strong></p> \n<p>Let’s say you want to use a SWOT analysis to evaluate your new social media strategy.</p> \n<p>If you’re looking at a new social media program, perhaps you want to evaluate how your brand is perceived by the public -- is it easily recognizable and well-known? Even if it’s not popular with a widespread group, is it well-received by a specific audience in particular?</p> \n<p>Next, think about your process: is it effective, or innovative? Is there good communication between your marketing and sales to ensure both departments use similar vocabulary when discussing your product?</p> \n<p>Finally, evaluate your social media message, and in particular, how it differs from the rest of the industry. I’m willing to bet you can make a lengthy list of some major strengths of your social media strategy over your competitors, so try to dive into your strengths from there.</p> \n<p><strong>2. Identify your weaknesses.</strong></p> \n<p>If you’re examining a new social media strategy, it’s critical to foresee any potential negative factors that could mitigate your success.</p> \n<p>Start by asking yourself these questions: First, if I were a consumer, what would prevent me from buying this product, or engaging with this business? What would make me click away from the screen?</p> \n<p>Second, what do I foresee as the biggest hinderance to my employees’ productivity, or their ability to get the job done efficiently? What derails their social media efforts?</p> \n<p>When identifying weaknesses, consider what areas of your business are the least profitable, where you lack certain resources, or what costs you the most time and money. Take input from employees in different departments, as they’ll likely see weaknesses you hadn’t considered.</p> \n<p><strong>3. Consider your opportunities.</strong></p> \n<p>This is your chance to dream big. What are some opportunities for your social media strategy you hope, but don’t necessarily expect, to reach?</p> \n<p>For instance, maybe you’re hoping your Facebook ads will attract a new, larger demographic. Maybe you’re hoping your YouTube video gets 10,000 views, and increases sales by 10%.</p> \n<p>Whatever the case, it’s important to include potential opportunities in your SWOT analysis. Ask yourself these questions: What technologies do I want my business to use to make it more effective? What new target audience do I want to reach? How can the business stand out more in the current industry? Is there something our customers complain about that we could fix with our social media strategy?</p> \n<p>The opportunities category goes hand-in-hand with the weaknesses category. Once you’ve made a list of weaknesses, it should be easy to create a list of potential opportunities that could arise if you eliminate your weaknesses.</p> \n<p><strong>4. Contemplate your threats. </strong></p> \n<p>It’s likely, especially if you’re prone to worrying, you already have a good list of threats in your head.</p> \n<p>If not, gather your employees and brainstorm: what obstacles might prevent us from reaching our social media goals? What’s going on in the industry, or with our competitors, that might mitigate our success? Is there new technology out there that could conflict with our product?</p> \n<p>Writing down your threats helps you evaluate them objectively. For instance, maybe you list your threats in terms of least and most likely to occur, and divide and conquer each. If one of your biggest threats is your competitor’s popular Instagram account, you could work with your marketing department to create content that showcases your product’s unique features.</p> \n<h2><strong>SWOT Analysis Examples</strong></h2> \n<p>The template above helps get you started on your own SWOT analysis.</p> \n<p>But, if you’re anything like me, it’s not enough to see a template. To fully understand a concept, you need to see how it plays out in the real world.</p> \n<p>Here are two examples of SWOT analyses on major corporations, Apple and Starbucks. The list of strengths and weaknesses is not exhaustive, and I’m sure you could add some yourself, but hopefully, it’s enough to inspire your own SWOT analysis.</p> \n<h3>Apple’s SWOT analysis</h3> \n<p>Here’s how we’d conduct a SWOT analysis on Apple.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-10-22%20at%2010.11.17%20AM.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-10-22%20at%2010.11.17%20AM.png\" alt=\"SWOT analysis showing Apple's Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, and Threats\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">First off, strengths. While Apple has many strengths, let’s identify the top three:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>Brand recognition</li> \n <li>High prices</li> \n <li>Innovative products</li> \n</ol> \n<p>Apple’s brand is undeniably valuable, and was named the <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/kurtbadenhausen/2017/05/23/apple-heads-the-worlds-most-valuable-brands-of-2017-at-170-billion/#192b9e3f384b\">world’s most valuable brand</a> by Forbes. Since it’s easily recognized, Apple can produce new products and almost ensure a certain degree of success by virtue of the brand name itself.</p> \n<p>This degree of recognition lends itself to Apple’s ability to sell products at extremely high prices. For instance, in 2016, Apple <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/kurtbadenhausen/2017/05/23/apple-heads-the-worlds-most-valuable-brands-of-2017-at-170-billion/#192b9e3f384b\">sold 78 million iPhones, the average cost of which was $695</a>. In comparison, Samsung sold their smartphones for $500 less. And yet, <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/kurtbadenhausen/2017/05/23/apple-heads-the-worlds-most-valuable-brands-of-2017-at-170-billion/#7ca54732384b\">92% of the profits in the smartphone category</a> for 2016 went to Apple. Often, people don’t care about price as much as they care about brand recognition.</p> \n<p>Lastly, their innovative products: Apple didn’t earn its reputation for nothing. They create highly innovative products, which are often at the forefront of the industry.</p> \n<p>Next, let’s look at three of Apple’s weaknesses.</p> \n<ol> \n <li>High prices</li> \n <li>Closed ecosystem</li> \n <li>Lack of experimentation</li> \n</ol> \n<p>While the high prices don’t deter Apple’s middle and high class customer-base, they do hinder Apple’s ability to reach a lower-class demographic.</p> \n<p>Apple also suffers from its own exclusivity. Apple controls all its services and products in-house, and while many customers become loyal brand advocates for this reason, it means all burdens fall on Apple employees.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, Apple’s tight control over who distributes their products limit their market reach.</p> \n<p>Lastly, Apple is held to a high standard when it comes to creating and distributing products. Apple’s brand carries a high level of prestige, but that level of recognition inhibits Apple from taking risks and experimenting freely with new products that could fail.</p> \n<p>Now, let’s take a look at opportunities for Apple.</p> \n<p>It’s easy to recognize opportunities for improvement, once you consider Apple’s weaknesses. Here’s a list of three we came up with:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>Expand distribution options</li> \n <li>Create new product lines</li> \n <li>Technological advancement</li> \n</ol> \n<p>One of Apple’s biggest weaknesses is its distribution network, which, in the name of exclusivity, remains relatively small. If Apple expanded its network and enabled third-party businesses to sell its products, it could reach more people globally, while alleviating some of the stress currently put on in-house employees.</p> \n<p>There are also plenty of opportunities for Apple to create new products. Apple could consider creating more affordable products to reach a larger demographic, or spreading out into new industries -- Apple self-driving cars, perhaps?</p> \n<p>Finally, Apple could continue advancing its products’ technology. Apple can take existing products and refine them, ensuring each product offers as many unique features as possible.</p> \n<p>Finally, let’s look at threats to Apple.</p> \n<p>Believe it or not, they do exist.</p> \n<p>Here are three of Apple’s biggest threats:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>Tough competition</li> \n <li>Lawsuits</li> \n <li>International issues</li> \n</ol> \n<p>Apple isn’t the only innovative tech company out there, and it continues to face tough competition from Samsung, Google, and other major forces. Many of Apple’s weaknesses hinder Apple’s ability to compete with the tech corporations that have more freedom to experiment, or that don’t operate in a closed ecosystem.</p> \n<p>A second threat to Apple is lawsuits. Over the last few years, Apple has faced a bunch of lawsuits, particularly between <a href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2017/10/23/16519546/apple-samsung-patent-lawsuit-damages-retrial-october\">Apple and Samsung</a>, and so far it has only <a href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2017/11/6/16614038/apple-samsung-slide-to-unlock-supreme-court-120-million\">won one case</a>. These lawsuits interfere with Apple’s reputable image, and could steer some customers to purchasing elsewhere.</p> \n<p>Finally, Apple needs to improve its reach internationally. It isn’t <a href=\"https://www.androidauthority.com/in-china-the-iphone-is-only-second-best-830776/\">number one in China</a>, and doesn’t have a very positive relationship with the Chinese government. Then, in India, which has one of the largest consumer markets in the world, <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2018/01/29/why-apple-sells-just-2-point-5-percent-of-indias-smartphones.html\">Apple’s market share is low</a>, and the company has trouble bringing stores to India’s market.</p> \n<p>If Apple can’t compete globally the way Samsung or Google can, it risks falling behind in the industry.</p> \n<h3>Starbucks SWOT Analysis</h3> \n<p>Now that we’ve explored the nuances involved with a SWOT analysis, let’s fill out a SWOT template using Starbucks as an example.</p> \n<p>Here’s how we’d fill out a SWOT template, if we were Starbucks:</p> \n<div>\n <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/market-research-kit?hubs_post-cta=image\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/starbucksswotanalysis.png\" alt=\"Starbucks SWOT Analysis example\"></a>\n</div> \n<div style=\"text-align: center;\">\n <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/market-research-kit?hubs_post-cta=imagebottom\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">Download this Template for Free</span></a>\n</div> \n<h3>Dine-In Thai Restaurant SWOT Analysis</h3> \n<p>Some small-business marketers may have difficulty relating to the SWOT's of big brands like Apple and Starbucks, so here's an example of how a restaurant might visualize each element:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-10-22%20at%2010.26.00%20AM.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-10-22%20at%2010.26.00%20AM.png\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"Dine-in Thai Restaurant SWOT analysis example\">While a Thai or any other restaurant might not be as worried about high-level lawsuits like Apple, the small business might be more worried about competitors or disruptors that might enter the playing field.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>Local Boutique SWOT Analysis</h3> \n<p>In another small-business example, a local boutique might be well known in its neighborhood, but it also might take time to build an online presence or get its products in an online store. Because of this, some of its strengths and opportunities might relate to physical factors while weaknesses and threats might relate to online situations.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-10-22%20at%2010.24.40%20AM.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-10-22%20at%2010.24.40%20AM.png\" alt=\"Local boutique SWOT analysis example\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h2>When to Use a SWOT Analysis</h2> \n<p>Ultimately, a SWOT analysis can measure and tackle both big and small challenges, and opportunities, and both big and little strengths and weaknesses.</p> \n<p>While the examples above focus on businesses in general, you can also use a SWOT analysis to evaluate and predict how a singular product will play out in the market.</p> \n<p>Hopefully, our SWOT template will supplement your market research and business analysis, and provide fair insights into how to optimize your products for bigger payoffs, and less hurdles.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in May, 2018 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fswot-analysis&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 07 Aug 2020 19:05:00 +0000","feedId":924,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/swotanalysishowto.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"9f22ef1f9504cd42dddbf2da0dba5e4b","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn52@2020_2/2020/08/16/13-48-27-414_2c6ff155beebac4e.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/swotanalysishowto.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"Caroline Forsey","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/SWOT%20Analysis%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg?width=1500&name=SWOT%20Analysis%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx17/cdn68@2020_3/2020/08/16/13-48-36-903_28f7ed392ffa061e.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-10-22%20at%2010.11.17%20AM.png?width=600&name=Screen%20Shot%202019-10-22%20at%2010.11.17%20AM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn88@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-38-555_d17ce5537f683cfa.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/starbucksswotanalysis.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn47@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-37-537_a268c0f05cb65a0a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-10-22%20at%2010.26.00%20AM.png?width=600&name=Screen%20Shot%202019-10-22%20at%2010.26.00%20AM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn67@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-31-575_e725d410d9523fc7.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-10-22%20at%2010.24.40%20AM.png?width=600&name=Screen%20Shot%202019-10-22%20at%2010.24.40%20AM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn60@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-30-777_8e5e600abafa5af5.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fswot-analysis&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn99@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-34-331_fb1068d473508007.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","title":"Everything You Need to Know About Affiliate Marketing","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/affiliate-marketing-guide","description":"<p>If you’ve ever came across <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/4-Hour-Workweek-Escape-Live-Anywhere/dp/0307465357\">Tim Ferris's iconic book</a> on how to just work four hours per week, you’ve probably dreamed of sipping a Mojito on a beach while your money worked for you in the background. One of the main ideas he constantly talks about is the concept of <strong>passive income</strong>.</p> \n<p>After all, having an income chart like this is the main goal of many online entrepreneurs:</p> \n<div> \n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Affiliate%20Marketing.png?width=1500&amp;name=The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Affiliate%20Marketing.png\" alt=\"passive income goal sample chart\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"> </img>\n</div> \n<p>For many entrepreneurs looking to build an online business or marketers looking to monetize their web traffic, affiliate marketing is often how they got started with generating income.</p> \n<p><strong>Affiliate marketing</strong> is one of the world’s most popular methods of generating passive income online, and it continues to grow. In fact, affiliate marketing spend is reported to <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/693438/affiliate-marketing-spending/\">increase to $8.2 billion</a> by 2022 — up from $5.4 billion in 2017.</p> \n<p>If you’re looking for a complete guide to affiliate marketing, read more to find out how you can promote products as an affiliate to create an additional source of income.</p> \n<p></p> \n<a></a> \n<p>There are typically four parties involved in affiliate marketing:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Affiliates: </strong>The promoters of the product</li> \n <li><strong>Product creators: </strong>The creators of the product</li> \n <li><strong>Networks: </strong>The networks managing the affiliates</li> \n <li><strong>Consumers: </strong>The end users of the product</li> \n</ul> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202018-12-10%20at%205.00.57%20PM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202018-12-10%20at%205.00.57%20PM.png\" alt=\"affiliate marketing model\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://digitaladsonline.com/\"><em>Image Source</em></a></p> \n<p>You don’t always need a network to become an affiliate, but the other three parties (the affiliates, the product creators, and the consumers) form the core of an affiliate program.</p> \n<h3>Who are the affiliates?</h3> \n<p>An affiliate, also known as a publisher, can be an individual or a company. Typically, these are other bloggers or content creators operating in the industry of the product they are creating.</p> \n<p>They help promote the product or service by creating content like blog posts, videos, or other media.</p> \n<p>They can also promote their content to get transactions by putting up ads, capturing search traffic from SEO, or building an email list.</p> \n<p>When one of their visitors creates a transaction, which could be a purchase or submitting a lead form, the affiliate gets a commission. How much commission is structured depends on the affiliate program terms.</p> \n<h3>Who are the merchants?</h3> \n<p>A merchant, also known as the product creator or advertiser, is typically the creator of the product or services. They offer revenue sharing and commissions to people or other companies (affiliates), which have a significant following on their brand.</p> \n<p>The merchant can be a company like HubSpot, which offers a commission to every affiliate who’s able to get their visitors to make a purchase.</p> \n<p>Or it can be an individual like Pat Flynn, who offers an affiliate program with his podcasts.</p> \n<p>The merchants can be anyone from a solopreneur to a big company, as long as they are willing to pay their affiliates to help them gain a transaction.</p> \n<p>Sometimes the merchant does not even have to be the product creator, as in the case of the <a href=\"https://affiliate-program.amazon.com/\">Amazon Associates Program</a>.</p> \n<h3>Who are the affiliate networks?</h3> \n<p>An affiliate network acts as an intermediary between the merchants and their affiliates. In some cases, a network is not necessary, but some companies choose to work with a network to add a layer of trust.</p> \n<p>The network manages the relationship and provides third-party checks and balances. Third-party checks can be important because they bring down fraud rates.</p> \n<p>Some popular networks include <a href=\"https://www.clickbank.com/\">ClickBank</a> and <a href=\"https://www.shareasale.com/\">ShareASale</a>.</p> \n<p>Some merchants choose to work with an affiliate network because they lack the time or resources to track, report, and manage payments to the affiliates. They might also choose to work with multiple affiliates or publishers within the affiliate network.</p> \n<h3>Who are the consumers?</h3> \n<p>The consumers or customers are the ones who makes the transaction. They are the ones who purchase the product or submit the lead form in order for the affiliate to gain the commission.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\"></span></p> \n<p>We'll talk more about <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/affiliate-marketing-guide#get-paid\">getting paid in the next section</a>. In the meantime, here are some common affiliate marketing models:</p> \n<p><strong>Pay-Per-Click (PPC):</strong> The affiliate gets paid for all clicks that were generated, regardless of whether a lead or sale happened. This is fairly rare since all the risk is on the product creator.</p> \n<p><strong>Pay-Per-Lead (PPL)</strong>: The affiliate gets paid for every lead they generated. This could be an online form submission, trial creation, or any pre-purchase. This is a shared risk on both the merchant and the affiliate.</p> \n<p><strong>Pay-Per-Sale (PPS)</strong>: The affiliate gets paid for every sale they generated. This is the most common model since all the risk is on the affiliate.</p> \n<p>Now, let's talk about how to get started with affiliate marketing.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p></p> \n<p>When it comes to affiliate marketing, most people think it's a process of earning a commission by promoting other people’s or company’s products.</p> \n<p>While affiliate marketing can seem straightforward — just find a product you love, promote it, and earn a piece of profit with every sale you make — there are actually a few moving parts you need to a monitor.</p> \n<h3>1. Choose a platform and niche.</h3> \n<p>To be an affiliate, you need to have influence. Establishing a website or blog that specializes in a niche is the best way to establish influence. Whether you focus on finance, personal health, business, or even cats, a niched blog or website will help you gain influence and build an audience.</p> \n<p>Affiliate marketers build audiences through blogs (on <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/wordpress\">WordPress</a> or <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/cms\">HubSpot</a>),&nbsp;via <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-create-email-newsletters-ht\">newsletters</a>, or even on&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/youtube-marketing\">YouTube</a> or other social media channels.</p> \n<h3>2. Build an audience.</h3> \n<p>A large, engaged audience is a highly valuable asset for any blog or website. Having people who read, view, and engage with your content can help you make affiliate income.</p> \n<p>The best way to build an audience is to first establish who your target audience is, and you can <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/target-audience\">find your target audience</a> by researching competitors, monitoring your traffic, and conducting first-hand research by talking to subscribers and customers.</p> \n<p>Once you establish this group, grow and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/build-audience-online\">cultivate your loyal online audience</a> through targeted content and emails. Give your audience a reason to read and engage with your content, and they'll find a reason to purchase your recommended products, too.</p> \n<h3>3. Sign up for an affiliate program.</h3> \n<p>The best way to get started with affiliate marketing is by signing up for an affiliate program like the <a href=\"https://affiliate-program.amazon.com\">Amazon Associates</a> or <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/partners/affiliates?utm_source=pillarpage\">HubSpot Affiliate Program</a>. After signing up, you will get an affiliate link that contains a unique ID. You can then use this link in your content.</p> \n<p>There are typically no upfront costs when it comes to joining an affiliate program, but your variable ongoing costs will depend on how you want to promote the products. If you choose to outsource content or run ads, those are costs that will come out of your pocket.</p> \n<h3>4. Choose which products to promote.</h3> \n<p>Choosing the right product to promote, working with the right company, fostering relationships, and updating content are all core essentials of excelling at affiliate marketing.</p> \n<p>According to <a href=\"https://www.smartpassiveincome.com/affiliate-marketing-strategies/\">Pat Flynn</a>, one of the pioneers of creating passive income through providing value to his audience, there are two important rules when it comes to affiliate marketing:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Only recommend products as an affiliate that you’re extremely very familiar with. If you are not confident in the product and do not feel it will help people, do not promote it.</li> \n <li>Never tell anyone to directly buy a product. Always recommend products based on your experience and in the context of what you’ve done.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>When it comes to choosing the right products, <a href=\"http://davidgonzalezagency.com/\">David Gonzalez</a> — founder of an affiliate management agency, suggests that you should think about these three components when choosing a product to promote:</p> \n<ol> \n <li><strong>Your audience:</strong> Will the product resonate with them and make them grateful you promoted it?</li> \n <li><strong>Product quality &amp; value: </strong>Would you advocate your best friend buying it?</li> \n <li><strong>Profitability: </strong>Does the offer have highly competitive conversions &amp; payouts?</li> \n</ol> \n<p>After reading these recommendations, do any products come to mind?</p> \n<h3>5. Create remarkable content that promotes your affiliate products.</h3> \n<p>To see the best success with affiliate marketing, you need to create genuine and remarkable content that promotes your chosen products. Write a round-up blog post of your favorite products. Create comparison charts that discuss the merits of similar products. Interview other users and fans of the products to showcase different opinions.</p> \n<p>Regardless of what kind of content you create, ensure it features authentic reviews and mentions of your affiliate products. Avoid discussing and promoting products you haven't used yourself.</p> \n<h3>6. Optimize and track.</h3> \n<p>Whenever your visitor clicks on your unique affiliate link, a cookie is inserted in their browser to track actions.</p> \n<p>When they make a transaction that is a qualified action (could be a sale or lead form submission, depending on the terms of the program), the merchant is able to record this action and attribute it to you as an affiliate so they can make a payout.</p> \n<p>You should track your own affiliate content, too, to see what has performed well and what you can improve and promote. Understanding what content resonates best with your audience will show you what to focus on for future affiliate marketing opportunities.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>7. Get paid.</h3> \n<p>There are different structures when it comes to payout, which varies based on affiliate program terms.</p> \n<p>Commission payouts by the company are usually given on a monthly basis, but this varies depending on the affiliate program terms.</p> \n<p>It could be a weekly payout or a monthly payment for all the leads or sales you've made.</p> \n<p>You'll want to pay attention to the payout structure when choosing an affiliate program to join, which ultimately depends on the goals you have.</p> \n<p>You might want to understand the commission structure of the company or product creator. Are you looking for a commission per sale or commission per lead generated? Are you looking at a recurring commission or a one-off payment?</p> \n<p>Depending on your goals, this will affect which product you choose, how you plan to promote the product as well as how much time &amp; resources you want to invest.</p> \n<p>For instance, if you choose to promote your content via paid ads, then that’s a cost you have to account for. You will have to compare how much you’ve spent to promote each piece of content or to generate each purchase against how much commission you’re getting for each referred sale.</p> \n<p>Or, if you have a blog and website, then you will have to pay for hosting. In this case, this should be a flat fee spread out across all your referred sale.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/marketing-plan-template-generator\">Use this marketing plan generator </a>to calculate how much you need to invest to get a basic marketing plan up and running.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3><strong>How much can you make from affiliate programs?</strong></h3> \n<p>You might be wondering, what are established affiliates earnings? (established affiliates are those working full-time.) Well, that varies. I've seen super affiliates <a href=\"https://affise.com/blog/how-much-you-earn-affiliate-marketing/\">earn upwards of $100,000 per month</a>.</p> \n<p>Making money from an affiliate program is more about the profits than the revenue you’re getting.</p> \n<p>An affiliate making $5000/day might be worse off than another affiliate making $500/day with no cash outflow because the former might be spending most of his revenue on paid acquisition.</p> \n<p>At the end of the day, before becoming an affiliate, you have to align your expectations to your earning potential. What kind of industry or niche you operate in, and what kind of work you do depends a lot on how much you want to make.</p> \n<p>If you focus on ads like Adwords or Facebook to promote your affiliate products, how much money you invest is as important (if not more) as how much you make.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Are you ready to start affiliate marketing?</h2> \n<p>I commonly hear one misconception: <strong>affiliate marketing is dead</strong>.</p> \n<p>It seems like every year in the world of online marketing, people have mentioned some variant of X is dead — SEO, email, mobile, etc.</p> \n<p>The test of time is a pretty good test — if something has stayed around for a while, there’s a better chance of it sticking around for a while.</p> \n<p>Everything evolves, and there are tactics that don’t work the exact same way as they did before. Affiliate marketing, of course, is no exception to that rule.</p> \n<p>Affiliate marketing has evolved from a get-rich-quick scheme into something that requires affiliate to build real trust with their audience in order to reap the rewards of the work that’s been put in.</p> \n<p>At the end of the day, become successful at affiliate marketing requires you to nail down the fundamentals of marketing. Authenticity is hard to fake, especially when it comes to building your own personal brand.</p> \n<p>A brand that promotes products incessantly without any regard for bring real value to its audience will find affiliate marketing to be a short-lived source of income. Choosing the right products to promote, stemming from a true passion for what the product does, forms the basis of all your promotional activities.</p> \n<p>While there are many tactics to scale your promotion, the golden rule of affiliate marketing stays the same: only promote products you love &amp; treat your audience like humans.</p> \n<p>Build your own brand, choose products that you love, create authentic content and you will be on your way to building a real source of passive income.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in December 2018 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p><em></em></p> \n<p><em></em></p> \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Faffiliate-marketing-guide&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \" />","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 04 Aug 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":924,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/GettyImages-1166371279.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"61ae5bd792623f20e17f60d15668167f","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn52@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-27-313_002f40c0c2626737.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/GettyImages-1166371279.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"jwlee@hubspot.com (Justin Lee)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Affiliate%20Marketing.png?width=1500&name=The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Affiliate%20Marketing.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn11@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-36-347_7a8152b120ebc75d.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202018-12-10%20at%205.00.57%20PM.png?width=1500&name=Screen%20Shot%202018-12-10%20at%205.00.57%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx20/cdn95@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-34-390_9062ed3f073b59f9.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Faffiliate-marketing-guide&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn84@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-31-351_7093cdb40ebbdc31.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","title":"15 Essential Social Media Marketing Tips From Beginner to Advanced","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/data-backed-social-media-marketing-tips","description":"<p>One of the most humbling experiences as a marketer is putting out that tweet you just <em>knew</em> would be a home run for your audience.</p>  \n<p>We’d like to think of ourselves as being able to come up with A+ <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/resources/courses/social-media\">social media</a> content every day, but the reality is that we're all human. Sometimes, we hit a wall with planning content that aligns with our company and goals.</p> \n<p>If you're just starting out in <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/social-media?utm_source=marketing_blog&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=social_media\">social media marketing</a> or are looking for a few tips to get inspiration, we've compiled some helpful knowledge to beef up your accounts — no matter your skill level.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3>1. Sync posts across all social media accounts.</h3> \n<p>If you're just starting out, it's a good idea to invest in a social media management service like <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/social-inbox\">HubSpot's Social Inbox</a>. This tool can help you schedule posts, monitor mentions, track your social analytics, and keep an eye on all your accounts. Similar tools include <a href=\"https://later.com/\">Later</a> and&nbsp;<a href=\"https://tweetdeck.twitter.com/\"> TweetDeck</a>.</p> \n<p>These apps will also let you sync posts across various accounts. Keeping content synced will ensure you post across all of your platforms and introduce followers with multiple accounts to your brand.</p> \n<h3>2. Republish and update older posts.</h3> \n<p>If you have a backlog of content that's outdated, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/guide-to-updating-republishing-blogging-content-ht\">update and republish it</a> with fresh ideas for SEO. This tactic has the potential to draw in new readers and take less time than continuously pumping out new ideas.</p> \n<p>This can be blog posts, landing pages, and offers that you have on your website. Your social media strategy exists to put your best foot forward by building engagement, and you don't have to start from ground zero.</p> \n<p>In fact, this exact post is an update from 2017, originally posted in 2013. We regularly update posts to ensure our readers are getting fresh content on our blog, social channels, and emails.</p> \n<h3>3. Schedule posts for evenings.</h3> \n<p>Don’t be afraid of weekends either. Scheduling content launches for evenings opens up a door for engagement that isn't cut off by time zone. That way, even if it's 3 AM in your geographic location, your tweet about your new app update reaches audiences around the world.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/hubspotlife/?hl=en\">HubSpot Life</a> is a behind-the-scenes look at HubSpot's culture, posting content from global offices on social media. During what's considered \"off\" hours in the US, HubSpot Life features posts during work hours in other countries, like Paris, Bogota, or Dublin.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-08-11%20at%2010.25.49%20AM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-08-11%20at%2010.25.49%20AM.png\" alt=\"hubspot life instagram\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/hubspotlife/?hl=en\"><em>Image Source</em></a></p> \n<p>This ensures that global audiences are able to get fresh content during their work days, as well.</p> \n<p>When scheduling posts for evenings, avoid content that requires engagement from your team. For instance, an Instagram photo that invites followers to <i> \"Comment below!\"</i> about something might not be the best idea to post at midnight, when you're not able to engage.</p> \n<h3>4. Include hashtags to increase engagement</h3> \n<p>Hashtags are like a golden ticket to increasing your online reach. Common tags like #SocialMedia and #MarketingGoals are great, but try searching for less-used ones like those of bigger brands (such as Adobe's #CreateYourStory), or community-based (#BrightonMA). Those are going to be the ones an active audience is checking out.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Buffer-on-Instagram-bio-example.png?width=1500&amp;name=Buffer-on-Instagram-bio-example.png\" alt=\"buffer on instagram hashtags\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://www.business2community.com/brandviews/buffer/the-science-behind-the-best-instagram-bios-02246266\"><em>Image Source</em></a></p> \n<p>As well as using existing hashtags, try your hand at creating your own branded hashtags, like <a href=\"https://buffer.com/\"> Buffer</a> did in the example above (#BufferLove). This allows you to track what your followers and customers are saying about your media presence and product.</p> \n<h3>5. Use visuals whenever possible.</h3> \n<p>If you're getting your feet wet with the social media game, it's okay not to invest a fortune into visual content. However, it's always a good idea to include pictures, videos, or graphics in posts whenever you can.</p> \n<p>There are a number of free services, like <a href=\"https://www.canva.com/\"> Canva</a> , to help you edit and create content. <a href=\"https://giphy.com/\"> GIFs</a> are a great way to engage with a younger audience. And never forget the smartphone most likely in your pocket they produce beautiful pictures you can definitely use on socials.</p> \n<p>If you've tried your hand at social media before and feel comfortable branching out, these intermediate tips are for you. They're aimed at easing the process of creating uniform content across your channels while increasing clicks.</p> \n<h3>1. Post multiple times a day.</h3> \n<p>You don't need to post every hour, but one to three times a day keeps your brand fresh in your audience's mind. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-user-generated-content-campaigns\">Reposting user-generated content</a> also counts, so don’t stress about coming up with dozens of new content ideas.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/guide-user-generated-content-ecommerce\"><em>Download this free guide to learn how to leverage user-generated content to improve your conversion rates.</em></a></p> \n<p>If you’re looking for ways to brush up your content marketing, how about incorporating an infographic or eBook into that Facebook post? For more tips like those, check out our list <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-marketing-types?_ga=2.163078463.2000696366.1572268289-940436819.1565181751\"> here.</a></p> \n<h3>2. Incorporate your brand into your social strategy.</h3> \n<p>Your brand should speak for you. Once you've established your brand, think of ways to blend it into your social media marketing. This can mean adding your logo to posts, including a company hashtag, or highlighting your employees.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/metter%20media%20branding.png?width=1500&amp;name=metter%20media%20branding.png\" alt=\"Metter Media branding example\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 1500px;\" width=\"1500\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/mettermedia/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>Check out this branding from social media management company, Metter Media. From a quick scroll through their Instagram homepage, you can quickly spot company colors, get a look into their team, and gain an idea of who they represent.</p> \n<h3>3. Engage audiences with interactive content.</h3> \n<p>From Twitter polls to Instagram Q&amp;As, there are many ways to engage your audience and make your company’s content diverse. You can use interactive content to educate your audience about your products or to connect with your audience.</p> \n<p>Think of ways your audience engages with competitors and how you can add your company into the mix. You can even ask your audience what type of content they prefer to see on an Instagram story, like this example below:</p> \n<div> \n <p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/polling%20screenshot-1.png?width=359&amp;name=polling%20screenshot-1.png\" style=\"width: 359px; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"Instagram poll example\" width=\"359\"><a href=\"http://instagram.com/frommybowl\"></a></p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"http://instagram.com/frommybowl\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n</div> \n<p>The story of this food blogger begins to recap previous recipes with links to corresponding blog posts. To put this in a B2B perspective, say you wanted to boost clicks on previous blog content. You could poll followers, <i> \"Which type of post goes best with your coffee?\" </i> and link to two options in the next parts of your story.</p> \n<h3>4. Invest in more visual content.</h3> \n<p>As you get into the swing of posting on social media, invest more time into visual content. On average, retweets with pictures gain more clicks and views than text-only posts.</p> \n<p>Visual content isn't just restricted to Instagram. Post infographics about your industry on LinkedIn, tweet a funny meme relating to your office culture, or post a video on Facebook taking viewers on a high-speed tour of your office.</p> \n<p>Next up are some advanced tips. These ideas are for social media pros in need of a new direction or options to brighten their feeds.</p> \n<h3>1. Use new app updates to your advantage.</h3> \n<p>Have you tried <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-tiktok\"> TikTok</a> or <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/igtv\">IGTV</a> yet? If not, we suggest expanding your strategy to include these channels. After all, you don’t want to miss out on your content having the potential to meet <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tiktok-hit-1-billion-downloads-surpassing-instagram-in-2018-2019-2\">one billion</a> phones.</p> \n<p>New apps and app updates add to the ability to diversify your brand and keep things fresh. If you're looking to show your company's humorous side, try uploading a little <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/brands-on-tiktok?_ga=2.157622713.2000696366.1572268289-940436819.1565181751\"> dance</a> video on TikTok. If you want to bring that podcast of yours to visual audiences, upload it to IGTV.</p> \n<div>\n <iframe style=\"margin: 0px auto display: block display: block; display: block;\" src=\"https://www.tiktok.com/embed/6720653674525363461\" width=\"340\" height=\"700\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n</div> \n<h3>2. Invest in influencers to promote your product or service.</h3> \n<p>It's official: young audiences listen to their idols. <a href=\"https://www.thinkwithgoogle.com/consumer-insights/youtube-stars-influence/\"> Four in 10</a> millennials trust the products their favorite influencers promote on their social channels, so <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-work-with-influencers\">investing in influencers</a> might be an avenue to look into when trying to generate sales.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/influencer-marketing-guide\"><em>Download our free ultimate guide to getting started with influencer marketing.</em></a></p> \n<p>If you have an audience that's younger, research influencers in your industry and pitch potential partnerships. Or, for a more budget-friendly option, look at how influencers are branding their content — you may be able to incorporate some ideas into your strategy.</p> \n<h3>3. Diversify content on every social media platform.</h3> \n<p>You can update and sync content on your accounts like a pro. Now it's time to make that content unique. Save your high-definition videos for Facebook and meme posts for Twitter.</p> \n<p>When diversifying content, make sure they all relate back to your company's goals and mission. There's no need to post a recipe for falafel on your marketing company's Instagram, but an infographic displaying the 'recipe' for a perfect caption would be a compelling, spot on example.</p> \n<div> \n <blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\"> \n  <p>If you're a writer, a filmmaker, or really anyone who’s looking for good career advice, check out this thread from <a href=\"https://twitter.com/chrismcquarrie?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@chrismcquarrie</a>. 🙌 <a href=\"https://t.co/RRCbxoO8kg\">https://t.co/RRCbxoO8kg</a></p> — LinkedIn (@LinkedIn) \n  <a href=\"https://twitter.com/LinkedIn/status/1187391628916510720?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 24, 2019</a>\n </blockquote> \n</div>   \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/linkedin%20diversifying%20content%20example.png\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"LinkedIn Facebook post\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"http://facebook.com/linkedin\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>On October 24th, LinkedIn highlighted a blog post on Facebook. On the same day, LinkedIn promoted a Twitter thread aimed at aspiring filmmakers. Threads are a Twitter-specific tool aimed at sectioning off long thoughts, while the Facebook post gives LinkedIn more clicks from their Facebook followers.</p> \n<h3>4. Start promotions to build audience growth.</h3> \n<p>Have you run a contest on your Twitter account yet? Totino's does them well.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/totinos%20promotion.png?width=1500&amp;name=totinos%20promotion.png\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"Totinos promotion tweet example\" width=\"1500\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"http://twitter.com/totinos\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>Don't worry, promotions don't have to be this fancy. Running a promotion can be simple as giving 10% off of your product or service to a lucky winner who retweets. This expands your reach and sparks lead generation among your customers' followers.</p> \n<h3>5. Create timely content that resonates with audiences.</h3> \n<p>As a huge believer in taking advantage in the meme of the moment, creating timely content adds some fun to your channels and can explain the uses of your product in a new way. Memes aren't the only way to accomplish this, seasons are, as well.</p> \n<p>Is it wintertime in your part of the world? Celebrate by snapping a pic of your company's favorite snowy activity and share it to Facebook. Alternatively, #NationalSandwichDay is November 3rd. Popeye's used this holiday to announce the comeback of a recent fan favorite.</p> \n<div> \n <blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\"> \n  <p>Y’all…the sandwich is back Sunday, November 3rd. Then every day. 🤯🔥 <a href=\"https://t.co/JDxyCIv0zz\">pic.twitter.com/JDxyCIv0zz</a></p> — Popeyes Chicken (@PopeyesChicken) \n  <a href=\"https://twitter.com/PopeyesChicken/status/1188780503601680384?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 28, 2019</a>\n </blockquote>  \n</div> \n<p>Is it too early to call this genius type of marketing “legendary?”</p> \n<p>Keeping content fresh can be difficult, even if you're a social media pro. The pressure is on nowadays when it seems like the trends are changing every second, and diving in can seem like jumping down a rabbit hole.</p> \n<p>These tips will keep you current on ways to organize your page, upgrade your content, and grow your target audience, but don't stop here. Check out our ultimate guide on social media marketing for more <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-media-marketing?_ga=2.192233897.2000696366.1572268289-940436819.1565181751\"> inspiration</a>.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in 2013 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fdata-backed-social-media-marketing-tips&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\"
