\">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 05 Aug 2020 11:30:00 +0000","feedId":924,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/imageedit_24_6767743391.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"55f1319403b354f5bfd03f0c32028cbd","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn87@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-28-374_a4fdee626f1f6f84.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/imageedit_24_6767743391.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"aechtwilson@hubspot.com (Ari Echt-Wilson)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/chatbots-improve-customer-experience-experiment-1.png?width=1500&name=chatbots-improve-customer-experience-experiment-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn55@2020_3/2020/08/16/13-48-31-948_087824bde2b2afbc.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/chatbots-improve-customer-experience-experiment-2.png?width=1500&name=chatbots-improve-customer-experience-experiment-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx17/cdn28@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-32-239_bbfe3b34eb7f56a4.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/chatbots-improve-customer-experience-experiment-3-1.png?width=1500&name=chatbots-improve-customer-experience-experiment-3-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn23@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-29-697_e6768fa8a751a02c.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/chatbots-improve-customer-experience-experiment-4.gif?width=480&name=chatbots-improve-customer-experience-experiment-4.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn87@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-33-638_2db4719445ea8594.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fchatbots-improve-customer-experience-experiment&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn24@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-28-574_91610e8525bc2856.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","title":"Lights, Camera, Action: How to Record a Webinar Worth Replaying","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/9990/how-to-record-a-webinar.aspx","description":"<p>A few short months ago, I discovered the beauty of webinars.</p>  \n<p>I love to learn more about the marketing industry. Every chance I get, I'm on LinkedIn searching for engaging content that teaches me something new about social media or content creation.</p> \n<p>And my favorite way to learn is by watching a webinar.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>By taking an hour out of my day, I can gain valuable insights from industry experts about virtually any topic. In most cases, I'm introduced to a new thought leader in the space, as well.</p> \n<p>The only downside to webinars is that a lot of them are live events. Most of the time, my schedule doesn't allow for a \"One-time only\" experience, so I miss out on a lot of compelling webinars.</p> \n<p>Fortunately, there's a simple fix around that: Recording them.</p> \n<p>If it sounds like a lot of extra work to record a webinar, edit, <em>and </em>figure out where it'll live post-launch, don't worry. This post will show you how to do it in five easy steps.</p> \n<p>Ready to get started and press \"Record\"?</p> \n<h2>Why record webinars?</h2> \n<p>Webinars are a fantastic addition to your content marketing toolkit. Though they take time to produce, they can be extremely valuable for your audience. They're basically vocal eBooks — They present educational lessons in a fun, engaging format.</p> \n<p>For example, this webinar is a short, insightful discussion about how to manage a remote sales team:</p> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; max-width: 560px; max-height: 315px; min-width: 256px; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.25%; margin: 0;\">\n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/c4Zl3vos-WA\" width=\"560\" height=\"315\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n </div> \n</div> \n<p>You might want to consider recording your webinar for a couple of reasons. First, recorded videos can be edited. If this is your first time hosting a webinar, it might be useful to host it with no audience,. so you can make small tweaks.</p> \n<p>Recorded webinars are also useful because they are accessible. If you decide to host yours during a time your audience can't attend, recording the webinar ensures they can still catch the information.</p> \n<p>Regardless of whether you're a webinar pro or a beginner, there's some extra things to keep in mind before you hit that \"Record\" button. Read on to learn more about recording, exporting, and sharing a webinar.</p> \n<h3>1. Choose proper video hosting software.</h3> \n<p>After the plans to record a webinar are set, the next step is choosing a platform. A lot of platforms are similar as far as what they offer, but go with one that will let you record <em>and</em> export. It's a good idea to look for one that will also record for a longer time.</p> \n<p>Some <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-screen-recorder?_ga=2.71137424.1276787802.1596678320-940436819.1565181751\">recording tools</a> are only built for certain operating systems, so make sure yours operates on multiple different systems. Most platforms you'll find work on both Mac and Windows devices, but keep a watchful eye as you're researching.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.vidyard.com/\">Vidyard</a> and <a href=\"https://zoom.us/\">Zoom</a> are good places to start. Both offer recording options and are easy to use. You can also record, export, and upload videos from these platforms onto web pages. Alternatively, check to see if your computer comes with recording software, like <a href=\"https://support.apple.com/quicktime\">QuickTime</a> — it's possible you won't have to download a new tool if your computer already comes equipped.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, choose one that will let you do everything you need. If you have to share your screen or ask for audience participation, make sure your software has those capabilities.</p> \n<h3>2. Decide where you will record.</h3> \n<p>The setting or background of your webinar shouldn't be disrupting. If your attention can be taken away by something near you, so can your audience's. Choose a place to record your webinar that's quiet and fit for a professional presentation.</p> \n<p>A quiet space with little outside distraction is going to be your best bet. If that's hard to accomplish, try to change your setting so it's more fit for a webinar. Think about what you want the background to look like in a video that will live past its original recording date.</p> \n<p>For instance, if the space you have includes a bright green poster and some laundry in the background, take the poster down and move the laundry. Ultimately, you'll want to present a space that won't take away from the lesson.</p> \n<p>Alternatively, if you decide your space isn't camera-ready, you don't have to show it. Turn your camera off and let the presentation be the visual, <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/m/webinar-series/churn-facebook-creatives-remotely\">like this one from Facebook</a>. If you go this route, though, you'll likely need an animator or designer to make sure your presentation is engaging enough to keep the viewer's interest.</p> \n<h3>3. Perform a practice version for mistakes.</h3> \n<p>Before you officially record, practice using the software. Familiarize yourself with how to export and upload a video so you'll be comfortable when the time comes.</p> \n<p>Practicing the full motions of the webinar helps with presentation and flow. When you watch it back, you can gauge how you come across, how you're speaking, and the impact of the lesson. Additionally, you'll see how to remedy technical difficulties — If it took you a little long to find <a href=\"https://support.zoom.us/hc/en-us/articles/205566129-Raising-your-hand-in-a-webinar\">Zoom's \"hand raiser\" tool</a>, for instance, you can practice the motion to speed up the process.</p> \n<p>If you're thinking that you won't have time to fit in multiple test runs, don't worry. You won't need the full hour to practice your presentation. Instead, record the section you're most unsure about — that way, you can tweak things to make it better.</p> \n<p>Alternatively, maybe your test run tells you that you need more help with the creation part. If that's the case, head on over to this guide for <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-a-webinar?_ga=2.113529735.1276787802.1596678320-940436819.1565181751\">making a compelling webinar</a> of your own. Otherwise, after you're comfortable with your setting and presentation, you're ready to record the real deal</p> \n<h3>4. Edit your presentation for professionality.</h3> \n<p>Recorded webinars aren't live, and because of that, things don't stop when it ends. After you finish your presentation, end the recording and then, export your video and watch it for any mistakes.</p> \n<p>Small mistakes, like a fumble on words, are normal. If you come across them, don't feel as if they should be edited out — after all, humans slip up every day. However, glaring mistakes, like recording the video too early, should be edited.</p> \n<p>The great thing about recorded webinars is that you have the option to edit. And, if you're not recording for a live audience, you have more room to tweak the final version. Look at your work before it goes up for the world to see so you and your company are represented professionally.</p> \n<p>Additionally, if you need to change anything about your presentation based on timing, you can trim certain parts. If you're recording it live, take note of any audience participation exercises that might be easy to replicate after the live version. Trivia questions can be fun past the live taping of the webinar, for example.</p> \n<h3>5. Share your webinar.</h3> \n<p>Now, you're ready to share your recording! You might have a plan for how you want to distribute it — especially if it's an event for your customers. But, if this is a stage you're stuck on, here are some ideas for sharing.</p> \n<p>Webinars have the great advantage of being extremely sharable. Even though it's a long format, they usually contain highly valuable information that audiences want to see. Plus, video is an <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing?_ga=2.113529735.1276787802.1596678320-940436819.1565181751\">incredibly popular format</a> and often does better than text for attracting a large audience.</p> \n<h4>1. Landing Page</h4> \n<p>Create a landing page where your webinar will live. It's convenient to do this, as you can track page performance. You can use the extra space of a landing page for copy explaining what viewers will gain from the webinar, or helpful resources that relate to the lesson.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Lights,%20Camera,%20Action%20How%20to%20Record%20a%20Webinar%20Worth%20Replaying-2.png\" alt=\"A landing page for a webinar. \" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><span style=\"font-family: 'times new roman', times;\"><a href=\"https://business.linkedin.com/marketing-solutions/webinars/20/06/essential-strategies-for-targeting-on-linkedin\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<p>This one, from LinkedIn, is very minimal. Below, there's a short description of the webinar, as well as background about the platform itself. Your page shouldn't be busy, just informative. Tell the audience what they'll get out of the lesson.</p> \n<h4>2. Social Media</h4> \n<p>Share your webinar with your followers to increase traffic. For example, this one, about a dental tool, was shared on Facebook:</p> \n<iframe style=\"border: none; overflow: hidden; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\" src=\"https://www.facebook.com/plugins/video.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2FZahnDental%2Fvideos%2F616142932578899%2F&amp;show_text=1&amp;width=560\" width=\"560\" height=\"512\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe> \n<p>LinkedIn is a popular social networking site for webinars because of its unique emphasis on professional content. If you go that route, it's likely you'll find qualified leads. Ultimately, though, go where your followers are. For instance, if most of your traffic comes from Facebook, choose Facebook.</p> \n<h4>3. Email Marketing</h4> \n<p>Don't forget to remind your audience about the recorded webinar. In weekly newsletters, hyperlink the video. Your content will get more views, and your customers will love the extra content in their inbox. Check out the one I got last week, for instance:</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Lights,%20Camera,%20Action%20How%20to%20Record%20a%20Webinar%20Worth%20Replaying-1.png\" alt=\"An email marketing message for a webinar.\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>Before the email, I had no idea the webinar was happening. Even if you promote the webinar, you can't catch <em>every</em> customer with just a couple of channels. Leverage multiple messaging channels to maximize participation.</p> \n<h4>4. Blog Posts</h4> \n<p>Webinars can live in multiple spaces on your website. If your recording was about social media marketing, and you have a guide on the subject, consider embedding a snippet of the webinar onto the post. You'll snag more traffic that way, and make the piece itself more actionable.</p> \n<p>Let's look at this example:</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Lights,%20Camera,%20Action%20How%20to%20Record%20a%20Webinar%20Worth%20Replaying.png\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"An example of a webinar embedded into a blog post.\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><span style=\"font-family: 'times new roman', times;\"><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/are-webinars-dead-how-to-make-a-webinar\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<p>Here, we see the webinar added to the blog post to make it more engaging. Readers who want the full run-down can follow along with the post. Additionally, those who are visually impaired will find value in being able to hear the topic explained in an accessible format.</p> \n<p>Webinars diversify the content you offer. Recorded ones are great for accessibility and extended value. Long after the initial recording, you can still earn leads from them.</p> \n<p>Every day on my lunch break, I have a recorded webinar queued up and ready to go. The next time I'm scouring the internet, looking for the next winner, will I see yours among the rest of the amazing content?</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fblog%2Ftabid%2F6307%2Fbid%2F9990%2Fhow-to-record-a-webinar.aspx&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 05 Aug 2020 23:45:00 +0000","feedId":924,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Lights,%20Camera,%20Action%20How%20to%20Record%20a%20Webinar%20Worth%20Replaying-2.png","linkMd5":"8ce6c5b27c0fab30f0338805d8558b22","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn15@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-27-650_e24cb6c6f3c65061.webp","author":"Kayla Carmicheal","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Lights,%20Camera,%20Action%20How%20to%20Record%20a%20Webinar%20Worth%20Replaying-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn87@2020_3/2020/08/16/13-48-39-407_e24cb6c6f3c65061.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Lights,%20Camera,%20Action%20How%20to%20Record%20a%20Webinar%20Worth%20Replaying-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn100@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-36-822_9307b230c5a4c928.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Lights,%20Camera,%20Action%20How%20to%20Record%20a%20Webinar%20Worth%20Replaying.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn76@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-36-712_2fdd55a42377d904.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fblog%2Ftabid%2F6307%2Fbid%2F9990%2Fhow-to-record-a-webinar.aspx&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn16@2020_2/2020/08/16/13-48-31-952_d8618e84f8d4ab53.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","title":"How 3 HubSpot Managers Found Strong Co-Marketing Partnerships [+How You Can, Too]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/co-marketing-partner-tips","description":"<p>A solid <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/34188/what-in-the-heck-is-co-marketing.aspx\">co-marketing</a> partnership is one of the better ways to reach a previously untapped audience, generate positive publicity, and create a wealth of valuable marketing collateral. When done right, it's a mutually beneficial, thoroughly productive way to boost your marketing efforts as a whole.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Aligning yourself with an industry peer can pay off in spades, but these kinds of relationships aren't easy to start and sustain. Your partner's interests and qualities need to complement yours, and the companies you work with have to be reliable enough to consistently pull their weight.</p> \n<p>Finding a company that fits that bill is hard in its own right, but once you've identified one you want to work with, you're faced with the challenges of successfully contacting them, corresponding with them, and convincing them to work with you.</p> \n<p>Those processes can be hard to figure out on your own, so to offer you some help, we spoke with three HubSpot experts about how they found strong co-marketing partnerships and the steps you need to take to do the same.</p> \n<h2>What do you look for in a co-marketing partner?</h2> \n<p>When asked about what they look for in a co-marketing partner, our experts all seemed to agree that the number one priority is alignment in audience, messaging, and image. As HubSpot Senior Marketing Manager, Margot Mazur, put it, <em>\"We look for partners who speak to similar personas and address their needs. Specifically, we want to make sure our partners have a similar audience and voice — with similar values and goals to meet.\"</em></p> \n<p>Though finding a company that checks those boxes is central to a successful co-marketing partnership, there's still a lot more to the process. You might identify a potential partner that lines up well with your brand identity and appeals to a similar audience, but co-marketing partnerships need to be productive and mutually beneficial — you need to know you'll get something out of it.</p> \n<p>According to HubSpot Marketing Manager, Diego Santos, <em>\"Once we are happy with [a potential partner's] suitability, we classify them according to a co-marketing matrix — one that takes the partner's popularity, relevance, and objective into consideration. This process helps us to prioritize collaborations and look at the big picture.\"</em></p> \n<p>Ideological and objective-oriented alignment isn't enough. There needs to be hard, quantifiable potential behind a co-marketing partnership. As Mazur said,<em> \"We also look at a potential partner's audience across social and email channels, making sure that our businesses are of a similar size.\"</em></p> \n<p>Co-marketing partnerships are, at their core, strategic plays. They can be invaluable assets in targeted marketing efforts. For instance, HubSpot Marketing Manager, Clara Landecy, spoke on how they can be leveraged to target specific areas, <em>\"I always look for partners who have a strong presence in targeted regions. Partnering with local partners is essential if your company does business in multiple languages and across the globe.\"</em></p> \n<p>Santos succinctly captured all those points when he laid out the key questions to consider when finding co-marketing partners, <em>\"We usually ask ourselves the following questions to make sure they are a good fit: Who are they? What is their area of expertise? And who — and how big — is their audience?\"</em></p> \n<p>It's important to have a firm understanding of what you want out of a co-marketing partnership before approaching potential partners. Find a company with similar values that will enhance your ability to effectively reach your target audience — one that will pull its weight, complement your messaging, and ultimately suit your long term goals.</p> \n<h2>How do you approach and connect with potential co-marketing partners?</h2> \n<p>Our experts stressed the importance of a personal touch in connecting with potential co-marketing partners. As Santos put it, <em>\"A more personal, network-oriented approach is usually much more effective than a cold introductory email or message.\"</em></p> \n<p>Co-marketing partnerships are inherently personal, so it's only fitting that you start your relationship with your partner off on a <em>personal</em> note. But how do you get there?</p> \n<p>Well, according to our experts, your best bet is leveraging resources and co-workers from within your own company. Landecy said, <em>\"To increase your response rate, ask your colleagues if they have any contacts at the companies you’re looking to partner with, warm outreach always helps.\"</em></p> \n<p>Santos agreed, <em>\"We always try to leverage the connections we already have in HubSpot. When we are looking for partners in a particular area, we reach out to everyone in the relevant regional team and encourage them to send ideas of potential collaborations.\"</em></p> \n<p>Mazur reiterated their points but added some insight about what she does when she can't reach potential partners through her colleagues, <em>\"Generally, I'll see if anyone at HubSpot already has a connection to someone at the partner company. If not, I'll reach out to a partnership, BD, or marketing person at the company on LinkedIn, using their InMail tool.\"</em> As I mentioned earlier, no matter how you reach potential partners you need to do so with a personal touch.</p> \n<p>Do your homework. Make sure you have a firm grasp on the nature of the company you're contacting, what it might need out of a co-marketing partnership, and what you can do to suit its objectives and interests. Or as Landecy said, <em>\"Make sure your outreach is personalized! Showing you did the research before reaching out shows you are invested in the potential partnership and makes their work feel special!\"</em></p> \n<p>But let's say you don't have the know-how and personal connections to identify and reach potential co-marketing partners. You're at a loss when it comes to finding interested companies whose size, values, and interests line up with your own.</p> \n<p>What can you do? Well, there are certain tools designed to expedite the process. For instance, <a href=\"https://www.crossbeam.com/?utm_source=adwords&amp;utm_campaign=9977203105_100586914017_441699244276&amp;utm_term=&amp;utm_term=&amp;utm_campaign=Content+Lead+Generation+(Blog)&amp;utm_source=adwords&amp;utm_medium=ppc&amp;hsa_acc=7141001143&amp;hsa_cam=9977203105&amp;hsa_grp=100586914017&amp;hsa_ad=441699244276&amp;hsa_src=g&amp;hsa_tgt=dsa-915029285266&amp;hsa_kw=&amp;hsa_mt=b&amp;hsa_net=adwords&amp;hsa_ver=3&amp;gclid=EAIaIQobChMIvOqtlKqW6wIVCTiGCh1VyQ9VEAAYASAAEgKksPD_BwE\"><span>Crossbeam</span></a> is a resource that leverages CRM data to help you find and connect with potential co-marketing partners with overlapping customer bases and other complementary attributes.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, a solid co-marketing partnership has tremendous potential that's only seen after tremendous effort. It often takes extensive research and critical thought just to identify the companies that suit your values, goals, and qualities. And actually conducting the necessary outreach and communication to establish one adds a whole new, often exhausting layer to the process.</p> \n<p>Still, there's a lot to be gained from these kinds of arrangements. If your business is looking for a shot of life to your marketing efforts, pursuing a co-marketing partnership is something to consider.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fco-marketing-partner-tips&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 12 Aug 2020 19:45:00 +0000","feedId":924,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/COMARKETING%20%281%29.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"b51605d148664a74132a069d63dd1ab4","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn31@2020_2/2020/08/16/13-48-27-469_f48edfe4afbb233d.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/COMARKETING%20%281%29.jpg#keepProtocol","destWidth":598,"destHeight":398,"author":"jfuchs@hubspot.com (Jay Fuchs)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fco-marketing-partner-tips&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn39@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-35-456_ce74fcca29bc477f.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","title":"How to Make an Instagram Post Template for Your Business or Brand","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/instagram-post-template","description":"<p>Instagram is an undeniably powerful marketing tool, but with over <a href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2017/11/30/instagram-25-million-business-profiles/\">25 million businesses</a> on the platform today, it's critical you take the time to create well-designed and thoughtful Instagram posts to stand out.</p>   \n<p>You'll need to apply a strategic design plan to your business's Instagram to attract a loyal following and find success on the app, long-term.</p> \n<p>However, creating a clean and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/instagram-themes?_ga=2.102356865.1473434295.1539618369-1112480672.1531259004\">cohesive Instagram feed</a> takes design skills you might feel you lack. Plus, <span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">Instagram's algorithm favors <a href=\"https://socialbuddy.com/how-often-should-you-post-on-instagram/\" style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">brands that post at least once a day</a> — that time commitment could be adding to your stress.</span></p> \n<p>If that's the case, you're in luck — there are ways you can create pre-made Instagram post templates, so you've got a stash ready-to-go. Plus, by ensuring you use the same templates for different posts, you'll have an easier time creating a cohesive and aesthetically-pleasing feed.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Instagram%20Post%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=Instagram%20Post%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg\" alt=\"free editable Instagram Post Template\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Here are some options to create and save Instagram post templates, so you can have stunning posts on-hand whenever you're ready to publish.</p> \n<h3><strong>1. Canva</strong></h3> \n<p>Canva offers thousands of customizable <a href=\"https://www.canva.com/templates/social-graphics/instagram-post/\">Instagram post templates</a>. To create an Instagram post on Canva, go to Canva's <a href=\"https://www.canva.com/create-a-design\">Create a Design page</a>, click \"Instagram Post\", and then follow these steps:</p> \n<p><strong>1. On the left side, you'll see an array of template options — some cost money, while others are free. Choose one.</strong></p> \n<p><strong><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand.png\" alt=\"\"></strong></p> \n<p><strong>2. Once you choose a template, click on the text box to write something. There are colors at the top if you want to alternate your text color — you can also change font, size, and spacing.</strong></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-6.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<p><strong>3. When you're finished with your text, click the background of your image (outside the text box). This will allow you to filter your background, adjust the brightness and contrast of the image, and more. </strong></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-2.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<p><strong>4. When you're happy with your template, open up the </strong><a href=\"https://www.canva.com/app/\">Canva app</a><strong> on your phone. Click on your Instagram post design. </strong></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand.jpeg?width=326&amp;name=How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand.jpeg\" alt=\"\" width=\"326\" style=\"width: 326px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p><strong>5. Click \"Share\" in the top right. </strong></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-4.jpeg?width=319&amp;name=How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-4.jpeg\" alt=\"\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 319px;\" width=\"319\">\n</div> \n<p><strong>6. Now, you can post straight to Instagram by clicking \"Import with Instagram\". If you aren't ready to post it, you can also \"Save Image\" and it will appear in your camera roll for later. </strong></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-3.jpeg?width=360&amp;name=How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-3.jpeg\" alt=\"\" width=\"360\" style=\"width: 360px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p><strong>7. If you are immediately posting to Instagram, choose whether you want to upload to your \"Story\" or \"Feed\". </strong></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-2.jpeg?width=337&amp;name=How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-2.jpeg\" alt=\"\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 337px;\" width=\"337\">\n</div> \n<p><strong>8. Edit the Instagram post like you would any other post — add tags, a caption, location, etc. When you're ready, click \"Share\" in the top right. </strong></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-1.jpeg?width=340&amp;name=How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-1.jpeg\" alt=\"\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 340px;\" width=\"340\">\n</div> \n<p>Remember, your template is automatically saved to your Canva account. You can access it in the future, on both desktop and app versions of Canva, and edit it with new text to post the same design again.</p> \n<p>Alternatively, you might consider creating a few posts now, and then saving them to your camera roll to post them in the future.</p> \n<p>Besides Canva, there are a few other design editors that offer free pre-made Instagram templates. In particular, here are three tools you might consider:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.fotor.com/features/instagram-post.html\">Fotor</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://crello.com/create/instagram-post/\">Crello</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/instagram-templates-for-business?_ga=2.102356865.1473434295.1539618369-1112480672.1531259004\">HubSpot</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h3><strong>2. ReciteThis</strong></h3> \n<p>If you're interested in creating a template for quote posts, it's easy to do — in fact, we've already curated a list of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/quote-maker-apps-instagram\">nine apps to help you make quotes for Instagram</a>.</p> \n<p>For our purposes, we'll try just one — ReciteThis.</p> \n<p>To create a quote template for Instagram, go to <a href=\"http://recitethis.com/\">ReciteThis</a>, then follow these three easy steps:</p> \n<p><strong style=\"color: inherit; font-size: 1.1rem; text-indent: -2em;\">1. Enter your quote in the text box.</strong></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-1.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<p><strong>2. Below, click the left or right arrows to peruse templates and choose one you like. Once you've chosen a template and written your text, click the \"Create\" button in the text box. </strong></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-5.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<p><strong>3. Click \"Download Image\" to post to Instagram's desktop version, or email it to yourself to post on your phone. </strong></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-7.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<h3>3. Creative Market</h3> \n<p>If you're willing to shell out the cash, you might consider buying one of <a href=\"https://creativemarket.com/templates/social-media/instagram\">Creative Market's Instagram Template bundles</a>.</p> \n<p>For instance, you could purchase this <a href=\"https://creativemarket.com/delightful.artifacts/2725116-1053-Social-Media-Quotes\">1053 Quotes social media pack</a>.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-3.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<p>Alternatively, you can purchase a bundle with Instagram Story content, like this <a href=\"https://creativemarket.com/tuckshopstudio/2247364-Animated-Instagram-Stories\">Animated Stories bundle</a>.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-4.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<p>Finally, you might consider purchasing a bundle to help you create a cohesive theme for your Instagram feed, like this <a href=\"https://creativemarket.com/MarigoldStudios/2688103-THE-GRID-Instagram-Posts-Layout\">The Grid template</a>.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-8.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<p>And that's it! You're all set to create and save pre-made Instagram templates, so you can focus on attracting a loyal following without tediously designing a post from scratch every day.</p> \n<p>Check out our <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/instagram-marketing\">Instagram Marketing: The Ultimate Guide</a> for more Instagram tips and tricks.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\"><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in October, 2018 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img Forsey","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Instagram%20Post%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg?width=1500&name=Instagram%20Post%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn63@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-39-031_f7fbb6522b593b17.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx20/cdn7@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-31-056_47db2a07e1494da0.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-6.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn36@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-39-160_1d17e81214258a0c.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn4@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-30-069_c7df92fb302258d9.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand.jpeg?width=326&name=How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn96@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-32-827_061f220a28448675.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-4.jpeg?width=319&name=How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-4.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn8@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-31-957_41db4992edc384b3.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-3.jpeg?width=360&name=How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-3.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn32@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-40-042_84550a77ec6c374d.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-2.jpeg?width=337&name=How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-2.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn31@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-36-423_0861748d74e10eba.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-1.jpeg?width=340&name=How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-1.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx17/cdn44@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-37-521_16727df57f416a61.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn67@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-30-709_cf2c595af6d32e6b.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-5.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn15@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-39-680_e0f888b7d4348236.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-7.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn35@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-37-407_1f2031a8a51411c4.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn100@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-28-746_74e7369835a3f3ce.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-4.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn11@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-28-453_de221f80354c932b.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/How%20to%20Make%20an%20Instagram%20Post%20Template%20for%20Your%20Business%20or%20Brand-8.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn28@2020_2/2020/08/16/13-48-38-260_0e93821fe2dccc84.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Finstagram-post-template&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn8@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-35-410_db6e49ba170eea8a.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","title":"What Is Co-Marketing? A Guide to Co-Branding Marketing Campaigns","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/34188/what-in-the-heck-is-co-marketing.aspx","description":"<p><span style=\"letter-spacing: 0px; background-color: transparent;\">As marketers, we are always looking for new ways to get more bang for our buck. Co-marketing allows you to do just that — the process involves two or more companies working together to reap the benefits of their combined efforts. </span></p>  \n<p>We've compiled the co-marketing tips and tricks below to help you create a successful co-marketing campaign and relationship, from start to finish.</p> \n<h3></h3> \n<p></p> \n<p></p> \n<a></a> \n<p>Partner companies typically collaborate on promotional efforts for a co-branded offer. In a co-marketing partnership, both companies promote a piece of content or product, and share the results of that promotion.</p> \n<p>By levering the relationship and reach of a partner, co-marketing campaigns are designed to deliver more leads, buzz, and awareness, with less work.</p> \n<h3>Co-Marketing vs. Co-Branding</h3> \n<p>You've probably heard the terms <em>co-marketing</em> and<em> co-branding</em> thrown around quite a bit — but what's the difference? Is there one?</p> \n<p>Turns out, they’re actually pretty similar.</p> \n<p>While co-branding refers to a partnership in which two companies combine their products or expertise to create an even more valuable product or offer (Think: <a href=\"https://www.tacobell.com/food/tacos/nacho-cheese-doritos-locos-tacos\">Doritos Locos Tacos</a>), co-marketing takes things a step further.</p> \n<p>Co-marketing campaigns provide teams with an opportunity to work together to promote a shared offer — such as a co-branded product or piece of content. In a co-marketing partnership, both companies promote that offer, and share the results of that promotion with each other.</p> \n<p>More on how this process works next.</p> \n<h3>How does co-marketing work?</h3> \n<p>The most common way to co-market is for two companies that have similar audiences to work together on a piece of content or campaign, and promote it to both audiences.</p> \n<p>This content (e.g. ebook, webinar, template, etc.) typically sits behind a lead generation form to capture contact information. The goal is for both partners to share the downloads from the offer, thus getting twice the leads that they normally would.</p> \n<p>But that's not the only way to carry out a co-marketing campaign. Straying from the approach above, two partners might agree to host an event together and split the costs. Or, on a smaller scale, partners could agree to a series of guest blog posts on each other’s sites.</p> \n<p>The most important thing when deciding to do co-marketing with a certain partner, is to make sure the purpose and goal of the project is similar for both parties. If one partner wants leads, but another is looking for ticket sales to their annual event, you'll be hard-pressed to find a project that satisfies both needs.</p> \n<p>One aspect of virtually every co-marketing campaign you'll need is a shared landing page.</p> \n<h4>Co-Marketing Shared Landing Page</h4> \n<p>Both your content and landing page should be co-branded — and it should be obvious. This entails using both partner's logos in the header, and mentioning both partners throughout the content.</p> \n<p>Since you will likely be sharing the offer's downloads with your partner, you will need to consult with your legal team about the proper disclaimer to include at the bottom of the form.</p> \n<p>For example, <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/digital-marketing-with-google\">our offer with Google</a> simply states that we are authorized to share their information with the specific partner after a user downloads the ebook.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-07-31%20at%203.18.17%20PM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-07-31%20at%203.18.17%20PM.png\" alt=\"example of a shared landing page for a co-marketing campaign\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"><span style=\"font-size: 13px; font-style: italic;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/digital-marketing-with-google\">Source</a></span></p> \n<p>To keep things organized within your marketing automation tool, we also suggest that you come up with a unique code for naming these co-branded pages to differentiate them from your existing ones. Not to mention, this will make it easy to locate them via internal search.</p> \n<p>Next, you may be wondering how you should go about determining which businesses would be good partners for your business. Let's review the answer to that question next.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>How to Find the Right Co-Marketing Partners to Work With</h2> \n<p>In any co-marketing relationship, you want to make sure there is mutual benefit to working together. Check out tips in determining if a partner is a good fit <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/co-marketing-partner-tips\">here</a>.</p> \n<p>You can also ask yourself the following questions:</p> \n<ol> \n <li><strong>Do they have a similar type of audience that my company has and wants to grow?</strong> If not, the value I would get out of promoting our content to their audience may not be worth it.</li> \n <li><strong>How many new leads am I going to get from this partnership? Is it large enough to be worth my time?</strong> Only you can decide what is worth it.</li> \n <li><strong>Do they have some expertise that I don’t have?</strong> Let’s say my audience is dying to know more about how to optimize for local SEO, but my knowledge base is limited to general SEO knowledge. Maybe I partner with an expert on local SEO.</li> \n <li><strong>Does their brand and name have a good reputation?</strong> Don’t partner with people who will bring down your credibility.</li> \n <li><strong>Are the people you are working with enjoyable to work with?</strong> Sure, co-marketing is a job, but it should still be enjoyable. Look for partners that you actually look forward to working with.</li> \n</ol> \n<a></a> \n<h2>How to Plan a Co-Marketing Agreement</h2> \n<p>You've found a partner to work with — that's great! But, what's the next step?</p> \n<h3>1. Come up with an idea to pitch.</h3> \n<p>Once you determine you'd like to work with a partner, it's time to come up with an idea to pitch. When approaching this step, do your homework first. Learn what you can about the company and their audience, tailor your ideas to what would be appealing to them, and show them the value you're going to provide.</p> \n<p>Odds are, if you are the one pitching the idea, you are the small fish and they are the big fish. In other words, it'd be easy for them to say no in this scenario. To combat this, go the extra mile to show them that they'd be crazy not to work with you.</p> \n<p>If you are on the other end of the pitch, remain open to ideas. Even if the person pitching you isn’t a pro, don’t disregard the opportunity immediately. If it's a totally unrealistic partnership, be honest with them. And if the idea sounds interesting but it's just not a great time for you to take on the project, consider adding them to a backlog of potential partners you'd want to work with in the future.</p> \n<h3>2. Make your goals clear.</h3> \n<p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">If you want leads, make sure your partner knows that. Make sure they also want leads, too. If your goals are misaligned, neither of you will get value you had hoped and planned for out of the relationship.</span></p> \n<h3><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">3. Agree on the content you'll share and promote. </span></h3> \n<p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Next, agree on the type of content you'll share and promote among your audience. This includes the topic and theme of the content. <span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Decide on a topic that is going to be mutually beneficial and appeal to both audiences.</span></span></p> \n<h3><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">4. Determine your timeline.<span style=\"color: #33475b;\"> </span></span></h3> \n<p>Set a timeline for your co-marketing campaign. This way, everyone is on the same page and gets their portion of the work done on time.</p> \n<p>Pro Tip: <span style=\"color: #33475b;\">For a larger project, like an ebook or webinar, double the amount of time it takes your team to write a campaign on your own. This will allow for time for approvals and feedback among your team members and your partner's team members.</span></p> \n<h3>5. Decide what your strong skills are.<span style=\"color: #33475b;\"> </span></h3> \n<p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Between the your business and your partner's, it's likely you both have specific strengths and bring different things to the table. So, a<span style=\"color: #33475b;\">ssign tasks and work accordingly. </span></span></p> \n<p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Simply, if you assign tasks related to your co-marketing content and/or campaign based on which partner is better at what, the process will be streamlined and efficient (and likely, a lot more effective among audience members, too!).</span></p> \n<h3>6. Write up a formal co-marketing partnership agreement.</h3> \n<p>Like most things in business, it's important your co-marketing partnership is solidified and official. To do this, ensure it's in writing, in a formal agreement. With an agreement in place from the start, you have something to point back at if anything goes wrong or any miscommunications arise. (This may be a legal document or a non-legal document of good faith.)</p> \n<p>The details of this agreement should include:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Topic</span></li> \n <li><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Timeline</span></li> \n <li><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Goals</span></li> \n <li><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Ownership of content and assets (who is creating what?)</span></li> \n <li><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Where the content will be hosted and shared</span></li> \n <li><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Lead-sharing agreements</span></li> \n <li><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Timeframe for promotion</span></li> \n <li><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Promotional plan</span></li> \n <li><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Reporting plan</span></li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Types of Co-Marketing Content</h2> \n<p>Time to decide what type of co-marketing project you're going to work on. Below are a few common examples to help get the wheels turning.</p> \n<h4>Ebook</h4> \n<p>An ebook is a very common form of co-marketing content because it is easy to split up the work — someone lays out the design, someone else writes the content, and so on.</p> \n<p>Below is an <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/linkedin-social-selling?\">example of an ebook</a> HubSpot created with the LinkedIn Sales Solutions team:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-07-31%20at%201.50.52%20PM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-07-31%20at%201.50.52%20PM.png\" alt=\"co-marketing example of an ebook by hubspot and linkedin\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 13px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/linkedin-social-selling\"><em>Source</em></a></p> \n<h4>Blog Post</h4> \n<p>Co-creating a blog post is one of the lower effort ways to do a co-marketing project. You may also each write a guest post for each other's blogs. For example, here's a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/sales-email-templates-examples\">guest post on the HubSpot blog</a>.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-07-31%20at%2011.22.39%20PM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-07-31%20at%2011.22.39%20PM.png\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"co-marketing guest post blog post\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/sales-email-templates-examples\"><em>Source</em></a></p> \n<h4>Webinar</h4> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-a-webinar\">Webinars</a> are often the go-to type of co-marketing content. Why? Well, it's pretty easy to find an expert who is willing to talk for an hour on the topic of their expertise. It is also a well-known format for educational materials. And they're easy to co-host.</p> \n<p>Below is an example of a <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/grow-better-with-customer-feedback\">webinar that HubSpot hosted with partner, HotJar</a>. Users could sign up via a landing page on HubSpot's site to attend. Now that the webinar is in the past, visitors can still download the recording at this URL.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-07-31%20at%202.53.42%20PM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-07-31%20at%202.53.42%20PM.png\" alt=\"webinar hosted by hubspot and hotjar\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"color: #33475b;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/grow-better-with-customer-feedback\"><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\"><em>Source</em></span></a></span></p> \n<h4>Video</h4> \n<p>Creating a video with a partner is a great way to have your message heard by many, while also promoting both of your brands. For example, <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/behind-the-screens\">HubSpot hosted an interview video series</a> with team members from Google, LinkedIn, and Facebook.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-07-31%20at%202.50.08%20PM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-07-31%20at%202.50.08%20PM.png\" alt=\"hubspot's a look behind the scenes campaign\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\"><em><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/behind-the-screens\">Source</a></em></span></p> \n<h4>Twitter Chat</h4> \n<p>A <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/28979/8-steps-to-hosting-a-successful-twitter-chat.aspx\">Twitter chat</a> is a virtual event where people gather to discuss a common topic. This allows you to show your expertise, and invite and interact with members of both of your target audiences. Also, Twitter allows you to <a href=\"https://business.twitter.com/en/blog/how-to-promote-your-twitter-chat.html\">promote your Chat</a> to broaden your reach even more.</p> \n<p>Here's a list of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/5835/10-examples-of-b2b-twitter-chats.aspx\">examples of Twitter Chats</a> for your review.</p> \n<h4>Event (Online or Offline)</h4> \n<p>Co-marketing can also take form in larger events, both in online or in person. You and your partner may host the event together and brand the entire event in a way that depicts and shares both of your branding and marketing.</p> \n<p>Aside from a webinar, you might host a live Q&amp;A. For instance, maybe your business has an employee be an interviewer for the session. Meanwhile, your partner can have one of their team members be the interviewee.</p> \n<p>For example, <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/adapt2020\">HubSpot's educational series, Adapt 2020,</a> offers a variety of content but the campaign includes live events that happen weekly. Those who choose to sign up are invited to a live, virtual event where industry experts — including HubSpot executives, HubSpot partners, and more — discuss the chosen topic of the week.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-07-31%20at%202.59.32%20PM.png?width=2020&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-07-31%20at%202.59.32%20PM.png\" alt=\"adapt 2020 campaign example of live events\" width=\"2020\" style=\"width: 2020px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 13px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/adapt2020\"><em>Source</em></a></p> \n<p>Once you choose the type of co-marketing content you'll move forward with, it's time for you and your partner to plan the execution of your campaign.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>How to Execute Your Co-Marketing Campaign</h2> \n<p>There are some steps you should work through to effectively execute your co-marketing campaign with your partner.</p> \n<h3>1. Outline your co-marketing campaign.</h3> \n<p>Once you have chosen your topic and form of co-marketing, start with a shared Google Doc — brain dump, collaborate, and outline your plan here.</p> \n<p>By using a Google Doc from the start, you your team and your partner's team can simultaneously edit and add to the details on the Doc. In terms of timing, allow both of your teams about a week or so to hash out and finalize all ideas/ plans in this Doc.</p> \n<h3>2. Begin content creation.</h3> \n<p>Once you have agreed on the outline, assigned marketers can jump in and begin content creation. Typically, I split the creation of content between partners by having one partner write and another design, so that voice and design are consistent.</p> \n<p>The other option is to have each partner write up and design half of the content, and then fuse the two together. Keep in mind that this will require a thorough consistency check once both parts are brought together.</p> \n<p>After the first draft is complete, send to the partner to give feedback or approve. Give ample time between a writing due date and a feedback due date. I like to give a week if I have planned far enough in advance to allow for this.</p> \n<h3>3. Finalize your campaign content.</h3> \n<p>During the content finalization period, have your promotional team begin creating the assets needed to promote the content, such as the shared landing page as well as emails, social media images, infographics, blog posts, etc. Since working with a partner will likely take longer than a normal content creation process, this will help to save you some time.</p> \n<p>Next, it's time to promote your co-marketing content.</p> \n<h3>4. Promote your content.</h3> \n<p>It's important to set an agreed upon launch date with the partner. On this date, both teams’ email, social campaigns, and blog promotion should start.</p> \n<p>About two or three weeks prior to the launch date, have a brainstorm with all people involved from both teams to discuss what promotional tactics you will use and the timeframe for promotion. Will you both promote the same hashtag on Twitter? What audiences will you be promoting it to?</p> \n<p>Below are a few examples of how you can promote your content across various inbound marketing channels:</p> \n<h4>Blog Posts</h4> \n<p>Blog posts are a great way to drive traffic to your co-marketing content and offers. Common places to share co-marketing blog content include daily and weekly emails to subscribers, social accounts, and mutually agreed upon areas that you can reach target audience members. For example, at HubSpot, this content may be shared via HubSpot Academy.</p> \n<h4>Social Media</h4> \n<p>Promoting your content on social media is a great way to drive awareness to your co-marketing campaign and attract visitors to your site and content.</p> \n<p>Remember, tag your your co-marketing partner and ensure they do the same while sharing content that involves your business. This is easy to do and you'll benefit from the cross-promotion as members of each other's audiences will be able to view and interact with the content.</p> \n<h4>Email</h4> \n<p>Email is still one of the best ways to reach a large group of people at once — you can easily encourage recipients to attend your co-marketing webinar or event, or download your content.</p> \n<p>In your message, be clear that the email involves your brand and your partner — your co-marketing efforts should be clear, meaning it's obvious to all recipients that there are two companies involved.</p> \n<p><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\">If you're looking to track your partner's promotions efforts versus your own, be sure to create unique tracking URLs. This will help you determine which leads came from where. If you're a HubSpot user, here's how you can <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/settings/how-do-i-create-a-tracking-url\">create unique tracking URLs</a>. </span></span></p> \n<p><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\">Speaking of tracking, let's talk more about how to measure your co-marketing efforts. </span></span></p> \n<h3>5. Measure your co-marketing campaign's results.</h3> \n<p>Your co-marketing campaign is live and being promoted — good work! Now it's time to look back and see if your initial efforts were successful.</p> \n<p>First and foremost, did you hit your original goal? If so, great. If not, why? What happened? Did you fail to hit the mark, or was it the partner? Keep these things in mind when making decisions to work with them a second time.</p> \n<p>Next, look to see if the leads generated through your co-marketing campaign were as high-quality as the leads you typically generate throughout your individual content and campaigns. Things to consider here are: lead-to-customer conversion rate, quality rating within your <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/marketing-automation\">automation tool</a> and <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/crm\">CRM</a>, and whether or not your sales team felt the leads were up to par.</p> \n<p>Finally, take a step back and ask yourself the following questions, too:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Was the partnership successful, in your opinion?</li> \n <li>Did your partner feel like the relationship was a helpful one for the campaign?</li> \n <li>Was it difficult to work with your partner, or smooth?</li> \n <li>Did you get high-quality content that you may not have been able to make without your partner?</li> \n <li>What worked well while working with this partner, and what didn't?</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Once the campaign is over, your partnership doesn't end. You should follow up with your co-marketing partner at this point.</p> \n<h3>6. Follow up with your co-marketing partner.</h3> \n<p>Communication with your partner throughout the co-marketing campaign if critical but you'll also want to debrief once the campaign comes to an end. While it typically doesn't make sense to do one project after another with the same partner, there may be an opportunity to work together again in the future.</p> \n<p>And if not, it's still important to keep a positive image for your brand and remain professional, no matter the outcome of the campaign.</p> \n<p>For instance, imagine you hosted a campaign's landing page on your website. Once the campaign ends, send over the leads generated from your form on that page to your partner. Often times, the easiest way to do this is to simply download the CSV file of leads from your database. If you are looking for a less manual process, you might use a tool like<a href=\"https://zapier.com/\"> Zapier</a> to send specific leads from your marketing automation platform to your partner’s.</p> \n<h2>Grow Better With Co-Marketing</h2> \n<p>There are so many ways for you and partners to benefit mutually from co-marketing. Don't be afraid to experiment with different types of campaigns and try working with different partners. This will help you determine what works best among your audience and, therefore, benefits your business most.</p> \n<p><span class=\"content-post__body\"><em><i>Editor's Note: This post was originally published in March 2013 and has been updated for accuracy and comprehensiveness.</i></em></span></p> \n<p></p> \n<div>\n <a class=\"close\"> </a>\n</div>  \n<img
