\">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 04 Aug 2020 11:30:00 +0000","feedId":924,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/guide%20to%20co-marketing.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"11bafb97e1433dfa4af33093541c05c1","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx17/cdn68@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-28-344_a979d1aa0a8d5268.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/guide%20to%20co-marketing.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"asibley@hubspot.com (Amanda Sibley)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-07-31%20at%203.18.17%20PM.png?width=1500&name=Screen%20Shot%202020-07-31%20at%203.18.17%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn91@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-30-990_4c8b065572a43531.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-07-31%20at%201.50.52%20PM.png?width=1500&name=Screen%20Shot%202020-07-31%20at%201.50.52%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx20/cdn31@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-39-209_764f97df6ad01843.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-07-31%20at%2011.22.39%20PM.png?width=1500&name=Screen%20Shot%202020-07-31%20at%2011.22.39%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn52@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-36-656_9ffce9401b4334d0.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-07-31%20at%202.53.42%20PM.png?width=1500&name=Screen%20Shot%202020-07-31%20at%202.53.42%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn43@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-39-148_2038e57e41929d98.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-07-31%20at%202.50.08%20PM.png?width=1500&name=Screen%20Shot%202020-07-31%20at%202.50.08%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn63@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-37-691_d9c4d7aaec9dbb77.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-07-31%20at%202.59.32%20PM.png?width=2020&name=Screen%20Shot%202020-07-31%20at%202.59.32%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn59@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-35-042_5d7c41c087b9e879.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fblog%2Ftabid%2F6307%2Fbid%2F34188%2Fwhat-in-the-heck-is-co-marketing.aspx&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn28@2020_2/2020/08/16/13-48-30-118_3b862a8c2b0f048d.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","title":"How Broadcast Journalism Helped Me Pivot to Social Media Management","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/journalism-skills-social-media","description":"<p>Pivoting from a career in broadcast journalism was a <em>big</em> decision for me.</p> \n<p>I loved everything about a newsroom environment: the breaking news, researching topics, identifying sources for stories, and feeling like I had a pulse on trends and issues taking place in the world.</p> \n<p>I was successful at it, too. In fact, I worked at some of the biggest news corporations in the world, including CNN, ABC News, CBSLA and others.</p> \n<p>However, at some point — because I was spending so much time on social media listening for breaking news and looking for story ideas — my interest in social media <em>evolved</em>.</p> \n<p>I knew I wanted to make a transition, but I was scared of taking a leap and pivoting to social media marketing.</p> \n<p>Today, I can tell you that I'm so happy I did. I learned that my job is not my entire identity, and through journalism, I have so many transferrable skills to thrive in any industry.</p> \n<p>Switching careers can feel exciting, but comes with feelings of self-doubt and anxiety.</p> \n<p>Here, I want to highlight how broadcast journalism helped me succeed in social media, and tips you can use if you're considering a career shift of your own.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2><strong>7 Takeaways From Journalism You Can Apply to Social Media</strong></h2> \n<h3>1. Ask the 5 W questions.</h3> \n<p><em>Who? What? Where? When? and Why?</em> These questions are ingrained in any journalist.</p> \n<p>The foundational questions to news gathering also apply in the context of content creation, marketing plans, and any content strategy. For instance, any marketer likely asks these questions daily:</p> \n<p><em>Who is this message for?</em></p> \n<p><em>What is the core message we want them to take away from this?</em></p> \n<p><em>When (and where) are they most likely to be to consume this message?</em></p> \n<p><em>Why should they care? </em></p> \n<p>\"Why\" also goes a little deeper in social media. The internet is flooded with information and it's your job to capture someone's attention — and hold their attention for your content.</p> \n<p><em>Why would someone click on this ad?</em></p> \n<p><em>Why are we targeting this group?</em></p> \n<p><em>Why is it important that they see this message? </em></p> \n<p>The root of these questions have helped me cut through the jargon of promotions and company announcements to get to the root of the message in the simplest words.</p> \n<p><strong>Pro Tip</strong>: In journalism school, I learned to simplify the facts by \"explaining this story to my mom.\" This framework has really helped me simplify information down to its core. I practice this often when trying to take a complex company announcement and whittle it down to its simplest takeaway.</p> \n<h3>2. Focus on the core story, not the details.</h3> \n<p>When it comes to creating content, journalists have a unique element they bring to the table: storytelling.</p> \n<p>Some people may get caught up in numbers, the tagline, a paragraph in an announcement, and so on.</p> \n<p>As a former journalist, I think about the core of the message we want to convey in a social post.</p> \n<p>The key takeaway could involve visual elements and emotional triggers, but its foundation will include a concise message or story.</p> \n<h3>3. Keep up-to-date on industry and competitor trends.</h3> \n<p>The advantage journalism has provided me when it comes to conducting research is that, even if you have an intuitive sense of your audience, your journalism instincts still compel you to \"look into it\" and confirm your hypothesis.</p> \n<p>For instance, for conducing market research — including what my audience is feeling, thinking, struggling with, dreaming of, reading about, etc. — I put my \"investigative\" hat on and look within Facebook Groups, or other websites where people can leave comments or questions (such as Quora or Amazon reviews) to gather information about what my audience is seeing, thinking, and feeling.</p> \n<p>Additionally, a couple of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-do-keyword-research-ht\">keyword searches</a> gives me a framework to work with while doing research.</p> \n<p>Referring to the latest studies, trends, and reports helps me identify any overlaps and enables me to be a successful social media professional because I keep a pulse on issues that are top-of-mind to my audience.</p> \n<p>A little research goes a long way in social media content and writing.</p> \n<p>Journalists are naturally curious people, so we sometimes find ourselves entertained by trends and topics that get people talking. We like to quickly parachute in on behavior like this and figure out what the hype is all about, source who started it, and figure out why it's taking off.</p> \n<p>It's amusing, to say the least, but this innate skill in journalists has helped me in social media because I can (for the most part) keep up with the latest memes, videos, or other trending news that's popular that day or week. It also helps me recall previous news events or trends that were popular in the past.</p> \n<p>Context of topics, audiences, and trends helps me while making editorial or marketing decisions and creating content.</p> \n<h3>4. Create quality content, even with minimal assets.</h3> \n<p>When it comes to content creation, journalists have had to work with little or major constraints when it comes to telling a story. You might have only a few usable sound bites, poor video quality, or you're working with only sound.</p> \n<p>Broadcast journalism helped me feel comfortable with improvising and maximizing any assets available.</p> \n<p>I learned how to do video, audio and photography editing. I learned different storytelling formats such as radio, TV, print, and online, as well as how to distinguish each piece (i.e. infographic, video, blog post, listicle) and how to adapt them to different social media platforms.</p> \n<p>I learned to do this in the most concise way possible, which helped me tremendously while writing short headlines and easy-to-understand text that includes a call to action.</p> \n<h3>5. Write concisely, and make every word count.</h3> \n<p>Whether it's copywriting, writing in a brand's voice, creating catchy headlines and titles, creating copy that converts a user, incorporating a call-to-action, or enticing a reader to learn more … it's all important in social media.</p> \n<p>Broadcast journalism helped my social media career with my writing skills alone. Ultimately, packaging information in a concise way is <em>so</em> important in social media.</p> \n<p>Twitter has a <a href=\"https://twitter.com/Twitter/status/777915304261193728\">280 character limit</a>. However, I'm proud that I learned how to write tweets when it had a 140-character limit — including character counts toward photos, videos, and GIFs that were attached!</p> \n<p>Brevity is always a best practice when it comes to writing on social media, and broadcast journalism has helped me succeed in that regard.</p> \n<p>Effective writing helps your audience understand you, what you offer, and your value and is a critical skill for attracting an online audience.</p> \n<p><strong>Pro Tip</strong>: Practice reading your words out loud to catch typos or awkward sentence structures. I learned this while writing copy for TV news and it has helped me tremendously while crafting social media posts.</p> \n<h3>6. Learn how to communicate effectively in crises.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>Social media is an extension of any brand, and understanding when something is a reputational risk is important.</p> \n<p>My career in broadcast journalism helped me identify potential pitfalls or anticipate remarks people might make. The last thing I want to do is appear tone-deaf or miss the mark with marketing messages.</p> \n<p>Working in broadcast journalism has trained me to never lower my guard and always keep my eyes open for threats or liabilities in social posts, marketing campaigns, and imagery.</p> \n<p>I also understand news cycles, and during a crisis, I've learned how to evolve and adapt to new circumstances and information.</p> \n<p>For example, during a crisis such as the COVID-19 pandemic, there were different phases of crisis communication companies needed to understand. It was important to pause, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-marketing-playbook-for-times-of-crisis?hubs_signup-url=blog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fauthor%2Fmeghan-keaney-anderson&amp;hubs_signup-cta=null\">pivot marketing and messaging</a>, and identify pain points and re-position your brand, among other things.</p> \n<p>Working with so many PR and marketing professionals over the years taught me about how to \"own the narrative\" of a brand's story and to serve as a brand steward on social media.</p> \n<h3>7. Stay resourceful and help your audience find answers to their needs.</h3> \n<p>I say I'm a digital content strategist, but really, I'm a professional problem-solver.</p> \n<p>If I don't have an answer, I'll either find the answer or find someone who does.</p> \n<p>Broadcast journalism taught me to be resourceful, help my audience with valuable and actionable information, and think quickly on my feet and pitch smart angles.</p> \n<p>I've come across so many random scenarios while working in social media, including:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Converting and transferring files</li> \n <li>Helping people with their wifi</li> \n <li>Syncing folders on Sharepoint</li> \n <li>Identifying fonts</li> \n <li>Pitching a story on behalf of the company</li> \n <li>Finding alternative channel or format to communicate a message</li> \n <li>Sourcing video to its original owner</li> \n</ul> \n<p>You name it, I've probably helped someone figure something out, and because of it, I'm an invaluable asset to my team and my company.</p> \n<p>I solve people's problems (in person and online) which makes me feel like I'm doing a great social service.</p> \n<p>Journalists have a big opportunity in the marketing, social media, content strategy, storytelling and advertising space — if you are on the fence, I encourage you to take the leap.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fjournalism-skills-social-media&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 06 Aug 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":924,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/journalism-shift-social-media.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"108ba171a630a9aa7aea9982ccaa2ab0","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn64@2020_3/2020/08/16/13-48-27-600_1a73c07296ff91ba.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/journalism-shift-social-media.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"Nancy Casanova","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fjournalism-skills-social-media&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn84@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-37-715_887ed2fd06f2f091.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:25","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:25","title":"10 Great Examples of Welcome Emails to Inspire Your Own Strategy","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/welcome-email-examples","description":"<p>We've all heard how important it is to make a good first impression. Show up late for a job interview?</p>  \n<p>That's a bad first impression. Eat a ton of garlic and forget to brush your teeth before a first date? Also a bad first impression.</p> \n<p>It turns out that the \"make a good first impression\" principle holds true not only in face-to-face encounters, but in email interactions as well.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>When you send a welcome email to a new blog or newsletter subscriber, or to a new customer, you're making a first impression on behalf of your brand. To help ensure you're making the best first impression possible, we've rounded up some examples of standout welcome emails from brands big and small.</p> \n<p><strong>Pro Tip:</strong> Use HubSpot's <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/email\">free email marketing software</a> to easily create a high-quality welcome email sequence like the ones featured below.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Email%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg?width=400&amp;name=Email%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg\" width=\"400\" style=\"width: 400px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"free welcome Email Template to send to customers\"></p> \n<p>As you'll soon discover, each example below showcases different tactics and strategies for engaging new email subscribers. Let's dive in.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"></p> \n<h2>10 Examples of Standout Welcome Emails</h2> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://www.virginamerica.com/\">Virgin America</a></h3> \n<h4>Type of welcome: Get Started</h4> \n<p><img style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/virgin-america-welcome-email.png\" alt=\"Virgin America welcome email with a red CTA to get started\" title=\"virgin-america-welcome-email.png\"></p> \n<p>A welcome email is the perfect medium for introducing folks to the characteristics (and eccentricities) that make your brand unique.</p> \n<p>For Virgin America, that means putting the \"I love you\" hand symbol front and center. This small gesture signals to the recipient that the folks atVirgin America really care about their customers. The playful accompanying copy, \"Welcome aboard,\" and casual call-to-action, \"Grab a seat,\" also help to position Virgin America as a hip, fun-loving brand right off the bat.</p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://food52.com/\">Food52</a></h3> \n<h4>Type of welcome: Get Started</h4> \n<p><img style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/food-52-welcome-email.png\" alt=\"Food52 welcome email with a gray CTA to get started\" title=\"food-52-welcome-email.png\"></p> \n<p>Sometimes the tiniest of elements in a welcome email can speak volumes about a brand. And when it comes to Food52's welcome email, their preview text at the top of the email, \"We brought snacks,\" definitely accomplishes this.</p> \n<p>Also known as a pre-header or snippet text, preview text is the copy that gets pulled in from the body of an email and displayed next to (or beneath) the subject line in someone's inbox. So when you see Food52's welcome email in your inbox, you get a taste of their brand's personality before you even open it.</p> \n<p><img style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/preview_text-3.png\" alt=\"preview_text-3.png\" title=\"preview_text-3.png\"></p> \n<p>Food52's welcome email also does a good job of building trust by putting a face (make that two faces) to their name. As soon as you open the email, you see a photograph of -- and welcome message from -- the company's founders.</p> \n<h3>3. Monday.com</h3> \n<h4>Type of welcome: Video</h4> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/monday.com-video-welcome-email.png\" alt=\"Monday.com welcome email with a link to watch a video by CEO Roy Man\"></p> \n<p>From the subject line to the conversational tone in the email body, the welcome email above keeps it friendly and simple so the focus stays on the introductory video inside.</p> \n<p>Monday.com is a task management tool for teams and businesses, and the welcome email you get when you sign up makes you feel like the CEO, Roy Man, is talking directly to you. The email even personalizes the opening greeting by using the recipient's first name -- this is well known for <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/marketing-statistics\">increasing email click-through rates</a> (especially if the name is in the subject line).</p> \n<p>The closer you can get to making your email sound like a one-on-one conversation between you and your subscriber, the better. If you have just so many details you need to inform your new customer of, follow Monday.com's lead and embed them in a video, rather than spelling them all out in the email itself.</p> \n<h3>4. <a href=\"https://www.katespade.com/\">Kate Spade</a></h3> \n<h4>Type of welcome: Thank You</h4> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/kate-spade-welcome-email.png\" alt=\"Kate Spade welcome email with orange envelope graphic saying thank you\" title=\"kate-spade-welcome-email.png\"></p> \n<p>Let's face it: We, the internet-using public, are constantly bombarded with prompts to sign up for and subscribe to all sorts of email communications. So as a brand, when someone takes the time to sift through all the chaos in order to intentionally sign up for <em>your</em> email communications, it's a big deal.</p> \n<p>In order to acknowledge how grateful they are to the folks who actually take the time to subscribe, Kate Spade uses a simple -- but effective -- tactic with their welcome emails: They say \"Thank You\" in big, bold lettering. And by placing that \"Thank You\" on an envelope, Kate Spade recreates the feeling of receiving an actual thank-you letter in the mail. (The 15% off discount code doesn't hurt either.)</p> \n<h3>5. Lyft</h3> \n<h4>Type of welcome: Get Started</h4> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/lyft-welcome-email.png?width=690&amp;name=lyft-welcome-email.png\" alt=\"Lyft welcome email with pink CTA to get started\" width=\"690\" style=\"width: 690px;\"></p> \n<p>If there's an ideal \"attitude\" that welcome emails should give off, Lyft has got it.</p> \n<p>The company's simple but vibrant welcome email, shown above, focuses entirely on the look and feel of the app, delivering a design that's as warm and smooth as the lifts that Lyft wants to give you. At the same time, the email's branded pink call-to-action draws your eyes toward the center of the page to \"Take a Ride\" -- inviting language that doesn't make you feel pressured as a new user.</p> \n<h3>6. <a href=\"http://www.ikea.com/\" style=\"font-size: 1.5rem;\">IKEA</a></h3> \n<h4>Type of welcome: Offer</h4> \n<p><img style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/ikea-welcome-email.png\" alt=\"IKEA welcome email with offer to join free membership\" title=\"ikea-welcome-email.png\"></p> \n<p>It might not be the most beautifully designed email on this list, but that doesn't mean IKEA's welcome email isn't effective.</p> \n<p>Instead of going for the hard sell (e.g., \"By stuff now!\"), or explaining what it is they do (which is something IKEA probably assumes most people already know), IKEA uses its welcome email to turn folks onto its other, lesser-known programs and content channels. For example, there's a call-to-action right at the top that explains the value of its member benefits program. There are also prompts to visit their design blog and to contribute to their collaborative \"Share Space\" site.</p> \n<p>Of course, if you're not interested in any of that stuff, IKEA's welcome email also makes it easy for you to simply log in and start shopping (there's a login field right up top).</p> \n<h3>7. <a href=\"http://www.michaels.com/\">Michaels</a></h3> \n<h4>Type of welcome: Offer</h4> \n<p><img style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/michaels-welcome-email.png\" alt=\"Michaels welcome email with offer of 20% off an entire purchase\" title=\"michaels-welcome-email.png\"></p> \n<p>The Michaels approach to the welcome email borrows elements from both Kate Spade and Virgin America. In addition to expressing gratitude to the folks who took the time to sign up, Michaels uses its welcome email to showcase the brand. And the company does a great job: The lengthy email feels like one big arts and crafts project, complete with paint, yarn, and chalkboards.</p> \n<p>Another standout feature of this welcome email is that Michaels makes it immediately clear what value its future email communications are going to provide. After thanking subscribers, there's this nice bit of copy that sums it up:</p> \n<p>\"We're going to send fun stuff like DIY tips and tricks, invites to in-store events, and exclusive deals and coupons.\"</p> \n<h3>8. Sphero</h3> \n<h4>Type of welcome: Hello</h4> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/sphero-welcome-email.png?width=690&amp;name=sphero-welcome-email.png\" alt=\"Sphero welcome email with BB-8 Star Wars Droid saying hello\" width=\"690\" style=\"width: 690px;\"></p> \n<p>Sphero's welcome email might in fact be the cutest one we've seen recently -- and it was sent from a galaxy far, far away.</p> \n<p>If you purchase a bluetooth-controlled BB-8, the friendly Droid from <em>Star Wars</em>, it was probably made by Sphero. And if it was, you'll have an email similar to the one above waiting in your inbox when you activate your new rolling companion.</p> \n<p>This email's subject line is what qualifies it for this list -- \"A little Droid told us you wanted our emails.\" By cleverly personifying the product, and being somewhat candid about its <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/email\">email marketing</a> newsletters, Sphero develops a relationship with their recipients through the product you just bought from them.</p> \n<p>Besides showing you how to use your new BB-8 Droid with your smartphone, all this welcome email wanted to do was say hi -- just like BB-8 himself.</p> \n<h3>9. <a href=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/\">InVision</a></h3> \n<h4>Type of welcome: Video</h4> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/invision-welcome-email.png\" alt=\"InVision welcome email with link to watch video\" title=\"invision-welcome-email.png\"></p> \n<p>When you sign up for InVision's free prototyping app, the welcome email makes it very clear what your next step should be: using the app.</p> \n<p>To facilitate this action, InVision's welcome email doesn't simply list out what you need to do in order to get started. Instead, it <em>shows you</em> what you need to do with a series of quick videos. Given the visual, interactive nature of the product, this makes a lot of sense.</p> \n<h3>10. <a href=\"http://www.drift.com/\">Drift</a></h3> \n<h4>Type of welcome: Get Started</h4> \n<p><img style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/drift-welcome-email-1.png\" alt=\"Drift welcome email with link to get started\" title=\"drift-welcome-email-1.png\"></p> \n<p>No fancy design work. No videos. No photos. The welcome email Drift sends out after signing up for their newsletter is a lesson in minimalism.</p> \n<p>The email opens with a bit of candid commentary on the state of email. \"Most people have really long welcome email sequences after you get on their email list,\" Dave from Drift writes, before continuing: \"Good news: we aren't most people.\" What follows is simply a bulleted list of the company's most popular blog posts. And the only mention of the product comes in a brief post-script at the very end.</p> \n<p>If you're trying to craft a welcome email that's non-interruptive, and that's laser-focused on adding value vs. fluff, this is a great example to follow.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in April, 2016 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p> \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 07 Aug 2020 15:08:00 +0000","feedId":924,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/welcome-email-examples.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"dd3aad22891870a7e45a5d47ea543ca0","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn79@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-28-412_0cac56d01dd07369.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/welcome-email-examples.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"edevaney@hubspot.com (Erik Devaney)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Email%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg?width=400&name=Email%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn75@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-31-609_03a99e311eca0ea0.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/virgin-america-welcome-email.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn15@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-38-788_8fdeac7429e2fd25.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/food-52-welcome-email.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn84@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-38-498_ce0f7ae78d84f539.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/preview_text-3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn88@2020_3/2020/08/16/13-48-29-722_8ead1ba4a4c18e18.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/monday.com-video-welcome-email.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn23@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-38-923_6da7f4217aa13774.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/kate-spade-welcome-email.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn48@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-36-472_d1744136ddd5194f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/lyft-welcome-email.png?width=690&name=lyft-welcome-email.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn3@2020_3/2020/08/16/13-48-33-693_35eb0c271499fe78.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/ikea-welcome-email.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn59@2020_2/2020/08/16/13-48-35-712_ea99e095eb844cf1.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/michaels-welcome-email.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn36@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-32-931_d651c206de0777df.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/sphero-welcome-email.png?width=690&name=sphero-welcome-email.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn16@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-29-455_c2c78bb8f30c40d7.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/invision-welcome-email.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn64@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-30-685_e35af7101e39b26a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/drift-welcome-email-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn8@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-29-115_08c1ef8de2ef95cd.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fwelcome-email-examples&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn71@2020_2/2020/08/16/13-48-36-757_9041613ae476bd94.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:25","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:25","title":"How to Write a Request for Proposal with Template and Sample","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/rfp-template","description":"<p>Whether you’re working for a small agency or a major marketing firm, you’re probably eventually going to need to fill out a Request for Proposal, or RFP.</p> \n<p>Your company can’t do everything internally, and when your business needs to purchase a product or service from elsewhere, you might need to shop around. An RFP allows you to collect offers from various vendors and select the vendor that best meets your criteria, both in regards to skill and budget.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Any time you outsource work to a supplier, there's a potential for issues such as miscommunication around the scope of the work and the compensation. What a good RFP does is eliminate gray area so that both parties understand what needs to be delivered, when, and for how much.</p> \n<p><span style=\"color: #33475b; font-size: 1.1em; font-weight: 300; letter-spacing: 0.01em;\"></span></p> \n<h2><strong>RFP Template</strong></h2> \n<p>Here, we’ve provided an RFP template you can follow for initial structure, as well as a sample RFP for further inspiration. But it isn’t one-size-fits-all — you’ll need to tailor your RFP to best articulate your company’s needs.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Request%20for%20Project%20Proposal%20(RPT)%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=Request%20for%20Project%20Proposal%20(RPT)%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg\" alt=\"Free editable rfp request for proposal pdf template\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/rfp-templates?hubs_post-cta=imagesir\"><em>Download a free, editable RFP template.</em></a><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"></span></p> \n<p>RFPs come in all shapes, sizes, and visual formats depending on the needs of your company and the work that must be performed. At the top of a standard RFP, you'll find the following:</p> \n<p><em>Project Name or Description</em></p> \n<p><em>Company Name</em></p> \n<p><em>Address</em></p> \n<p><em>City, State, Zip Code</em></p> \n<p><em>Procurement Contact Person</em></p> \n<p><em>Telephone Number of PCP</em></p> \n<p><em>Email Address of PCP</em></p> \n<p><em>Fax Number<br /></em></p> \n<p>The body of the RFP will contain additional details about the project, including:</p> \n<ol> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/rfp-template#background\">Background/Introduction</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/rfp-template#goals-scope\">Project Goals and Scope of Services</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/rfp-template#selection-schedule\">Anticipated Selection Schedule</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/rfp-template#proposal-submission\">Time and Place of Submission of Proposals</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/rfp-template#timeline\">Timeline</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/rfp-template#elements\">Elements of Proposal</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/rfp-template#evaluation-criteria\">Evaluation Criteria</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/rfp-template#roadblocks\">Possible Roadblocks</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/rfp-template#budget\">Budget</a></li> \n</ol> \n<p>Read on to learn more about what goes into each of these sections so that you can build an RFP of your own.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>1. Background/Introduction</h3> \n<p>In your introductory paragraph, you’ll want to include useful background information about your company — who founded it, what product or service your company offers, what sets you apart from competitors, and where you’re located. If any vendor is serious about working with you, they’ll want this information before moving forward.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>2. Project Goals and Scope of Services</h3> \n<p>Next, you’ll want to outline the project you need completed, and the goals you expect to accomplish from the project. It’s important you get as specific as possible — even outlining individual tasks and criteria involved. You’ll want to include phrases such as “The award will be given to X firm,” with the “X” establishing how you’ll determine the best candidate.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>3. Anticipated Selection Schedule</h3> \n<p>It’s crucial you include a detailed schedule so vendors know if they can meet your deadlines. You’ll also need to give vendors a window for when they can ask questions regarding your project. This’ll limit the hassle, for you and for them.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>4. Time and Place of Submission of Proposals</h3> \n<p>Similar to paragraph #3, this is important information you’ll want to clearly present, so vendors know how and where to submit themselves for consideration.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>5. Timeline</h3> \n<p>By including a time frame in your RFP, you’re able to eliminate any vendor who can’t work within your time constraints. If you’re flexible on your time, you can write something like, “Our company hopes to finish the project within six months, but we’re open to negotiation for the right candidate.”</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>6. Elements of Proposal</h3> \n<p>If you don’t outline clearly and specifically what you expect bidders to include in their proposal, you can’t necessarily fault them if they don’t include it. It’s critical you outline a checklist so vendors know which elements you’re expecting to receive. It’s also a good test for who’s capable of handling your demands — if a vendor can’t complete all elements of your proposal, you probably can’t trust them to finish your project, either.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>7. Evaluation Criteria</h3> \n<p>Outlining your expectations will help eliminate vendors who don’t meet them. For this section, you’ll want to do some brainstorming with your team to come up with a mandatory list of items you feel are the best indicators of impressive candidates. Your list could include samples of past work, a proven success record with companies in similar industries, the expertise and technical skills to meet your demands, and a cost of services within your price range.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>8. Possible Roadblocks</h3> \n<p>Here, you’ll want to outline any roadblocks, such as limited resources or a custom website, that might prevent certain vendors from successfully completing the project. This allows you to eliminate unsatisfactory bidders, and it will also help you determine which vendors have the skills and expertise to tackle those challenges.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>9. Budget</h3> \n<p>Any vendor needs to know how much you’re able to pay them for their services before they’ll move forward with their bid.</p> \n<h2><strong>RFP Sample</strong></h2> \n<p>The above elements might manifest on the page in a number of ways. For example, here is an RFP sample from TemplateLab.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/rfp-sample-templatelab.jpg?width=485&amp;name=rfp-sample-templatelab.jpg\" alt=\"rfp sample templatelab with tables and red headings\" width=\"485\" style=\"width: 485px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"><a href=\"https://templatelab.com/request-for-proposal/\"><em><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\">Image Source&nbsp;</span></em></a></img></p> \n<p>Now that you understand the elements of an RFP , you can build your own template and then fill it out so that you can start accepting bids. We'll use a fictitious company, Caroline's Websites, Inc., to illustrate exactly how each section should be executed, starting with the header:</p> \n<p><em>Project Name or Description: Marketing Services</em></p> \n<p><em>Company Name: Caroline’s Websites, Inc.</em></p> \n<p><em>Address: 302 Inbound Ave.</em></p> \n<p><em>City, State, Zip Code: Boston, MA 29814</em></p> \n<p><em>Procurement Contact Person: Caroline Forsey</em></p> \n<p><em>Telephone Number of PCP: 227-124-2481</em></p> \n<p><em>Email Address of PCP: cforsey@consulting.com</em></p> \n<p><em>Fax Number: N/A<br /></em></p> \n<p>Next, we'll go into each of the elements of the RFP with information using the same fictitious company.&nbsp;<br><br /></br></p> \n<h3>1. Background/Introduction</h3> \n<p>Caroline’s Websites, Inc. is a web design firm created by Caroline Forsey in 2010. Caroline’s Websites, Inc. prides itself on a team-oriented, solutions-based approach to web design. We provide our clients with web design services including coding, development, and branding. Our staff is located in two offices in Massachusetts.</p> \n<h3>2. Project Goals and Scope of Services</h3> \n<p>Caroline’s Websites, Inc. is seeking the services of a full-service communications and marketing firm to develop and execute a comprehensive integrated marketing plan that increases our SEO presence; attracts more social media followers; and effectively completes a lead generation campaign. The award will be made to a responsive and responsible firm based on the best value and professional capability.</p> \n<p>The selected firm will be responsible for the development and implementation of a comprehensive and cost-effective marketing plan.</p> \n<p>Tasks include but may not be limited to the following criteria:</p> \n<p>• Lead generation campaign</p> \n<p>• Paid media strategy</p> \n<p>• Production of creative material including collateral and direct mail</p> \n<p>• Online marketing campaign</p> \n<p>• Website enhancement</p> \n<p>• Search engine optimization</p> \n<p>• General account management</p> \n<p>• Other communications and/or marketing-related assistance as required</p> \n<h3>3. Anticipated Selection Schedule</h3> \n<p>The Request for Proposal timeline is as follows:</p> \n<p>Request for RFP: June 1, 2020</p> \n<p>Deadline for Bidders to Submit Questions: July 5, 2020</p> \n<p>[Company Name] Responds to Bidder Questions: July 20, 2020</p> \n<p>Selection of Top Bidders / Notification to Unsuccessful Bidders: July 31, 2020</p> \n<p>Start of Negotiation: August 5, 2020</p> \n<p>Contract Award / Notification to Unsuccessful Bidders: August 31, 2020</p> \n<h3>4. Time and Place of Submission of Proposals</h3> \n<p>The RFP will be posted on our website, Carolinewebsites.com, and can be downloaded from there directly as of 10 a.m. on June 1, 2020.</p> \n<p>Respondents to this RFP must submit one original and five copies of their proposal. Responses must be received no later than July 25, 2020. Responses should be clearly marked “RFP-MarketingServices” and mailed or delivered to the contact person listed above.</p> \n<h3>5. Timeline</h3> \n<p>Caroline’s Websites, Inc. needs the project completed within 8 months.</p> \n<h3>6. Elements of Proposal</h3> \n<p>A submission must, at a minimum, include the following elements:</p> \n<p>• Description of the firm that includes a general overview, names and credentials of creative team, number of full-time employees.</p> \n<p>• A one-page narrative outlining the firm’s strengths and distinguishing skills or capabilities as they might relate to Caroline’s Websites, Inc.</p> \n<p>• A representative selection of social media ads, direct response material, collateral, and website development created for current and past clients.</p> \n<h3>7. Evaluation Criteria</h3> \n<p>The successful respondent will:</p> \n<p>• Have been operating continuously as a marketing agency for a minimum of 24 months and possess full-service, in-house capabilities for marketing, creative services, production, media planning and placement, direct response and research.</p> \n<p>• The education, experience, knowledge, skills, and qualifications of the firm and the individuals who will be available to provide these services.</p> \n<p>• The competitive cost of services.</p> \n<p>• The expertise of the firm in working with similar customers.</p> \n<h3>8. Possible Roadblocks</h3> \n<p>At this time, Caroline’s Websites, Inc. currently has custom coding on our website, of which bidders should be aware.</p> \n<h3>9. Budget</h3> \n<p>Caroline’s Websites, Inc.’s budget for the project is $8,750.00.</p> \n<p>These elements were written in a way to clarify the scope of the project that Caroline's Websites, Inc. wants completed so that suppliers know whether or not to make a bid. Defining the project allows the bidder to determine if they're a good fit and how much they'd likely charge. Being as transparent as possible serves to benefit (and even protect) <em>both </em>parties in the long run.</p> \n<p>To use some of these elements in your own RFP, start with an RFP template and adjust it to your liking.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in June 2018 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p> \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Frfp-template&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \" />","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 07 Aug 2020 13:00:00 +0000","feedId":924,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/RFP-template-1.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"b16f44ad020dd479d55a150de2981c30","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn20@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-27-404_f54021e72f231c61.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/RFP-template-1.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"Caroline Forsey","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Request%20for%20Project%20Proposal%20(RPT)%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg?width=1500&name=Request%20for%20Project%20Proposal%20(RPT)%20Template,%20Blog%20Image.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn39@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-30-326_59851a7ee2fb2497.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/rfp-sample-templatelab.jpg?width=485&name=rfp-sample-templatelab.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn67@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-29-710_f309d07aeec0f7ac.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Frfp-template&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn11@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-37-922_f7220c7d633eea49.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","title":"How to Create Content for Every Stage of the Buyer's Journey","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-for-every-funnel-stage","description":"<p>No one wakes up in the morning and decides, “I’m going to buy something today.” Instead, they go through a path to purchase that includes research and evaluation before committing to a sales call.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>That journey is called the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/what-is-the-buyers-journey\">buyer’s journey</a>. Because consumers are more informed and more empowered than ever before, it’s important to deeply understand your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/buyer-persona-research\">buyer persona</a> and the journey they make so you can create content that helps them along that path while positioning you as an authority in your space.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>In this post, we'll cover:&nbsp;</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-for-every-funnel-stage#buyers-journey\">Understanding the Buyer's Journey in Marketing</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-for-every-funnel-stage#marketing-funnel\">What a Marketing Funnel Is</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-for-every-funnel-stage#marketing-channels\">Marketing Channels for Each Stage of the Funnel</a> \n  <ul> \n   <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-for-every-funnel-stage#attract-channels\">Attract Channels</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-for-every-funnel-stage#engage-channels\">Engage Channels</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-for-every-funnel-stage#delight-channels\">Delight Channels</a></li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-for-every-funnel-stage#buyers-journey-content\">Creating Content for Each Stage of the Buyer's Journey</a> \n  <ul> \n   <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-for-every-funnel-stage#awareness-content\">Content Formats for the Awareness Stage</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-for-every-funnel-stage#consideration-content\">Content Formats for the Consideration Stage</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-for-every-funnel-stage#decision-content\">Content Formats for the Decision Stage and Beyond</a></li> \n  </ul> </li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Understanding the Buyer’s Journey in Marketing</h2> \n<p>In most cases, with the exception of impulse buys, an individual begins their journey in an “unaware stage.” This individual likely fits the demographics of your ideal client (also known as your buyer persona), but they are not aware of your product or in need of it.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>However, they may experience a triggering event that changes their situation or a pain that needs to be solved. This kicks off their buyer’s journey.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/buyers-journey-3-stages.jpg?width=600&amp;name=buyers-journey-3-stages.jpg\" alt=\"buyer's journey showing progression through the awareness stage, consideration stage, and decision stage\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<p>When you don't have a complete understanding your audience, a disconnect is created between your business and your potential customers. For content marketers, this usually means you're putting out content that your readers don't really relate with, which can cause you to lose them.</p> \n<p>As is the case in all marketing disciplines, it’s <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33491/Everything-Marketers-Need-to-Research-Create-Detailed-Buyer-Personas-Template.aspx#sm.0000o5c3iom8gdkipdw2l236rj19q\">important to understand your audience</a>:&nbsp;how they think, the answers they seek, and the path they tend to take to find a solution. From that research, you can <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-marketing-plan\">begin crafting a documented content strategy</a> that maps your content to the various stages of the buyer's journey.</p> \n<p>Developing the buyer’s journey for your business is the first step to creating content that resonates with your buyer and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33711/The-Steps-You-Need-to-Define-the-Stages-of-Your-Sales-Marketing-Funnel.aspx?&amp;_ga=2.183949606.1430126461.1594683485-303082430.1584047107#sm.0000o5c3iom8gdkipdw2l236rj19q\">building out your marketing funnel</a> so that you can meet them at each stage of their journey.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>What Is a Marketing Funnel?&nbsp;</h2> \n<p>A marketing funnel — more commonly known as a sales funnel since its output is revenue — describes the different stages a customer goes through leading up to their purchase, from looking at your website for the first time and subscribing to your email list to reading your emails and talking to a sales associate.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/attract-engage-delight.jpg?width=787&amp;name=attract-engage-delight.jpg\" alt=\"illustration of marketing funnel with marketing at the top, sales in the middle, and customers at the end. Also shows corresponds to the attract, engage, and delight strategy.\" width=\"787\" style=\"width: 787px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<p>How the funnel works is simple. The top of the funnel indicates they are further away from a purchasing decision while those who make it to the bottom of the funnel are closer to a purchasing decision.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Often, it’s a marketer’s job to <strong>attract</strong> your buyer persona in the early stages of their journey and hand off qualified prospects to the sales team to <strong>engage</strong> them. Once they become a customer, your service team <strong>delights</strong> them so that they buy from you again and again and tell all their friends.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>The funnel is a useful tool when used in the context of the buyer’s journey. However, keep in mind that the funnel has one issue: It puts customers as the output. At <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-QC2SHjBiag\">INBOUND 18</a>, HubSpot officially <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/our-flywheel\">retires the funnel in favor of the flywheel</a>.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Funnel-To-Flywheel-Morph.gif?width=450&amp;name=Funnel-To-Flywheel-Morph.gif\" alt=\"an animation of the funnel morphing into a flywheel, a circle with marketing, sales, and service surrounded by growth (or customers) at the center\" width=\"450\" style=\"width: 450px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">The result puts customers at the center, which creates a more unified and less linear approach to all your marketing, sales, and service activities.</img></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Flywheel-Continuous-Spin.gif?width=400&amp;name=Flywheel-Continuous-Spin.gif\" alt=\"flywheel with attract, engage, and delight, spinning and feeding into each other as it shows strangers becoming prospects, customers, and promoters\" width=\"400\" style=\"width: 400px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<h3>Marketing Funnel Stages</h3> \n<p>Even so, the funnel is still a good starting point before you begin moving to your flywheel strategy.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>All you have to do take the buyer’s journey and ask the question: “How do we attract and engage this person so they become a customer?”&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Whether you subscribe to the funnel or the flywheel methodology, earning business from your prospects comes down to three simple things:&nbsp;</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Attracting strangers</li> \n <li>Engaging prospects</li> \n <li>Delighting customers</li> \n</ul> \n<p>As you create create content that performs these functions, you'll consider the stage they're at in their journey and the best channels to put the content in front of them.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>The internet has made it easier for marketers (and salespeople) to engage customers at the various stages of their journey&nbsp;using content marketing.&nbsp;That’s one of the main reasons that<strong><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing\"> 60% of marketers</a> consider content as 'very important' or 'extremely important' to their overall strategy.</strong></p> \n<p>However, it can be challenging to create the right content, for the right people, at the right time.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Marketing Channels for Each Stage of the Funnel</h2> \n<p>Building a content strategy starts with identifying the channels in which you’ll reach your audience.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/marketing-channels-per-stage.jpg?width=600&amp;name=marketing-channels-per-stage.jpg\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"marketing channels for each stage of your strategy: attract, engage, delight\" /></p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Marketing Channels for the Attract Stage</h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/attract-stage.jpg?width=600&amp;name=attract-stage.jpg\" alt=\"Attract Stage: The stage of the inbound methodology where you use your expertise to create content and conversations that start meaningful relationships with the right people.\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">Remember, a large majority of your prospects may even be in the awareness stage of their buyer’s journey when you begin to attract them. That means your goal is to solve for their pains/problems by creating content they can easily discover and consume.</img></p> \n<p>At this point, a buyer is trying to solve problems, get an answer, or meet a need. They’re looking for top-level educational content to help direct them to a solution, like blog posts, social content, and ebooks.&nbsp;Their&nbsp;value as a lead is low because there’s no guarantee that they’ll buy from you. But those who find your content helpful and interesting may journey on to the middle of the funnel.</p> \n<p>The ideal channels for your attract stage may include:&nbsp;</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Blogging</li> \n <li>Search Engine Marketing</li> \n <li>Social Media Marketing</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Marketing Channels for the Engage Stage</h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/engage-stage.jpg?width=600&amp;name=engage-stage.jpg\" alt=\"Engage Stage: The stage of the inbound methodology where you build lasting relationships with people by providing insights and solutions that align with their pain points and goals\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<p>When someone moves into the middle of your funnel, it means you’ve captured their attention. They know they have a problem that has to be solved, and now they’re trying to discover the best solution. The need for a future purchase commitment creeps up as they’re evaluation their options.</p> \n<p>While the top of the funnel is designed to educate a prospect, this is the stage where you want to show why your solutions in particular are the best fit.</p> \n<p>(You also want to help people determine if they're <em>not&nbsp;</em>a good fit, which will be very important later for healthy customer retention. If you convince customers to buy who aren't a good fit for your business in the long run, you could be shooting yourself in the foot in the form of high churn rate later.)</p> \n<p>The middle of the funnel is typically a point of extended engagement where you’re nurturing a lead, building a relationship, and establishing trust between the audience and your brand.</p> \n<p>The ideal channels for your engage stage may include:&nbsp;</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Email Marketing</li> \n <li>Retargeting/Remarketing</li> \n <li>Social Media</li> \n</ul> \n<p>You also need to engage prospects at the bottom of your funnel.</p> \n<p>The bottom of the funnel is where someone is making the actual purchase decision. They're ready to&nbsp;buy, but that&nbsp;still doesn’t guarantee that they’re going to buy from <em>you.</em> That’s the last choice they have to make: Where do they get the solution they’re seeking?</p> \n<p>In most cases, leads at the bottom of your funnel just need that final nudge and that compelling call-to-action to get them to make a purchase decision. The right offer and content at this stage can have a dramatic impact on lifting your conversions.</p> \n<p>You might also consider sales outreach to engage qualified prospects and continue to engage them through personalization and contextual marketing.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Marketing Channels for the Delight Stage</h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/delight-stage.jpg?width=600&amp;name=delight-stage.jpg\" alt=\"Delight Stage: The stage of the inbound methodology where you provide an outstanding experience that adds real value, and empowers people to reach their goals and become promoters of your company.\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<p>Marketing shouldn’t stop once someone becomes a customer. Cultivating a relationship with your customer beyond the sale can lead to higher customer lifetime value as well as word-of-mouth referrals and more.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>The key here is to go above and beyond their expectations and provide a customer experience that’s easy and frictionless.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>The ideal channels for your delight stage may include:&nbsp;</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Email Marketing</li> \n <li>Retargeting/Remarketing</li> \n <li>Self-Service Channels Such as Knowledge Bases</li> \n <li>Live Chat and Chatbots for Service</li> \n <li>Loyalty Programs</li> \n</ul> \n<p>On the surface, this process seems really linear, but you can also target multiple stages of the buyer’s journey across channels.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>For example, you may still be able to attract someone in the consideration stage or delight someone who isn’t a customer yet. Your knowledge base might convince someone in the consideration stage to buy since they perceive that you have great service, or someone in the awareness stage could engage your chatbot to find the content they need.</p> \n<p>One of the joys of content marketing is thinking outside the box.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Creating Content for Each Stage of the Buyer's Journey</h2> \n<p>Once you have an idea of who your buyer persona is and what channels will work best for your business, you can begin creating content for your buyer at different stages and tailor that content per channel.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Doing so can help you <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/customer-journey-map-template\">map your content to the relevant stages of the buyer’s journey</a> to make your funnel.</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Top of the Funnel:</strong>&nbsp;The \"awareness\" stage, where people looking for answers, resources, education, research data, opinions, and insight.</li> \n <li><strong>Middle of the Funnel:&nbsp;</strong>The \"evaluation\" stage, where people are doing heavy research on whether or not your product or service is a good fit for them.</li> \n <li><strong>Bottom of the Funnel:</strong>&nbsp;The \"purchase\" stage, where people are figuring out exactly what it would take to become a customer.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Your funnel may look very different depending on factors like your industry, business model, product, pricing, and audience.&nbsp;Some B2C customers, for example, spend very little time in the middle of the funnel compared to B2B customers that require far more nurturing, engagement, and relationship development before a purchase is made. A $50 pair of sneakers, for instance, requires a lot less handholding when it comes to making purchase decisions than a $10,000 business software investment.</p> \n<h2>Content Ideas for Each Stage of the Buyer's Journey</h2> \n<p>Because audiences can vary so widely based on industry and intent, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33491/Everything-Marketers-Need-to-Research-Create-Detailed-Buyer-Personas-Template.aspx\">persona research is of the utmost importance</a>. Only by understanding their unique process for awareness and evaluation will you be able to create a truly effective content marketing strategy, packed with custom content that best supports their journey toward making a purchase.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/content-buyer-journey-stage.jpg?width=600&amp;name=content-buyer-journey-stage.jpg\" alt=\"content ideas for each stage of the buyer's journey: awareness, consideration, decision\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Blog Post&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>A blog post is an ideal piece of content targeting the awareness stage. By targeting a pain, problem, or other topic your target audience wants to discover and then posting it to your website, you’re creating a brand asset that’s crawlable by Google and discoverable by search engine users. You can also promote your blog content across other channels.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/blog-post-example-ahrefs.jpg?width=600&amp;name=blog-post-example-ahrefs.jpg\" alt=\"blog post example from ahrefs's blog that reads 'how long should blog posts be?'\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://ahrefs.com/blog/blog-post-length/\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>Ahrefs is a great example of a brand that does blog content right. They include original data and informational advice to create long-form articles that serve their audience.</p> \n<h3>Social Media Post</h3> \n<p>Social media is a channel that can be used to promote your other content, and you can also create content specifically for the channel. According to <a href=\"https://www.pewresearch.org/internet/fact-sheet/social-media/\">Pew Research</a>, 72% of the public uses some form of social media, so it’s likely that your audience is native to this channel. Unlike blog posts, social media posts are likely shorter form, and <a href=\"https://www.oberlo.com/blog/video-marketing-statistics\">video consumption is also on the rise</a>.</p> \n<iframe style=\"margin: 0px auto; display: block;\" src=\"https://www.linkedin.com/embed/feed/update/urn:li:ugcPost:6672147901583642624\" width=\"504\" height=\"653\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe> \n<p>In the above example, HubSpot Agency Partner <a href=\"https://www.yokellocal.com/\">Yokel Local</a> shares attractive customer marketing tips on the LinkedIn platform. SlideShare formats are popular on LinkedIn, so the content is created to be snackable with short-form take-aways.</p> \n<h3>Whitepaper&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>A whitepaper is an organization’s report or guide on a particular topic. Whitepapers are especially useful as downloadable offers when a reader wants to go more in-depth on a particular subject they’re reading about. For whitepapers, it’s important to provide information that can’t be found elsewhere so that your audience understands the value of the report and is compelled to get it.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/whitepaper-example-hubspot.jpg?width=518&amp;name=whitepaper-example-hubspot.jpg\" alt=\"whitepaper example from hubspot that reads: &quot;not another state of marketing report&quot;\" width=\"518\" style=\"width: 518px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>Every year, HubSpot publishes a survey on the state of marketing to provide helpful guidance based on thought leadership to marketers, sales professionals, and business owners. Inside, readers find statistics from a broad survey as well as industry experts’ opinions on what the data means and where the industry is going.</p> \n<h3>Checklist&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>For tasks that are complicated and have a lot of moving parts, individuals may simply want a blueprint that spells out what they’re supposed to do to achieve their end goal.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/checklist-example-opendoor.jpg?width=600&amp;name=checklist-example-opendoor.jpg\" alt=\"checklist example from opendoor that reads &quot;the essential checklist for first-time home buyers&quot;\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://www.opendoor.com/w/guides/checklist-for-first-time-home-buyers\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>Buying a home is a perfect example of this, and Opendoor meets their audience’s need by providing a handy checklist (in infographic form!) for the reader that spells out all the steps that need to be taken. The graphic is aesthetically pleasing and even allows room for a few tips along the way.</p> \n<h3>How-To Video&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>Sometimes, the best way to solve a pain or problem is to learn a new skill. Sure, a purchase of some kind may be required along the way, but the audience may need to become more informed about the problem and how to solve it. That’s where instructional video content comes in.</p> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; max-width: 534px; max-height: 300px; min-width: 256px; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.18%; margin: 0;\"> \n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/FyOqoV90v58?autoplay=0&amp;fs=0&amp;iv_load_policy=3&amp;showinfo=0&amp;rel=0&amp;cc_load_policy=0&amp;start=0&amp;end=0&amp;origin=https://youtubeembedcode.com\" width=\"534\" height=\"300\" frameborder=\"0\"></iframe> \n </div> \n</div> \n<p>Whiteboard Fridays is a popular video series by <a href=\"https://moz.com/\">Moz</a> where SEO principles are broken down to the audience in easy-to-understand language and visuals. Moz knows that SEO is a difficult subject and aims to make it accessible to their viewers.</p> \n<h3>Kit or Tool&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>Informational content provided to a broader audience may not always be enough for your buyer persona to make a decision or take action of some kind. In some cases, they may require a little more utility or personalization. That’s why kits and tools are a great piece of content to create to help the reader along their path to purchase.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/tool-example-nerdwallet.jpg?width=600&amp;name=tool-example-nerdwallet.jpg\" alt=\"tool example from nerdwallet that reads &quot;the 50/30/20 budget&quot; and is a budget calculator\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://www.nerdwallet.com/article/finance/nerdwallet-budget-calculator\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>Nerdwallet creates content around several financial topics, budgeting being one of them. It can be difficult to create a budget, though, so they developed a calculator that allows the user to provide their own numbers in order to receive a customized recommendation.</p> \n<h3>Ebook or Tip Sheet&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>Similar to whitepapers, ebooks and tip sheets are great options for downloadable content. In contrast, they tend to be shorter form and more actionable.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/tip-sheet-example-coschedule.jpg?width=600&amp;name=tip-sheet-example-coschedule.jpg\" alt=\"tip sheet example from coschedule that reads &quot;180+ power words for writing emotional headlines&quot;\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/emotional-headlines/\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>CoSchedule combines a few tactics by promoting their headline analyzer tool with a <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/emotional-headlines/\">blog post about writing great headlines that drive traffic</a>. On that blog post, they include a great <a href=\"https://coschedule.com/blog/emotional-headlines/\">tip sheet of powerful words</a> to include in headlines if you want to catch a reader’s attention.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>Educational Webinar&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>A webinar is a web seminar where information is typically provided through video. A webinar can be prerecorded or streamed live, and this opens up tons of possibilities to disseminate information to an audience who wants more visual and auditory content.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/webinar-example-semrush.jpg?width=600&amp;name=webinar-example-semrush.jpg\" alt=\"semrush's webinar page on their website\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://www.semrush.com/webinars/\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>SEMrush makes webinars a key part of their content marketing strategy, often running a valuable topic multiple times to get more mileage out of the content.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Product Comparison Guides</h3> \n<p>In the consideration stage, the buyer persona is still considering solutions to their pain or problem. For this reason, product comparisons are a great way to help them make a decision.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/comparison-example-verwell-fit.jpg?width=600&amp;name=comparison-example-verwell-fit.jpg\" alt=\"comparison example from verywell fit that reads &quot;pros and cons of hiit training&quot;\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://www.verywellfit.com/is-hiit-training-or-steady-state-cardio-better-4126506\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>Verywell Fit provides such a comparison to help their readers choose between high-intensity workouts vs. steady-state cardio, providing the pros and cons and use cases for each.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>Case Study</h3> \n<p>A case study can be used in both the consideration stage and the decision stage simultaneously by convincing the reader that the solution works by establishing that the provider achieves results for their clients by administering the solution. A good case study will appeal to the emotions and logic of the persona by providing detailed information and quantitative data on the final solution.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/case-study-example-bluleadz.jpg?width=600&amp;name=case-study-example-bluleadz.jpg\" alt=\"case study example from bluleadz that reads &quot;lead generation strategy lands 77 new clients for credit counseling agency&quot;\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://www.bluleadz.com/case-studies/credit-canada-new-content-offer\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>HubSpot Partner Agency <a href=\"https://www.bluleadz.com/\">Blueleadz</a> does this by telling a story about their client and the problems they had while providing a detailed account of how they solved it.</p> \n<h3>Free Sample&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>A free sample is another example of content or an offer that overlaps between buyer’s journey stages. Consider this: An individual wants to paint the inside of their home, but they don’t know what color.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>As they consider which color (the solution), they pick up paint chip cards from their hardware store. These cards are created by a provider based on their individual solution. When the individual falls in love with a color, they already know who the provider is that makes it.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/free-sample-example-4colorprint.jpg?width=600&amp;name=free-sample-example-4colorprint.jpg\" alt=\"free sample example from 4colorprint that depicts a pack of sample business cards\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://4colorprint.com/sample-request.php\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>SILKCARDS taps into this buying behavior by offering samples of their unique printing methods on the content that they create. They know that their business is tactile, and digital content alone is not enough to close a deal. Once their prospective customer holds the sample in their hands, other business cards are put to shame.&nbsp;</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Free Trial or Live Demo</h3> \n<p>What better way to know if you want to purchase a product than take it for a spin? Car dealerships have been using the “test drive” tactic for years because it works. If the product itself checks all the boxes the buyer has, all the sales team has to do is handle their objections and make the close.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/free-trial-example-hellosign.jpg?width=600&amp;name=free-trial-example-hellosign.jpg\" alt=\"free trial example from hellosign that reads &quot;unlimited signature requests with no hidden fees&quot; and has four pricing tiers, one that's free and two that offer free trials\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://app.hellosign.com/info/pricing\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>Hellosign does this well. Though they have a free option with limitations, they know that the key to getting clients into their larger tiers is by offering a free trial upfront. Their pricing page sets the prospect’s expectations and points them to the free trial.</p> \n<h3>Consultation Offer&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>A consultation is another example of providing just a little bit of service in exchange for the opportunity to close the sale. The best consultation offers reduce the anxiety of entering into a sales conversation by promising something concrete they can walk away with (a strategy or actionable advice) in exchange for their time.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/consultation-offer-blkbld-co.jpg?width=600&amp;name=consultation-offer-blkbld-co.jpg\" alt=\"consultation offer from blkbld &amp; co that reads 'for our initial consultation, we will discuss what you are looking to do, your budget, my marketing plans you can execute &amp; lastly the next steps&quot;\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://blkbld.lpages.co/free-consultation/\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>Blk Bld &amp; Co.’s consultation offer is a great example because it reduces the friction of scheduling a consultation. By removing friction, this organization increases the chances of conversion.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>Coupon</h3> \n<p>A coupon appeals to a fear of missing out (FOMO) mindset. By reducing the price by a certain amount, a coupon is handing a price objection while convincing the prospect that they’re leaving money on the table if they don’t use the coupon. This inertia enough to win the prospect’s business.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/coupon-example-fragrant-jewels.jpg?width=500&amp;name=coupon-example-fragrant-jewels.jpg\" alt=\"coupon example from fragrant jewels in a &quot;spin-to-win&quot; style popup format\" width=\"500\" style=\"width: 500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://www.fragrantjewels.com/\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>Fragrant Jewels does this well by gamifying their coupons. By spinning the wheel, the website visitors have the chance to get a coupon before checking out the products. They’ll likely be evaluating the products that are a good deal with the coupon they won.</p> \n<p>In addition to decision stage content, you should also create content to delight your existing customers. This may include FAQ and knowledge base content to make the customer experience easier, coupons for the opportunity to upsell, and additional educative content that deepens their understanding of a topic.</p> \n<h2>Mapping Content Across All Stages of the Funnel and Buying Cycle</h2> \n<p>Every business has a unique sales funnel, sculpted and designed around their buyer’s unique journey.&nbsp;It’s a recipe that can’t necessarily be replicated from one business to another.&nbsp;When creating your own buyer's journey, there are a number of factors specific&nbsp;to your business to take into consideration.</p> \n<p>That said, the general approach remains the same: Understand your audience, develop your funnel around your industry and audience intent, and create a documented content marketing strategy that maps custom content specifically to each phase of their journey through the funnel.</p> \n<p>Do it well, and this process will have the greatest possible impact on your customer relationships, as well as the greatest possible lift in your overall conversions.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in August 2016 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<img
