\">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 05 Aug 2020 12:00:00 +0000","feedId":924,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/imageedit_26_3434612923.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"ae57ccac4a1d258016c2f9b7a6d9699e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn95@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-27-551_a45d0bcf0807bb1d.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/imageedit_26_3434612923.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"Connor Cirillo","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/How%20Using%20Humans%20And%20Chatbots%20Together%20Generated%20182%25%20More%20Qualified%20Leads.png?width=1500&name=How%20Using%20Humans%20And%20Chatbots%20Together%20Generated%20182%25%20More%20Qualified%20Leads.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn79@2020_1/2020/08/16/13-48-32-607_8b0297669ec2bbeb.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/chatbot-hubspot-2.png?width=1500&name=chatbot-hubspot-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn72@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-39-270_54409768d3c91410.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/How%20Using%20Humans%20And%20Chatbots%20Together%20Generated%20182%25%20More%20Qualified%20Leads-1.png?width=1500&name=How%20Using%20Humans%20And%20Chatbots%20Together%20Generated%20182%25%20More%20Qualified%20Leads-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn84@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-39-816_f570b406c29749a2.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-chatbot-generated-more-qualified-leads&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx20/cdn39@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-32-835_a4a0ac8866ccc044.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","title":"The Plain-English Guide to Data Deduplication","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/data-deduplication","description":"<p>Nowadays, with so much critical information saved on our computer systems, we've learned to backup data regularly -- including our email inboxes, our Word documents, our photos, and entire folders of old work.</p> \n<p>It's typically a <em>ton </em>of data. And, since we usually backup and save our data on auto-pilot, we might not realize just how much has been re-copied and re-saved, time and time again.</p> \n<p>Unfortunately, over time, our data storage becomes unnecessarily burdened with redundant copies of data -- this could cost your company money, as data requirements become larger, or time, as processing time becomes slower.</p> \n<p>This is where data deduplication comes in.<br></p> \n<p>Andrew Le, an IT Helpdesk Technician at HubSpot, further explains the importance of data deduplication for a business looking to grow -- \"[Data deduplication] really improves scaling and efficiency when pulling data from one source. If you have lots of the same data in different spaces, your entire system can be slowed down.\"</p> \n<p>So, you might be wondering, <em>\"How does this work?\"</em> Let's dive into it below.</p> \n<h2>How does data deduplication work?</h2> \n<p>The data deduplication process might seem intimidating, but it's actually a simple process.</p> \n<p>You can use data deduplication software when you backup your computer. Additionally, some marketing automation software, like HubSpot, might have a deduplication feature to keep track of your marketing contacts.</p> \n<p>To ensure you're optimizing your data backup storage, we've cultivated a list of the best data deduplication software you can use to minimize unnecessary data copies, today.</p> \n<h2><strong>Examples of Data Deduplication Software</strong></h2> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/articles/kcs_article/contacts/deduplication-of-contacts-companies-deals-tickets?_ga=2.176575980.81589904.1554671928-644648569.1551722047\">HubSpot's Deduplication Feature</a></h3> \n<p>If you use HubSpot's CRM to manage your contacts, you'll be impressed to find out you can also use HubSpot's machine learning-powered deduplication feature to keep your contact database clean. HubSpot contacts can be deduplicated by a user token set with a cookie in their web browser or email address -- additionally, contacts, companies, deals, and tickets can be deduplicated using a unique object ID.</p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://www.barracuda.com/resources/Barracuda_Backup_WP_Deduplication\">Barracuda Backup Deduplication</a></h3> \n<p>With a 9.1 user rating out of 10 on <a href=\"https://www.trustradius.com/products/barracuda-backup/reviews\">TrustRadius</a>, Barracuda Backup is a good option, offering a robust, secure, fully-integrated data deduplication solution. Their tool can help your business reduce bandwidth requirements and backup costs. Additionally, Barracuda is a good option if your business needs to protect multiple sites, since its cloud storage technology helps distributed networks stay protected.</p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://www.dellemc.com/en-us/data-protection/avamar.htm#accordion0\">Avamar</a></h3> \n<p>Avamar, a solution from Dell EMC, provides variable-length deduplication, which reduces backup time by only storing unique daily changes while simultaneously maintaining daily backups. Avamar is an efficient, secure option and is particularly useful for virtual environments, remote offices, and enterprise applications.</p> \n<h3>4. <a href=\"https://buy.hpe.com/b2c/us/en/storage/disk-storage-systems/storeonce-systems/storeonce-systems/hpe-storeonce-systems/p/5196525\">HPE StoreOnce</a></h3> \n<p>HPE StoreOnce, a solution from Hewlett-Packard Enterprise, offers disk-based backup, deduplication, and secure long-term data storage. Their deduplication software is equipped for virtual backup machines in small remote offices, and equally capable of handling high-performance dedicated applications for larger businesses. Ultimately, this is an impressive tool to help you keep your data secure and efficient as you scale-up.</p> \n<h3>5. <a href=\"https://exagrid.com/exagrid-products/product-architecture/\">Exagrid EX Series</a></h3> \n<p>Exagrid implements a highly efficient approach to data deduplicaton that allows six times the backup performance, and up to 20 times the restore and VM boot performance. With Exagrid, you can backup your data straight onto a disk without inline deduplication processing, enabling a shorter backup window.</p> \n<p>If your company stores a lot of data, it's important to begin the data deduplication process. By using software, you can simply automate this process.</p> \n<p style=\"background-color: #ffffff;\"><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in April 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fdata-deduplication&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 12 Aug 2020 18:00:00 +0000","feedId":924,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/data-deduplication.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"4f5256bb04b3a5f3f4d5776a29c900e7","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn72@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-27-590_00641583d041fd7a.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/data-deduplication.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"Caroline Forsey","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fdata-deduplication&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn92@2020_2/2020/08/16/13-48-32-639_2adf3bddfac19183.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","title":"How to Conduct Research for an Infographic: A Simple Step-by-Step Guide","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-research-infographics","description":"<p>They say a picture is worth 1,000 words. In reality, a picture is worth closer to <a href=\"https://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/~afb21/publications/Student-ESP.html\">84.1 words</a>&nbsp;depending on a variety of other factors, but let’s face it, that’s not as catchy.</p> \n<p>The original point of the saying still stands, though: Images communicate information more effectively than text alone, and they’re best when working together.</p> \n<p>And, brands agree with the statement above. In fact, in 2020, infographics were considered the <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing?_ga=2.257152651.1039809124.1597073295-631527517.1595282187&amp;hubs_signup-url=www.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing-statistics&amp;hubs_signup-cta=null\">third-most effective type of marketing content</a>, just behind blogging and video.<br></p> \n<p>But before you design&nbsp;an eye-catching infographic, you must first do the research to determine what story you’re going to tell, and how you’re going to tell it visually. And that research stage can be pretty tricky -- especially if you don’t have a plan.</p> \n<p>That why we put together a helpful guide that’ll walk you through how to conduct research for an infographic, without driving yourself crazy.</p> \n<h2>Why Marketers Should Use Infographics</h2> \n<p>There’s a reason infographics are such a popular form of content: Viewers love, engage with, and remember them.</p> \n<p>When people hear information, they're likely to remember only <a href=\"http://www.brainrules.net/vision\">10% of that information</a> three days later. Meanwhile, if a relevant image is paired with that same information, people retain <a href=\"http://www.brainrules.net/vision\">65% of it after the same timespan</a>.</p> \n<p>This is clearly a type of content your readers search&nbsp;for, so how do you make an infographic that’s informative, beautiful, and <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/anatomy-of-winning-infographic\">shareable</a>?</p> \n<p>Siege Media conducted a study on what makes infographics inherently shareable (the results of which they turned into a <a href=\"http://www.siegemedia.com/creation/infographics\">great infographic</a>&nbsp;of their own), and as it turns out, the most oft-shared infographics had an average of just 396 words.&nbsp;(For a point of reference, you’re almost 300 words into this article.)</p> \n<p>That’s some seriously effective storytelling, and if you want to craft a killer story, no matter what the content format, you have to do great research.</p> \n<p>You might think that all research is created equal, but there are specific tasks to ensure that you tell the right story for a graphical interpretation.</p> \n<p>Check out our list below for tips on how to begin your infographic design journey with a strong foundation of research.</p> \n<h2><span>How to Conduct Research for an Infographic</span></h2> \n<h3>1. Identify your audience.</h3> \n<p>Before you start conducting research on your topic, it’s essential to think about the audience who will view it. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/market-research-buyers-journey-guide#sm.00006uybatuk9erxqe91juzya6sra\">Market research</a>&nbsp;is important because it makes you think beyond just one piece of content and instead about the impact it will have.</p> \n<p>Questions content creators should ask&nbsp;themselves before starting infographic research include:</p> \n<ol> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Who searches&nbsp;for information on this topic? What are their ages, job roles, and demographic traits?</li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">What emotions do you want to evoke with your infographic?</li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">What do you want viewers to do with your infographic once they view it?</li> \n</ol> \n<h4>Tools:</h4> \n<ul> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://images.google.com/\">Google Images: </a></strong>Hop into this search tool&nbsp;and check out infographics on similar topics. Then, drop them into the search bar and conduct a <a href=\"https://support.google.com/websearch/answer/1325808?hl=en\" style=\"font-weight: 400; background-color: transparent; font-family: proxima-nova, 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 1em;\">reverse Google&nbsp;image search</a>&nbsp;to see what sites link&nbsp;to these graphics. What do they have in common, and what trends can you apply to your research?</li> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/free-template-creating-buyer-personas?_ga=2.92329885.1039809124.1597073295-631527517.1595282187\">HubSpot’s Buyer Persona Templates</a><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/free-template-creating-buyer-personas?_ga=1.124373450.170111609.1470925141\">:</a>&nbsp;</strong>These templates&nbsp;make it easy to keep track of what your audience is motivated by and searching for. Even though you’re not selling the infographic, if you’re using this content to attract potential customers, you’ll want to keep their objectives and motivators in mind.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>2. Leverage keyword research to find image SEO opportunities.</h3> \n<p>Once you’ve determined <i>who</i> will be searching for your infographic, you’ll want to figure out exactly <i>what</i> they’re searching for.</p> \n<p>In her article, HubSpot Customer Demand Manager <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/rachelsprung\">Rachel Liest</a> explains <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-do-keyword-research-ht#sm.00006uybatuk9erxqe91juzya6sra\">how to conduct keyword research</a>&nbsp;for SEO.</p> \n<p>Key to this process is starting with broad topics and potential search terms, then&nbsp;working your way to more specific terms using quantitative data.</p> \n<h4>Tools:</h4> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"http://google.com\"><strong>Google Search: </strong></a>At the bottom of a Google search engine results page, a list of related popular search terms appears. Below is an example of my search for “blogging.” (Remember -- start with broad search terms.)</li> \n <li>Use the related search results to dig&nbsp;into the information your audience searches&nbsp;for so you can better tailor your infographic research.</li> \n</ul> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/blogging%20%20%20Google%20Search.png?width=254&amp;height=145&amp;name=blogging%20%20%20Google%20Search.png\" alt=\"blogging   Google Search.png\" width=\"254\" height=\"145\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://www.google.com/trends/\">Google Trends:</a></strong> This tool shows you how searches for a specific word or term have evolved over time. If searches for a certain term are increasing, that may be an angle to pursue in a piece of content. <br><br>Below is the search history of “blogging” over the past five years. From this result, it’s reasonable to assume that search volume for this term is on a slight decline, and that my research process could benefit from more specific search terms to really pinpoint my audience.</li> \n</ul> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/blogging%20%20%20Explore%20%20%20Google%20Trends.png?width=669&amp;name=blogging%20%20%20Explore%20%20%20Google%20Trends.png\" alt=\"blogging   Explore   Google Trends.png\" width=\"669\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 669px;\" title=\"blogging   Explore   Google Trends.png\"> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://adwords.google.com/KeywordPlanner\">Google Ads Keyword Planner:</a></strong>&nbsp;This tool&nbsp;shows you the search volume of terms compared to similar terms. This is&nbsp;helpful to determine which words or set of several keywords, or <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/definition-long-tail-keyword-100-words-sr\">long-tail keywords</a>, are the most popular in search. These long-tail keywords will help determine the angle your content should address.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/free-trial-keywords-tool\">HubSpot SEO Marketing Software:</a></strong> If you're a HubSpot customer, this handy app has several of the above capabilities already built-in. You can use the tool to conduct general keyword research and narrow your focus when selecting a topic. For example, I once searched for “blogging” and found that “how to make money from blogging” has a high number of search terms, so I might consider that angle as the topic of my infographic.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>3. Keep search terms broad to find lots of data.</h3> \n<p>Once you start to conduct&nbsp;research on the topic of your infographic, don’t limit your content by what angle you <em>think</em> the infographic should pursue. It’s smart to do general research on a topic so you gain a basic understanding, but be mindful that it can influence the information you’re searching for.</p> \n<p>For example, if you decided to focus your infographic on how to make money from blogging and only researched advertising as a means to achieve that goal, the data you pull won’t provide all of the information necessary to create a comprehensive infographic.</p> \n<p>Research a topic, not a particular story or angle, until you have more concrete data.</p> \n<h4>Tools:</h4> \n<ul> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://scholar.google.com/\">Google Scholar:</a></strong>&nbsp;This resource serves as a great place to start your research. It’s a free search engine of scholarly literature on a variety of different topics and disciplines that will give you an idea of the type of data aggregated on the topics you research.</li> \n <li><strong><a href=\"http://www.jstor.org/\">JSTOR:</a></strong>&nbsp;This tool provides a&nbsp;database of primary resources, such as journals, original research, and books. You may need to purchase login access ($19.50/month) or log in through the credentials of an academic institution you’re associated with.</li> \n <li><i><strong><a href=\"https://hbr.org/\">Harvard Business Review:</a></strong>&nbsp;HBR</i>&nbsp;is a scholarly magazine that publishes research, case studies, and statistics on a variety of different topics, including business, leadership, strategy, and economics.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>4. Pull data from reputable, original, and validated sources.</h3> \n<p>When you find data during your research process, we recommend the following standards to decide&nbsp;whether or not to use it in your content:</p> \n<p><strong>Is it original?</strong></p> \n<p>Find the original data source for any statistics you encounter during your research process. Due to the plethora of different blogs and news outlets, many different websites can cite the same statistic without citing its original source. If you find a compelling data point that you want to use in your infographic, trace it to the original research source.</p> \n<p>If you can’t find the original source, the statistic is unsubstantiated and shouldn’t be used.</p> \n<p><strong>Is it reputable?</strong></p> \n<p>Another question to ask yourself <i>when</i> conducting research is <i>where</i> you’re conducting research. Any individual or organization can start a website and publish content, but that doesn’t mean all content on the internet can be taken as fact.</p> \n<p><a href=\"http://www.verticalmeasures.com/content-marketing-2/how-to-do-research-for-an-infographic-video/\">Vertical Measures</a>&nbsp;recommends starting internet research on .gov, .edu, and .org sites, which are associated with governing bodies, educational institutions, and organizations with greater legitimacy than blogs or individuals.</p> \n<p><strong>Can it be validated?</strong></p> \n<p>Even if you find a statistic on a reputable source, you’re not done yet. <a href=\"https://raventools.com/blog/infographic-research/\">Raven Tools</a>&nbsp;recommends that researchers make sure to properly fact-check information they find by a) determining if it’s cited by any other organizations or b) checking the methodology of its original research. If the data point seems unreasonable, trust your instincts and dig deeper.</p> \n<h4>Tools:</h4> \n<ul> \n <li><strong><a href=\"http://www.pewresearch.org/\">Pew Research Center:</a></strong>&nbsp;\"From economic conditions, to political attitudes, to social media usage, the Pew Research Center website has a ton of free research that you can use to better understand your target market,\" noted HubSpot Content Strategy Manager <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/jamioetting\">Jami Oetting</a>&nbsp;in her roundup of the&nbsp;<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/market-research-tools-resources#sm.00006uybatuk9erxqe91juzya6sra\">best market research tools</a>.&nbsp;Check out the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/market-research-tools-resources?&amp;_ga=1.230592218.7546083.1477915232#sm.00006uybatuk9erxqe91juzya6sra\">full article</a> for even more related tools.</li> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://research.hubspot.com/\">HubSpot Research:</a></strong>&nbsp;Our very own research hub offers free market research data and <a href=\"https://research.hubspot.com/charts?_ga=1.150021622.170111609.1470925141\">presentation tools</a> to visualize your data.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>5. Use recent data.</h3> \n<p>You've put time and resources into researching and designing a great infographic.</p> \n<p>Make sure you cite recent data so other sources will be interested in referencing&nbsp;your graphic once it's published.</p> \n<p>We recommend sticking with data that’s one to two years old so your graphic will be relevant for months to come.</p> \n<p>As a caveat, some original research data that would make a compelling case for your infographic may have set the standard for its industry more than two years ago.</p> \n<p>For example, I’ve referenced research on the <a href=\"https://www.cmu.edu/dietrich/sds/docs/loewenstein/PsychofCuriosity.pdf\">curiosity gap</a>&nbsp;that’s from 1994 in previous posts, as this original study coined the term that’s still used today.</p> \n<p>The trick is to find <a href=\"https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1308286\">more recent research</a>&nbsp;that re-tests and substantiates the original theory so it’s a legitimate data point, instead of simply dropping an older statistic into your infographic.</p> \n<h4>Tools:</h4> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.google.com/advanced_search\"><strong>Google Advanced Search:</strong></a>&nbsp;This feature allows you to limit search results to a certain timeframe to search&nbsp;for only the most recent info available. If you have trouble, widen the time range slightly. To set this up, enter a search term, select ‘Search Tools’ in the menu bar at the top of the page, and narrow your results by choosing how recently you want the data to have been published.</li> \n</ul> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/google%20advanced%20search.png?width=640&amp;name=google%20advanced%20search.png\" alt=\"google advanced search results for blogging.png\" width=\"640\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 640px;\"></p> \n<p>With the feature above, you can filter your search engine results according to when articles were published and according to their domains (.gov, .edu, .org, .com), among other features.</p> \n<h3>6. Imagine how your data could be visualized.</h3> \n<p>Remember what Siege Media found?</p> \n<p>The most-shared infographics had an average of just under 400 words. This means that the graphics relied on data visualizations, charts, and illustrations to tell the data’s story.</p> \n<p>Research for a blog post is different than research for an infographic because visitors expect to read a blog, but they don’t necessarily anticipate close-reading a graphic.</p> \n<p>Think about data that can be turned into visuals while you research. Numbers, such as percentages, survey results, and change over time can be easily <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/data-visualization-choosing-chart-0?hs_preview=SwwNpWDi-4361706628#sm.00006uybatuk9erxqe91juzya6sra\">visualized</a>&nbsp;using graphs and charts.</p> \n<p>Are there categories within your data that you can visualize using icons or illustrations? Can you turn a multi-step process into a mini-graphic instead of writing it out?</p> \n<p>Analyze all of your research findings wearing the hat of an illustrator and ask yourself if there’s a balance between data that can be visualized and data that must be written out.</p> \n<h4>Tools:</h4> \n<ul> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://www.canva.com/\">Canva:</a></strong> HubSpot Senior Content Strategist <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/amandazantalwiener\">Amanda Zantal-Wiener</a>&nbsp;wrote an <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/resources-for-creating-infographics#sm.000825bf4hgvedv10qu25jm8py60v\">article</a>&nbsp;about tools to make your own infographics, and Canva made the top of the list. Even if you won't design your infographic yourself, experiment with this design tool (and others on <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/resources-for-creating-infographics?&amp;_ga=1.235833927.7546083.1477915232#sm.00001jv8k2j9vzembr7434ir2v3u3\">the list</a>) to see how easily your data can, or cannot, be visualized.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>7. Use the data you've compiled to craft a story.</h3> \n<p>When you think you’re done with your research, try to lay out the story that your graphic will tell. You may even want to storyboard your infographic: Write out your data points, and lay them out according to the order they’ll be visualized in the infographic. Does the story make sense? If the story isn’t clear or obvious, then you’re not done researching.</p> \n<p>It’s easy to get stuck in the story you think your graphic should tell, but does your research data actually tell the story? <a href=\"http://www.verticalmeasures.com/content-marketing-2/how-to-do-research-for-an-infographic-video/\">Vertical Measures</a>&nbsp;suggests that you let&nbsp;the research drive the topic and narrative of the infographic. If you’re stuck in what you think the data should be saying, you run the risk of citing your research in a way that manipulates the data.</p> \n<p>If a data point isn’t self-evident as a visualization, it’s probably not the right data point, or it doesn’t have the right context. Go back and gather more research if you can’t craft a story that makes sense with just the data -- If you have to fill in too much with text, it will make for a visually unappealing and potentially incorrect infographic.</p> \n<h4>Tools:</h4> \n<ul> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/trello-board-tips-for-teams#sm.00006uybatuk9erxqe91juzya6sra\">Trello</a>.</strong>&nbsp;This interactive planning and organizing tool lets you create cards that you can move around your board to organize in any way you want. You can storyboard using Trello by creating cards with different statistics on them and rearranging them to create a skeleton for your infographic.</li> \n <li><strong>Index Cards:</strong>&nbsp;Okay, so this one requires you to get a little crafty, but it's actually my personal favorite method. Write out the key facts of your story and start laying them out on your desk to get an idea of your infographic’s flow.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>8. Choose a provocative fact to anchor your infographic.</h3> \n<p>Strong infographics are loaded with interesting data that’s beautifully illustrated. These infographics are shared when they prompt an emotional response.</p> \n<p>Content that shocks, disgusts, saddens, delights, or scares people performs well: Researchers Jacopo Staiano and Marco Guerini found that content that prompts feelings of <a href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1503.04723.pdf\">valence, arousal, and dominance</a>&nbsp;tends to go viral.</p> \n<p>Additionally, in an analysis of photos shared on Reddit,&nbsp;<a href=\"http://www.frac.tl/research/viral-emotions-study-2\">Fractl</a>&nbsp;found that <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/shareable-content-emotions#sm.00006uybatuk9erxqe91juzya6sra\">positive emotions</a>&nbsp;were most likely to generate virality, but that content that provoked negative emotions with the right combination of arousal and dominance could be hits as well.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://raventools.com/blog/infographic-research/\">Raven Tools</a>&nbsp;and <a href=\"http://killerinfographics.com/conducting-research-that-matters.html\">Killer Infographics</a>&nbsp;suggest finding a data point that gets to the heart of the topic you’re tackling to hook your reader and incite an emotion that will make them share your graphic. Then, use that hook as the infographic’s visual focal point, and build the rest of your story around it.</p> \n<p>Check out Siege Media’s meta <a href=\"http://www.siegemedia.com/most-popular-infographics\">infographic</a>&nbsp;about what makes infographics popular. They visualize and highlight the most surprising findings first to keep viewers scrolling, and then break down each finding with more research results.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/siegemedia.png?width=669&amp;name=siegemedia.png\" alt=\"siegemedia infographic example\" width=\"669\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 669px;\" title=\"siegemedia.png\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"http://www.siegemedia.com/creation/infographics\"><span style=\"font-size: 11px;\">Image Source</span></a></p> \n<h4>Tools:</h4> \n<ul> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://www.google.com/\">Google Search:</a>&nbsp;</strong>To avoid being&nbsp;repetitive, &nbsp;“[topic] + infographic” to see what else is out there. Ask yourself:&nbsp;<span>Has this angle already been covered, or would you provide a unique view on the topic?</span></li> \n</ul> \n<h3>9. Get feedback from your peers.</h3> \n<p>This may seem obvious, but feedback is a critical step in determining when the research phase is over and when writing and designing your infographic can begin. Before presenting a design proposal to your manager or client, tap your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/peer-feedback-tips#sm.00006uybatuk9erxqe91juzya6sra\">peers</a>&nbsp;for their input. Ask questions like:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Do you understand the story’s flow?</li> \n <li>Is the hook of the infographic interesting?</li> \n <li>Does this data need further explanation to make sense?</li> \n</ul> \n<p>It’s often challenging to remove yourself from a project you’re immersed in to honestly edit it, so feedback during the research phase will identify any weaknesses that may need to be addressed with the help of further fact-finding.</p> \n<h4>Tools:</h4> \n<ul> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://www.google.com/drive/\">Google Drive:</a></strong>&nbsp;Teams can provide feedback on documents and images by sharing them on Google Drive&nbsp;and leaving feedback comments.</li> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT201740\">PDF Preview:</a></strong>&nbsp;This tool lets you edit image files and share them with your team for feedback. They can add comments or delete items from the infographic and share their feedback with you by sending PDF or JPEG files back and forth.</li> \n</ul> \n<h2>Ready to Research?</h2> \n<p>In most cases, great&nbsp;data is the foundation of a successful infographic, so it’s worth investing time and efforts in finding the most relevant, current, and credible information out there.</p> \n<p>Key to the process is remaining open to letting the research inform the editorial strategy, instead of the other way around. And once you’re ready to start designing, check out these <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-infographics-2015\">infographic examples</a>, as well as these free <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/how-to-create-infographics-in-powerpoint\">infographic templates</a>, for inspiration.</p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-research-infographics&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 11 Aug 2020 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":924,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/how-to-conduct-research-for-an-infographic.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"643f098f02205a5c8e23435e2787f2fd","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn63@2020_3/2020/08/16/13-48-27-314_7222fddb4b2915cc.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/how-to-conduct-research-for-an-infographic.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"sbernazzani@hubspot.com (Sophia Bernazzani)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/blogging%20%20%20Google%20Search.png?width=254&height=145&name=blogging%20%20%20Google%20Search.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn19@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-39-943_7f8742ea24234da2.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/blogging%20%20%20Explore%20%20%20Google%20Trends.png?width=669&name=blogging%20%20%20Explore%20%20%20Google%20Trends.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn12@2020_2/2020/08/16/13-48-34-547_3377173d282654c4.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/google%20advanced%20search.png?width=640&name=google%20advanced%20search.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn32@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-34-697_b73c127c3e0bb3a4.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/siegemedia.png?width=669&name=siegemedia.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn92@2020_2/2020/08/16/13-48-33-604_6381f7ebe3d7232b.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-research-infographics&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn80@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-35-972_a0b6e07efdc17a1c.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","title":"The Optimal Instagram Story Dimensions [+ Tips for Best Quality]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/instagram-story-dimensions","description":"<p>New social media sites continue to emerge, new features are added, and algorithms are always being updated, making it tough to keep up with social media best practices.</p>  \n<p>However, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ultimate-guide-social-media-image-dimensions-infographic\">social media</a> is here to stay. According to <a href=\"https://instagram-press.com/our-story/\">Instagram</a>, there are more than one billion active users monthly and more than 500 million Stories active every day.</p> \n<p>In fact, Instagram Stories are a popular trend that isn't going away. Pamela Bump, audience growth writer at HubSpot, writes about Instagram Stories in this <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/instagram-story-examples\">blog</a>. She says, \"Instagram Stories serves as an outlet for brands to creatively show their products, services, or happy customers in action. Branded Instagram Stories also enable audiences to learn more about topics related to your brand's industry. Helpful and valuable content might also allow prospective buyers to trust your brand more.\"</p> \n<p>With this knowledge, you want your marketing team ready to develop a strategy for your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/instagram-stories\">Instagram Stories</a>. To create this strategy, your team should decide what kind of images or videos they want to post. How do you plan on taking those images? With phones or professional cameras?</p> \n<p>Below, you'll learn the Instagram Story dimensions and why it's important to add Instagram Stories to your strategy.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2>How do I fix the quality of my Instagram Stories?</h2> \n<p>You might be asking, why do you need to know about the specific Instagram Stories <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/ads-guide/video/instagram-story\">dimensions</a>? There are instances in which you might find that your Stories aren't uploading with the quality that you'd like. The following tips can help you isolate the problem and improve the look of your brand assets:</p> \n<h3>1. Ensure your content is high-quality before you upload.</h3> \n<p>Instagram will compress images during the upload process, so an already grainy or pixelated image will only get worse it gets to the platform.</p> \n<p>Check that your images are at least 72 ppi resolution and clear on your computer before you add them to Instagram.</p> \n<h3>2. Upload the right size and shape.</h3> \n<p>Instagram is strict about adhering to its dimensions in order to ensure quality photos and videos. When you upload a vertical image or video from your phone, you most likely won't have to think about these dimensions because Instagram will automatically format them.</p> \n<p>However, if you have horizontal photos that don't fit the dimensions, Instagram will crop your photos, zoom in on content, or zoom out (making your image look small and placing it on a background). This typically results in lower quality images and videos.</p> \n<h3>3. Use photo editing apps.</h3> \n<p>Photo editing apps can help you control the quality of your Stories and ensure you're always using the right dimensions. In order to edit your photos for Instagram, you can use sites including:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://www.canva.com/\">Canva</a>: </strong>This is the perfect option for creating images for your Instagram Stories. To get started, Canva has templates that are designed with the Instagram dimensions in mind. <a href=\"https://www.canva.com/pro/\">Canva offers free and paid plans</a><a href=\"https://www.canva.com/pro/\">.</a></li> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://lumen5.com/\">Lumen5</a>: </strong>This software makes it easy to produce videos for Instagram Stories. Once you get started creating a video, you can choose the right dimensions on the platform. <a href=\"https://lumen5.com/pricing/\">Lumen5 starts at $19/month</a><a href=\"https://lumen5.com/pricing/\">.</a></li> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://about.easil.com/#dm\">Easil</a>:</strong> Easil has templates for Instagram Stories to help create engaging content. They have templates for single images, and multi-card Stories as well. <a href=\"https://about.easil.com/pricing/\">Easil offers free and paid versions.</a></li> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://spark.adobe.com/\">Adobe Spark</a>: </strong>Adobe Spark makes creating images and video graphics for Instagram Stories easy. You can build your own Stories with their typography and imagery options. <a href=\"https://spark.adobe.com/pricing/\">Adobe Spark has free and paid plans available</a><a href=\"https://spark.adobe.com/pricing/\">.</a></li> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://embedsocial.com/blog/instagram-story-tools/#embedstories\">Embed Social</a>: </strong>Embed Social is a different kind of tool for Instagram Stories — with Embed Stories, you can make your Stories Shoppable by adding CTAs, and creating embeddable code that you can add to your website. <a href=\"https://embedsocial.com/pricing/embedstories/\">Embed Social offers free and paid plans</a><a href=\"https://embedsocial.com/pricing/embedstories/\">.</a></li> \n</ul> \n<p>With these tools, you can input the specifications, upload images and videos, and complete the editing process. These work well if you have higher quality images taken with a camera or want to add graphics or text to your images or videos.</p> \n<p>Here's what the process would look like for Canva. Click on \"Templates\" and choose \"Instagram Story\" to see templates that are the right dimensions for Instagram.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/The%20Optimal%20Instagram%20Story%20Dimensions%20%5BBookmarkable%5D.jpeg?width=600&amp;name=The%20Optimal%20Instagram%20Story%20Dimensions%20%5BBookmarkable%5D.jpeg\" alt=\"Canva templates for Instagram Stories.\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\"><strong>Image source: </strong><a href=\"https://www.canva.com/\">Canva</a></p> \n<h3>4. Check if the quality is better on other devices.</h3> \n<p>If your internet connection is poor, Instagram stories will appear lower quality than the would on a faster connection.</p> \n<p>Instagram does this to save resources for user experience as you interact with other areas of the site. Consider asking someone you know if the quality is low on their end as well. They — and your audience — may be viewing your stories with no issues.</p> \n<h3>5. Turn off Data Saver.</h3> \n<p>Data saver is a feature that prevents videos from loading in advance, which helps reduce your data usage.</p> \n<p>If your connection is fine but you're still having issues with quality, this feature may be lowering the quality of your feed on your end.</p> \n<h3>6. Test photos from different cameras.</h3> \n<p>As a last resort, test whether there's a difference in quality between your phone's integrated camera vs. the Instagram camera. The photos you take with your phone's camera vs. the in-app camera (or vice versa) may weather Instagram's compression settings better.</p> \n<h2>Stats &amp; Tips You Should Know About Instagram Stories</h2> \n<p>Why should you care about Instagram Stories? Here are a few stats from <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/marketing/instagram\">Instagram</a>:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>90% of accounts follow a business on Instagram</li> \n <li>More than 1 billion Instagram accounts worldwide are active every month</li> \n <li>More than 500 million accounts use Instagram Stories every day</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Sophia Bernazzani, HubSpot blog writer, wrote about how to use Instagram Stories for business in this <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/instagram-stories\">blog</a>. She says you can use Instagram Stories to:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Post footage of an office event</li> \n <li>Post breaking news about your industry</li> \n <li>Demonstrate your product</li> \n <li>Promote a company event</li> \n <li>Preview one of your company's blog posts</li> \n <li>Mention other companies who follow or work with yo</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Using Instagram Stories is a tactic that all marketers should consider. With active and engaged users, using Stories can improve your discoverability and increase brand reputation and awareness.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Editor's note: This post was originally published in October 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Finstagram-story-dimensions&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 06 Aug 2020 13:00:00 +0000","feedId":924,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/instagram-dimensions.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"56faf414a922b546eac3be2366b8f42b","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn83@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-27-426_440295ae4c5a40b5.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/instagram-dimensions.jpg#keepProtocol","destWidth":598,"destHeight":398,"author":"Rebecca Riserbato","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/The%20Optimal%20Instagram%20Story%20Dimensions%20%5BBookmarkable%5D.jpeg?width=600&name=The%20Optimal%20Instagram%20Story%20Dimensions%20%5BBookmarkable%5D.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn40@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-33-958_1477d1a802dd5bcb.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Finstagram-story-dimensions&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn43@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-40-014_91a1b0186c623b32.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:25","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:25","title":"How to Use Instagram Insights (in 9 Easy Steps)","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-use-instagram-insights","description":"<p>It's no&nbsp;secret that we love data.</p>  \n<p>Data helps you understand your audience. It tells you how they do things, what they prefer, and who they are.</p> \n<p>And when it comes to social media, our love for data doesn't fade.</p> \n<p>That's why we love analytics and insights. They help you measure the impact of your marketing efforts across different channels to see if there's something you need to do differently -- like target a different audience, post at a certain time of day, or experiment with a new content format.</p> \n<p>Instagram Insights are no exception. Here are the analytics on this channel that marketers need to know and understand -- and how to use them.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>To use Instagram Insights, you must first have a business profile.</p> \n<p>If you're already using a personal account, you can switch to a business profile. In order to have a Business Account, you must also have a Facebook Page for your brand. Instagram will give you the option to create a new one during this process if you don't already have one. Here's how to convert your account in a few simple steps.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Once your set up as a Business Account, you can begin to use Instagram Insights. Here's how to get started.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3>1. Click the insights icon.</h3> \n<p>To view insights into your overall Instagram account, start by visiting your profile. Then, at the top, click the icon of a bar chart, which will take you to your overall insights.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/IMG_2136%20copy.png?width=300&amp;name=IMG_2136%20copy.png\" alt=\"Instagram Profile with circled Instagram Insights Icon\" width=\"300\" title=\"IMG_2136 copy.png\" style=\"width: 300px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>From there, you'll see some general information about people are engaging with your profile, like how many followers you gained or lost in the past week.</p> \n<p>Next, we'll get into the more specific profile insights you can explore.</p> \n<h3>2. View your impressions and reach.</h3> \n<p>This insight represents how many times your ads appeared on users' screens. Reach reflects the number of unique users that have seen any of your Instagram posts.</p> \n<h3>3. Determine website clicks.</h3> \n<p>This insight reflects the number of times any links you've included in your business profile have been clicked.</p> \n<h3>4. Track profile visits and followers.</h3> \n<p>Profile visits reflects the number of times your profile has been viewed. Followers reflect how many followers you've gained or lost over the past week, as well as the average times of day when your followers are using Instagram — data that can be highly beneficial when planning posts. To view insights for a specific Instagram post, start by visiting your profile. Tap on the post you'd like to look into, then click \"View Insights\" below the image.</p> \n<h3>5. Click view insights below a post for specifics.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>You may have also promoted a certain post -- if that's the case, an arrow icon that looks like this will appear:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/13717845_659368444211466_1452706666_n.jpg?width=59&amp;name=13717845_659368444211466_1452706666_n.jpg\" alt=\"View Post insights button on Instagram\" title=\"13717845_659368444211466_1452706666_n.jpg\" width=\"59\" style=\"width: 59px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>For these posts, you can either view insights on the original version of the post, or specific ones from its promotion. For the latter, tap \"Promotion.\"</p> \n<p>Next, we'll get into the more specific post insights you can explore.</p> \n<h3>6. View your posts likes, comments, and saves.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>Likes speaks for itself, and reflects the number of users who liked your post. As with likes, comments reflects the number of comments left on your post. Saves highlights the number of unique users or accounts who saved your post, or clicked the bookmark-like icon that appeared below it in their feeds.</p> \n<h3>7. Learn which actions were taken on your post.</h3> \n<p>These insights indicate the number of actions that users took on your profile as a result of seeing your post -- things like visiting your profile, then taking an action like clicking on your website link or following you.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202018-01-18%20at%202.01.33%20PM.png?width=308&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202018-01-18%20at%202.01.33%20PM.png\" alt=\"Instagram Insights Actions Feature\" title=\"Screen Shot 2018-01-18 at 2.01.33 PM.png\" width=\"308\" style=\"width: 308px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/help/788388387972460?helpref=related&amp;ref=related#\">Instagram</a></em></span></p> \n<h3>8. Use Discover to see where your post showed up in feeds.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>As the name might suggest, these insights indicate <em>where</em> your post was seen -- or discovered -- the most, including how many accounts weren't already following you when they first saw the post.</p> \n<p>This section includes metrics on Impressions, which reflect the number of times your post was discovered from a particular place within Instagram, like the user's home feed, a search, your profile, a location tag, or a hashtag.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202018-01-18%20at%202.06.26%20PM.png?width=433&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202018-01-18%20at%202.06.26%20PM.png\" alt=\"Instagram Insights Discovery Feature\" title=\"Screen Shot 2018-01-18 at 2.06.26 PM\" width=\"433\" style=\"width: 433px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/help/788388387972460?helpref=related&amp;ref=related#\">Instagram</a></em></span></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">Discovery insights also include data on a post's reach -- which reflects the number of unique accounts that saw your post.</p> \n<h3 style=\"text-align: left;\">9. View Instagram Story Insights</h3> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\"><span style=\"font-size: 1em;\">Finally, Instagram users with a business profile are able to view insights into their ephemeral Stories. Instagram does not, however, offer such analytics for live videos.</span></p> \n<p>To view your Story insights, start by visiting your profile. Then, at the top, tap the icon of the bar chart, which will take you to your overall profile insights.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/IMG_2136%20copy.png?width=300&amp;name=IMG_2136%20copy.png\" alt=\"Instagram profile insights feature\" width=\"300\" title=\"IMG_2136 copy.png\" style=\"width: 300px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Scroll down to the Stories section, and you'll be able to see insights for older stories, as well as any that have not yet expired.</p> \n<p>Next, we'll get into the more specific Story insights you can explore.</p> \n<h4>Impressions</h4> \n<p>This insight represents how many times your Story was seen.</p> \n<p>When viewing these insights, keep in mind that you're able to add multiple images or videos to your Story. When you do this, every piece of visual content in your Story is counted as a single photo or video in your post.</p> \n<p>Let's say you add six photos to your Story. Whether someone only views one or views all six, Instagram only counts your entire Story having received <em>one</em> impression.</p> \n<p>The same goes for Story content that has been viewed by a single user more than once. Instagram still only counts that interaction as the entire Story having received one impression.</p> \n<h4>Reach</h4> \n<p>This insight reflects the number of unique users that have seen your Story.</p> \n<h4>Taps Forward</h4> \n<p>This insight reflects the number of times a user taps your Story photo or video to skip to the next piece of media.</p> \n<h4>Taps Back</h4> \n<p>This insight reflects the number of time a user taps your Story photo or video to go back to the previous piece of media.</p> \n<h4>Replies</h4> \n<p>This insight reflects the number of times users send messages through the \"Send Message\" text box on your Story.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/IMG_2138%20copy.png?width=300&amp;name=IMG_2138%20copy.png\" alt=\"Replies on Instagram Stories\" title=\"IMG_2138 copy\" width=\"300\" style=\"width: 300px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h4>Swipe Aways</h4> \n<p>This insight reflects the number of times users swipe to skip to the <em>next account’s</em> Story -- not to be mistaken for \"tap forward,\" which reflects users skipping ahead to <em>your</em> next piece of Story media.</p> \n<h4>Exits</h4> \n<p>This insight reflects the number of times a user leaves the Stories section entirely to return to the home feed.</p> \n<p>Now that you know how to measure the effectiveness of your Instagram strategy using Insights, you can analyze that data and determine what's working for your audience. From there, creating content that gets a ton of engagement will be a lot easier as you consider those benchmarks.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's Note: This post was originally published in January 2018 but has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-use-instagram-insights&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 13 Aug 2020 12:00:00 +0000","feedId":924,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/instagram-insights-1.jpg#keepProtocol","linkMd5":"eecd826bb39f09b5e07cac1f62ae055f","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn7@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-27-314_c0ac8bb475cd9521.webp","metaImg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/instagram-insights-1.jpg#keepProtocol","author":"Amanda Zantal-Wiener","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/IMG_2136%20copy.png?width=300&name=IMG_2136%20copy.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn91@2020_3/2020/08/16/13-48-38-593_00850413dbb8e0b7.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/13717845_659368444211466_1452706666_n.jpg?width=59&name=13717845_659368444211466_1452706666_n.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx17/cdn100@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-30-055_5e5ecfb6bdc5c630.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202018-01-18%20at%202.01.33%20PM.png?width=308&name=Screen%20Shot%202018-01-18%20at%202.01.33%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn56@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-30-816_c3a6f7de0bb3d9f2.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202018-01-18%20at%202.06.26%20PM.png?width=433&name=Screen%20Shot%202018-01-18%20at%202.06.26%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn51@2020_6/2020/08/16/13-48-34-042_4803b943f96aea89.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/IMG_2138%20copy.png?width=300&name=IMG_2138%20copy.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn15@2020_4/2020/08/16/13-48-37-380_5b3c709865855896.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-use-instagram-insights&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn36@2020_5/2020/08/16/13-48-33-613_eea03947b9e34ff2.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","updatedTime":"2020-08-16 21:48:26","title":"How Often Should You (or Your Company) Blog? [New Data]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/blogging-frequency-benchmarks","description":"<p>Starting a blog is tough. Thinking about what to post and how to promote it requires strategic planning. And will your content resonate with and delight your customers?</p>  \n<p>We haven't even covered how often companies should post — a factor that can make or break even the greatest of content.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>You might be surprised to know that even though there's a surplus of hard data about why blog posts are integral to marketing, there's not much on the frequency of posting. This is because, well, it depends.</p> \n<p>If ambiguity gets your heart racing, fear not. Here, we'll offer suggestions and stats to help inform your decision.</p> \n<p>If you're a marketing team of one, don't feel the need to constantly pump out content. If you do, you'll probably find yourself getting burned out and releasing content that's not beneficial to you or your audience.</p> \n<p>Keeping a schedule when blogging is important for two reasons. First, it builds organic traffic. Next, it helps with brand awareness. We'll get into why below.</p> \n<h3>Organic traffic</h3> \n<p>Blogging is important for SEO if you want to increase visits to your website. But, if you are already posting valuable content, it might benefit you to go back and update that content, especially if after a little while, you want to give certain posts a boost.</p> \n<p>Blog post traffic is compounding, which means it gains organic results over time. This is why updating posts are important. This gives you more reads, more recognition, and possibly, more fans.</p> \n<p>  </p> \n<div class=\"playbuzz\">\n &nbsp;\n</div> \n<h3>Brand awareness</h3> \n<p>Because Google can crawl every page of a website for SEO, every blog post you make has the chance to enhance not only optimization but awareness of your brand. For example, if you're in the beauty industry and you publish high-quality posts about how to apply eyeliner or mascara, you have the opportunity to be seen in those Google search results.</p> \n<p>To build brand loyalty, make sure you're producing high-quality content. If you're producing content with images, keywords, and industry-relevant content, you can increase your brand awareness.</p> \n<p>So, blogging is still of high importance for brand discovery and building leads. If you're trying to figure out the right publishing frequency for your team and your business, keep reading.</p> \n<h2>Blogging Frequency</h2> \n<p>Blogging frequency ultimately depends on what you aim to accomplish with your blog. So, let’s look at the basics of how often you should blog for what you aim to accomplish.</p> \n<h3>Organic traffic</h3> \n<p>If your main goal is to raise traffic numbers and bring clicks to your website and content, you want to post frequently. It's ultimately up to you to determine what that schedule looks like.</p> \n<p>As a small blog with a limited team, it can be difficult to brainstorm, create, and promote a new post every day. This is where planning comes in handy. When you're coordinating your next product launch campaign, plan for blog posts in tandem, and set aside time to outline those posts.</p> \n<p>Having the material outlined and organized before you begin writing saves you time. Because you want to publish as much as possible, think of content that will educate your readers. This can look different depending on the blog, but some blog ideas include industry how-tos, campaign round-ups, and listicles.</p> \n<p>For more blog post ideas, check out this list of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/23973/41-fresh-blog-post-ideas-for-your-company-blog.aspx?_ga=2.220501086.737336006.1574093010-940436819.1565181751\">101</a> ideas HubSpotters put together.</p> \n<h3>Brand awareness</h3> \n<p>When you're focusing on building your brand, the key is to diversify content. Try to think of the ways blog posts can highlight your brand and help to define it. How can a blog post tell your audience who you are?</p> \n<p>Because your focus will be on building a voice for your company, these posts don't need to be published as frequently as a traffic-building agenda would demand. Instead, smaller businesses should try to fit these in once a week or so.</p> \n<p>Building brand awareness gives you a chance to provide useful information to your target audience. Providing branded infographics or statistics about your industry that are branded are good ways to build loyalty.</p> \n<p>Content can vary even further, from an \"Employee of the month\" post celebrating your team to an event recap of a recent company outing, or an infographic that explains your core values.</p> \n<p>Below is a graphic that summarizes some goals to shoot for when thinking about blog frequency. Remember that updating posts with new information is a great way to build SEO, no matter the goal.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Copy%20of%20Comparison%20Chart%20Template%20--%20Blog%20Team%20(2).png?width=1024&amp;name=Copy%20of%20Comparison%20Chart%20Template%20--%20Blog%20Team%20(2).png\" alt=\"how often should you blog? graphic\" width=\"1024\" style=\"width: 1024px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p>With proper planning in place, the volume of blogs you produce may surprise you. We chose the soft goal of three to four times a week for smaller blogs focusing on organic traffic because blogging should be a priority if boosting clicks is the goal.</p> \n<p>In 2019, <a href=\"https://www.stateofinbound.com/?__hstc=20629287.baf2406400c73bbe46641b2b9cd8a38f.1563824949326.1573769524426.1573831850666.235&amp;__hssc=20629287.1.1573831850666&amp;__hsfp=3915993429\">HubSpot</a> found that marketers who prioritize marketing efforts are 13x more likely to see positive ROI. Making blogging a serious portion of your day-to-day is hard work, but rewarding in that you may garner visits and leads.</p> \n<p>  </p> \n<div class=\"playbuzz\">\n &nbsp;\n</div> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem;\">Larger blogs with a few team members are able to increase volume but should be wary of burnout and over-saturation of search engine results. That's why the goal is four to five times a week. This ensures new posts have time to gain traffic and updated posts are being boosted properly to round out your campaign goals.</span></p> \n<p>Because content for brand awareness is more specialized and not as focused on gaining traffic, the frequency of blog posts is not as high. We recommend smaller, brand-awareness focused blogs post one to two times a week. While they may not perform as well as researched, traffic-focused content, they give a voice and holistic medium to your blog.</p> \n<p>For blogs with more resources, it's easier to up the frequency of brand awareness posts, especially because large blogs probably already have a decent amount of organic traffic. There's more room to focus on content that grows a company's brand and provide thought leadership.</p> \n<p>Starting a blog and keeping it consistent can be really difficult, but there's no exact science to it. Because of this, you can be flexible with how you maintain your blog, as long as you are sticking to your business goals.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's Note: This blog post was originally published in Nov. 2019 but updated for freshness in August 2020.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fblogging-frequency-benchmarks&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\"
